projects.name: libarchive
projects.summary: C library and command-line tools for reading and writing tar, cpio, zip, ISO, and other archive formats
projects.description:
= Ongoing Libarchive Development is now at Github =

libarchive's homepage is now at [http://www.libarchive.org].

Development is now done via git. The main git repository is at [https://github.com/libarchive/libarchive].

The wiki pages have migrated over to `GitHub` as well. See [https://github.com/libarchive/libarchive/wiki/_pages].

Downloads are now found at [http://www.libarchive.org/downloads].

= Issues should still be reported on !GoogleCode =

The issue tracker still remains at Google Code. See [http://code.google.com/p/libarchive/issues/list].

To report an issue, use the "Issues" tab above.

Of course, code changes should be provided using `GitHub's` pull request feature. See [https://github.com/libarchive/libarchive/pulls].

= Mailing Lists are still at !GoogleGroups =

See the sidebar to the left for links.

items.title: #undef'ing archive types at end of archive.h breaks callbacks
items.summary: #undef'ing archive types at end of archive.h breaks callbacks

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Implement a read callback in 2.5.5: __LA_SSIZE_T LibArchiveReadCallback(struct archive* a, void* client_data, const void **buffer) { //... } 2. Upgrade from 2.5.5 to 2.6.0. 3. Compiler errors because __LA_SSIZE_T is no longer defined. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? I'd expect __LA_SSIZE_T to still be defined. Or alternatively, a new #define like __LA_USING_CALLBACKS, which if #define'd will prevent the #undefs at the end of the header file. What version of the product are you using? On what operating system? 2.6.0 on Linux, OSX, and Win32.
Fixed in libarchive/trunk revision 343.

Fixed in release/2.6 revision 344 in SVN.
Will be included in libarchive 2.6.1 release (likely in another week or two).

items.title: please add support for zisofs
items.summary: please add support for zisofs

items.content:
zisofs is an extension to the ISO 9660 file system that adds transparent
compression support. It would be nice if libarchive supported unpacking
images created with zisofs-tools. For more information see
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zisofs
I second this!

Patches are always appreciated.  The Zip reader demonstrates how to handle compressed
bodies.

This could still happen for 2.8 if someone sends patches, but noone has shown
interest so far.
I've just committed in r1414.

items.title: bsdtar fails on extracting .zip archives with empty files
items.summary: bsdtar fails on extracting .zip archives with empty files

items.content: Bsdtar, which is provided by libarchive, fails when attempting to extract a zip archive that contains empty files, as is often seen in Python packages with init.py files. What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Download MyghtyUtils 0.52 package (http://pypi.python.org/packages/source/M/MyghtyUtils/) 2. bsdtar -x -f MyghtyUtils-0.52.zip Fails with messages: MyghtyUtils-0.52/lib/myghtyutils/__init__.py: Attempt to write to an empty file MyghtyUtils-0.52/lib/myghtyutils/ext/__init__.py: Attempt to write to an empty file What version of the product are you using? On what operating system? libarchive 2.6.0-1 on i386 Arch Linux

Do you know which Zip program created these files?  I'd like to create some other
examples that exercise this problem, but I haven't been able to convince Info-Zip to
create a Zip file with empty files encoded in this particular fashion.

Fixed in trunk r407 and in release/2.6 r408.  The fix will be in the upcoming 2.6.1
release.

The root problem here is pretty funny, actually:

Apparently, some Zip programs actually compress zero-length files.  This is a silly
thing to do, as it only makes the file larger.  Such programs should be fixed.  (I
haven't found a program that actually does this, but I've seen archives created by it.)

Libarchive's zip reader produces a fairly silly response when it tries to read such
an entry:  It decompresses and returns a zero-byte block, then returns end-of-entry
on the second call.  This probably should be changed to just return end-of-entry
immediately.  (Actually, libarchive should be able to avoid initializing the
decompression machinery if it knows the result will be empty.  Of course, this
doesn't work for the length-at-end case; it's not quite as trivial as it sounds.)

Libarchive's write-to-disk logic produces an error if you try to create a zero-byte
file and then write to it.  I changed this to always accept zero-byte write requests,
which fixes the immediate problem.

items.title: Can't extract .tar.gz archives with C:\
items.summary: Can't extract .tar.gz archives with C:\

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? Create an archive using MKS tar or any of a multitude of other tar/gzip utilities for Windows. Some archives are created containing the full path of the compressed files; when extracting, libarchive tar chokes on these: Example: ============================================== C:\Windows\Temp> bsdtar -xvf d:\some_file.tar x C:/agent/backup/: Failed to create dir 'C:': No such file or directoryCan't create 'C:/agent/backup': No such file or directory x C:/agent/backup/progress.log: Failed to create dir 'C:': No such file or directoryCan't create 'C:/agent/backup/progress.log': No such file or directory ... snip ... bsdtar: Error exit delayed from previous errors. C:\Windows\Temp> ============================================== What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Well.. GnuWin32 tar.exe has a conditional in the source code that looks at the second character of the filename, and if it's ":" then skips two characters. The fix is only compiled in sometimes, so may or may not work depending on the build environment used, unfortunately. I think a better solution is to just convert characters that will not survive WinAPI. NTFS itself don't care what you throw at it, but WinAPI does not allow fx ":". In the interest of making stuff work as fast and effortlessly as possible, silently converting all ":" to "_" in filenames (when extracting on Windows) would work just fine. (I don't have a need to force files to go into C:\ when the archive says so, in fact I prefer tar to stay in the local filesystem. I can always go to C:\ myself if that's what I want. Which it's not ;-))
GnuWin32 tar creates archives with C:\ too, by the way.
Better patch by kientzle in comment #6 of issue #6.
r682 commits the change to tar to strip Windows drive letters if -P is not specified.

Committed the winfs_naming_fix.patch from Issue 6 as r702.

Proper -P support for paths that include drive letters is still pending.

I'm going to close this for now; the support for drive letters with -P seems low
enough priority to be deferred.

items.title: Feature request: docs
items.summary: Feature request: docs

items.content:
Want to real-world test a patch for bug #5 before I submit it.

Followed the build instructions at:
http://code.google.com/p/libarchive/wiki/BuildInstructions

That is, I pulled down rHEAD with Subversion, installed CMake and tried to 
generate Visual Studio project files.

CMake doesn't work, it croaks with the message "YACC-NOTFOUND".  What the 
hell is a yacc, and why would I need one?

It would be nice if you could include working .csproj files in the source 
package.

Or alternatively enhance the build instructions at the above URL to show 
how you can actually get a complete build instead of a half way there 
one ;-)...

(Also, it'd be nice if you could configure the issue tracker so that non-admins can 
create Type-Enhancement items, currently it's only possible to create Type-Defect.)

"...configure the issue tracker..."

Done.

"What the hell is a yacc, and why would I need one?"

Yacc is a tool for converting parsers described in ".y" files into C source code. 
The trunk development version requires this; the release versions will include
pre-built versions of the C source for those who lack a yacc.  I don't think the
getdate.y file that requires this has changed in some time; you should be able to
copy getdate.c and getdate.h from release/2.6 to get it working.

"It would be nice if you could include working .csproj files ..."

Volunteers?

"Yacc ..."

Thanks for the explanation! Could you put a link to the correct vendor/application 
to download and use for Windows into the build instructions?

"... copy getdate.c and getdate.h from release/2.6 to get it working."

by "work" I guess you you mean to make the thing compile had I had an otherwise 
working build environment, but I'm at an earlier step trying to make CMake do it's 
thing, so I guess that's not going to help.

"Volunteers?"

If only I had a clue.  Anybody else?

Uhm, sounds like finding volunteers and getting the build environment to a point 
where it's newbie friendly to setup might take a couple of months/years ;-)..  In 
the mean time, could you test this patch (attached) and do opinions?

Unable to build & test means I'm not sure if the code is in the correct spot.  Did 
my best though!

Attached: proposed fix for issue #5 "Can't extract .tar.gz archives with C:\".

I think I have a better fix for the immediate problem:  This patch extends the
default "strip leading /" behavior of bsdtar to also strip leading drive letters. 
(I've done this on all platforms in case someone wants to extract a Windows tarfile
on Linux, for example).

I think your patch is a good idea to cover cases of extracting non-Windows tar files
on Windows.  I'll commit it as well.

But there's still one remaining bit:  If you're on Windows and use bsdtar with the
"-P" option, then drive letters should actually be obeyed.  This will require some
work in archive_write_disk.

Sorry; that comment should have gone with Issue 5; let's keep this discussion about
better documenting the Windows build process.

Unfortunately, I don't have a Windows machine handy at the moment, but the procedure
should be something like:
 * Download and install a recent cmake binary from cmake.org
 * Run cmake:  You'll need to specify a "generator" (which development system you are
using) and the directory where the libarchive source code is located (the directory
containing the CMakeLists.txt file).  I believe the default generator is for some
version of Visual Studio; there are also generators for MinGW, NMake, and others.
 * The result should be a usable project file, solution file, and/or Makefile for
your environment.

I regularly test this on Unix and occasionally test it on MacOS/XCode.  There are a
couple of other folks around here using Windows, though; perhaps we should ask on the
discuss mailing list and see if someone can clarify.

Re comment #7:

Exactly what I did - it's the CMake generator that dies, complaining about 
YACC_something ;-).

I'll go find the "discuss" list, see if I can join it and ask there.  Thanks!

Re comment #6:

Even better!  Looking forward to trying out the fixed version.  Is there a nightly 
build server, or do I need to get my own build environment running..

Re the -P option:

To heck with that...

Difficult to implement.
----------
Fx if libarchive is compiled with Cygwin, C:\ changes to /cygdrive/c.  Only on a 
default install though, it can be changed in the registry.  C:\ might not 
necessarily even be mounted.

MINGW compilations would work with Windows-style paths, I guess, but in the MSYS 
shell it's called /c for C:\, for what it's worth.

Other emulators like MKS, Unix Services for Windows, etc probably have their own 
path conventions.

Wants to be exploited.
----------
-P seems like a nice way of opening up gaping security holes, by allowing the 
creator of the extracted archive power over the entire filesystem.  I can't imagine 
many people use it?  They probably shouldn't ;-).

Easy to workaround.
----------
A simple "cd /" or "cd /d c:\" before extracting the archive, and you've got the 
feature of -P covered.

Ho hum.  If you decide to skip the feature, I can write up a paragraph for the 
manual documenting that it would be a security risk and what the workaround is.

I believe r696 (which eliminates the need for YACC entirely) and recent changes to
the build docs in the Wiki have addressed this.  Please let me know if you see ways
to improve the documentation.

Looked it over.  Besides for all the XXX's, looks reasonable at first glance.

(Build instructions really needs to be tested though, from a blank machine, to see 
if the instructions actually work.)

The source package under "downloads" still contains the yacc stuff.  A new source 
package would be nice!

Also, the Windows download package:
http://gnuwin32.sourceforge.net/packages/libarchive.htm

is horribly old, I think it's a 2.4 version.  A new Windows package would also be 
nice!

Can't edit the wiki, but here are complete, working build instructions for building 
on Windows.

0. Install Subversion command line client.

1. Get the source code with:
   svn checkout -rHEAD http://libarchive.googlecode.com/svn/trunk C:/libarchive

   (Prints "At revision 842.")

2. Install CMake 2.6.

3. Run CMake.

4. Point source code parameter to C:/libarchive.

5. Point build output parameter to C:/libarchive.
   Choosing something else doesn't work.  Takes some figuring out.

6. Click 'Configure'.  Wait for a long time.

7. Get a screen with a lot of uninteresting red stuff.
   Stuff that might interest you (enabling zlib and bzip2) are nowhere to see (?).

8. Click 'Configure' again, which takes some figuring out.  Bad user interface.

9. Click 'OK'.

10. Open the generated C:/libarchive/libarchive.sln file in Visual Studio 9.

11. Click 'Rebuild Solution'.

12. Build succeeds!  Good work, guys.

I've updated the build instructions in the Wiki with some of this additional information.

I expect to have a libarchive-2.6.990a.tar.gz package available for download in the
next couple of days.

It would be nice to get additional clarification on the Cmake issues you found.

items.title: Crashes when call archive_read_open_filename for an file that not exists
items.summary: Crashes when call archive_read_open_filename for an file that not exists

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? int main(){ struct archive* a = archive_read_new(); archive_read_support_format_all(a); archive_read_open_filename(a, "C:\\notexistent.tar", 512); return 0; } What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Actual Results: The program crashes. Expected Results: The program exits silently. What version of the product are you using? On what operating system? libarchive trunk r656 Visual C++ 2008 Windows XP SP3 Please provide any additional information below. archive_read_open2 calls client_closer when opening file have been failed.

I have read r624 and r628.
The patch is inadequate.
Fixed in r658.  I've also added the example code as a new test case.  Please verify.

items.title: archive_compression_name returns NULL
items.summary: archive_compression_name returns NULL

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? int main(){ archive* a = archive_read_new(); archive_read_support_compression_all(a); archive_read_support_format_all(a); archive_read_open_filename(a, "D:\\desktop\\desktop.tar", 512); const char* name = archive_compression_name(a); puts(name ? name : "NULL"); return 0; } What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Actual Results: "NULL" Expected Results: "none" What version of the product are you using? On what operating system? libarchive trunk r656 Visual C++ 2008 Windows XP SP3 Please provide any additional information below. build_stream overwrites a->archive.compression_name and a->archive.compression_code in line 346-347 in archive_read.c. libarchive 2.6.1 doesn't have this issue.
Fixed in r659.

items.title: compiler warnings in test suite
items.summary: compiler warnings in test suite

items.content:
I think I have a different build environment from everyone else, so 
reporting these just in case they go unnoticed elsewhere.

This code:

[test_tar_large.c line 202+]
-----------
DEFINE_TEST(test_tar_large)
{
	/* The sizes of the entries we're going to generate. */
	static off_t tests[] = {
		/* Test for 32-bit signed overflow. */
		2 * GB - 1, 2 * GB, 2 * GB + 1,
		/* Test for 32-bit unsigned overflow. */
		4 * GB - 1, 4 * GB, 4 * GB + 1,
		/* 8GB is the "official" max for ustar. */
		8 * GB - 1, 8 * GB, 8 * GB + 1,
		/* Bend ustar a tad and you can get 64GB (12 octal 
digits). */
		64 * GB - 1, 64 * GB,
		/* And larger entries that require non-ustar extensions. */
		256 * GB, 1 * TB, 0 };
-----------

causes these warnings:

C4307: '*' : integral constant overflow	line 207
C4307: '-' : integral constant overflow	line 207
C4307: '*' : integral constant overflow	line 207
C4307: '*' : integral constant overflow	line 207
C4307: '*' : integral constant overflow	line 209
C4307: '*' : integral constant overflow	line 209
C4307: '*' : integral constant overflow	line 209
C4307: '*' : integral constant overflow	line 211
C4307: '*' : integral constant overflow	line 211
C4307: '*' : integral constant overflow	line 211
C4307: '*' : integral constant overflow	line 213
C4307: '*' : integral constant overflow	line 213
C4307: '*' : integral constant overflow	line 215
C4307: '*' : integral constant overflow	line 215

This code:

[test_read_pax_truncated.c]
-----------
	size_t i;
	ssize_t filedata_size;
[...]
	for (i = 0; i < filedata_size; i++)
-----------

Causes these warnings:

C4018: '<' : signed/unsigned mismatch	line 51
C4018: '<' : signed/unsigned mismatch	line 85
C4018: '<' : signed/unsigned mismatch	line 100
C4018: '<' : signed/unsigned mismatch	line 134
C4018: '<' : signed/unsigned mismatch	line 147

in Visual Studio.

Please try changing "static off_t tests" to "static int64_t tests" and let me know if
that fixes the first problem here.  Someone recently pointed out to me that Visual
Studio declares off_t as a 32-bit integer type.  Let me know what other problems this
causes.

I believe the second issue here is fixed by r690.

The second issue does seem to be fixed.  The suggestion almost but not quite fixed 
the first issue.  off_t needs to be changed in two places:

Index: libarchive/test/test_tar_large.c
===================================================================
--- libarchive/test/test_tar_large.c    (revision 842)
+++ libarchive/test/test_tar_large.c    (working copy)

 /* The following size definitions simplify things below. */
-#define KB ((off_t)1024)
-#define MB ((off_t)1024 * KB)
-#define GB ((off_t)1024 * MB)
-#define TB ((off_t)1024 * GB)
+#define KB ((int64_t)1024)
+#define MB ((int64_t)1024 * KB)
+#define GB ((int64_t)1024 * MB)
+#define TB ((int64_t)1024 * GB)

...

 DEFINE_TEST(test_tar_large)
 {
        /* The sizes of the entries we're going to generate. */
-       static off_t tests[] = {
+       static int64_t tests[] = {
===================================================================

With the above changes, the truncation warnings disappear.

(Proper unified diff attached!)

I just committed r844, which is a slightly more ambitious version of this.
Please let me know...

I believe this has been fixed now, so I'm going to close it.
Please let me know if you still see any problems.

Thanks for fixing!
(Haven't got a suitable build environment for testing right now, sorry.)

items.title: simplify build process with optional yacc parser
items.summary: simplify build process with optional yacc parser

items.content:
The main objective of this issue is to simplify the build process.  With 
the following patch, a build can be successful even with a broken or 
missing yacc.

Any calls to the missing functionality gives a nice error message.

(See also: relevant messages on libarchive-discuss.)
r696 solves this problem completely.  yacc is no longer needed on any platform.
Nice !!!

items.title: Document options
items.summary: Document options

items.content:
The libarchive-formats man page needs to document the options supported by
each format.

The bsdtar man page needs to document the --options command line argument
and refer to the libarchive-formats man page for details.

The archive_read.3 and archive_write.3 man pages need to document the
options functions.

I've updated archive-read.3 and archive-write.3 with details about the new calls and
lists of currently-supported options.

Still need to update the bsdtar.1 manpage.
Added --options documentation to bsdtar.1.

items.title: Fix error handling for external programs
items.summary: Fix error handling for external programs

items.content:
If you invoke --use-compress-program with a nonexistent
filter program, no error is returned from libarchive.
Similarly, there is no error if the filter program
crashes.

$ tar -tvf test.tar --use-compress-program /nonexistent
$ echo $?
0

r790 and r791 fix the specific case described above.  The error is only reported at
archive_close(), which is less than ideal.  I'm going to see if I can find a clean
way to reap the child earlier in these cases.
This could be improved, but it's good enough for now.

items.title: Cmake install target
items.summary: Cmake install target

The cmake build process should support at least

I've commited about this issue at r775.
It's tested on FreeBSD stable and Windows.
I'll test it on Ubuntu. I believe it works on other platforms.
Good work!
I've tested the installation on Ubuntu and it works fine.

items.title: Recent win32 portability changes break cygwin
items.summary: Recent win32 portability changes break cygwin

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. checkout svn rev 772 2. bootstrap and (try to) build 3. see glorious errors... On cygwin, it is possible for _WIN32 to be defined -- which disables a lot of unix-oriented code and enables w32-specific workarounds. But, on cygwin, that's the job of the cygwin runtime; in almost all cases, the proper choice is to use the "unix" code and let cygwin do its thing. Most of this patch is mechanical: #ifdef _WIN32 --> #if defined(_WIN32) && !defined(__CYGWIN__) #ifndef _WIN32 --> #if !defined(_WIN32) || defined(__CYGWIN__) but not *always*. I also created new files cpio/cpio_cygwin.c cpio/cpio_cygwin.h tar/bsdtar_cygwin.c tar/bsdtar_cygwin.h by copying the relevant portions of the _windows files (cygwin doesn't provide a mechanism to determine whether a user is privileged or not, so you have to use the w32api to do so...) Finally, I revised the Makefile.am to add the new files to the _SOURCES as appropriate, and updated configure.ac to supply the necessary AM_CONDITIONALS and AC_DEFINES. I tried to also update CMakeLists similarly, but I'm not a CMake guru so I'm not sure if I did that part right; it's untested. The rest, though, is tested: I maintain the cygwin libarchive package http://cygwin.com/ml/cygwin-announce/2009-03/msg00057.html http://cygwin.com/ml/cygwin-announce/2009-03/msg00054.html and with these changes it once again passes all of the tests in the testsuite (and actually builds, too...) I'm fairly sure that these changes do not impact other platforms at all, since they are all guarded by #ifdefs or AM_CONDITIONALs, but I'm not set up to easily verify that. If you like, I can break this relatively large patch into smaller chunks, complete with ChangeLog entries, but I'm not sure how you prefer to operate on this project. The attached patch is against rev 722. CMakeLists.txt | 58 ++++--- Makefile.am | 68 ++++++++ configure.ac | 22 ++ cpio/cpio.c | 26 ++- cpio/cpio_cygwin.c | 139 +++++++++++++++++ cpio/cpio_cygwin.h | 41 +++++ cpio/cpio_platform.h | 4 cpio/cpio_windows.c | 3 cpio/test/main.c | 10 - cpio/test/test.h | 18 +- cpio/test/test_0.c | 2 cpio/test/test_basic.c | 14 - cpio/test/test_format_newc.c | 14 + cpio/test/test_gcpio_compat.c | 10 - cpio/test/test_option_L.c | 10 - cpio/test/test_option_a.c | 2 cpio/test/test_option_c.c | 12 - cpio/test/test_option_f.c | 4 cpio/test/test_option_u.c | 2 cpio/test/test_option_version.c | 2 cpio/test/test_owner_parse.c | 56 +++++-- cpio/test/test_passthrough_dotdot.c | 2 cpio/test/test_passthrough_reverse.c | 4 libarchive/archive.h | 4 libarchive/archive_check_magic.c | 4 libarchive/archive_entry.c | 2 libarchive/archive_entry.h | 4 libarchive/archive_read_disk_set_standard_lookup.c | 6 libarchive/archive_read_support_compression_program.c | 2 libarchive/archive_string.c | 16 +- libarchive/archive_windows.c | 5 libarchive/archive_write_disk.c | 21 +- libarchive/archive_write_disk_set_standard_lookup.c | 4 libarchive/archive_write_set_compression_program.c | 2 libarchive/archive_write_set_format_mtree.c | 6 libarchive/config_windows.h | 2 libarchive/filter_fork_windows.c | 4 libarchive/test/main.c | 12 - libarchive/test/test.h | 11 - libarchive/test/test_read_disk.c | 6 libarchive/test/test_read_extract.c | 6 libarchive/test/test_write_disk.c | 18 +- libarchive/test/test_write_disk_failures.c | 2 libarchive/test/test_write_disk_hardlink.c | 2 libarchive/test/test_write_disk_perms.c | 4 libarchive/test/test_write_disk_secure.c | 4 tar/bsdtar.c | 13 + tar/bsdtar.h | 1 tar/bsdtar_cygwin.c | 141 ++++++++++++++++++ tar/bsdtar_cygwin.h | 44 +++++ tar/bsdtar_platform.h | 4 tar/bsdtar_windows.c | 3 tar/cmdline.c | 1 tar/read.c | 2 tar/test/main.c | 10 - tar/test/test.h | 9 - tar/test/test_0.c | 2 tar/test/test_basic.c | 14 - tar/test/test_copy.c | 4 tar/test/test_patterns.c | 2 tar/test/test_strip_components.c | 2 tar/test/test_symlink_dir.c | 12 - tar/test/test_windows.c | 8 - tar/tree.c | 14 - tar/write.c | 2 65 files changed, 764 insertions(+), 194 deletions(-)

Thank you very much.  I've read through this once and it looks really quite good,
although I did notice a few stylistic nits.  It will take me another day or two to
read through this again and decide how best to handle it.
It's nice. I like it.

I agree there are a few warts, and stuff that you probably don't want in the official
repo:

(1) AC_PROG_LIBTOOL -> LT_INIT implies requiring libtool-2.2.x or better. Are you
ready to do that?

(1a) I haven't tested my configure.ac changes with anything older than autoconf-2.63.
I don't know what version of autoconf you prefer. I don't THINK I did anything that
requires newer than 2.59.

(2) I'm pretty sure you omitted the GNU tar "--same-owner" option for a reason; I
added it back because it's sometimes useful on cygwin. ("I don't care if tar can't
figure out that I actually have privileges; I just want it to go ahead a TRY to
chown; it'll work or it'll fail...")

(3) explicitly linking against /usr/lib/binmode.o -- even if restricted to cygwin
$hosts only -- is not portable.  What if you're cross-building (e.g. $build !=
cygwin, so /usr/lib/ contains linux stuff?).  I'll ask on the cygwin list if there is
a better way to do this (e.g. a cygwin analogue to _set_fmode()). Otherwise, a
configure option to add user-specified "EXTRA_APP_LDOBS" to the link commands of all
applications, but not the library, might be a better choice. Then, it could default
to empty everywhere except on $host=cygwin where it defaults to /usr/lib/binmode.o
(and, configure could check if $host=cygwin but $build!=cygwin, and error out if the
option is not specified).

(4) There are other ways than using AM_CONDITIONALS to include additional sources.
For instance, you could have a "bsdtar_platform_extra.c" that is always built, but it
uses #defines to control #including bsdtar_cygwin.c (yes, .c) or bsdtar_windows.c or
<nothing>, just like bsdtar_platform.h uses #defines to control loading the specific
.h files.  However, that sometimes causes linker warnings because if you #include
nothing -- then the .c file is effectively empty, the .o contains no symbols, and
some linkers don't like that. This is why I went the AM_CONDITIONAL route. Besides,
you already do something similar in the CMakeList, so I figured that was the way to go.

(5) I have *no* idea if the changes I made to the CMakeList are correct.

(6) I haven't yet tested if 'make dist' creates a full and completely buildable
archive. It should be a lot closer than before; previously Makefile.am was missing a
lot of stuff that I've added to the various EXTRA_DIST_* vars.

However, if the bulk of the patch is acceptable (e.g. and is verified not break other
platforms) -- especially the mechanical bits -- that'd be good to get into the repo
before the 2.7.0 release.

BTW, is it possible to fix the typo in the Issue title? cygiwn -> cygwin?

(1) libtool version ... autoconf version

    As long as those changes are separate commits we retain the option of backing
them out.  It would be good to make sure we get those requirements documented,
though.  Perhaps the INSTALLING description should be updated.

(2) I'm pretty sure you omitted the GNU tar "--same-owner" option for a reason...

    The reason:  Nobody asked.  bsdtar was never intended to be a GNU tar clone; I
honestly believe that a fair number of GNU tar options may have been good ideas at
the time but are mostly useless now, so I've taken the stance that bsdtar will adopt
options from GNU tar (and other tar implementations) when people ask for those
specific options.

(3) cygwin, cross-building

    Platform esoterica like this is tedious to work out.  Your idea of
EXTRA_APP_LDOBS sounds like a reasonable approach.  Although it also sounds like
another nudge towards breaking libarchive apart from bsdtar and bsdcpio.  I don't
think I'm personally ready for that yet, but it might be getting closer.

(4) handling platform specific code

  I want to spend the 2.8 cycle looking at this issue.  We've hacked up a lot of
stuff to get the Windows builds working at all; there's definitely room for
improvement.  If we really need specific platform support for that many platforms,
then I'd rather simply fork archive_write_disk and archive_read_disk_entry_from_file,
which are the two API entries that hold almost all of the platform-specific code. 
(Almost all of libarchive is clean, portable code with no platform dependencies at
all.)  Platform-specific code in bsdtar and bsdcpio should be carefully pushed down
into the library.

(5) CmakeList updates

   I'm hoping to start the 2.7 pre-release testing in another week or so.

(6) 'make dist'

   'make dist' has worked well for years; I'll let you know if you've broken it.  ;-)

Before 2.7 --- absolutely.

Fix the title --- done.

updates.summary: Recent win32 portability changes break cygwin

items.content:
Re: libtool and autoconf versions.

One of my sanity checks for version acceptance is the FreeBSD ports tree, which
currently ships libtool 1.5.26 and autoconf 2.62.  I'd prefer to not require anything
later than those versions unless we get some significant benefit from doing so.

Okay, I've committed the first three chunks. These are the mechanical modifications
to the #defines for the libarchive, tar, and cpio subdirectories.

With those three, I can't yet build on cygwin (need the rest of the patchset, for
that), but building on linux works and passes all tests, both before and after -- so
at least I didn't do anything silly.

Remaining chunks:

These four should be uncontroversial, assuming it is ok to add the --same-owner option.
bsdtar_02_cygwin_extra_files.patch
cpio_02_cygwin_extra_files.patch
cpio_04_test_nlinks.patch
bsdtar_04_option_same_owner.patch

These will need a little reworking, to accommodate previous comments and recent svn
changes...
libarchive_02_other.patch
bsdtar_03_other.patch
cpio_03_other.patch
build_system.patch

But the mechanical ones were the bulk of the changes.

[*] I needed the following patch to cpio/test/test.h to build on linux; otherwise I
got a warning (-Werror) about 'time' function not defined, assuming int..

@@ -63,6 +63,17 @@
 #endif
 #include <wchar.h>
 
+#ifdef TIME_WITH_SYS_TIME 
+# include <sys/time.h> 
+# include <time.h> 
+#else 
+# ifdef HAVE_SYS_TIME_H 
+#  include <sys/time.h> 
+# else 
+#  include <time.h> 
+# endif 
+#endif 
+
 #ifdef USE_DMALLOC
 #include <dmalloc.h>
 #endif
Seems to still build fine on FreeBSD as well.

Just committed parts 4-7:
bsdtar_02_cygwin_extra_files.patch
cpio_02_cygwin_extra_files.patch
cpio_04_test_nlinks.patch
bsdtar_04_option_same_owner.patch

Still passes all tests on linux.

One comment: my version of [bsdtar|cpio]_cygwin.c retains the local #define
_WIN32_WINNT (plus an extra #define WINVER; both are necessary when using the mingw
w32api headers as cygwin/mingw do, rather then the official MS api headers).

This is contrary to the change in r786, which moves this #define from
[bsdtar|cpio]_windows.c to config.h (effectively) -- but only when building with
cmake.  Since my comment on r786 in which I expressed no opinion, I now think r786
should be reverted -- for two reasons. (1) These sorts of #defines -- WINVER,
POSIX_SOURCE, GNU_SOURCE, etc -- are specific to the translation unit being compiled,
not the entire package. You're indicating that THIS file needs certain declarations
-- not that everything in the package needs those declarations.  Really, these sorts
of #defines should *never* be in .h files -- because then some .c that, perhaps down
the road, needs stuff from POSIX2 rather than POSIX1e, or from WinXP rather than
Win2k, must do the #undef dance. This is bad. (2) Secondly, of course, r786 breaks
mingw builds that are hosted on msys or cygwin, where you might actually run
configure, instead of using cmake.

The remaining four chunks need a little more work. I've had a conversation on the
cygwin lists about the binmode.o issue; see this thread:
http://cygwin.com/ml/cygwin/2009-03/msg00599.html

I'm not sufficiently versed in Windows development to debate whether WINVER and
_WIN32_WINNT should be defined per-translation unit or per-application.  (And I know
examples of "these sorts of #defines" that must be set consistently across an
application, so your argument from general principle isn't very convincing.) 
Certainly we need to ensure that both configure-based and cmake-based builds work
correctly.  So it does make sense to put such knowledge into .h and .c source files
where feasible instead of putting it into the build framework since knowledge in the
build framework will need to be duplicated.

I've now committed all but the build system changes to svn, although part 12 (r819)
did include a small piece of the build system changes.  So far, still continues to
build and pass all tests on linux [*].

[*] I included in part 8 (r815) a variant of the patch posted above in comment #6, as
well a the related parts of the original big cygwin patch). Also, r808 fixed Ubuntu
-- but broke Mandriva; it's an order-of-inclusion thing; fixed in r815. I hope this
way works also for Ubuntu...

Part 14 (build system changes) is committed at r827. This is the last bit; libarchive
now compiles and passes all tests on cygwin. Also tested on linux with autoconf-2.61,
automake-1.10, and libtool-1.5.22, and passes all tests.

I didn't need to add a configure option for binmode.o; itstead, I borrowed a page
from libtool and extracted the library search path from the compiler, and then
searched that path for binmode.o if $host is cygwin.  This should work even if
cross-building.

Finally, I updated all of the *_EXTRA_DIST variables as necessary. My final tarball
was still missing the following files:

build/autogen.sh
build/release.sh
contrib/shar/Makefile
cpio/Makefile
cpio/test/Makefile
examples/minitar/Makefile
libarchive/Makefile
libarchive/test/.cvsignore
libarchive/test/Makefile
PROJECTS
tar/Makefile
tar/test/Makefile

But I wasn't sure whether any of those should be included, anyway.

items.title: There are no documents on Windows platform.
items.summary: There are no documents on Windows platform.

items.content:
A user who uses libarchive on Windows platform cannot read Unix style man
pages.

We need at least ascii text documents(pdf is better) for Windows platform.
That documents can be generated by
  groff -man -T ascii <man-file> > <man-file>.txt
  or
  groff -man -T ps <man-file> | ps2pdf - <man-file>.pdf

The "make dist" process already does this; it creates text documents and places them
in doc/text.  PDF is a good idea; I'll add that.
"make dist" now creates PDF versions of the documentation as well.

items.title: Build fails under 64-bit Interix 6.1
items.summary: Build fails under 64-bit Interix 6.1

items.content: 1. ./configure 2. make In file included from libarchive/archive_entry.c:69: libarchive/archive_entry_private.h:121: error: parse error before "uint64_t" libarchive/archive_entry_private.h:121: warning: no semicolon at end of struct or union libarchive/archive_entry_private.h:121: warning: no semicolon at end of struct or union libarchive/archive_entry_private.h:139: error: parse error before '}' token libarchive/archive_entry_private.h:139: warning: data definition has no type or storage class libarchive/archive_entry_private.h:177: error: parse error before '}' token libarchive/archive_entry.c: In function `archive_entry_clear': libarchive/archive_entry.c:365: error: dereferencing pointer to incomplete type libarchive/archive_entry.c:366: error: dereferencing pointer to incomplete type libarchive/archive_entry.c:367: error: dereferencing pointer to incomplete type then many "error: dereferencing pointer to incomplete type" follow for each dereference of any struct archive_entry* variable. What version of the product are you using? 2.6.0 and 2.6.2 are affected Please provide any additional information below.

Please try the attached patch and let me know if this fixes it for you.

Well, now the other error appears:

gcc -DHAVE_CONFIG_H -I.  -I./libarchive -I./libarchive   -g -O2 -MT tar/bsdtar-r
ead.o -MD -MP -MF tar/.deps/bsdtar-read.Tpo -c -o tar/bsdtar-read.o `test -f 'ta
r/read.c' || echo './'`tar/read.c
tar/read.c: In function `list_item_verbose':
tar/read.c:379: error: `uintmax_t' undeclared (first use in this function)
tar/read.c:379: error: (Each undeclared identifier is reported only once
tar/read.c:379: error: for each function it appears in.)
tar/read.c:379: error: parse error before "st"

Joerg Sonnenberger just committed a change to trunk that should fix this.  Could you

items.title: XZ/LZMA writer fails if compression-level option is set > 6
items.summary: XZ/LZMA writer fails if compression-level option is set > 6

items.content:
I committed the last patch here in r904 so that "compression-level=9" doesn't break
anything.  I'd still like to know why presets larger than 6 break the writer, though.
"xz" command uses the same lzma_lzma_preset() and works correctly for presets > 6. Is there still any reason for this hack?

items.title: Prefer getpwnam_r/getgrnam_r in archive_write_disk_set_standard_lookup
items.summary: Prefer getpwnam_r/getgrnam_r in archive_write_disk_set_standard_lookup

items.content:
getpwnam_r and getgrnam_r are thread-safe, so
archive_write_disk_set_standard_lookup should use those when they're available.

archive_read_disk_set_standard_lookup has example code that uses getpwuid_r
and getgrgid_r
Implemented in r905.

items.title: Fix Zip Writer
items.summary: Fix Zip Writer

items.content:
I've committed the last draft of a Zip writer for libarchive, including a
number of test cases.

This still needs some work to complete.

items.title: test_option_tnv.stdout.uu is wrong
items.summary: test_option_tnv.stdout.uu is wrong

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. make check What is the expected output? PASS What do you see instead? 1 of 25 tests reported failures Total of 796 assertions checked. Total of 1 assertions failed. Total of 1 assertions skipped. FAIL: bsdcpio_test ===================================== 1 of 3 tests failed Please report to kientzle@freebsd.org ===================================== What version of the product are you using? On what operating system? 2.6.992a on Linux and FreeBSD Please provide any additional information below.
What timezone are you in?  <sigh>

The archive has a timestamp of 1, which is indeed Dec 31, 1969 west of Greenwich but
Jan 1, 1970 east of Greenwich.

< -rw-r--r--   1 1000     1000            0 Dec 31  1969 file
---
> -rw-r--r--   1 1000     1000            0 Jan  1  1970 file

Changing the reference file will just break it in different timezones.
I've disabled this check in r1004 until I can come up with something more robust.
Why cannot you use TZ=UTC?
Windows doesn't have /usr/bin/env.
What about just using setenv()?

"What about just using setenv()?"

That might work.  Let's try that in trunk and see what happens.  I'd rather not put
this change into 2.7 until we get thorough test coverage of it.

After thinking about it some, I'm not enthusiastic about setenv():  the code to set
and then restore the TZ value is a little tedious, and I don't want to leave the
timezone set to UTC for every test, since we have seen bugs in the past that only
appeared in certain timezones.

Since we're testing a single line of output that has only two possible values,
I found it easier to just hardcode the two possibilities in the C source.
This should work on all platforms.  Implemented in r1037.

items.title: Conditionally disable openssl requirement for mtree format in 2.7.0
items.summary: Conditionally disable openssl requirement for mtree format in 2.7.0

items.content: What version of the product are you using? On what operating system? libarchive-2.7.0. GNU/Linux. Please provide any additional information below. Hi, I've just downloaded latest released version (2.7.0) and noticed that unconditionally libarchive was linked to libcrypto (openssl), therefore I investigated why. It seems that the mtree write support uses some openssl hash algorithms; it's ok but I'd like to see this optional, i.e personally I don't need this part and I don't want libarchive to detect openssl and link to it because that means another dependency. I made a patch that adds "--with(out)-openssl" flag to the configure script, respecting current behaviour (use them if available). I'd really like to see this in next version, if possible! thanks.

Committed as r1047 in trunk, r1048 in release/2.7 branch.  It will be in 2.7.1.

Still remains to add a similar switch to the cmake build system.
Brad:  Do you have time to take a look at this?

I've committed CMake build support as r1750:

  cmake -DENABLE_OPENSSL=OFF ...
I think this is completely resolved now.

items.title: Build problems on MinGW
items.summary: Build problems on MinGW

items.content:
From Christian Ehrlicher:

I've some problems compiling libarchive with mingw:

- I've an old libarchive installed therefore you've to make sure cmake
adds ${CMAKE_CURRENT_SOURCE_DIR}/libarchive o include directories before
all others (line 557) - otherwise the old headers will be used for the
test program
- ino_t is short on windows (unsigned short for msvc, short for mingw)
which will result in a warning at archive_write_set_format_cpio.c:128
and because -Werror is defined... :)
- HCRYPTPROV and friends (archive_windows.h:270) are defined in
wincrypt.h which needs to be included (see
http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/aa382471(VS.85).aspx )
- fileno is already defined (archive_windows.h:90) for mingw - simply
add an ifndef to work around this
- wcsncpy_s isn't available on mingw - those crappy _s functions are
msvc8 and up only
- isalpha(), toupper() are defined in ctype.h (archive_windows.c)
- WriteFile() takes a DWORD as 4th parameter (archive_windows.c:1065)
- CryptHashData() needs a (BYTE*) as 2nd parameter (not const BYTE* -
crappy winapi --> http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/aa380202.aspx )

And now a very annoying thing: _dosmaperr() is not available for mingw -
it was added with the msvc runtime version 7.1 (afaik) but mingw is
still using msvc runtime 6.0 ...
I'm looking for a way to work around this - iirc postgres or mysql have
an own implementation of this function. But don't know if you will
accept such an implementation because of possible copyright things...
I believe the attached patch addresses the second item in this list.

Regarding "copyright things":  Copying code from other projects is easy if that code
is public domain or BSD licensed; please talk to me before copying code that uses
other licenses.  In all cases, existing license and copyright notices should be very
carefully preserved.

Regarding the fourth item ("fileno already defined"), please try the attached patch
and let me know if this fixes it in this case.

Here's a candidate patch that may fix the 2nd, 3rd, 4th, 7th, and 8th items lists
here.  Untested as yet...
Here are some sources from PostgreSQL that Christian found that should be useful:

Here's a slightly edited version of the above files that should be suitable for
inclusion in libarchive.

I've committed fixes for most of this in libarchive/trunk r1082 and r1083.
I've verified that it now mostly builds under MinGW; there's still the _dosmaperr
issue to work through.

r1084 and r1085 substituted a custom dosmaperr().

libarchive per se now builds cleanly on MinGW; the test suite doesn't build yet,
though.  There's still some more work to do there.

For reference, here are the build problems in libarchive_test:

C:\Documents and Settings\Tim\Desktop\libarchive\trunk\libarchive\test\main.c:37:20:
crtdbg.h: No such file or directory
C:\Documents and Settings\Tim\Desktop\libarchive\trunk\libarchive\test\main.c: In
function `get_refdir':
C:\Documents and Settings\Tim\Desktop\libarchive\trunk\libarchive\test\main.c:974:
warning: implicit declaration of function `sprintf_s'
C:\Documents and Settings\Tim\Desktop\libarchive\trunk\libarchive\test\main.c: In
function `main':
C:\Documents and Settings\Tim\Desktop\libarchive\trunk\libarchive\test\main.c:1034:
warning: implicit declaration of function `_set_invalid_parameter_handler'
C:\Documents and Settings\Tim\Desktop\libarchive\trunk\libarchive\test\main.c:1036:
warning: implicit declaration of function `_set_fmode'
C:\Documents and Settings\Tim\Desktop\libarchive\trunk\libarchive\test\main.c:1038:
warning: implicit declaration of function `_CrtSetReportMode'
C:\Documents and Settings\Tim\Desktop\libarchive\trunk\libarchive\test\main.c:1038:
error: `_CRT_ASSERT' undeclared (first use in this function)
C:\Documents and Settings\Tim\Desktop\libarchive\trunk\libarchive\test\main.c:1038:
error: (Each undeclared identifier is reported only once
C:\Documents and Settings\Tim\Desktop\libarchive\trunk\libarchive\test\main.c:1038:
error: for each function it appears in.)

I had hoped to fix this for 2.7.1, but it's turning out to be trickier than I
thought.  I'm going to defer it until 2.8.

This has been fixed in libarchive/trunk.  The very few remaining test failures are
common to Visual Studio and MinGW and are being handled as separate bugs.

items.title: Memory leak and blocked function call reading truncated ISO
items.summary: Memory leak and blocked function call reading truncated ISO

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Read a truncated ISO using any input method (tested with archive_read_open, archive_read_open_FILE, archive_read_open_filename). 2. Traverse till the last partial file is reached (skip as desired). 3. Attempting to read the last file will work until the EOF is reached. Once EOF is reached, the call archive_read_data will block, and the program will consume memory at around 100MBps on my system until RAM and swap are filled. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Expected it to error out or otherwise fail (gracefully, but even segfault is better than this). What version of the product are you using? On what operating system? Confirmed on 2.6.2 and on 2.7.0. Linux lintux 2.6.29-gentoo-r1 #1 SMP Thu Apr 9 08:04:40 PDT 2009 x86_64 Intel(R) Core(TM)2 Extreme CPU X9650 @ 3.00GHz GenuineIntel GNU/Linux gcc version 4.3.3 (Gentoo 4.3.3-r2 p1.1, pie-10.1.5) Please provide any additional information below. http://tehinterweb.com/test.iso (12MB) is the offending iso file (which is part of an ubuntu iso, nothing illicit). http://tehinterweb.com/test.c is an example of code that produces the above results on my system. (The file mentioned in it, install/initrd.gz, is the last file which will hang.) I have also confirmed this on other truncated iso files. I would classify this as a dangerous vulnerability, as it will very quickly overwhelm a system. If more information is desired, I should be readily available for contact.

Try this patch and let me know if it fixes it for you.

I'll also add a test to the test suite to guard against this kind of error in the future.

Confirm that the patch indeed fixes the issue.

Thanks much for the quick action!

Committed to trunk as r1028, to 2.7 as r1029.  It will be in the 2.7.1 release.

I'm marking this as fixed, even though I'd like to get a good test for it into
libarchive_test, one that verifies handling of truncated archives for all formats,
not just ISO, and which doesn't require a 12MB reference file.  Unfortunately, the
bug doesn't seem to be triggered by truncated compressed archives.

items.title: Failure reading body of first regular file in mtree archive
items.summary: Failure reading body of first regular file in mtree archive

items.content:
When reading an mtree archive, attempting to read the body is supposed to
pull bytes from the corresponding file on disk.  This enables a powerful
idiom for controlling metadata when building tar or cpio archives:

tar cf - --format=mtree .
   | sed 's/uid=[0-9]*/uid=0/'
   | tar cf archive.tar @-

Unfortunately, there is an error that causes the body of the first regular
file to be dropped, resulting in zero bytes for the body in the final tar
archive.
Fixed in trunk r1033; merged to 2.7 branch in r1036.

items.title: bsdcpio tests fail on linux x86_64
items.summary: bsdcpio tests fail on linux x86_64

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. ./configure --prefix=/usr --host=x86_64-pc-linux-gnu -- sysconfdir=/etc --localstatedir=/var/lib --disable-dependency-tracking -- bsdcpio=shared --with-zlib --with-bz2lib --with-lzma --without-lzmadec -- 2. make 3. make check What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Running tests in: /tmp/bsdcpio_test.2009-04-21T13.50.57-000 Reference files will be read from: /home/ingmar/development/git/libarchive/cpio/test Running tests on: /home/ingmar/development/git/libarchive/bsdcpio Exercising: bsdcpio 2.7.0 -- libarchive 2.7.0 0: test_0 1: test_basic 2: test_cmdline 3: test_format_newc cpio/test/test_format_newc.c:209: Assertion failed: Ints not equal 0x41fd=16893 from_hex(e + 14, 8)=17917 4: test_gcpio_compat 5: test_option_a *** SKIPPING: Cannot verify -a option Your system appears to not support atime. 6: test_option_B_upper 7: test_option_c cpio/test/test_option_c.c:188: Assertion failed: memory not equal size 6 = 6 Dump of e + 18 0000 30 34_32_37 37 35 042775 Dump of "040775" 0000 30 34_30_37 37 35 040775 8: test_option_C_upper 9: test_option_d 10: test_option_f 11: test_option_help 12: test_option_l 13: test_option_L_upper 14: test_option_m 15: test_option_t 16: test_option_u 17: test_option_version 18: test_option_y 19: test_option_z 20: test_option_Z_upper 21: test_owner_parse Ignore this message: Couldn't look up group ``nonexistentgroup'' Ignore this message: Couldn't look up group ``nonexistentgroup'' Ignore this message: Couldn't lookup user ``nonexistentuser'' 22: test_passthrough_dotdot 23: test_passthrough_reverse 24: test_pathmatch 2 of 25 tests reported failures Total of 796 assertions checked. Total of 2 assertions failed. Total of 1 assertions skipped. FAIL: bsdcpio_test What version of the product are you using? On what operating system? libarchive 2.7.0 on Linux x86_64 Please provide any additional information below. Attaching the entire build log...

Thank you for the report.  This has been fixed in SVN: r1049 in trunk, r1050 in
release/2.7.  It will be included in the 2.7.1 point release.

Diagnosis:  You have sgid set on /tmp and are using a filesystem that propagates sgid
bits to subdirectories.  I've modified the affected tests to ignore extraneous sgid
bits in these cases.
That was fast, thanks!

items.title: Add UDF support
items.summary: Add UDF support

items.content:
libarchive-based programs such as gvfs' archive backend cannot access UDF
data on ISO9660 images, such as Microsoft Windows 7 RC's ISO images.

This would be nice to have but will require someone to step up and do a significant
amount of work, starting with researching UDF and figuring out if it's possible to
read UDF images in a streaming fashion.

I made a UDF ISO that doesn't work with gvfs's archive mounter, but it does work with
fuseiso... fuseiso may already have done the hard work.
Just FYI. http://www.gnu.org/software/libcdio/ supports UDF so perhaps that is easier to get UDF support.. Not exactly sure though.
I mounted the windows (XP, 2008 and 7) ISOs using fuseiso using fuseiso but I didn't see any content at the mount point so even they don't have proper support for it.

I did a bit more research on this. It turns out that http://www.gnu.org/software/libcdio/ is supporting both UDF and ISO9660 and sound cd's but i'm guessing that part isn't very useful for libarchive.

So, in other words: add libcdio as dependency and start using it for UDF and ISO9660 reads then we "finally" can open iso files in both formats without the need to mount them or use fuse.

I will make a separate issue for this.

Out of pure coincidence, I just wrote a sample app using libcdio/libiso9660 to list directories out of ISOs. It worked for normal (fedora, RHEL installer/live etc) ISOs and some of the UDFs that libarchive fails on but not all of them. It was able to read windows XP ISO but not windows 7 one.

So my advice would be to test cdio with various UDFs out there (different windows installer ISOs should be enough) before concluding that that will solve the problem.
#8, cdio is the only one (that i know if) that has UDF support. If anything is broken there then you should really send them a bug report. Would be nice :)
Done! http://savannah.gnu.org/bugs/index.php?34358

#10, responding in here now since i don't have an account there yet. I really do wonder why you use iso9660_ functions when you are actually testing UDF images... use the udf_ functions and it _might_ just work for you.

Just the first thing i noticed in your example code ^_-
I really want Libarchive able to read UDF File System.

items.title: Add a python wrapper
items.summary: Add a python wrapper

items.content:
Having a python wrapper for libarchive would be awesome!
Either a ctypes or swig wrapper

bzr co http://pkgcore.org/~ferringb/pyarchive # may be of interest.

The intention of these bindings is to expose libarchives stream design, while being
able to provide a tarfile equivalent api (where sane... since tarfile is mostly
insane).  What's there provides a very *basic* api matching that; it probably
segfaults like a mother also, although the blatantly obvious ones I've snagged thus far.

No tests, mostly since I've been mangling the design pretty heavily feeling out which
fits best for the intentions- tests will be added in the near future (fairly happy w/
the current design although it'll be mangled).

Re: usage of bzr, may proxy it into git; I'm just using what I started with
originally, if folks scream loudly enough I'll convert the underlying repo over.

Cheers-

Brian:
Thanks!
very nice!
I am going to play with that puppy and report here

I'd like to be able to access the extended attributes (xattr) if you could implement
access to them.

I just wanted to let folks know that I needed a complete wrapper for libarchive, so I implemented one.

http://code.google.com/p/python-libarchive/

I would love to hear feedback about the work I have done on this wrapper. I tried to make it as simple as possible, but also I wanted to provide a compatibility layer for the zipfile (and later tarfile) stdlib modules.

Thanks.

items.title: Minor build problem on QNX
items.summary: Minor build problem on QNX

items.content:
Version: libarchive 2.7.0 release
OS: QNX (Posix real-time OS)
Compiler: gcc 3.3.5

Compilation failed.

I made it compile by adding '#define wchar_t unsigned long' to 'config.h'.

On my system, sizeof(wchar_t) gives 4 bytes.
Adding -fshort-wchar to gcc did not resolve the problem.


This is the output:

...
 gcc -DHAVE_CONFIG_H -I. -I ./libarchive -Wall -Werror -g -O2 -MT 
libarchive/libarchive_la-archive_entry.lo -MD -MP -MF 
libarchive/.deps/libarchive_la-archive_entry.Tpo -c 
libarchive/archive_entry.c  -fPIC -DPIC -o libarchive/.libs/libarchive_la-
archive_entry.o
libarchive/archive_entry.c: In function `archive_entry_acl_text_w':
libarchive/archive_entry.c:1486: warning: assignment from incompatible 
pointer type
libarchive/archive_entry.c: In function `append_entry_w':
libarchive/archive_entry.c:1535: warning: passing arg 2 of `wcscpy' from 
incompatible pointer type
...
libarchive/archive_entry.c: In function `__archive_entry_acl_parse_w':
libarchive/archive_entry.c:1648: warning: passing arg 2 of `wmemcmp' from 
incompatible pointer type
libarchive/archive_entry.c:1654: warning: passing arg 3 of `prefix_w' from 
incompatible pointer type
...
make[1]: *** [libarchive/libarchive_la-archive_entry.lo] Error 1
make[1]: Leaving directory
make: *** [all] Error 2

$ gcc test.c -o test
$ ./test
	sizeof(wchar_t) = 4
	sizeof(L"abc"[0]) = 4

$ gcc -fshort-wchar test.c -o test
$ ./test
	sizeof(wchar_t) = 4
	sizeof(L"abc"[0]) = 2

$ uname -a
	QNX BlackQNX 6.3.2 2006/03/16-14:20:03EST x86pc x86

$ qconfig
	QNX Installations

	  Installation Name: QNX Momentics Development Suite 6.3.2
	            Version: 6.3.2
	     Base Directory: /usr/qnx632/
	           QNX_HOST: /usr/qnx632/host/qnx6/x86/
	         QNX_TARGET: /usr/qnx632/target/qnx6/

	Additional Packages

I verified where the compiler passes in header files got what is written below.
Finally, it seems like 'wchar_t' is 'unsigned', but libarchive only compiles when 
defining it to 'unsigned long'.

include dir: /usr/qnx632/target/qnx6/usr/include
<wchar.h>
	...
	#include <sys/platform.h>
	...
	#if defined(__WCHAR_T)
	typedef __WCHAR_T wchar_t;
	#undef __WCHAR_T
	#endif
	...
<sys/platform.h>
	...
	#elif defined(__GNUC__)
		#include _NTO_HDR_(sys/compiler_gnu.h)
	...
	#include _NTO_HDR_(sys/target_nto.h)
	...
	#ifdef __WCHAR_T
		typedef __WCHAR_T _Wchart;
		#undef __WCHAR_T
		#if !defined(__cplusplus)
			#define __WCHAR_T _Wchart
		#endif
	#endif
	...
<sys/target_nto.h>
	...
	#undef __WCHAR_T
	#if defined (__cplusplus)
		#define __WCHAR_T	wchar_t
	#else
		#define __WCHAR_T	_Uint32t
	#endif
	...
<sys/compiler_gnu.h>
	...
	#if __INT_BITS__ == 32
		// **** LIBARCHIVE GETS HERE ****
		typedef unsigned _GCC_ATTR_ALIGN_u32t;
		typedef _GCC_ATTR_ALIGN_u32t _Uint32t 
__attribute__((__aligned__(4)));
		...
	#elif __GNUC__ > 2 || (__GNUC__ == 2 && __GNUC_MINOR__ >= 7)
		typedef unsigned int _GCC_ATTR_ALIGN_u32t 
__attribute__((__mode__(__SI__)));
		typedef _GCC_ATTR_ALIGN_u32t _Uint32t  
__attribute__((__aligned__(4)));
		...
	#else
		typedef unsigned long _GCC_ATTR_ALIGN_u32t;
		typedef _GCC_ATTR_ALIGN_u32t _Uint32t 
__attribute__((__aligned__(4)));
		...
	...

This is not so broken as I feared.  The key problem:  For some reason, your compiler
is using a type for wide-character string literals (written L"abc") that is not the
same as wchar_t.  This is basically a mismatch between the compiler and the system
headers.  Fortunately, both L"..."[0] and wchar_t are 32 bits wide, so you should be
able to work around it with a simple cast.  Find the few wide-character literals in
the libarchive sources (search for uppercase 'L' followed by a double-quote) and add
an explicit cast to each one, so that
     L"this is a wide string"
becomes
     (const wchar_t *)L"this is a wide string"

Please try this and let me know if it fixes it for you.
Waiting for feedback; marking this issue as "Waiting"

Since it has been a few months, I'm going to close this as "WontFix".
I'll happily reopen it if there's additional information.

items.title: Autodetection of some but not all xz-compressed tarballs fails
items.summary: Autodetection of some but not all xz-compressed tarballs fails

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. run "bsdtar xf coreutils-7.4.tar.xz" What is the expected output? What do you see instead? I expect bsdtar to uncompress the archive. Instead, I get the following output: bsdtar: Unrecognized archive format bsdtar: Error exit delayed from previous errors. What version of the product are you using? On what operating system? libarchive-2.7.0 on Linux 2.6 using the current tip of xz's master branch (commit 1735d31ea347210e914df038eeea4b2626e76e42) so I only have liblzma but not liblzmadec. Please provide any additional information below. I can properly extract the tarball using bsdtar x --use-compress-program=unxz -f ~/sourcen/coreutils-7.4.tar.xz Also, libarchive's autodetection works great with another xz-compressed tarball, m4-1.4.13.tar.xz. URLs for those two tarballs: ftp://ftp.gnu.org/gnu/coreutils/coreutils-7.4.tar.xz ftp://ftp.gnu.org/gnu/m4/m4-1.4.13.tar.xz

Both of those tarballs work for me using the current tip of libarchive's development
branch; I note that the XZ support code is unchanged since 2.7.0.  To be sure we're
testing the same files, here are the MD5s for the tarballs I downloaded from the
links you provided:

MD5 (/tmp/coreutils-7.4.tar.xz) = e8d906c153f271430e3efb2b9a35a35f
MD5 (/tmp/m4-1.4.13.tar.xz) = 206b13cb45e95cd2ba60bf401900ab2d

The md5sums match.

I'll try libarchive's trunk.

Switching to the trunk didn't help, so I debugged the problem:
Apparently the 10 MB decompression buffer that we're giving to liblzma isn't large
enough. For the coreutils tarball, liblzma requires a ~64 MB buffer apparently (the
variable memusage is 67174292 in stream_decoder.c:207).

For the m4 tarball, liblzma wants a ~8 MB buffer so this works with the current 10 MB
buffer libarchive specifies.

I patched the release/2.7 branch to use a very large value for the memory limit.  I
haven't yet found any information that suggests this is inappropriate.

Please try the tip of the release/2.7 branch and let me know if that works for you.
Yes, release/2.7 works nicely for me. Thanks.

items.title: [PATCH] Replace call to bsdtar_errc to lafe_errc in tar/siginfo.c
items.summary: [PATCH] Replace call to bsdtar_errc to lafe_errc in tar/siginfo.c

items.content:
libarchive's trunk doesn't build for me:

  cc1: warnings being treated as errors
  tar/siginfo.c: In function 'siginfo_init':
  tar/siginfo.c:94: error: implicit declaration of function 'bsdtar_errc'

I believe it should try to call lafe_errc() instead.
Fixed.  Thanks for the report and the patch.

items.title: Directories with spaces
items.summary: Directories with spaces

items.content:
There seem to be some lingering problems with directories containing
spaces, especially on Windows.

In particular, bsdtar_test fails badly on Windows if the TMPDIR environment
variable points to a directory that has spaces in the pathname.  I
experimented with quoting arguments when building up command strings, but
that seems insufficient.

I've also seen some odd behavior on FreeBSD if I try to build and run the
tests in a directory where the path has spaces in it.

I have partial fix for this in trunk and expect it to be fully addressed for 2.8.  It
mostly impacts Windows users building in their home directory (the infamous
"C:\Documents and Settings\").

I believe this is fully fixed in trunk.  I've been running the full test suite out of
directories on my Desktop with the temp directory set to "C:\Documents and
Settings\tim\Local Settings\Temp" and it all seems to work fine.

items.title: C++ wrapper
items.summary: C++ wrapper

items.content:
I'm not going to have time to work on this anytime soon.
If anyone else is interested, please feel free...

Does this really give any new functionality? I can't even imagine a useful case for
inheritance here.

Inheritance is useful for filtering the files returned when the archive is scanned, so it does have a purpose.  I've 
used it in my Obj-C wrapper (http://bazaar.launchpad.net/%7Epelle-
morth/modazipin/trunk/annotate/head%3A/ArchiveWrapper.m and .h if anyone is interested). The filtering is in 
the DazipArchive subclass though.

What would be great is if we could wrap this for use as an istream and ostream.  The istream can then function as a universal decompressor.  We would want to select the compression scheme to use for the ostream.

I think the best way to implement boost's Filter interface (see http://www.boost.org/doc/libs/1_43_0/libs/iostreams/doc/concepts/filter.html) it would give C++ developers a lot of power and could help to raise more awareness of this project.  Currently there is only support for gzip and bzip2 so we could really use all the schemes supported by libarchive.

I wrote a C++ wrapper that simplifies the interface with streams, iterators and RAII.

https://github.com/do-m-en/libarchive_cpp_wrapper/tree/develop

It was written for C++11 and above.

items.title: bsdtar handling of tarfiles with individually gzipped blocks
items.summary: bsdtar handling of tarfiles with individually gzipped blocks

items.content:
If a tar file is assembled via concatenation of individual gz files, bsdtar
appears to only read the first concatenated chunk when decompressing with -z. 

This is somewhat subtle and weird, and I don't know if any specification
actually defines this behavior for tar.gz files, or if anyone will even
consider this a bug.

I figure its a bug because I would expect the behaviors of gzip -cd
file.tar.gz | tar -xvf - to be exactly the same as tar -zxvf file.tar.gz .

with bsdtar (freebsd 7.0):

$ touch file1 file2
$ tar -cvf base.tar file1 file2
a file1
a file2
$ split -b512 base.tar
$ gzip xa?
$ cat xa?.* > combined.tar.gz
$ tar -zxvf combined.tar.gz
x file1
$ gzip -cd combined.tar.gz | tar -xvf -
x file1
x file2

linux gnutar (centos 5.3):
# touch file1 file2
# tar -cvf base.tar file1 file2
file1
file2
# split -b512 base.tar
# gzip xa?
# cat xa?.* > combined.tar.gz
# tar -zxvf combined.tar.gz
file1
file2
# gzip -cd combined.tar.gz | tar -xvf -
file1
file2
This is completely fixed in later versions of libarchive.

items.title: Support extracting archive already in memory to disk without intermediate file
items.summary: Support extracting archive already in memory to disk without intermediate file

items.content:
This is a feature request more than anything else.

I have recently started using libarchive in an embedded hardware project
where space is tight (64 MB) or NAND flash. As a result, I don't want to
have to write to it if at all possible. Memory however, is fair game and I
have room to spare there.

What would be nice, and it doesn't just apply to the above scenario, is
reading in an archive, storing the contents in memory, and extracting the
contents out without having to store the data back to disk. This may sound
a little silly, but it's required in a case such as the following:

Firmware image format.
<Header>
<Compressed Tar archive>

Let's say the Header is 200 to 1000 bytes long. I have to open the file,
read that header to find the offset of where the payload data unit starts
(in this case, a compressed tar archive) and how big it is, as the firmware
image file may support loading more than one PDU. This means, I have to
either read the contents of the archive starting at let's say 200 bytes
from the start of the file (fseek to it) then read from there, to the end
of the file, storing it in a byte array only to flush it out to disk so I
can open it again and let libarchive extract the data.

I should not have labeled this a defect, my apologies. It should be labeled as an
Enhancement. I do not know how to change it now.

The scenario you describe has always been very well supported.  In fact, libarchive
was designed in part specifically to support such use cases.

The most general way to open an archive is to use archive_read_open2(), although for
your use, I would recommend the slightly simpler archive_read_open().  That call
accepts three function pointers.  By implementing those functions, you can read data
from any data source, including memory, offsets within files, network sockets,
literally anything you can write code to access.

The other archive_read_open_XXXX() are all convenience functions around
archive_read_open2().  Most of the documentation refers to
archive_read_open_filename(), which is the one that seems to be most useful to most
people, but there are several others and it's easy to write your own.

Three in particular may be of interest to you:  archive_read_open_memory() accepts a
pointer and size of a block of memory, which is useful if you have data in memory and
want to extract from it; archive_read_open_fd() can be used to read from an opened
file descriptor, which is very useful if you need to skip the first part of a file
before asking libarchive to read the rest; and archive_read_open_FILE() is similar to
archive_read_open_fd() but accepts a FILE * instead of a file descriptor.

So, in your case, assuming your embedded OS supports open()/lseek()/read()/close()
system calls, you can simply:
   struct archive * a = archive_read_new();
   int fd = open("myfile", O_READ);
   lseek(fd, offset);
   archive_read_open_fd(fd, 512);
with additional error checking, of course, which I've omitted here.  In particular,
archive_read_open_fd() does return an error code and you should check it.

As I said, this has all been very well-supported since libarchive's earliest
prototypes.  If you're having trouble with it, feel free to post your questions to
the libarchive-discuss@googlegroups.com mailing list.

On further reflection, this may really be a documentation bug.

I've added an "Examples" page to the Wiki area, linked from the home page of the project.
For now, it demonstrates how to extract archive data from files, memory, or other
sources; please let me know what other examples would be helpful.

items.title: Cmake does not work on linux
items.summary: Cmake does not work on linux

items.content: First, please not that autotools work fine on my machine. (so you can see this as a non-issue) What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Type cmake . at project's root 2. Type make What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Instead of compiling successfully (as it does when using ./configure; make) we got this: -- Looking for acl_get_perm -- Looking for acl_get_perm - not found. -- Looking for acl_get_perm_np -- Looking for acl_get_perm_np - not found. (neither acl_get_perm nor acl_get_perm_np are found) So, when compiling: archive_read_disk_entry_from_file.c: In function setup_acl_posix1e: archive_read_disk_entry_from_file.c:264: error: implicit declaration of function ACL_GET_PERM What version are you using? Trunk: revision 1365 On what operating system? Arch linux. acl version 2.2.47-2 Please provide any additional information below. * Attached patch fixed the problem on my desktop. Warning: I could not test if I did not break something for other OS... The patch does two things: 1. look for acl_get_perm in acl/libacl.h (where it is on my machine) 2. link with acl library (finding an adding acl at the ADDITIONAL_LIBARARIES if ACL_ENABLE is true) * I can test this patch on ubuntu if you want. PS: Good to know: pacman, the awesome package manager of arch linux use your lib :)

Should be fixed in r1376.

Unfortunately, the patch as provided broke acl_get_perm_np() testing on FreeBSD
because FreeBSD has different acl headers.  I generalized the existing header checks
to provide what should be a general solution to this sort of problem.

>> Unfortunately, the patch as provided broke acl_get_perm_np() testing on FreeBSD
>> because FreeBSD has different acl headers.

Damned! Sorry about that. I was feeling something like this would happen. 


>> I generalized the existing header checks to provide what should be a general 
>> solution to this sort of problem.

Good idea :)

Keep up good work !

items.title: Passing files with CRLF line endings to --files-from/-T
items.summary: Passing files with CRLF line endings to --files-from/-T

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. On Windows, pass a file with CRLF line endings with the -T option. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? The CR (\r) should probably be an non-inclusive delimiter on any platform (so that DOS files work on *nix), but certainly on Windows it's common to have CRLF line endings in text files. What version are you using? Both 2.7 and 2.71 should have this problem. On what operating system? Windows Please provide any additional information below. It's caused by this logic: separator = bsdtar->option_null ? '\0' : '\n'; This line doesn't appear to be in trunk. Has it been fixed in 2.8? How stable is trunk?

Please try the attached patch for tar/util.c.  I believe this will fix the issue with
libarchive 2.7.x.

It looks like trunk has the same problem, actually, so that's probably not an option
for you.

After more extensive testing, I've committed a fix for this in
libarchive 2.7 at r1384 and a very different fix to libarchive/trunk
at r1385.  With these fixes, tar seems to correctly handle varying
line endings (including CRLF and NL) and properly handle null-terminated
lines with --null (including filenames that have NL characters in them).

items.title: Truncated archive extraction error message
items.summary: Truncated archive extraction error message

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. extract libarchive-2.7.1.tar.gz 2. cd there, then ./configure && make 3. head -c 1M ../librachive.tar.gz | ./bsdtar -t -f - What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Last lines of output are: libarchive-2.7.1/libarchive/test/test_compat_zip_1.zip.uu libarchive-2.7.1/libarchive/test/test_fuzz_1.iso.uu bsdtar: (Empty error message) bsdtar: Error exit delayed from previous errors. zsh: done head -c 1M ../libarchive-2.7.1.tar.gz | what we should see is that there is something else than (Empty error message) at the output (something like truncated archive) Gnu tar says: zip: stdin: unexpected end of file tar: Unexpected EOF in archive tar: Error is not recoverable: exiting now What version are you using? 2.7.1 On what operating system? Linux x86 (fedora 11) Please provide any additional information below.

This has already been fixed in libarchive/trunk and will be fixed in libarchive 2.8.

I'll take a look and see if there's an easy patch for 2.7.
With 2.8 coming out soon, I'm going to just close this.

items.title: libarchive cannot properly handle Rock Ridge Extention's deeper level directories
items.summary: libarchive cannot properly handle Rock Ridge Extention's deeper level directories

items.content:
-- How to make a iso image.

dr-xr-xr-x  3 0      0        2048  9 27 20:18 dir2/dir3/dir4/dir5/dir6

dir2/dir3/dir4/dir5/dir6/dir7

dir2/dir3/dir4/dir5/dir6/dir7/dir8
dr-xr-xr-x  3 0      0           0  9 27 20:18 
dir2/dir3/dir4/dir5/dir6/dir7/dir8/dir9

The bsdtar has showed me "rr_moved" directory. Basically, this directory
is only visible on systems that dot not support RRIP.

-- I've expected bsdtar outputs as follows.
%bsdtar tvf test.iso

dr-xr-xr-x  3 0      0        2048  9 27 20:18 dir2

dir2/dir3/dir4/dir5/dir6/dir7
