items.title: Support for RAR
items.summary: Support for RAR

items.content:
Hi,

it would be great if libarchive supported the RAR format; even if it would
be passworded archive.

This is just a wish/enhancement, not a bug; and I know it's probably not
easy to implement and may take a long time. And thanks for this great
project, I use it through GNOME's gvfs-mount.

I'm pretty sure that won't happen. The RAR format decoders are free-as-in-beer but
not free-as-in-speech AND if you use the "free" decoder you are agreeing never to try
to reverse-engineer and create your own encoder.  Needless to say (but I'll say it
anyway) the RARlabs encoders are not free in any sense.

Now, libarchive is BSDish, not GPLish, so maybe that's of less concern to Tim...

The deeper problem is that the existing RAR code almost certainly will not integrate
cleanly into libarchive.  So RAR support would probably require at least refactoring
the existing RAR code and may require rewriting parts of it more-or-less from
scratch.  This hasn't been a problem for well-documented open formats such as ZIP and
ISO9660 but could be a problem for RAR.

My suggestion:  Talk to the RAR developers and ask them if they would help with such
a project.  If they don't want to build a libarchive module themselves (libarchive's
internal API is pretty stable at this point, so this could be a reasonable approach),
they may be willing to provide enough documentation for someone else to implement
such a module.  It never hurts to ask!

Note: The distribution of such a module would also be a little tricky.  I've tried to
keep the libarchive distribution entirely BSD-licensed.  If the RAR developers insist
on a more restrictive license, they could either distribute their own fork of
libarchive or I could try to come up with a way to organize the libarchive
distribution so that there was a well-defined area for code with different licenses.
 I have no objection at all to someone distributing their own fork and would be
entirely open to discussing the latter approach.

I knew it won't be easy... :)
the idea came from VLC, that's capable of playing movies inside RAR archive(s), and
my wish of Totem being able to do this too. One way of doing this was through
mounting the RAR(s) with gvfs (with libarchive) and than playing it. The other way is
writing a special plugin for GStreamer. Both ways are pretty difficult... I will
probably try to takl to GStreamer guys too.
Anyway, I will contact RARlabs and track the progress of the negotiation here...

reply:
Eugene Roshal
	
Hello,

Sorry, we do not plan to make such libarchive module and we do not
have any additional documentation about RAR format. All what we have
now is the brief archive headers description in technote.txt
and unrar source code available in "RAR extras" on www.rarlab.com.

If libarchive team will decide to make such module, I can answer to
their questions related to any unclear parts of unrar source code
by email.

Eugene

package containing "technote.txt": http://www.rarlab.com/rar/rarlinux-3.9.0.tar.gz
unrar source code: http://www.rarlab.com/rar/unrarsrc-3.9.6.tar.gz
email: roshal(at)rarlab.com

The unrar sources are not useful.  Because of the unusual license restrictions on
them, we cannot use any part of them in libarchive.  In fact, anyone who has read
them carefully cannot be allowed to work on RAR support for libarchive.  (I myself
downloaded, skimmed the readme, technote, and copyright notices, then deleted them
from my local system.)

The format described in the technote.txt is relatively simple to implement in
libarchive from scratch.  Anyone who has worked with libarchive even a little should
be able to use that technote to implement a reader for the RAR format.

The decompression is trickier.  Because of the license terms, we can't copy any of
the unrar source code.  Which means libarchive would have to link against a separate
library that implemented the RAR decompression algorithm.  As far as I know, no such
library exists.   Without that, there's very little that could be done.

[7zip][1] has a rar module make it able to extract RAR files. But it's certainly not
a library.

The source code is in p7zip_9.04_src_all.tar.bz2/CPP/7zip/Archive/Rar, can this code
be reused?

[1]: http://p7zip.sourceforge.net/

p7zip seems to have bundled the (non-free) unrar source code, so it's probably not
any help.

VLC media player has support for playing files inside RAR archive(s), so maybe
looking at it's code might help.

modules/stream_filter/rar.c from
http://download.videolan.org/pub/videolan/vlc/1.0.4/vlc-1.0.4.tar.bz2

or quick look into the git repository
http://git.videolan.org/?p=vlc.git;a=blob;f=modules/stream_filter/rar.c

The VLC rar.c only handles *uncompressed* files inside a rar file. Might be okay for a 
video program but not so useful for libarchive.

The author of the program "The Unarchiver" wrote his own implementation of a RAR decompressor from scratch. The relevant code can be found in his hg repository in googlecode.
http://code.google.com/p/theunarchiver/

You can browse from http://code.google.com/p/theunarchiver/source/browse/XADMaster?r=tip.

The relavant RAR files don't show up in the above link for some reason. Here's another link with his code plus some of my own work (for license clarification and a C wrapper for his project).
http://gitorious.org/theunarchiver/theunarchiver/trees/master/XADMaster

The relevant code is written from scratch, as he notes in a log message in an hg commit. He's stated he's willing to relicense his work under BSD license (it's currently LGPL).
http://wakaba.c3.cx/sup/kareha.pl/1151796773/852

I've volunteered to port his implementation to libarchive. His code is written in Objective-C and would need some major work to remove parts of the code that are only useful for The Unarchiver.

As long as the code is suitably licensed (ideally using exactly the same license as the other core libarchive files), I have no objections to this.

I presume you're planning to adapt the code to plain C rather than Objective-C?

I would suggest you start with the bare format (without the compression) to understand the libarchive interfaces.  You should be able to get support for uncompressed RAR archives working fairly quickly.  That would also give a chance for one of the folks with a lot of libarchive experience (myself, Joerg, or Michihiro, for example) to give you some feedback on the project style.  That's how we got Zip support working:  First by implementing the archive format without compression, getting that fully working and tested, then adding the compression.  (Fortunately, we could just use zlib for the Zip compression.)

I'm looking forward to seeing your first contribution!

If someone is interested, I made a gvfs backend for uncompressed multipart rar files a while ago.

The source patch is here:
http://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=569126

64bit Ubuntu package (should work on 10.04, 10.10) available here:
http://walmis.balticum-tv.lt/share/gvfs-rar_1.6.0-1ubuntu2_amd64.deb
Mount option should appear by right clicking the rar file in nautilus.

Here's my first attempt at getting something implemented for RAR support. This applies against current SVN.

Some notes follow.

This implementation of RAR support only reads uncompressed files. There is no support for compressed files, multivolume RAR files, or files encrypted with a password.

This implementation will only read RAR files whose host OS has been set as WIN32 or UNIX. In other words, it will only read RAR files created on Windows or UNIX machines. This is because of how RAR file headers store the file attributes of the host OS. I only have access to Linux and Windows machines and thus could only work with file attributes from both machines.

The new C source code file was formatted using 'astyle --style=bsd -c -s2'.

I tested RAR files with directories, regular files, and symlinks. I've tested large file support. I implemented support for UTF8 encoded filenames though I could not properly test this. Also, I could not properly test parsing arctime from the EXTTIME structure in a RAR header.

I am subscribed to libarchive-discuss so feel free to send feedback/comments there and I will read them at my leisure.
Here's a new patch to improve RARv3 support, in particular, the parsing of sub-blocks (comments).

This does look like a very good start!

Before I commit this, could you please add a basic test:  You can copy libarchive/test/test_read_format_ar.c to get started.  This just opens a sample file (a RAR file that is UUencoded in your case) and reads the entries and verifies basic properties of the entries.  After you get a basic test working, it's easy to extend it to verify that you properly read different kinds of RAR files (such as files from different host platforms).

I also suggest you add your sample file to the list of files used by test_fuzz.c.  The "fuzz test" tries to crash your code by randomly altering a sample file.  It has been very helpful in finding common programming errors.

Here is an updated patch adding tests.

Also, there is a fix for a renamed file in the tests directory (libarchive/test/test_archive_read_support.c > libarchive/test/archive_read_support.c). I included that fix in this patch. I can update the patch again once the renaming is fixed.

Here is an updated patch adding tests.

Also, there is a fix for a renamed file in the tests directory (libarchive/test/test_archive_read_support.c > libarchive/test/archive_read_support.c). I included that fix in this patch. I can update the patch again once the renaming is fixed.

I've committed your patch.  (I also fixed the renaming issue; thanks for pointing that out.)

I've left the RAR support out of archive_read_support_format_all() until the test failures are fixed.  Specifically, both test_fuzz and test_read_format_rar are consistently crashing here with this message:

libarchive_test(78034) malloc: *** error for object 0x104209250: incorrect checksum for freed object - object was probably modified after being freed.

Here's the backtrace that shows where malloc() is detecting the failure; it probably happened somewhat earlier than this:
#0  0x00007fff88f5576d in malloc_error_break ()
#1  0x00007fff88f568c4 in szone_error ()
#2  0x00007fff88e82c83 in tiny_free_list_remove_ptr ()
#3  0x00007fff88e801ee in szone_free_definite_size ()
#4  0x00000001000d3267 in archive_string_free (as=0x10482bbf0) at /Users/tim/projects/libarchive/trunk/libarchive/archive_string.c:238
#5  0x00000001000d8d46 in archive_mstring_clean (aes=0x10482bbf0) at /Users/tim/projects/libarchive/trunk/libarchive/archive_string.c:3654
#6  0x000000010009b693 in archive_entry_clear (entry=0x10482ba00) at /Users/tim/projects/libarchive/trunk/libarchive/archive_entry.c:161
#7  0x00000001000a110e in _archive_read_next_header2 (_a=0x10482b200, entry=0x10482ba00) at /Users/tim/projects/libarchive/trunk/libarchive/archive_read.c:406
#8  0x00000001000a1318 in _archive_read_next_header (_a=0x10482b200, entryp=0x7fff5fbfec90) at /Users/tim/projects/libarchive/trunk/libarchive/archive_read.c:465
#9  0x00000001000da67a in archive_read_next_header (a=0x10482b200, entry=0x7fff5fbfec90) at /Users/tim/projects/libarchive/trunk/libarchive/archive_virtual.c:133
#10 0x000000010004a1a1 in test_basic () at /Users/tim/projects/libarchive/trunk/libarchive/test/test_read_format_rar.c:77
#11 0x000000010004afbf in test_read_format_rar () at /Users/tim/projects/libarchive/trunk/libarchive/test/test_read_format_rar.c:171
#12 0x00000001000072ae in test_run (i=96, tmpdir=0x7fff5fbff360 "/var/folders/64/64A1HgeYHKW11UT3X70fok+++TI/-Tmp-//libarchive_test.2011-06-26T17.43.56-000") at /Users/tim/projects/libarchive/trunk/libarchive/test/main.c:2038
#13 0x0000000100008430 in main (argc=3, argv=0x7fff5fbff4a0) at /Users/tim/projects/libarchive/trunk/libarchive/test/main.c:2455

Ok. Here's a new patch fixing the above issues. I suppose this was a matter of using CFLAGS="-g -O0". I tested this without adding CFLAGS.

I've also added a test for one of the RAR files I forgot to add in the previous patch. This lead to finding a problem with test fuzz, where it would fail when the size was less than 100. This patch fixes that as well.

I'm seeing this on the tests as well:

Totals:
  Tests run:                1
  Tests failed:             1
  Assertions checked:      90
  Assertions failed:       65
  Skips reported:           0

Failing tests:
  96: test_read_format_rar (65 failures)

Details for failing tests: /tmp/libarchive_test.2011-06-27T10.41.15-000

$ ls -R /tmp/libarchive_test.2011-06-27T10.45.09-000
/tmp/libarchive_test.2011-06-27T10.45.09-000:
test_read_format_rar  test_read_format_rar.log

/tmp/libarchive_test.2011-06-27T10.45.09-000/test_read_format_rar:
test_read_format_rar_noeof.rar  test_read_format_rar.rar  test_read_format_rar_subblock.rar

Looks like the test doesn't properly #ifdef on RAR support being enabled or something?

I'm not getting any issues running the tests (using the last patch I submitted). Could you try cleaning and rebuilding libarchive? Would you mind telling me what system your building/running on?

There's no #ifdef or configure switch that disables rar support. It's basically an implementation for rar support written from scratch with no external dependencies, so I didn't see the need to have the option to disable rar support.

I've committed your latest patch but test_read_format_rar still fails.
all of failures were caused by the test of time stamps.

When I ran test_read_format_rar on Windows, I got a following error (except about time stamps):

..\..\..\libarchive\libarchive\test\test_read_format_rar.c(67): "testdir/test.txt" != archive_entry_pathname(ae)
              "testdir/test.txt" = "testdir/test.txt" (length 16)
      archive_entry_pathname(ae) = "testdir\test.txt" (length 16)

That means the RAR reader does not replace  a '\' character by a '/' character on
Windows platform.
Other format readers replace it or add '/' as a path separator on every platform,
so you should do the replacement on every platform.

A new patch to address the latest issues. RAR files are stored with localtime I'm afraid, so the test is changed to simply check that {a,c,m}time is set.

Also, I had thought '\' were not converted on Windows.

I've just committed this.  All of the tests seem are now passing for me.  Nice work!

Libarchive's interfaces always use '/' for the path separator, regardless of platform.

When I made the RAR archive which had files whose name was non ASCII,
I got empty file names.

The result was:
$ bsdtar.exe tvf test_jp2.rar
-rw-r--r--  0 0      0           8 3 19 03:27 (null)
-rw-r--r--  0 0      0           4 3 19 03:28 (null)

I made this patch and applied it.
$ svn diff
Index: libarchive/archive_read_support_format_rar.c
===================================================================
--- libarchive/archive_read_support_format_rar.c        (revision 3447)
+++ libarchive/archive_read_support_format_rar.c        (working copy)
@@ -489,8 +489,8 @@
   {
     if (filename_size != strlen(filename))
     {
-      memcpy(filename, p + strlen(filename), filename_size - strlen(filename));

-      filename[filename_size - strlen(filename)] = '\0';
+      memcpy(filename, p + strlen(filename) +1, filename_size - strlen(filename
) -1);
+      filename[filename_size - strlen(filename) -1] = '\0';
     }
     sconv = archive_string_conversion_from_charset(&a->archive, "UTF-8", 1);
     if (sconv == NULL)

Result after patched:
$ bsdtar.exe tvf test_jp2.rar
-rw-r--r--  0 0      0           8 3 19 03:27 o`"W[.t
bsdtar.exe: Pathname cannot be converted from UTF-8 to current locale.
-rw-r--r--  0 0      0           4 3 19 03:28 (null)
bsdtar.exe: Error exit delayed from previous errors.

I got incorrect file names and some conversion errors.


Following text is the dump data of the RAR file.
$ hexdump -C test_jp2.rar
00000000  52 61 72 21 1a 07 00 cf  90 73 00 00 0d 00 00 00  |Rar!.....s......|
00000010  00 00 00 00 a4 b6 74 20  92 38 00 08 00 00 00 08  |......t .8......|
00000020  00 00 00 02 3f 9b 1b c3  7a 1b 73 3e 14 30 13 00  |....?...z.s>.0..|
00000030  20 00 00 00 8a bf 8e 9a  2e 74 78 74 00 6f 60 22  | ........txt.o`"|
00000040  57 5b 2e 74 00 78 74 00  f0 f4 0f 51 8a bf 8e 9a  |W[.t.xt....Q....|
00000050  82 a9 82 c8 52 98 74 20  92 34 00 04 00 00 00 04  |....R.t .4......|
00000060  00 00 00 02 18 f8 c8 44  86 1b 73 3e 14 30 0f 00  |.......D..s>.0..|
00000070  20 00 00 00 95 5c 2e 74  78 74 00 88 40 68 2e 74  | ....\.txt..@h.t|
00000080  78 00 74 00 b0 a0 25 26  6c 69 73 74 c4 3d 7b 00  |x.t...%&list.={.|
00000090  40 07 00                                          |@..|
00000093

the byte sequence of a first file ".txt":
8a bf 8e 9a  2e 74 78 74 00 6f 60 22 57 5b 2e 74 00 78 74   (19 bytes)

the byte sequence of a second file ".txt":
95 5c 2e 74  78 74 00 88 40 68 2e 74 78 00 74 (15 bytes)

Those file names seems to be split by zero, and its first half is
a file name in natural character-set(in this case it is CP932), and
its second half is a unicode file name, but it does not seems that
the unicode file name is a natural unicode, not UTF-8 nor UTF-16!

I compared several forms of that files.   
".txt":
UTF-8 form     : e6 bc a2 e5 ad 97 2e 74  78 74
UTF-16BE form  : 6f 22 5b 57 00 2e 00 74  00 78 00 74
the second half: 6f 60 22 57 5b 2e 74 00 78 74

".txt":
UTF-8 form     : e8 a1 a8 2e 74 78 74
UTF-16BE form  : 88 68 00 2e 00 74 00 78  00 74
the second half: 88 40 68 2e 74 78 00 74

So I think those were converted from its UTF-16 string in some rules
so as to trim 0x00 from the UTF-16 string as much as they can.

If my guess is right, the handling of file names should be:

    if (filename_size != (fn_bytes = strlen(filename)))
    {
      memcpy(xxfilename, p + fn_bytes +1, filename_size - fn_bytes -1);
      /* decode rar's unicode. */
      fn_bytes = decode_rarunicode_to_utf16be(filename, xxfilename, filename_size - fn_bytes -1);
      sconv = archive_string_conversion_from_charset(&a->archive, "UTF-16BE", 1);
    } else
      sconv = archive_string_conversion_from_charset(&a->archive, "UTF-8", 1);
  .......  
  .......  
  if (archive_entry_copy_pathname_l(entry, filename, fn_bytes, sconv))
  .......

This attached RAR file, which was broken by test_fuzz, caused a infinity loop on at least both FreeBSD and Cygwin.


(gdb) run tf inf.rar
Starting program: /usr/proj/libarchive/cab/bsdtar tf inf.rar
test.txt
testlink
testdir/test.txt

    request=1073741824) at libarchive/archive_read_open_filename.c:288

    request=1073741824) at libarchive/archive_read_open_filename.c:322

    at libarchive/archive_read.c:195

    request=8391162079611977667) at libarchive/archive_read.c:1228

    request=8391162079611977728) at libarchive/archive_read.c:1175

    at libarchive/archive_read.c:1163

    at libarchive/archive_read_support_format_rar.c:377

    at libarchive/archive_read.c:651
#10 0x0805004a in read_archive (bsdtar=0xbfbfe4c4, mode=116 't', writer=0x0)
    at tar/read.c:299
#11 0x0804f8d1 in tar_mode_t (bsdtar=0xbfbfe4c4) at tar/read.c:84

Would you mind if I added the test_jp2.rar file to the test suite? I have been trying to generate a rar file with unicode file names, but had no success.
Would you mind if I added the test_jp2.rar file to the test suite? I haven't been able to generate a rar file with unicode file names.
Of course not.
The unicode file names are encoded in the rar file in some form. Could you provide another rar with longer unicode file names, to include some inside a unicode directory?

Here is an additional sample file which has two files in Russian.
test_ru.rar can be tested on Windows platform in variety of countries
more than test_jp2.rar can, but I'd like you to use both files. 

First file "":
UTF-8 form   : d0 9f d0 a0 d0 98 d0 92 d0 95 d0 a2
UTF-16BE form: 04 1f 04 20 04 18 04 12 04 15 04 22

Second file "":
UTF-8 form   : d0 bf d1 80 d0 b8 d0 b2 d0 b5 d1 82
UTF-16BE form: 04 3f 04 40 04 38 04 32 04 35 04 42

And you can copy test_read_format_cpio_filename.c and modify it for tests for
the unicode file names.

Here is a new sample file which has long file names.

The file includes two files :
\\ .txt
\long-filename-in-.txt

I decided to work on the compression first before tackling the unicode support or test_fuzz issues. This patch will implement read support for RAR's lzss compression (normal, fast, and fastest compression).

I've been using theunarchiver to help with getting the lzss compression working. The author wrote the RAR implementation from scratch. There isn't much code reused from theunarchiver in use in libarchive, primarily because theunarchiver is written in Objective-C and is not a library. In any case, I have received permission to use code from theunarchiver and relicense code for the RAR implementation in theunarchiver in BSD. See http://wakaba.c3.cx/sup/kareha.pl/1151796773/852.

This implementation took some time, and I would like to submit what I have so far. I believe there is still much room for improvement. Even so, this implementation is already surpassing the official "unrar" program in terms of performance. The two log files show basic stats for time runs on bsdtar and unrar on my system. bsdtar was built using default optimizations and unrar is from whatever unrar package that is available in Debian.
BTW, I am interested in getting commit access solely for the purpose of working on the RAR implementation for libarchive.

Nice work!

I've committed your patch.

Contact me directly at kientzle@freebsd.org to discuss getting commit access.

test_fuzz often stalls at reading RAR files at least on both Linux and FreeBSD.

Andres, You should execute a following script for one or two hours in order
to eliminate these sort of test_fuzz failure caused by the RAR reader.
#!/bin/sh
while true
do
  echo -n "."
  ./libarchive_test test_fuzz > /dev/null
  sleep 1
done
I'll handle this one.

There are some memory access error when reading a broken file.
Please see an attached log file.
How is the rar support now ? Can libarchive support compressed rar files ?

RAR is supported since libarchive 3.0:
https://github.com/libarchive/libarchive/wiki/ReleaseNotes#libarchive-302

multi-volume RAR is apparently planned for the 3.1.x release.

items.title: Support for 7z
items.summary: Support for 7z

items.content:
7z is a very good archive format designed to work well with also very good
LZMA compress format and hence is a direct competitor to evil proprietary
RAR (and beats it in all ways).
support for this would be cool
again, thanks very much
Can you point us to documentation for this format?
does this satisfy your needs? http://www.7-zip.org/sdk.html

The summary information I've found for 7z list the compression methods used but
nothing about the format.  I presume it's related to the Zip format but documentation
would help.

The compression algorithms used don't present much of an obstacle:  lzma, lzma2, xz,
bzip2, and deflate are all well-supported via compression/decompression libraries,
and libarchive already uses those libraries in conjunction with other formats.  I
don't know much about "BCJ" coding, though.

In short, this seems pretty doable.  The next problem is finding someone who actually
has time and interest to do the work.  Please remember that libarchive is a volunteer
project.  If you're interested in working on this, I'm happy to answer questions. 
I've also written up several articles in the Wiki area about libarchive internals,
including a couple of step-by-step guides to implementing certain types of new features.

I looked into the 7z format.

As I understood libarchive has been designed to be able to work with file 
streams. 

The 7z files I looked at had the header informationen at the end of the file. I 
exactly know after reading the first few bytes where the header is located in 
terms of file position, so I could say look ahed for this number of bytes but 
that would need huge amount of memory.

Am I correct that I cannot implement 7z with the current libarchive architecture 
or am I missing something?

Libarchive does rely on streaming very heavily.  However, the Zip support in
libarchive might be worth investigating.  Zip format has a directory at the end of
the archive.  Most Zip readers start by reading this directory.  But it turns out
that there is just enough duplicate information stored with each entry that
libarchive can successfully read most Zip archives without reading the directory first.

I don't know enough about 7z to know whether this is possible there, but it is
certainly worth investigating.

I think not. The file structure from the files I found looks like this:

Header
pointer to next header (which is at the end of the file)
compressed files*
header (which has been pointed at the beginning of the file
end of file


* If you compress with no compression you see that there is really only data with no 
header/seperators at all


From the documentation I found in the 7zip sdk (7zFormat.txt iirc) it might be 
possible to write a 7z archive with libarchive but I wanted with uncompressing these 
archives :(
Based on the discussion so far, this sounds like it might not be feasible.

I added 7-Zip reader and writer. Those has been released as a part of libarchive 3.0.2.
The reader can extract several compression types, copy, deflate, bzip2, lzma1, lzma2 and
PPMd, and few filter types, BCJ and BCJ2 with all those compression types, DELTA with 
lzma1 and lzma2.
The writer can use several compression types, copy, deflate, bzip2, lzma1, lzma2 and PPMd
to create a 7-Zip archive file, but not support any filter types. The default compression
type is lzma1 if liblzma is available. you can choose a compression type by
compression option like this, for example,
bsdtar -cf foo.7z --format 7zip --options 7zip:compression=lzma2 foo/

items.title: write example can' work
items.summary: write example can' work

items.content:
Hello!

Your example can't work from here:
http://code.google.com/p/libarchive/wiki/ManPageArchiveWrite3

It creates a tarball with undefined/random name, with empty contents,
please correct it!

Best Regards,
Laszlo Papp

The debugging message from me after archive_write_header:
RETVAL: -25, ERRORSTR: File size out of range, SIZE: 17592186048964 

I think your API function, named archive_write_header, is wrong, it can't copy the
size quantity.

I've attached the working example, please consider to apply it.
Issue 43 has been merged into this issue.

You are using Linux.  Linux has two different "struct stat" and you need to compile
with the right options to use the same "struct stat" that libarchive uses:

gcc -D_FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64

It should be possible to change libarchive to work correctly with either "struct
stat" definition, but no one has yet offered to do the necessary work.

I'll edit the example in the manpage to clarify this point.

Updated the example as of r1506 (Wiki), r1507 (libarchive/trunk), and r1508
(libarchive/release/2.7).
Thanks, works.

items.title: test_pax_filename_encoding failed on Windows
items.summary: test_pax_filename_encoding failed on Windows

items.content: Please see attached log file.
attach log file again.

As near as I tell, the problem with this test (and test_entry) has to do with how the
test programs try to set the Windows default character encoding for the current
thread (specifically, the code page implied by CP_THREAD_ACP).

Today, the tests all use setlocale() to try to force the default character encoding
to UTF-8.  They then feed some invalid UTF-8 into libarchive to verify the correct
error handling.

So far, I've found a few forum posts that suggest that SetThreadLocale() can be used
to set the code page used by CP_THREAD_ACP.  Unfortunately the MSDN documentation
flatly contradicts this:  the argument to SetThreadLocale() is a language code that
does not specify a character encoding.  (I suspect the MSDN docs are wrong somehow.)

After doing some more research, I now believe that:
 1) We should be using CP_ACP instead of CP_THREAD_ACP.
 2) The tests that try to force conversion errors will have to simply be disabled on
Win32.  Apparently Win32's UTF-8 support is very limited and I cannot find an
appropriate mechanism to set the code page just for this process or thread.
I believe this is fixed now; I've made the changes described in comment 3 above.

items.title: HFS+ and dmg support
items.summary: HFS+ and dmg support

items.content:
Opening a DMG file from MacOS X, requires:
- bzip2 support
- HFS+ support

The former is already supported in libarchive, libguestfs could be used to handle the HFS+ part.

http://rwmj.wordpress.com/2009/10/25/unpack-a-mac-dmg-installer-using-guestfish/
Give it a try; let us know how it goes!

libguestfs does not contain any code to read HFS+ filesystems; it starts a Linux VM 
with access to the filesystem, then mounts the filesystem in the VM and uses the Linux 
kernel's HFS+ driver to access its contents.  This approach is completely incompatible 
with libarchive's design.

It may be possible to implement a streaming HFS+ reader for libarchive, but that would 
require documentation of the HFS+ format.

items.title: [patch] add support for Haiku OS
items.summary: [patch] add support for Haiku OS

items.content:
I'm attaching a patch which allows building on Haiku OS.
Let me know if I need to correct anything or if you have questions.

Thanks

I think I see a couple of ways to reduce the number of places where we need to put
Haiku-specific conditionals.  Could you try the attached patch (instead of yours) and
let me know.  Thanks!
Adjust labels.

Yes, it builds and runs well.

Still a lot of failures in the cpio and tar tests due to the fact that Haiku doesn't
have hard links on BFS, and because st_atime doesn't really work(it just uses the
current time).

As far as the libarchive tests, all but two are successful.  I haven't figured out
why they are failing though.  Related to st_mode and sparse writes.  Attaching the
logs in case you have any ideas, but, it's definitely not a high priority.

Thanks for looking into adding Haiku support!

I've committed a couple of changes that should enable libarchive/trunk to build for
you.  It should also suppress the atime tests for libarchive, cpio, and tar.

The test_write_disk failure is a test that asks libarchive to create a directory,
then  fails to verify the directory because the st_mode value read back from disk
doesn't match.  There's an extra bit set in the st_mode coming from disk for some
reason.  The st_mode value from disk is 0100040555 (octal).  The lower 9 bits are the
permissions (which agree with what the test expects), the 040000 marks it as a
directory (this should match S_IFDIR on your system), but the additional bit is a
mystery.  If you could tell me why that bit is set, that will tell me the best way to
address this.

I'm still looking into the test_write_disk_sparse failure.

I hope you'll forgive my ignorance when it comes to the stat() call.  I generally
don't have a need to use it in my software.  BeOS and Haiku do have extra bits in
st_mode.  I assume it's getting S_ATTR_DIR since that is automatically added to
directories on bfs.  From sys/stat.h:

/* extended file types */
#define S_ATTR_DIR			01000000000	/* attribute directory */
#define S_ATTR				02000000000	/* attribute */
#define S_INDEX_DIR			04000000000	/* index (or index directory) */
#define S_STR_INDEX			00100000000	/* string index */
#define S_INT_INDEX			00200000000	/* int32 index */
#define S_UINT_INDEX		00400000000	/* uint32 index */
#define S_LONG_LONG_INDEX	00010000000	/* int64 index */
#define S_ULONG_LONG_INDEX	00020000000	/* uint64 index */
#define S_FLOAT_INDEX		00040000000	/* float index */
#define S_DOUBLE_INDEX		00001000000	/* double index */
#define S_ALLOW_DUPS		00002000000	/* allow duplicate entries (currently unused) */

/* link types */
#define	S_LINK_SELF_HEALING	00001000000	/* link will be updated if you move its target */
#define S_LINK_AUTO_DELETE	00002000000	/* link will be deleted if you delete its
target */



I did have to make a small change to tar/test/test.h similar to the ifdef in
cpio/test/test.h.  I'll attach the patch if you want to incorporate it.



Besides the sparse test and the mode problem I think the only test failures are from
cpio and tar not being able to create hard links.  These are not critical in my
opinion.  I believe the tests would succeed if I were to mount a partition with
hardlink support.  The vfs layer does support hardlinks, just not on bfs.




On a side note:
You've already done so much that I hate to bring this up.  Are you interested in
supporting legacy compilers?  libarchive builds properly on gcc2. cpio and tar would
need a couple of changes.

This would involve not using 'j' in the format string of various *printf calls, and
also adding __HAIKU__ to the '#ifdef __FreeBSD__' in tar/bsdtar_platform.h,
cpio/cpio_platform.h and libarchive/archive_platform.h.  Haiku uses some portions of
FreeBSD and does actually have 'sys/cdefs.h' which confuses gcc2(but not gcc4 for
some reason).

r1560 should fix the test_write_disk failure you're seeing.

r1561 adds the additional header to tar/test/test.h and libarchive/test/test.h

Let me know the status after these changes.

Re: hardlink tests.  I would prefer to pursue the same approach we've used for
symlink tests.  Look at canSymlink() in test/main.c for details:  The basic idea is
that the test framework actually probes the local disk (by creating files and testing
them) to see if symlinks are supported on the current OS and filesystem.  Individual
tests can then use the result of this check to avoid running tests that are certain
to fail.  (Even better, run the tests anyway and verify that they return correct
error codes if the underlying filesystem doesn't support hardlinks.)

Re: gcc2.  I'm always interested in seeing patches.  I have on occasion rejected
patches that I deemed too intrusive, of course.

Note that generally, I'm trying to reduce the platform checks (such as "#ifdef
__FreeBSD__") and use capability tests ("#if HAVE_SYS_CDEFS_H") instead.  There's
already configuration logic that is supposed to only use 'j' format specifiers if
they're available in bsdtar_platform.h.  Clearly, that's not quite sufficient.  If
you have ideas for how to improve that, I'm very interested.  One possibility is to
alter configure.ac to explicitly test for printf modifier support.  Another
possibility would be to write a simple i64toa that formats int64 arguments and use
that instead of trying to determine the correct printf modifiers for the current
platform.

The attached patch eliminates use of %j modifier for bsdtar.  Let me know if this
works for you.

yes, the patch works on gcc2 for bsdtar.  I did need to add __HAIKU__ to the '#ifdef
__FreeBSD__' part, but as you said, this should probably be changed in the build
scripts to detect the presence of sys/cdefs.h.

Something similar would be needed for cpio...

[ 90%] Building C object cpio/CMakeFiles/bsdcpio.dir/cpio.c.o
cc1: warnings being treated as errors
/boot/home/libarchive.cmake/cpio/cpio.c: In function `list_item_verbose':
/boot/home/libarchive.cmake/cpio/cpio.c:962: warning: unknown conversion type
character `j' in format
/boot/home/libarchive.cmake/cpio/cpio.c:962: warning: too many arguments for format
/boot/home/libarchive.cmake/cpio/cpio.c:965: warning: unknown conversion type
character `j' in format
/boot/home/libarchive.cmake/cpio/cpio.c:965: warning: too many arguments for format
/boot/home/libarchive.cmake/cpio/cpio.c:986: warning: unknown conversion type
character `j' in format
/boot/home/libarchive.cmake/cpio/cpio.c:986: warning: too many arguments for format
make[2]: *** [cpio/CMakeFiles/bsdcpio.dir/cpio.c.o] Error 1
make[1]: *** [cpio/CMakeFiles/bsdcpio.dir/all] Error 2
make: *** [all] Error 2



I will definitely look into modifying the hardlink tests for tar and cpio as you
suggested.

"Something similar would be needed for cpio..."

Done in r1563.

At this point, it sounds like you're capable of working up patches for the remaining
issues.  Let me know if you need any help.

P.S. You should also subscribe to libarchive-announce if you're not already.  In
particular, I'm hoping to start the release process for libarchive 2.8 in about a
month and will be asking there for people to test the release candidate on different
systems.

I have the first patch ready for your consideration.  It adjusts the build scripts
and headers so that __FBSDID is searched for.  I'm assuming that this macro will
always be in sys/cdefs.h.  I think that is a safe assumption.

There were a couple places were it was used that I was not aware of.  Fixed the patch
to include those as well.  The only place that isn't fixed is in contrib/shar.  But
at the moment, it looks as though that will only build on FreeBSD so I'm hesitant to
change that one.

Maybe I should quadruple check before submitting :)
The changes in the second patch would have broken tar/getdate.c.

Sorry for the noise.

It seems the code below would be a little more straightforward if it works.  As a
bonus, it only requires the configure checks to test for sys/cdefs.h.  I also have
two other requests for you:
  * Please don't touch getdate.c unless you absolutely have to.  Because it's a
rewrite of public domain source, I'm leaving it as public domain and trying to keep
it separate from everything else so people can easily reuse it.
  * Please avoid gratuitous whitespace changes in your diffs (your last patch has a
bunch of unnecessary changed lines in CMakeLists.txt).

/* Get a real definition for __FBSDID if we can. */
#if HAVE_SYS_CDEFS_H
#include <sys/cdefs.h>
#endif

/* If not, define it so as to avoid dangling semicolons. */
#ifndef __FBSDID
#define	__FBSDID(a)     struct _undefined_hack
#endif

I hadn't even noticed that getdate.c was under a different license.  I apologize for
that.  I debated about the whitespace change, but the addition would have put that
line out of step with the rest of the lines in that section.  I had just assumed that
you would like to keep the arguments columnized.  This addition is no longer in there
so the point is moot.

I have altered the patch to use your suggested methods, and tested it on
OSX(10.4-ppc) as well.  I may submit a patch for OSX some time in the future as one
of the files fails to build because of an unrelated issue.
Looks good.  Committed as r1565.

I believe all of the issues raised here have been addressed, so I'm closing this as
"Fixed."  Please let me know if there are any further issues.

items.title: cygwin 1.7 cmake build problems
items.summary: cygwin 1.7 cmake build problems

items.content:
CMake building on Cygwin 1.7 isn't currently working.

The first problem is that HAVE_CYGWIN_CONV_PATH (required by
tar/test/test_copy.c) isn't defined anywhere.  Here's a patch for CMake
(something similar should also be added for autoconf).

===================================================================
--- a/tar/CMakeLists.txt      (revision 1628)
+++ b/tar/CMakeLists.txt      (working copy)
@@ -33,6 +33,14 @@
     LIST(APPEND bsdtar_SOURCES bsdtar_windows.h)
   ENDIF(WIN32 AND NOT CYGWIN)

+  IF(CYGWIN)
+    INCLUDE(CheckSymbolExists)
+    CHECK_SYMBOL_EXISTS(cygwin_conv_path  sys/cygwin.h HAVE_CYGWIN_CONV_PATH)
+    IF(HAVE_CYGWIN_CONV_PATH)
+      ADD_DEFINITIONS(-DHAVE_CYGWIN_CONV_PATH)
+    ENDIF(HAVE_CYGWIN_CONV_PATH)
+  ENDIF(CYGWIN)
+
   # bsdtar documentation
   SET(bsdtar_MANS bsdtar.1)


After making this change, bsdtar and bsdcpio still have some linking problems:

CMakeFiles/bsdtar.dir/bsdtar.c.o:bsdtar.c:(.text+0xf4b): undefined reference to
`__imp__archive_version'
CMakeFiles/bsdtar.dir/read.c.o:read.c:(.text+0xec): undefined reference to
`__im
p__archive_position_compressed'
...

I can investigate that more later if needed.

Committed a slight variation of this patch as r1629.

Please let us know what else you find.  The configure-based build works on Cygwin
1.7, so there should be no more than minor issues with the Cmake-based build.

The below patch fixes the above linking errors on Cygwin.

Index: tar/CMakeLists.txt
===================================================================
--- tar/CMakeLists.txt  (revision 1647)
+++ tar/CMakeLists.txt  (working copy)
@@ -42,11 +42,13 @@
     TARGET_LINK_LIBRARIES(bsdtar archive ${ADDITIONAL_LIBS})
   ELSE(ENABLE_TAR_SHARED)
     TARGET_LINK_LIBRARIES(bsdtar archive_static ${ADDITIONAL_LIBS})
+    SET_TARGET_PROPERTIES(bsdtar PROPERTIES COMPILE_DEFINITIONS
+      LIBARCHIVE_STATIC)
   ENDIF(ENABLE_TAR_SHARED)
   # On Windows, DLL must end up in same dir with EXEs
   IF(WIN32 AND NOT CYGWIN)

Index: cpio/CMakeLists.txt
===================================================================
--- cpio/CMakeLists.txt (revision 1647)
+++ cpio/CMakeLists.txt (working copy)
@@ -35,11 +35,13 @@
     TARGET_LINK_LIBRARIES(bsdcpio archive ${ADDITIONAL_LIBS})
   ELSE(ENABLE_CPIO_SHARED)
     TARGET_LINK_LIBRARIES(bsdcpio archive_static ${ADDITIONAL_LIBS})
+    SET_TARGET_PROPERTIES(bsdcpio PROPERTIES COMPILE_DEFINITIONS
+      LIBARCHIVE_STATIC)
   ENDIF(ENABLE_CPIO_SHARED)
   # On Windows, DLL must end up in same dir with EXEs
   IF(WIN32 AND NOT CYGWIN)
Committed as r1653.

items.title: Use CMAKE_CURRENT_SOURCE_DIR
items.summary: Use CMAKE_CURRENT_SOURCE_DIR

items.content:
The attached patch allows libarchive to be built as a subdirectory
(subproject) of another project under CMake.  It replaces
CMAKE_(SOURCE|BINARY)_DIR with CMAKE_CURRENT_(SOURCE|BINARY)_DIR.

Nice!  I was planning to submit a similar patch with the same goal.  Here are some
comments on your patch.

1.) The hunk in CMakeLists.txt looks good.

2.) The RUNTIME_OUTPUT_DIRECTORY properties can be set to ${libarchive_BINARY_DIR},
which is defined by the project(libarchive) command at the top of libarchive:

  http://www.cmake.org/cmake/help/cmake2.6docs.html#command:project

This avoids the need for ".." in the paths, and IMO is more readable too.

3.) The modules that need to look for .c files next to them can do this:

  +get_filename_component(_selfdir "${CMAKE_CURRENT_LIST_FILE}" PATH)
  ...
  -${CMAKE_SOURCE_DIR}/build/cmake/CheckFileOffsetBits.c
  +${_selfdir}/CheckFileOffsetBits.c
  ...

4.) Hunks like this:

  - FILE(APPEND ${CMAKE_BINARY_DIR}${CMAKE_FILES_DIRECTORY}/CMakeOutput.log
  + FILE(APPEND ${CMAKE_CURRENT_BINARY_DIR}${CMAKE_FILES_DIRECTORY}/CMakeOutput.log

are not necessary.  It is preferred that all logging be done in the top level's
CMakeOutput.log and CMakeError.log so that there is only one place to look when a
try-compile goes bad.

> 2.) The RUNTIME_OUTPUT_DIRECTORY properties can be set to ${libarchive_BINARY_DIR},

It would be nice to allow individual directories here to be incorporated into other
projects, so relying on libarchive_BINARY_DIR within those directories would be
wrong.  Why wouldn't we just leave those as ${CMAKE_BINARY_DIR}, putting the output
into the top level of the incorporating project, whatever that might be.

> 4.) Hunks like this ... are not necessary.

Do you mean the change isn't needed or the logging itself isn't needed?

updates.summary: Use CMAKE_CURRENT_SOURCE_DIR

items.content: I committed some of these changes as r1733.
Changing status to "Started" since some work has been committed.

>> 4.) Hunks like this ... are not necessary.
> Do you mean the change isn't needed or the logging itself isn't needed?

The logging is necessary, the change isn't.  Logging to the top level is fine.

>> 2.) The RUNTIME_OUTPUT_DIRECTORY properties can be set to ${libarchive_BINARY_DIR},
> It would be nice to allow individual directories here to be incorporated into other
> projects, so relying on libarchive_BINARY_DIR within those directories would be
> wrong.  Why wouldn't we just leave those as ${CMAKE_BINARY_DIR}, putting the output
> into the top level of the incorporating project, whatever that might be.

The best approach is to let the outside projects configure the output location.
Perhaps:

  if(NOT libarchive_RUNTIME_OUTPUT_DIRECTORY)
    set(libarchive_RUNTIME_OUTPUT_DIRECTORY ${libarchive_BINARY_DIR})
  endif()

then use ${libarchive_RUNTIME_OUTPUT_DIRECTORY} to set the property.

Another approach is

  if(NOT CMAKE_RUNTIME_OUTPUT_DIRECTORY)
    set(CMAKE_RUNTIME_OUTPUT_DIRECTORY ${libarchive_BINARY_DIR})
  endif()

at the top, and then do *not* set the property.  CMake will use this as the property
default when it creates the target.  If an outside user project sets the value first,
libarchive simply won't override it.  This approach is a little simpler but provides
slightly less flexibility.
I committed this final change as r1800.  Let me know if you see any problems with this.

items.title: "Pathname too long: File name too long" on amd64, but not on i386
items.summary: "Pathname too long: File name too long" on amd64, but not on i386

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. create a file with a long pathname (>150 characters), with a long filename (>100 chars) 2. using ustar, _set_pathname() and _write_header() 3. compile and test on i386, everything works as expected, with a valid tarball created. 4. compile and test on amd64, "Pathname too long: File name too long" will be returned by archive_error_string() when _write_header() fails. What version are you using? 2.6.2 On what operating system? debian etch Please provide any additional information below. This was also present with version 1.2.53, which is the default available with etch. Upgrading to 2.6.2 didn't fix. I can provide sample code if that will help.

I mischaracterized this. It has to do with filenames that contain certain escapes 
instead. Please close this issue.

I'm closing this as "Invalid" as requested by the original reporter.

If you're still having problems, please provide additional detail and I'll take
another look.

items.title: error in zip decompression
items.summary: error in zip decompression

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. use the file Optik.wmz 2. list contents (see seek_thumb_03.gif) What is the expected output? What do you see instead? expected: log.txt:09/11/24-14:08:54 0.0620 DEBUG process file into compressed file: 'seek_thumb_02.gif' log.txt:09/11/24-14:08:54 0.0620 DEBUG process file into compressed file: 'seek_thumb_03.gif' i get: expected: log.txt:09/11/24-14:08:54 0.0620 DEBUG process file into compressed file: 'seek_thumb_02.gif' log.txt:09/11/24-14:08:54 0.0620 DEBUG process file into compressed file: 'seek_th'^Z(#' What version are you using? latest svn On what operating system? windows xp Please provide any additional information below. i read the file twice (no rewind support yet) in this case i got this error: INTERNAL ERROR: Function 'archive_read_data_block' invoked with archive structure in state 'eof', should be in state 'data' i got no errors with other files Thanks

I tried this with the current svn trunk and haven't yet been able to reproduce it. 
I'm going to close it as "WorksForMe" for now.

If you're still having problems, please add more information to this bug and I'll
take another look.

items.title: @foo.mtree fails with Empty error message [+patch]
items.summary: @foo.mtree fails with Empty error message [+patch]

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. echo '#mtree' | bsdtar -cf foo.tar @- What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Expected result: tar created without error. Actual result: tar created, but error reported "(Empty error message)" What version are you using? trunk revision 1693 On what operating system? linux-i386 Please provide any additional information below. Caused by incorrect error status check in append_archive_filename in tar/write.c: it should check the return code of append_archive, but instead it checks the error code in the archive. This error code has been set before by archive_read_support_compression_all / archive_read_support_compression_lzma et al. archive_read_support_compression_all clears the error string in the archive but not the error number. Attaching a patch which fixes the problem.

Thanks!  Committed as r1715.

I'm going to leave this bug open until there's a regression test for this issue...
Regression test committed as r1732.

items.title: Invalid use of printf format strings
items.summary: Invalid use of printf format strings

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. add attribute((format(printf,X,Y))) to lafe_vwarnc, lafe_warnc, and lafe_errc 2. compile with gcc and -Wformat (included in -Wall) What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Expect no warnings, but calls to lafe_warnc and lafe_errc pass a non-literal string as the format string. This is a problem because the computed string could contain %-format-specifiers from user-supplied data, if not right now, then perhaps in the future, which might be a security problem. Additionally a few true format errors were found. What version are you using? trunk revision 1693 On what operating system? linux-i386 Please provide any additional information below. Attaching patch.

Thank you again!

Committed as r1716.

items.title: Build failure on Ubuntu 9.10
items.summary: Build failure on Ubuntu 9.10

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1.Install libarchive 2.7.1 on Ubuntu 9.10 2. 3. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? I expect success. However, there are a lot of files where the expected return value is ignored (typically write() and chdir()). The makefile is configured to treat warnings as errors, so the build fails. What version are you using? 2.7.1 On what operating system? Ubuntu 9.10 Please provide any additional information below. I have created a patch to pretend to check the return values. I don't actually check them, so the program works as before. It will, however, build successfully. These changes should not affect the operation of the program.

Thank you!

Since 2.7.1 is a production release, I instead merely removed -Werror in commit r1717.
I believe these issues are already fixed in trunk; I expect we'll begin early testing
for the libarchive 2.8 release soon and would appreciate if you could repeat your
tests at that time.

items.title: cpio extraction: hardlink detection isn't careful enough
items.summary: cpio extraction: hardlink detection isn't careful enough

items.content:
I have a (newc-format) cpio archive, which I attach for your convenience,
which contains two files whose inode numbers on-disk happen to match in the
lower 18 bits, i.e. they have identical inode numbers in the archive.

My test program is calling archive_read_extract() on each entry in turn;
record_hardlink() is only comparing the device and inode numbers from the
archive and unconditionally linking these two files together - despite both
entries containing valid file data of different lengths and mtimes.

The GNU cpio tool doesn't have this issue with the same archive. That tool
only considers files for hardlinkage when a file has a link count more than
1, and a size of 0; I suspect that similar logic would be the right answer
here.

I am using a static build of libarchive 2.6.2 on Ubuntu, though comparing
with release 2.7.1 archive_read_support_format_cpio.c seems to not have
changed.

Very timely!  A couple of us have recently been discussing
this exact issue (ino collisions leading to false hardlink
detection) and the possibility of addressing it from the
writing side.  But you're right that we should also be
a little more careful on the reading side.

I've altered the hardlink detection logic in r1718 to
ignore entries with a link count less than 2.  That seems
to address the issue you found.

This fixes it for me, and is in fact remarkably similar to the fix I had cooked up
for myself. Thank you :-)

items.title: FreeBSD 6 build failure
items.summary: FreeBSD 6 build failure

items.content:
FreeBSD 6.4 has an older version of OpenSSL that lacks the SHA256, SHA384,
and SHA512 implementations but does have a sha.h header.

The configure.ac needs to explicitly test for SHA256, SHA384, and SHA512
support (as documented in a TODO in that file).
Can you try the attached patch?
Should be fixed.

items.title: memory initialization in archive_write_set_format_zip.c, patch included
items.summary: memory initialization in archive_write_set_format_zip.c, patch included

items.content:
Working with the test version of libarchive (2.7.902a) that supports zip with deflate compression, 
trying to create a archive containing a single directory will crash in deflate().  Problem is that the 
"zip" structure allocated in archive_write_set_format_zip() needs to be initialized (the avail_in field 
was garbage).  Included is a patch file to clear the struct using memset().  Thanks.

(btw, great library, many thanks!)

-- gordon
Thanks!  I've committed a slightly different fix as r1807.

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. (install Opensolaris) 2. ./configure 3. make What is the expected output? Hum the result of a successfully compilation? :) What do you see instead? It fails. (see the errors at the last question) What version are you using? 2.7.1 On what operating system? OpenSolaris How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) configure What compiler or development environment (please include version)? gcc (GCC) 3.4.3 (csl-sol210-3_4-20050802) Please provide any additional information below. gcc -DHAVE_CONFIG_H -I. -I ./libarchive -Wall -Werror -g -O2 -MT libarchive/libarchive_la-archive_read_disk_set_standard_lookup.lo -MD -MP -MF libarchive/.deps/libarchive_la-archive_read_disk_set_standard_lookup.Tpo -c libarchive/archive_read_disk_set_standard_lookup.c -fPIC -DPIC -o libarchive/.libs/libarchive_la-archive_read_disk_set_standard_lookup.o libarchive/archive_read_disk_set_standard_lookup.c: In function `lookup_uname_helper': libarchive/archive_read_disk_set_standard_lookup.c:199: error: too many arguments to function `getpwuid_r' libarchive/archive_read_disk_set_standard_lookup.c:199: warning: assignment makes integer from pointer without a cast libarchive/archive_read_disk_set_standard_lookup.c: In function `lookup_gname_helper': libarchive/archive_read_disk_set_standard_lookup.c:247: error: too many arguments to function `getgrgid_r' libarchive/archive_read_disk_set_standard_lookup.c:247: warning: assignment makes integer from pointer without a cast *** Error code 1 make: Fatal error: Command failed for target `libarchive/libarchive_la-archive_read_disk_set_standard_lookup.lo' Current working directory /home/lukc/libarchive-2.7.1 *** Error code 1 make: Fatal error: Command failed for target `all'

A fix for this was put into 'trunk' a few months ago.

Please try the current development snapshot and let us know if that fixes it.

http://pastealacon.com/12505
  Same error

It appears that OpenSolaris and Solaris both still default to a non-standard version
of getpwuid_r and getgrgid_r.  According to Sun's documentation:

http://docs.sun.com/app/docs/doc/816-5168/getpwuid-r-3c?a=view

"For POSIX.1c-conforming applications, the _POSIX_PTHREAD_SEMANTICS and _REENTRANT
flags are automatically turned on by defining the _POSIX_C_SOURCE flag with a value
199506L."

So it looks like you should be able to fix this by adding _POSIX_C_SOURCE=199506L to
the C compiler flags for this platform.  Please try that and let us know.

$make

but we have some problems with `make check'.

items.title: libarchive does not support writing GNUTAR archives
items.summary: libarchive does not support writing GNUTAR archives

items.content:
The array "codes" from libarchive/archive_write_set_format.c has no entry
for ARCHIVE_FORMAT_GNUTAR, so this file type cannot be written.  This is
also contrary to one of the wiki pages which lists supported formats where
"tar (with GNU extensions)" is listed.

It would be great if this would get supported.  It would seem to easily be
done via gnu's libtar, however the license is incompatible with this one. 
How much more work would it be to write in the gnu specific stuff?  I think
this would be a great feature.

Libarchive reads many legacy tar formats, including the old GNU tar extensions.  The
"pax" format---which libarchive supports very well---is displacing the old GNU tar
extensions for most applications.

What application are you working with that specifically requires GNU tar extensions?

Actually, I realized that I could just move to the pax format.  However, I was having
problems reading extended attributes from a GNU-style tar.  I don't need this right
now, so won't look into it further.  This issue can be closed.

It would be nice to suppress some of the extended pax header keywords that confuse 
gnutar (SCHILY.*).  This is mainly useful to avoid confusion in certain environments.  In 
some old linux environments (namely RHEL), old versions of gnutar exit with failure 
status when reading these :-\  You can work around it by using --pax-
option="delete=SCHILY.*", but that can be problematic if you don't have control of the 
target environment.

I'll close this issue now.  Thanks for the feedback.
Please do let us know as much as you can about your "problems reading extended
attributes from a GNU-style tar."  Compatibility with other tar
implementations--including GNU tar--is very important to us.

I also encourage you to mention some of your issues to the GNU tar maintainers.  It
would be nice if GNU tar would simply recognize and ignore those additional keywords
you mentioned.

items.title: Invalid assumptions about wchar_t
items.summary: Invalid assumptions about wchar_t

items.content:
__archive_string_utf8_w assumes UCS2/UCS4 for wchar_t, which is only valid
if __STDC_ISO_10646__ is defined.

If this macro is not defined and iconv is present, it should be used to
convert to the current character set first, followed by mbtowc.

Any guesses about what should happen if __STDC_ISO_10646__ is not defined and iconv
is not present?

Best effort is just assume the locale is compatible to UCS. I am not aware of a
portable alternative.

I have a patch for this issue.
but I think my patch needs more work or to be rewritten.

This needs to be solved for libarchive 3.0.

There is some more discussion in Issue 132.  I think Michihiro's patch is going to be insufficient.
Please test libarchive/trunk r2993, which I believe fixes this problem.
I believe the work that has been done recently (mostly by Michihiro) to change the text interfaces has fully addressed this issue.  Any objection to my closing this bug?

As Tim mentioned, recent libarchive/trunk does not have this issue.
Unfortunately, fixing this has made the incompatibility that we cannot read UTF-8
file names in the PAX file made by older version of libarchive or bsdtar in non-UTF-8
locale with a locale dependent file name, which is non ASCII, for the entry files.
Those who made that sort of PAX files may need tar:compat-2x option so as to properly
decode the file names. When the option is specified, libarchive 3.0 and
later treat the UTF-8 file names as libarchive 2.x does, but using the option
requires the same locale that the PAX file was made in for correct reading.
The option works only on read side. A test for the option is test_compat_pax_libarchive_2x.
I beleive the iconv work has completely addressed this, so I'm going to close it.

items.title: archive_clear_error fails to clear archive_errno
items.summary: archive_clear_error fails to clear archive_errno

items.content:
After trying to upgrade libarchive 2.8.0 in Debian gvfsd-archive started
crashing. Many wasted hours of debugging later I found out that someone
else had already tracked down the problem, please see:

http://bugs.gentoo.org/289260

Applying the patch in the gentoo bug report fixed the issue.

I believe this is a gvfs bug.  According to the gentoo bug report, gvfs ignores the
return code from archive_read_next_header() and instead checks archive_errno() to see
if an error occurred.  Archive_errno() is not meaningful except immediately after an
error is returned from an API call.

I'll update the documentation to try to make this clearer.

I won't object if someone wants to change archive_clear_error(), but it won't really
fix broken clients like this, as there are still plenty of libarchive API calls that
don't call archive_clear_error() on entry.  (There may even be some cases where
archive_errno() is zero after an error does occur.  Again, archive_errno() wasn't
intended to indicate whether an error happened; it's intended only to provide
additional detail after an error does happen.)

FYI:
I've opened a bug against gvfsd-archive at:
https://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=611057
I committed this change despite my misgivings.

items.title: Debian 530301:  build problems on HURD
items.summary: Debian 530301:  build problems on HURD

items.content:
Filed on Debian bug tracker against libarchive 2.6.2:
http://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=530301

Includes condidate patch for two issues:
 * HURD does have st_flags field in struct stat but doesn't have UF_NODUMP;
code in tar needs more accurate guard
 * HURD does not have PATH_MAX.  I'm unsure whether that means that open()
has no limits on the path argument or whether HURD supports some other
mechanism for determining that limit.
Fixed now.

items.title: Debian #546185: problems with username failures after --chroot
items.summary: Debian #546185: problems with username failures after --chroot

items.content:
Another bug reported to Debian:

http://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=546185

Summary:  If you use "tar -x --chroot" and the chroot doesn't have
user/group lookup support, then uname/gname lookups will fail and the
extraction will use the uids/gids.

I'm a little unsure whether to consider this a bug or not.  I can certainly envision
scenarios where a user would expect uname/gname lookups to occur against the chroot
environment.  (Although admittedly, you could use "chroot tar" in that case.)

The solution originally requested isn't really feasible because libarchive doesn't
know that a library failed to load:  It asks libc for a user lookup and is told by
libc that the user in question couldn't be found.

It might work to do a gratuitous user and group lookup (maybe lookup the current user
and group names?) before processing the --chroot flag, with the expectation that any
required dynamic libraries and/or system files would be loaded before the chroot was
executed.

I agree that --chroot should not try to deal with /etc/passwd and /etc/group from
outside the chroot. In fact, it would partially defeat the purpose of using it in
first place.

Tim: chroot tar is different, as it requires the chroot to be compatible with the
outside system. On of the uses for the option is dealing with embedded systems.

Note that I will likely add some code to make it easy to implement something like -N
of NetBSD's pax, so that tar can use a custom file for the translation.

Reading the original Debian PR, I would consider the main issue here is a glibc bug.
It is not the fault of bsdtar if getpwnam and friends are broken due to missing
fallbacks in glibc.

It seems that there are three different possible uses here:
 1) Use tar from outside the chroot and user info from outside.
 2) Use tar from outside and user info from inside.
 3) Use tar from inside and user info from inside.

Use case #3 here is handled by "chroot tar", of course.  For the other two, I'm not
sure I see how we can reasonably force either one in a completely consistent fashion.
 Libc can do user info lookup however it wants and the mechanism it chooses may or
may not obey chroot boundaries.  On some systems, you may have to do some basic
configuration of the chroot environment before you can perform certain operations.

I'm going to close this as "Won't Fix" for now, unless someone has a convincing
argument otherwise.

items.title: On windows, O_BINARY is required for open() in tar/write.c
items.summary: On windows, O_BINARY is required for open() in tar/write.c

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. On windows, use notepad.exe to create a file with "test\r\nfile" 2. bsdtar cf test.tar test.txt 3. The file in test.tar had its line endings changed What is the expected output? What do you see instead? \r\n is replaced with \n What version are you using? 2.8 On what operating system? Windows How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) Binary cross-compiled with mingw-w64's 32bit toolchain. Same problem in the mingw.org package. What compiler or development environment (please include version)? mingw / mingw-w64 Please provide any additional information below. The patch attached fixes the problem but is not really mergeable: it would be better to surround the open calls with #if defined(_WIN32) && !defined(__CYGWIN__). I'm ready to make a cleaner patch and test it on a bunch of platforms (linux, cygwin, win32/64) but I'd like to know first if I'm completely missing something or if the idea and the approach are good.

This is very good; thanks for catching this.  What we did elsewhere was to use
exactly the code you gave here without any conditionals and put the following at the
top of the file:

#ifndef O_BINARY
#define O_BINARY 0
#endif

This is a complete patch (yeah, took me five days...). Made it against HEAD but it
applies against 2.8.0 just as well. It's extracted from a git-svn of libarchive btw.

As a sidenote, I compiled with almost everything but bsdtar disabled because I would
run into other errors at compile. I'll try to make other patchs for windows.

Applied patch to both trunk and 2.8 release branch.

Feel free to post the errors you're seeing to libarchive-discuss.

items.title: archive_crc32 missing in 2.8 release package
items.summary: archive_crc32 missing in 2.8 release package

items.content:
For some reason archive_crc32.h is missing in the libarchive-2.8.0 packages 
provided in the Downloads section. This results in a build error for the 
files archive_read_support_format_zip.c and archive_write_set_format_zip.c 
when compiling without zlib.

Ouch.  I've fixed the distribution-building scripts in trunk and in the 2.8 branch. 
When I roll the 2.8.1 distribution in a few days, this will be fixed.

items.title: Need a logo
items.summary: Need a logo

items.content:
Libarchive project could use a logo.

I tried to create one but my artistic skills aren't quite
up to the challenge.  Right now, libarchive.googlecode.com
just has some Google-provided default icon.

Here are the specs for custom logos on Google Code:
* The image file should be in PNG, JPG or GIF format and a maximum of 153 x 55
pixels. Larger images will be scaled automatically.
* The logo will be shown on the upper left of every page in your project, instead of
the default Google Code logo.
* Do not include any Google trademarks.

As I don't have any artistic skill I've managed to find a site where to find logos under GPL license. Here is an example of logo that you could use http://www.iconfinder.com/icondetails/8818/128/archive_box_inventory_zip_icon .

Hope it helps :)

A GPL-licensed icon is not really appropriate (since the software is BSD licensed; it would be awkward if there were many people who could distribute the software but not the icon. :-)

But there are some interesting ideas in there.  I've long thought that a suitable logo or icon for libarchive would somehow incorporate a box idea and some idea of "construction or building", since libarchive is a software library for building tools that manipulate archives.  Possibly a wooden crate with one side missing and a hammer next to it, or a box drawn so that part of it is incomplete (low resolution or pencil sketch) while the rest is smoothly rendered.
I'm sorry as I can't do it because of my low skills in this area, but thought the icon search engine was useful :).

items.title: [PATCH] Simplify and improve digest function checks
items.summary: [PATCH] Simplify and improve digest function checks

items.content:
The attached patch makes it possible to avoid the repetitive code and uses
instead autoconf macros to do the same thing. It also makes it simpler to
deal with multiple implementations in the C library (by mean of stopping if
SHA1Init, as an example, is found rather than always trying SHA1Init _and_
SHA1_Init).

HTH!
Diego

I disklike this patch as it hides the important point of what is taken from OpenSSL
and what not. Completely ignoring the question of whether using more m4 is helping or
not...

Uh? How does it hide it?

checking for MD5Init... no
checking for MD5_Init... no
checking for MD5_Init in -lcrypto... yes

checking for RMD160_Init in -lcrypto... no

checking for SHA1_Init... no
checking for SHA1_Init in -lcrypto... yes

checking for SHA256_Init... no
checking for SHA256_Init in -lcrypto... yes

checking for SHA384_Init... no

Because it is no longer easy to figure out from the *code* where it comes from.
Especially the part of what is used when no OpenSSL is desired at all.

Uhm I guess it subjective, and probably because we both wrote the respective code, I
find this much more readable

I agree with Joerg that this could probably be made a little clearer, but I like the
overall approach.  It's certainly eliminates a lot of duplication in the current code.

What if we used two macro calls for each probe, so the usage looked like this:

MD_CHECK_INIT([MD5], [MD5Init, MD5_Init])
MD_CHECK_INIT([MD5], [MD5_Init], [openssl/md5.h])

Argument #1: name of the feature, used to synthesize MD5_found variable name to
suppress redundant checks
Argument #2: list of function names to probe
Argument #3: optional list of headers to probe

Would that make it sufficiently clear that we're first looking for MD5Init or
MD5_Init in the default libraries, then (if that fails) looking for MD5_Init in the
openssl library?  I think it's just a small change to Flameeyes' patch to get this
kind of behavior.

More along the lines of

MD_CHECK_INIT([SHA512], [SHA512_Init, SHA512Init], [sha2.h], [SHA512_Init],
[openssl/sha.h])

E.g. Hash, Candidate functions in libc, libc header, OpenSSL function, OpenSSL header.
