items.title: bsdcpio cannot produce restricted pax archives
items.summary: bsdcpio cannot produce restricted pax archives

items.content:
Because bsdcpio sets the format name to odc if the user does not specify 
one, and libarchive's default restricted pax format has no name, there is 
no way to ask bsdcpio to produce a restricted pax archive.

Please add the following lines to the names array in 
libarchive/archive_write_set_format_by_name.c:

	{ "bsdtar",	archive_write_set_format_pax_restricted },
	{ "paxr",	archive_write_set_format_pax_restricted },
	{ "rpax",	archive_write_set_format_pax_restricted },

I have attached a patch to make this change in libarchive 2.8.1; I don't know whether 
it will apply to the current sources correctly.
Here's another patch, this time against the Subversion sources.

A nice, clean patch.  Thanks for taking such care.

Committed to trunk at r2026.

items.title: [PATCH] incorrect permissions stored for symlinks on Linux
items.summary: [PATCH] incorrect permissions stored for symlinks on Linux

items.content:
In libarchive SVN trunk r2024 on my Fedora 12 system, bsdcpio tests 
test_format_newc and test_option_c fail, because libarchive writes the 
permission bits of a symlink's target instead of the permission bits of the 
link itself.  

The underlying problem is that, on Linux, archive_read_disk_entry_from_file 
uses acl_get_file(3) to look for an ACL on *every* entry read from disk, 
even if it is a symlink, and acl_get_file dereferences symlinks.  
archive_read_disk_entry_from_file then sets the permission bits in the 
entry's mode based on the ACL.

The attached patch fixes this problem.

Excellent work!  Thanks.

Committed to trunk at r2025.
Does this need to be merged to the 2.8 branch as well?

> Does this need to be merged to the 2.8 branch as well?

It probably should be.  This bug is present in libarchive 2.8.1, and in modern archive 
formats (including pax restricted), it can leak the entire ACL (with user and group 
names and IDs) of a symlink's target.

Merged to releases/2.8 at r2027.  I expect there will be a 2.8.2 release in the next
week or two.

items.title: archive_read_support_format_zip bid error
items.summary: archive_read_support_format_zip bid error

items.content: Can you please tell what you are doing? This sounds like a bug in your application.

It looks like this usage of __archive_read_ahead() didn't get updated when I changed
it's return convention; that function used to return non-NULL if any data was
available but now returns NULL unless it can satisfy the full request.

So if you have a file that is less than 128k, then __archive_read_ahead will return
NULL at some point even though bytes_avail indicates that there is some data
available (but not the full offset+4096 that was requested).  This will happen only
if the Zip bidder sees a file that begins with 'MZ' (the signature for PE-format
executables used by self-extracting Zip archives) that is less than 128k long.

I've committed a slight variation of this fix as r2028 to trunk and r2029 to the
release/2.8 branch.  Please let me know if you have any further problems.

items.title: zip64 write support
items.summary: zip64 write support

items.content:
Figure out if the streaming write works for zip64, too. If yes, add support
for it.

items.title: Encrypted zip support
items.summary: Encrypted zip support

items.content:
Encrypted entries should be have the same flags in the entry as in the
directory. It should therefore be possible to supported encrypted entries.

This needs extensions to the libarchive API for passing down / querying the
password.

I would suggest handling passwords through an option, e.g.,
  --option password=357X8&4z
That will easily extend to other formats.  Though we may need to rethink the options
API somewhat; the current API wouldn't allow commas in passwords.  Maybe the internal
API should only permit a single option at a time instead of trying to support
comma-separated lists of options?  If we need to make that change, 3.0 is our chance.

An option is bad as it is visible to other users on many systems. I also don't think
it makes sense from a user-perspective to require knowing in advance that something
in an archive is encrypted.

I can think of two interface extensions to deal with this kind of problem:

archive_read_set_password(struct archive *, void *, size_t)
archive_read_set_password_callback(struct archive *, int (*)(void *, struct
archive_entry *, void **, size_t *), void *)

The former would cover the case of an explicit --password option (or
--password-file), the latter would allow a callback for interactive use.

I'm not concerned about writing them ATM -- at least for zip files the default
encryption mechanism is more about obscurity than security and not something I really
consider useful.

For reading the common case of a single password is covered by the first approach and
if you need anything more complex, use the callback. I think that's fine. Policies
like asking at most three times for the same entry can be implemented in the callback
easily.

> archive_read_set_password(struct archive *, void *, size_t)

This can be handled as
  archive_read_set_options(struct archive *, "password=XXXX");
there's no need for another option.
Being able to set an option value from a file might be an interesting
general feature.

I'm not a big fan of the callback approach (despite evidence
to the contrary ;-).  If libarchive had better error management,
we could maybe handle password requirements by returning a
"PASSWORD_REQUIRED" error and allowing the client to try
again.  But this isn't easy to integrate into the existing
framework, so a callback may be the best we can do.  <sigh>
Note:  The recent addition of a seek-based Zip reader should make this much easier, since that reader has full access to the extended Zip fields stored in the Central Directory.
Any plans to add this feature anytime soon?
I do not know of anyone working on this feature right now.

Hi, I've implemented the encryption detection support in libarchive and I might start working on this as soon as I have made progress with the integration of the UnRAR library for future proof and maintainable RAR support. But I need more time for this.

In my opinion, there's no other option but to implement a callback because you can have an archive with files in it that were encrypted using different passwords. At least in RAR you can do this. If you don't want to use a callback it would require you to pass in a list of passwords. Then all you could do is try decryption with all the passwords in your list. For big files this trial and error approach can possibly slow things down quite significantly.

I understand the goal would be to decrypt the archived data, but at the very least it would be nice to have a standard flag or error code to indicate an archive is encrypted.

I'd like to use libarchive as a library to handle unknown archive data and there's no way to differentiate between an archive that is corrupt and one that is encrypted.

For example, password protected zip files can still be listed by the standard command line tools under Linux, but attempting to list the contents with libarchive yields a decompression failed error.

items.title: Libarchive 2.8.2 fails to compile
items.summary: Libarchive 2.8.2 fails to compile

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. make What is the expected output? What do you see instead? libtool: compile: gcc -DHAVE_CONFIG_H -I. -I/usr/include/libxml2 -Wall -Werror -g -O2 -MT libarchive/archive_read_disk_entry_from_file.lo -MD -MP -MF libarchive/.deps/archive_read_disk_entry_from_file.Tpo -c libarchive/archive_read_disk_entry_from_file.c -fPIC -DPIC -o libarchive/.libs/archive_read_disk_entry_from_file.o libarchive/archive_read_disk_entry_from_file.c: In function setup_acls_posix1e: libarchive/archive_read_disk_entry_from_file.c:248: error: expected statement before ) token libarchive/archive_read_disk_entry_from_file.c:253: error: else without a previous if make[1]: *** [libarchive/archive_read_disk_entry_from_file.lo] Error 1 make[1]: Leaving directory `/home/dmcgee/projects/libarchive' What version are you using? 2.8.2 / SVN Fix is to kill the extra right parenthesis: $ svn diff Index: libarchive/archive_read_disk_entry_from_file.c =================================================================== --- libarchive/archive_read_disk_entry_from_file.c (revision 2035) +++ libarchive/archive_read_disk_entry_from_file.c (working copy) @@ -245,7 +245,7 @@ acl = acl_get_link_np(accpath, ACL_TYPE_ACCESS); #else else if ((!a->follow_symlinks) - && (archive_entry_filetype(entry) == AE_IFLNK))) + && (archive_entry_filetype(entry) == AE_IFLNK)) /* We can't get the ACL of a symlink, so we assume it can't have one. */ acl = NULL;

Fix committed to releases/2.8 and trunk; I'll push up a 2.8.3 release as soon as
possible.

2.8.3 release has been pushed up with this fix.  Please let me know if there are any
other problems.
Looks good now, thanks for the quick resolution!

items.title: Allow explicit format specification for bsdtar -x
items.summary: Allow explicit format specification for bsdtar -x

items.content:
It should be possible to explicitly say "this is a mtree spec" or even
"this is a raw" file for bsdtar, disabling the normal bidding once the
input files are done.
The same applies for other cases where an archive is read -- @foo.mtree comes to mind.

There are a couple of pieces here.

1) Within libarchive, I've long wanted to split out archive_read_support_format_XXX()
and archive_read_set_format_XXX().  Ideally, the second of these would be identical
to the current init() methods called for the winning bidder.  This is actually on the
WishList Wiki page already.

2) Once that's in place, --format= can call read_set_format() to set the format
explicitly, bypassing the bidding.

3) For the @foo.mtree case, we need some additional syntax to specify the format.  A
command-line option is one possibility, keying from the filename is another, we could
also extend the syntax to something like @{mtree}foo.bar.

One big motivator here is, of course, the mtree format.  I'm not happy about
requiring a magic initial line, because it makes it hard to do Unix-like things such as
  $ find . -mtree | grep Makefile | sed 's/root/nonroot/' | tar cf file.tar @-
I would like to look for ways to auto-detect mtree without requiring the magic line,
but I expect that some way to explicitly provide a format hint might be required in
some cases.

The other motivator is handling slightly-damaged files.  The bidders are necessarily
rather strict, so we want a way to coerce the format so that people can use
bsdtar/bsdcpio with files that are damaged enough to fail the bid but still recoverable.

Of course, the next obvious step is to extend similar capabilities to the filters. 
The command-line interface could be tricky; I expect we should use strings that look
similar to file extensions to specify the full transform and archive format, e.g.,
"tar.gz.uu".

items.title: ISO9660 writer is inefficient for large directories
items.summary: ISO9660 writer is inefficient for large directories

items.content:
Try adding 100k entries to the same directory, all different. Note how it
gets very slow.

I wonder if I should port and merge Matt Thomas' red black tree from NetBSD. It is
small (rb.o < 4KB) and fast, so it wouldn't impact library size much for those
components that use it.

Thanks.
I've already started to implement the red black tree based on FreeBSD's
/usr/include/sys/tree.h (ported from NetBSD,OpenBSD).

I think that switching to use Matt Thomas' red black tree is not so hard,
if you would port it.
I'm comfortable with whatever you guys come up with.
Simple test case.

I believe I fixed this issue at trunk/r2324 and mainly r2346. 
Recent trunk code has good performance in this case.
Thanks, it now takes 22s for the 100k entries, which looks very good.

items.title: The bsdtar option --check-links does not work
items.summary: The bsdtar option --check-links does not work

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Create a directory and a file in it 2. Create 2 hard links to that file inside the directory and 1 hard link outside it 3. Execute "bsdtar -c --check-links -v -f some_name.tar directory_name What is the expected output? What do you see instead? A warning message about missing links is expected, none is displayed. I have executed both GNU tar with the same command line and also star on the same directory. Both programs give the "missing links" warning message, as expected. What version are you using? I have tried both libarchive 2.7.1 and 2.8.3, none of the 2 versions of bsdtar gives any warning. I have also tried the short option "-l", it also gives no warning message. On what operating system? Gentoo Linux on AMD64 with XFS file system. How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) I have compiled libarchive with the standard Gentoo ebuild scripts, ACL & extended attributes were enabled. What compiler or development environment (please include version)? gcc 4.3.4 Please provide any additional information below. I doubt that the operating system or the development environment can have any influence on this bug. I intended to switch from GNU tar to bsdtar, because I need extended attributes support, which is missing in my version of GNU tar. Nevertheless, it appears that I will have to use star instead, because I believe that this "check-links" feature is required to guarantee that the backup archive contains everything that is needed to restore the original files.

Now I have looked at the source files and I cannot find any place where the field option_warn_links of the 
bsdtar structure is used, after being set by the --check-links option. Therefore, there is no wonder that the 
option does not work. If this is the case, you should document this option as being not implemented.

What puzzles me is that I have seen some old e-mail discussions that seemed to imply that this option was 
implemented in bsdtar at that time.

The patch is the 95% solution. It doesn't work correctly when using newc as format,
because the normal deferred step kicks in before. I am not sure how to correctly
handle that case without changing the API of the linkify function. That might
actually be the best approach though. Tim, what do you think of essentially
deprecating the current flush interface and make archive_entry_partial_links the
default interface for flushing, always returning the last reference in that case?

The patch is the 95% solution. It doesn't work correctly when using newc as format,
because the normal deferred step kicks in before. I am not sure how to correctly
handle that case without changing the API of the linkify function. That might
actually be the best approach though. Tim, what do you think of essentially
deprecating the current flush interface and make archive_entry_partial_links the
default interface for flushing, always returning the last reference in that case?

> ... cannot find ... where the field option_warn_links ... is used ...

It certainly did work at one time; I suspect it was disconnected when we refactored
bsdtar to use the libarchive link resolver to track hardlinks.

> [This] patch is the 95% solution.

If I understand correctly, you're suggesting that the final cleanup loop be used both
for writing any remaining regular entries for the newc case and for printing out
errors for the -l flag?  And that to get proper error messages, we need to return the
remaining link count, hence the API change?  That makes a lot of sense to me.

Would that allow us to keep the existing flush interface as-is for backwards
compatibility?  That would be a nice bonus.

Yeah, I also suspect it was forgotten in the refactoring. Given that bsdtar handles
the archive creation correctly independent of the format, it is seldomly used.

Looking further the present issues, I think it should be
struct archive_entry *archive_entry_linkify_flush(struct linkresolver *res, int
*deferred, unsigned int *links);

archive_entry_linkify would call this function for *e == NULL in a loop. If *deferred
= 1, it sets *e and returns, otherwise frees the entry.

Programs that don't care about missing links can just go with the old API.

I have opened another issue (83), where I have attached a patch that solves a timestamp bug. Unfortunately, 
I had not read this issue before, and I had assumed that you will not work soon on the hard links issue, so 
that patch also inserted a lafe_warnc message in tar/bsdtar.c, when either -l or --check-links were used.

That solution was good enough from my point of view, because it would not fool your trusting users into 
believing that the check was done and it was OK.

If you have really implemented this option now, then that part of the patch is undesirable.

I actually need this check, but this tar option does not seem to be the right solution, because, if the check 
fails, I do not want a warning, I want the archive creation to be aborted because the tar arguments must be 
modified to obtain a valid archive.

Therefore, for myself, I will make a separate script to implement this check before invoking bsdtar. So I 
raised this issue mainly because it was dangerous to believe that bsdtar does what it claims to do, not 
because I believe that this option is useful in its current form.

At least star allows to choose if this check is a warning or an error, which is much more useful than the 
GNU tar behavior, where I have to capture the output and search for the warning message in order to make 
an abort decision, since the exit status code cannot be used.
I don't mind making bsdtar return an error in this case.

I am glad to hear that. I cannot actually imagine why would somebody want --check-links as a warning.

I can see only two use cases.
1. The user does not want to be bothered with a hard links check, because he either knows or assumes that 
there are no chances for problems to appear due to this cause.
2. The user wants to be sure that the created archive is valid, then he needs --check-links as an error.

A valid archive is an archive for which you can delete all the archived files, then restore them from the 
archive, and then you obtain the original file system.

According to this definition, any archive where --check-links fails, is obviously not a valid archive. When the 
user gets this error, he must change the bsdtar command line by either excluding the offending hard linked 
files or by including all their links and only then he can rerun bsdtar and obtain a valid archive.

I, and probably many other users, use normally the creation mode of an archiver, e.g. bsdtar, inside a more 
complex script, so the --check-links failure must return a failure exit status code so that the script will be 
aborted because the recovery requires a manual intervention.

The --check-links option is a synonym for the 'l' modifier specified in SUSv2-1997:

"l   Report if all of the links to the files being archived cannot be resolved. If l
is not specified, no error messages are written."

I interpret this to mean that the messages indicating missing links are considered
error messages (not just informational) and that a non-zero exit code should be
returned in this case.

items.title: bsdtar in extraction mode truncates the directory timestamps (patch attached)
items.summary: bsdtar in extraction mode truncates the directory timestamps (patch attached)

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Create a directory on a file system whose timestamps have nanosecond resolution, e.g. xfs or ext4 2. Archive the directory with "bsdtar --create --format=pax" (the older formats do not store complete timestamps) 3. Extract the archive with "bsdtar --extract --preserve-permissions", then check the directory timestamp with "ls -d --full-time" What is the expected output? What do you see instead? The expected result is to restore the original timestamp. I see instead that the timestamp is truncated to microsecond resolution. What version are you using? 2.8.3 On what operating system? Linux that has utimensat How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) configure What compiler or development environment (please include version)? Does not matter. Please provide any additional information below. This bug is caused by the file "libarchive/archive_write_disk.c", where only the function set_time at line 1841 was updated to use utimensat instead of utimes, but the function _archive_write_close at line 1230 was not updated. I have attached a patch that ensures that _archive_write_close uses utimensat, where available. The patch also adds a lafe_warnc message in tar/bsdtar.c, which gives a temporary solution for issue 82. I am now using a patched bsdtar and I am happy with it. Nevertheless, I have written the patch after just 10 to 20 minutes of browsing the source files so someone familiar with the libarchive sources should review it. I have derived the HAVE_UTIMENSAT case from the HAVE_UTIMES case, but I do not know if there exists any system that has both HAVE_UTIMENSAT and HAVE_STRUCT_STAT_ST_BIRTHTIME and if the code is right for that case. I want to add a comment. In my opinion, the first requirement for an archiving program is to be able to make an exact copy of the archived files. If this requirement is not fulfilled, then the archiving program is useless, regardless how fast or convenient it might be. Sadly, in the year 2010, most widespread archiving programs that are available for UNIX file systems, either are not able at all to make exact copies, or they require non-default options that are not well documented. The two usual problems are the extended attributes (including ACLs) and the timestamps. bsdtar is by far the best archiving program that I have found (from this point of view), but I still had to waste a day to experiment with the options in order to discover that "--format=pax" is mandatory for archive creation and "--preserve-permissions" is mandatory for archive extraction, then I had to read the sources and patch the bug and now I finally have a bsdtar that can be used to backup XFS files. At least the source files were quite clear, thus I could find quickly what to change, so their authors did a very good job.

Are you sure about the HAVE_STRUCT_STAT_ST_BIRTHTIME fragment? It looks like the
second call to utimensat is redundant?

Please keep patches specific to the issue at hand.

I have deleted from the patch given above the warning message that did not belong to this issue and I have 
attached the new patch here.

Regarding the HAVE_STRUCT_STAT_ST_BIRTHTIME case, I have just copied the code from the 
HAVE_UTIMES case, replacing utimes with utimensat.

I have no idea what this birthtime means and why on such systems utimes is called twice. Whoever wrote 
that code should know the reason.

I assume that this birthtime applies to some file systems that maintain a file creation time, and that there 
exists some operating system that uses this non-standard means to set it. Whoever wrote that code should 
have commented it better.

Anyway, the HAVE_STRUCT_STAT_ST_BIRTHTIME case is not used on Linux, so I cannot test it. Like I said in 
my first post, I do not know if there exists any OS where both HAVE_STRUCT_STAT_ST_BIRTHTIME and
HAVE_UTIMENSAT are true, so that part of the code might be never used.

Tim, you did the original change in r212. Please double check the intention of the
original fragment and apply the patch.

joerg.sonnenberger wrote:
> Are you sure about the HAVE_STRUCT_STAT_ST_BIRTHTIME fragment?
> It looks like the second call to utimensat is redundant?


According to FreeBSD's utimes(2) manpage:

"For file systems that support file birth (creation) times (such as UFS2), the 
birth time will be set to the value of the second element if the second element 
is older than the currently set birth time.  To set both a birth time and a 
modification time, two calls are required; the first to set the birth time and 
the second to set the (presumably newer) modification time.  ..."

I do not know if this behavior has been reproduced in utimensat, if this system call was introduced in newer 
versions of FreeBSD, because I am still a happy user of "FreeBSD 4.11-STABLE" (six years of uptime without 
a minute of downtime) :-)
OK, please add a proper comment about that then.

I have looked at the man pages on the FreeBSD site and utimensat appears neither in FreeBSD 8 nor in 
FreeBSD 9.

Therefore the lines belonging to the HAVE_STRUCT_STAT_ST_BIRTHTIME case will never be compiled yet.

When the FreeBSD developers will introduce utimensat, it will be logical to make it behave exactly like 
utimes does now. In that case the code from the patch will be correct.

The alternative is that suggested in the FreeBSD utimes(2) man page: "Ideally a new system call
will be added that allows the setting of all three times at once."

If this will happen (not very likely), the existing code will have to be modified to use the new system call.

I have modified the patch by adding a comment containing these facts and I have attached it here.

Since the version 5.0, NetBSD has adopted the birthtime feature from FreeBSD, so this is the second 
operating system for which HAVE_STRUCT_STAT_ST_BIRTHTIME is true. OpenBSD & DragonFlyBSD do not 
appear to have adopted the birthday feature.

However, like FreeBSD, NetBSD does not have utimensat and it is unlikely that they will introduce this 
feature before FreeBSD or in an incompatible way.

Therefore, I do not think that is necessary to modify the comment posted above to also mention the fact that 
what is said about FreeBSD is also true for the recent versions of NetBSD.

OK, I was lazy.

I have modified the patch by extending the comment.
Now the comment really contains all the known facts.
I have attached the new patch.

I believe that in your web home page, where you list "The libarchive library features:", you should add a 
bullet and mention the fact that, when using the 2001 PAX format, libarchive is able to store all the 
information pertaining to a file, including extended attributes, ACLs and full timestamps, even when they 
have nanosecond resolution.

In my opinion, the ability of making an exact copy of any archived file is even more important then the other 
features that you list there.

GNU tar from the standard distribution lacks this feature. There are patched versions of GNU tar, e.g. 
RedHat, that might be better, but I did not test them and I doubt that they preserve the full timestamps.

The cpio and pax programs that are available in most distributions are old programs that do not preserve 
extended attributes or timestamps.

star, when given a lot of non-default options, preserves extended attributes & ACLs, but truncates the 
timestamps.

Therefore, bsdtar is the only program that I have found and that is able to make exact copies of files from 
UNIX file systems and you should advertise better this fact.

While the various "dump" programs are able to make exact copies, they are not suited for most applications 
because it is much more likely to need to restore the files on a different hard disk than the original one.

Re: timestamp patch

Please try the attached patch.  This takes your idea a step further by refactoring
some of the existing time setting functions.  In particular, there is now only one
place that calls utimensat, only one place that knows about the BSD birthtime
convention, etc.  It's a considerably more intrusive patch but I think the result is
a bit cleaner.  Let me know if this works properly for you.

Re: "when using the 2001 PAX format, libarchive is able to store all the information
pertaining to a file"

Unfortunately, this is not yet universally true, though with the ongoing help and
support of folks like yourself, we are getting closer.  ;-)  Probably the most
important omission at the moment is support for NFS4/NTFS ACLs.

I have tried the "dir_tstamp3.patch" and it seems to be all right. Actually I was also of the same opinion with 
you when I saw the duplicated code for setting times that it should be unified in a single set_time function, 
but, because I was not familiar with your code, I preferred in my initial patch to make minimal changes to 
your sources.

However, if you have already cleaned up most of the code, you should finish it and take the prototype of the 
set_time function, including the opening "{", outside the conditional compilation branches. Likewise, the 
closing "}" of the set_time function should be taken outside the conditional compilation branches.

As it is now, when the function prototype is repeated a large number of times, it is confusing and it also it 
presents an opportunity of errors, if someone would modify by mistake only one of the copies of the 
function prototype.

Best regards !

Committed to libarchive/trunk as r2231.

Thank you very much for your help working through this problem.  I'm quite pleased
with the final result.

What do you see instead? libtool: compile: gcc -DHAVE_CONFIG_H -I. -I/usr/include/libxml2 -Wall -Werror -g -O2 -MT libarchive/archive_write_set_format_gnutar.lo -MD -MP -MF libarchive/.deps/archive_write_set_format_gnutar.Tpo -c libarchive/archive_write_set_format_gnutar.c -fPIC -DPIC -o libarchive/.libs/archive_write_set_format_gnutar.o cc1: warnings being treated as errors libarchive/archive_write_set_format_gnutar.c: In function archive_write_gnutar_header: libarchive/archive_write_set_format_gnutar.c:352:12: error: ret2 may be used uninitialized in this function libarchive/archive_write_set_format_gnutar.c:231:6: error: tartype may be used uninitialized in this function make[1]: *** [libarchive/archive_write_set_format_gnutar.lo] Error 1 make[1]: Leaving directory `/home/dmcgee/projects/libarchive' make: *** [all] Error 2 What version are you using? SVN HEAD On what operating system? Arch Linux, kernel 2.6.33 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) configure What compiler or development environment (please include version)? gcc 4.5.0 Please provide any additional information below. I'm not sure what is supposed to be going on with ret2 here, otherwise I'd try to prepare a patch that fixes this. The variable never gets assigned the entire function.

SVN head should compile, although I'd like someone to please review svn revno 2268- 
that codepath is rather odd.

Which revision are you compiling?  The first error message (about ret2) should not 
appear in r2268.

2267 fixes ret2, 2268 fixes the tartype complaint- that specific change I want review 
on since the intent looks like it wants to set a warning and have that returned, but 
the code didn't handle that properly (thus converting it into a flat out 
ARCHIVE_FAIL).

I was originally trying to compile 2265; sorry for not including that. Things do
compile now at least but it looks like the correctness of the fix is still up in the air.

I don't think setting a warning there is really apropriate, we were asked to write a header which 
we can't write, so I think returning failure is the apropriate thing to do.

Just my 2 cents.

Brian's fix is exactly the same as the fix I had put together here.

Note that ARCHIVE_FAILED indicates that this entry cannot be written.  It's distinct
from ARCHIVE_FATAL, which indicates that the entire archive is now unusable. 
ARCHIVE_FAILED was introduced exactly for this situation:  when it's not valid to
write a certain kind of entry and the only possible remedy is to continue with the
next entry.

items.title: bsdtar  strange extract behavior, writes overlapping buffers
items.summary: bsdtar  strange extract behavior, writes overlapping buffers

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Build a tar archive of say /bin directory 2. Run MacFuse loopback files system (with some trace in the write vfsop) 3. Extract the tar -xf file into the loopback filesystem 3. You will see many writes to the same file with overlapping offsets What is the expected output? What do you see instead? "tar -xf file.tar -C dir/" -- expected tar to write one or more buffers to destination file in an appending fashion -- instead tar will write multiple buffers of data that overlap in file position offset This is ok when extracting to a hard disk that supports write in place (a bit inefficient) but when extracting to a flash memory device, this results in multiple random writes the the flash medium. "pax -rf file.pax" behaves as expected What version are you using? 2.6.2 On what operating system? OS X 10.6.3 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) pre-packaged binary with OS X What compiler or development environment (please include version)? XCODE gcc 4.2.1 Please provide any additional information below.

Can you actually tracec the tar binary and check that it is in fact doing that? This
sounds more like a bug in the kernel or the FUSE filesystem. The code in libarchive
certainly only does linear writes. It will seek only to create sparse files.

As Joerg says, except when restoring sparse files, bsdtar does only perform appending
writes to the output file.

However, those writes are not always uniformly sized.  In particular, bsdtar reads
the input archive in fixed-size blocks and writes to the output files directly from
the data in the read buffers.  As a result, the first write to a file can be oddly-sized.

For example, if tar is reading 10k blocks (the default in bsdtar 2.6) and the archive
contains a 4.5k file followed by a 100k file, then you will see the following I/O
operations:

 read 10k
    open first file
    write 4.5k to first file
    open second file
    write 4.5k to second file [a]
 read 10k
    write 10k to second file [b]
 read 10k
    write 10k to second file
 ... etc ...

(The first block only has 9k of data because it also contains two file headers of 512
bytes each.)

If the filesystem block size is 8k, then write [a] above would only partially fill a
filesystem block.  That same block would be fully filled by write [b] above. 
Depending on how the filesystem handles write caching, that block might indeed get
written twice, once following write request [a] and a second time following write
request [b].

Question: Would this explain the behavior you're seeing?

I've recently made some changes to the read code so that bsdtar will default to much
larger blocks (64k by default) when reading archives from disk.  Larger read blocks
should reduce, but not eliminate, this kind of effect.

Question: If you use "-b 128" (which sets the read block size to 64k), do you see
less of this?

I'll give some thought to ways we might eliminate this effect entirely.  The most
obvious approach is to reblock data before writing it out, but that potentially
introduces a lot of in-memory data copying, which is troublesome.  There might also
be ways to push block sizing information from the write side back to the read side
(if the second read above were 3.5k and the remaining reads were 8k then all writes
after the first two would be properly aligned).

A simpler solution might be to use mmap() to read the input archive.  bsdtar uses the
code in archive_read_open_filename.c.  In the current trunk code, this now has some
concept of an "I/O strategy" that could be used to select mmap() when feasible.  This
essentially makes the entire input file look like a single read block to libarchive,
which means it can try to write every output file with a single write operation. 
(Compressed archives complicate this, though.)

This was reported almost a year ago, but there hasn't been any verification that there is a real bug here.

I'm going to close it for now; if there's more information, we can reopen it.

items.title: bsdtar produces an unextractable tar file when run with -T acting on hardlinks
items.summary: bsdtar produces an unextractable tar file when run with -T acting on hardlinks

items.content:
To reproduce:

  mkdir a b
  echo > a/one
  ln a/one b/two
  find a b -print | tar -c -f test.tar -T -

When trying to extract test.tar,

  $ tar xvf ../test.tar 
  x a/
  x a/one
  x a/one: Can't create 'a/one'
  x b/
  x b/two
  x b/two: Can't create 'b/two'
  tar: Error exit delayed from previous errors.

However, a tar file created with tar -c -f test.tar a b (without the
indirection through -T) works fine. Adding -depth to the find invocation
doesn't help.

I'm running libarchive 2.8.3 on linux 2.6.32.7 with glibc 2.3.6, built with
a straightforward ./configure --prefix= --enable-bsdtar=dynamic and a
(slightly ancient) gcc 3.4.3.

It may be possible to make bsdtar a little smarter about this, but the primary
problem here is that you didn't specify -n.  So bsdtar was asked to backup the 'a'
directory (along with all contents) and was then asked to backup 'a/one' a second
time.  Seeing the same file did confuse the hardlink detection logic, which is why
b/two was stored as a regular file.

I'll double-check the man page to try to better explain that -T often requires -n.

This isn't specific to hardlinks, if you try this with a regular directory tree that
has no nardlinks, you'll see files get added multiple times, which is almost
certainly not what you want.

Ah, sorry, you're quite right. I had misunderstood the behaviour of -T when trying it
out for the first time.

Since I haven't come up with any way to improve this, I'm going to close this report.

Thank you, and please let us know if you find anything else.

Michihiro:  It sounds like we should change the variables you mention to int64_t. 
Does that fix this problem?

archive_read_data() calls archive_read_data_block() and the fourth parameter,
which is named 'offset', of archive_read_data_block() uses off_t for its type.

the type of the parameter to int64_t.
if we changed the type to int64_t, it would break 2.x API.

and archive_read_data() in the patch uses it.

items.title: Option --newer-ctime-than does not work as expected
items.summary: Option --newer-ctime-than does not work as expected

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? date >TIMESTAMP mkdir x echo hallo >x/hallo.txt tar --newer-ctime-than TIMESTAMP -cf x.tar x # x.tar is empty... tar tf x.tar What is the expected output? What do you see instead? x.tar should contain hello.txt but is empty What version are you using? 2.7.0 on FreeBSD 8 On what operating system? FreeBSD 8 Please provide any additional information below. Problem lies at line 187 in read.c: Directories are skipped even if they contain newer files. Regards, Udo

I just noticed this my self in relation to 'differential' backups for my day-job, here's what I wrote up before finding this issue.

Debian Sid (6.0.1) Linux 2.6.32-5-amd64, bsdtar 2.8.4 - libarchive 2.8.4

This should probably have a different type and priority than 'defect medium'.

--

The behavior of the filesystems I've used seems to follow this general convention.  A directory is a listing of files, it's creation, modification and sometimes access are updated for changes to the pointers in that list, not the contents of the objects those pointers link to.

This is a more exacting and repeatable test case:

mkdir -p f/o
touch --date='2011-01-01' f
touch --date='2011-02-01' f/o
touch --date='2011-02-20' f/o/o
 ls -lRt | grep rw
drwxr-x---+ 3 - - 4096 Jan  1 00:00 f
drwxr-x---+ 2 - - 4096 May 25 09:48 o
-rw-rw----+ 1 - -    0 Feb 20 00:00 o

This isn't a problem for full backups.
However when invoking with one of the --newer tests it becomes an issue.

The expected behavior of `bsdtar -c -f test.tar  -v --newer-mtime '2011-02-01' f`
is

$ bsdtar -c -f test.tar  -v --newer-mtime '2011-02-05' f
a f/o
a f/o/o
$

However the result is:

$ bsdtar -c -f test.tar  -v --newer-mtime '2011-02-05' f
$


I /suspect/ without even looking at the code that bsdtar is testing each node as it walks the tree, and skipping a node and all it's children if the prescribed value isn't newer.

The bug is therefore some combination of behavioral assumption (All parents updated on child event) or omission (failure to search all potential children) or not following the planned procedure.

Re-reading the manual and performing a few experiments adding --null -n and the test produces the desired results.  However this still requires an invocation exception.  (thankfully I can begin using it today without additional validation).

find ./f -print0 | bsdtar -c -n -f - -v --newer-mtime '2011-02-01' --null -T- | xz -0 > test.tar.xz

I was authorized to submit the patch I made yesterday, I've tried to keep it to the smallest possible change in both functionality and code (in that order).

Signed then raw copies (tab indentation):
http://dpaste.com/546855/plain/
http://dpaste.com/546856/plain/


Descend directories even if not adding the parent directory due to timestamp.

I am authorized to contribute this upstream,
 please contact me at mjevans1983@gmail.com if there
 are any questions related to this contribution.

diff --git a/tar/write.c b/tar/write.c
index f13bc78..b7b86be 100644
--- a/tar/write.c
+++ b/tar/write.c
@@ -783,8 +783,24 @@ write_hierarchy(struct bsdtar *bsdtar, struct archive *a, const char *path)
 		 * In -u mode, check that the file is newer than what's
 		 * already in the archive; in all modes, obey --newerXXX flags.
 		 */
-		if (!new_enough(bsdtar, name, st))
+		if (!new_enough(bsdtar, name, st)) {
+			/* Copy from beneath; must check children also. */
+			/*
+			* If the user vetoes this file/directory, skip it.
+			* We want this to be fairly late; if some other
+			* check would veto this file, we shouldn't bother
+			* the user with it.
+			*/
+			if (bsdtar->option_interactive &&
+			    !yes("add '%s'", name))
+				continue;
+
+			/* Note: if user vetoes, we won't descend. */
+			if (descend && !bsdtar->option_no_subdirs)
+				tree_descend(tree);
+
 			continue;
+		}
 
 		archive_entry_free(entry);
 		entry = archive_entry_new();
See Issue 159 for more discussion.

items.title: how to extract binary zip format file
items.summary: how to extract binary zip format file

items.content:
I have a zip file, including .png file and .exe file.
How can extract it with libarchive?
I can use libarchive to extract zip file including .txt,
but I cannot extract such as binary files.

libarchive itself doesn't (currently) expose binary vs text files.
What exactly are you doing?

People use libarchive to extract binary files from Zip archives quite regularly.
How are you doing the extraction?

If you are on Windows, you'll need to specify BINARY mode when writing the file to disk, of course.

Please tell us the operating system you're using, what version of libarchive you're using, and how you're using libarchive (code samples help).

I got the reason. The zip format need zlib surport, but I configure with --without-zlib.
Thanks all.

Glad you figured it out.  Technically, you can extract Zip files without zlib, but only uncompressed zip files, which are not very common.

If we get many more questions about this, we'll consider making the zip reader simply fail if zlib is unavailable.  For now, I'll just close this bug.

items.title: Failure to parse ISO9660 content on files generated with WinISO.
items.summary: Failure to parse ISO9660 content on files generated with WinISO.

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. wget -O /tmp/winiso_testcase.iso 'http://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?msg=5;filename=winiso_testcase.iso;att=1;bug=587513' 2. bsdtar -tf /tmp/winiso_testcase.iso 3. mount -o loop /tmp/winiso_testcase.iso /mnt && ls /mnt && umount /mnt What is the expected output? What do you see instead? bsdtar should list the same files as the linux kernels iso9660 filesystem support (test.txt). Currently bsdtar fails to find any contents. What version are you using? libarchive 2.8.3 On what operating system? Debian GNU/Linux How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) configure What compiler or development environment (please include version)? gcc Please provide any additional information below. Disabling the joliet extension code with the option below did not help: bsdtar --options 'iso9660:!joliet' -tf /tmp/winiso_testcase.iso This issue was originally filed in the Debian bug tracking system by Mike Qin who thankfully provided the testcase: http://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=587513

I did some quick initial analysis of this:
 * The ISO9660 bidder doesn't recognize this as an ISO image at all.  Apparently, WinISO encodes the PVD a little differently than we expect.
 * So it's getting read as a valid empty tar archive (the first 1024 bytes of an ISO image happen to also be a valid end-of-archive mark for tar archives)

In the debugger, I forced the bid to select ISO and then the ISO reader complained about an invalid directory record, so there's something else going on here as well.

WinISO apparently produces ISO images that don't follow the spec, which is why libarchive doesn't recognize them as ISO images:

ECMA 119, section 6.9.3: "One or more Path Table Groups shall be recorded on a volume."
ECMA 119, section 6.9.2: "A Path Table Group shall comprise ... one or two identical Type M Path Tables."

But this image has a zero value for the "Type M Path Table Offset".  (Many operating systems ignore the Path Tables entirely, so it's not surprising that WinISO has been able to get away with this.)

Libarchive doesn't use the path tables either, but it does check this value as part of the auto-detect process.  I've just committed r2516 to permit a zero here.  With this change, bsdtar seems to be able to read this test image correctly.

TODO: Should take this sample archive and build a test case around it.

Thanks for the quick fix. I've emailed WinISO support and provided them with a link to this issue in case they are interested in fixing it. Workaround in libarchive still needed ofcourse, to be able to handle all already produced invalid isos.
I'm going to mark this as "Fixed".

items.title: Problems in test_write_format_iso9660_filename
items.summary: Problems in test_write_format_iso9660_filename

items.content: It seems to me that the added files and the extracted files from the created iso file in test_write_format_iso9660_filename does not match, or atleast the output has many more files then was actually added. I guess there's a problem either in the iso9660 joliet extension WRITE or READ support. What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Edit libarchive/test/test_write_format_iso9660_filename.c and add debug printout of the filenames added to the iso in the "add_entry" helper function then add debug printout of extracted/parsed files last in the "verify_file" helper function. 2. run test to capture added and extracted/parsed files debug output. 3. sort the output of each into a file and diff these files. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? I'd expect the diff to say there are no changes. Instead there where alot of extra files extracted/parsed. Please use labels and text to provide additional information. The diff is attached for your convenience. This problem was found by enabling "trailing dot stripping" in the joliet extension read support iso9660 code. This made duplicates appear in the test. With closer investigation the problem doesn't seem to be actual duplicates but what was described above. An exact check of added/found files would probably be better in the test then just a check for duplicate files.
for more info / previous discussion see: r2514, r2515, r2520, r2521
The writer should not change filenames any more than is necessary.

A new patch:

--- libarchive/archive_write_set_format_iso9660.c       (revision 2526)
+++ libarchive/archive_write_set_format_iso9660.c       (working copy)
@@ -5951,6 +5951,11 @@
                if ((int)l > ffmax)
                        l = ffmax;
                np->identifier = (char *)p;
+               /* If the last character of a filename is '.', Windows
+                * standard tools(such as cmd.exe, explorer.exe or notepad.exe)
+                * cannot access the file. */
+               if (p[l-2] == 0 && p[l-1] == 0x2E) /* '.' */
+                       archive_be16enc(&p[l-2], 0x005F); /* '_' */
                lt = l;
                dot = p + l;
                weight = 0;

I made some files through cygwin and checked whether
those can be accessed by Windows tools or not.

filename cmd.exe explorer.exe notepad.exe
 f         o          o            o
 f.        x          x            x
 f..       x          x            x
 f._       o          o            o
 f.._      o          o            o

  o: OK.
  x: NG, access 'f' file.

I think the patches posted are quite off-topic. It might be nice to not write trailing dots in filenames, but assuming all other iso readers strip trailing dots and we can enable the code to do so as well it's not a problem.

The real problem here is why, when adding foo to the iso, we read back foo, foo000, foo001, ..., foo00A, ...

Where does all these extra files come from?

Has this issue been resolved in libarchive/trunk?

Is there any reason to hold up the libarchive 3.0 release for it?

I looked at this a little bit and haven't yet found anything alarming, though I agree the test could be improved.

The test recreates the ISO image 6 times (with different options) and reads those images back a total of 17 times (with different options), so you should expect to see names appear different numbers of times in add_entry and verify_file.

It would be nice to improve the test to verify that each filename was read back exactly as many times as expected.  This would require adding some bookkeeping to the existing code, of course.  The tricky part is accounting for how different ISO formats change names (plain ISO9660 converts names to uppercase, for example).

items.title: Using libarchive in a thread on OSX in release mode crashes
items.summary: Using libarchive in a thread on OSX in release mode crashes

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Build in release mode, create archive in thread. 2. Add entry to archive, in 2.8.x will crash, in 3.x will crash on close What is the expected output? What do you see instead? This is strange because I don't see this behavior in debug builds or on any other platform (Linux, Win32). The code runs in a thread--but is completely mutex locked, no other threads are talking to the libarchive code. The code creates a archive add adds entries that are data buffers. This is always the error: Critical: Archive write error INTERNAL ERROR: Function 'archive_write_header' invoked with archive structure in state 'new', should be in state 'header/data' Here is the code: a = archive_write_new(); Q_ASSERT(0 == archive_write_set_compression_gzip(a)); Q_ASSERT(0 == archive_write_set_format_ustar(a)); archive_write_open_filename(a, filename.toAscii().constData()); Then in a loop with vars (const QString& name, const * char entry, int size): struct archive_entry *entry; entry = archive_entry_new(); archive_entry_set_mode(entry, AE_IFREG | 0444); archive_entry_set_size(entry, size); archive_entry_set_birthtime(entry, QDateTime::currentDateTime().toTime_t(), 0); archive_entry_set_pathname(entry, name.toAscii().constData()); archive_write_header(a, entry); archive_write_data(a, data, size); archive_entry_free(entry); Any idea why this is popping up on release mode only? What version are you using? 2.8.4 and 3.x SVN On what operating system? OSX 10.6.4 GCC 4.2.1 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) My makefile. What compiler or development environment (please include version)? GCC 4.2.1 Qt 4.6.3, Cocoa, 64-bit, release mode. Please provide any additional information below.

You should be getting an error from archive_write_open_filename().  I presume your outline is omitting the required error checking after calls to write_new, write_open_filename, entry_new, write_header, and write_data.

Libarchive has an internal state machine to guard against programming errors.  In particular, it catches cases where you've failed to handle an error and are requesting operations that the archive object cannot handle.

For reference, the basic state transitions are:
  * A new archive object is in state 'new'
  * After a successful open, it is in state 'header'
  * It alternates between 'header' and 'data' states as you alternately write headers and associated data.
  * It becomes 'closed' when you close.
  * After any fatal error, the archive will enter state 'fatal'; in this state, a finish() (aka free()) operation is basically the only thing allowed.

So the message says that you've asked to write data to an archive object that isn't opened, probably because the open failed.
I still don't know what's going on, here is a small sample that doesn't seem to work (archive_write_data fails).

Ok, this is strange.  I'm attaching a minimal sample, when compiled in debug mode it works fine, but in release mode it segfaults.  Here is all I can get from gdb for the segfault:


#0  0x0000000000000000 in ?? ()
#1  0x000000010000915d in _archive_write_header ()
#2  0x0000000100002c07 in add_entry ()
#3  0x0000000100003831 in main ()
(gdb) 


The GCC line for release mode is:

g++ -c -pipe -O2 -Wall -W -DQT_NO_DEBUG -DQT_GUI_LIB -DQT_CORE_LIB -DQT_SHARED -I/usr/local/Qt4.6/mkspecs/macx-g++ -I../../../../qtsync/src/3rdparty/tests -I/Library/Frameworks/QtCore.framework/Versions/4/Headers -I/usr/include/QtCore -I/Library/Frameworks/QtGui.framework/Versions/4/Headers -I/usr/include/QtGui -I/usr/include -I../../../../qtsync/src/3rdparty/libarchive -I/Users/m3ntat/Code/GUI/qtsync-release/src/3rdparty/tests/. -I../../../../qtsync/src/3rdparty/tests -I. -F/Library/Frameworks -o tests.o ../../../../qtsync/src/3rdparty/tests/tests.cpp 
g++ -headerpad_max_install_names -o tests tests.o -F/Library/Frameworks -L/Library/Frameworks ../libarchive/libarchive.a -lz -framework QtGui -framework QtCore 


For debug:

g++ -c -pipe -g -gdwarf-2 -Wall -W -DQT_GUI_LIB -DQT_CORE_LIB -DQT_SHARED -I/usr/local/Qt4.6/mkspecs/macx-g++ -I. -I/Library/Frameworks/QtCore.framework/Versions/4/Headers -I/usr/include/QtCore -I/Library/Frameworks/QtGui.framework/Versions/4/Headers -I/usr/include/QtGui -I/usr/include -I../libarchive -I. -F/Library/Frameworks -o tests.o tests.cpp 
g++ -headerpad_max_install_names -o tests tests.o -F/Library/Frameworks -L/Library/Frameworks ../libarchive/libarchive.a -lz -framework QtGui -framework QtCore 

This is linking against the Qt built libs from the website for 4.6.3 OSX (non debug).  I'll test again without any Qt linking to ensure it's not Qt somehow breaking libarchive in release mode, but it seems doubtful.    Could it be that the -O2 is causing unstable code?
It looks like I've found the culprit--the linker was using a different version of zlib causing a difficult to spot gzip error.  You can close this now--thanks for the help.
Glad you found the problem.

items.title: ZIP format does not handle symbolic links
items.summary: ZIP format does not handle symbolic links

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Try to create a zip archive from a directory containing symlinks What is the expected output? What do you see instead? A zip archive containing symlinks and I get the error: "archive_write_header:Filetype not supported" What version are you using? 2.7.900a (the one embedded with CMake 2.8.2) On what operating system? Linux Debian Squeeze How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) From cmake. What compiler or development environment (please include version)? gcc version 4.4.4 Please provide any additional information below. Info-zip zip implementation (the "zip" command line tool) supports symlinks if it is given the "-y" option. Would be great to have symlinks support in libarchive.

This would not be very hard to support in libarchive when writing Zip archives.

Supporting symlinks when reading Zip archives would require more work, as Zip archives only seem to store that information in the Central Directory.  Libarchive's Zip reader does not currently use the Central Directory; it only uses the per-file headers to identify the file type and other information.

I did never develop or submit a patch for libarchive and 
I have no particular knowledge about zip, however if ever I try a patch
is there anything I should be aware of about libarchive way of contribution?

"about libarchive way of contribution"

Start with something small and simple.
Create a patch in "unified diff" format (diff -u) and attach it to a comment on this Issue report.
One of the regular developers will take a look and let you know if there's anything that needs to be changed.

Hi,

I did not forget my proposal but I'm currently lacking time for trying...
As soon as some free time appears I'll try.
In the meantime if anyone is faster than me please go ahead, do not wait
for me.
With the recent addition of a seek-capable Zip reader that does use the Central Directory, it should be relatively easy to implement this now.

Reading symbolic links is now implemented in trunk (for the seeking Zip reader only; it's not feasible for the streaming reader because Zip archives don't store the necessary information in the right place).

It would be nice to add write support as well.
Michihiro has implemented writing symlinks to Zip files, so this is now complete.

libarchive/test/libarchive_test-main.o:(.data+0x228): undefined reference to `test_open_failure'

Yes it is, thanks.

items.title: Linux setup_sparse() should merge adjacent extents when generating sparse list
items.summary: Linux setup_sparse() should merge adjacent extents when generating sparse list

items.content:
The Linux implementation of setup_sparse() in libarchive/archive_read_disk_entry_from_file.c contains the code

	if (fe->fe_logical == 0 && length == size) {
		/* This is not sparse. */
		do_fiemap = 0;
		break;
	}

before calling archive_entry_sparse_add_entry which is obviously intended to make non-sparse files have no ae_sparse entry instead of one, but this doesn't work when the kernel allocates two separate extents with no hole in the middle.  archive_entry_sparse_add_entry does consolidate logically adjacent extents, but this still leaves the archive entry having one ae_sparse entry instead of zero.  This confuses test_sparse_basic, which adds a non-sparse file (sparse_file3) and checks that there are no ae_sparse entries.  On my system (Linux 2.6.34-gentoo-r1, ext3) the kernel reports two extents for this file, therefore the test fails:

libarchive/test/test_sparse_basic.c:246: blocks != archive_entry_sparse_count(ae)
      blocks=0 (0x0, 00)
      archive_entry_sparse_count(ae)=1 (0x1, 01)

Adding a debugging printf() to setup_sparse() shows

size = 11264 fe_physical = 5736488960 fe_logical = 0 fe_length = 8192
size = 11264 fe_physical = 5736497152 fe_logical = 8192 fe_length = 4096

when running the test in question.  I'm not sure why there are two extents when they're logically and physically adjacent (possibly a kernel bug, or maybe just something I don't fully understand) but in any case it could also happen when the parts aren't adjacent on disk.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------

[1] For reference, list of patches applied versus vanilla 2.6.34, none of which are related to this issue unless there are some major unintended consequences happening:

Patch:	2700_nouveau-acpi-lid-open-undefined-fix.patch
From:	http://bugs.gentoo.org/show_bug.cgi?id=322001
Desc:	nouveau: fix acpi_lid_open undefined

Patch:	2710_vbfb-section-cleanup.patch
From:	http://bugs.gentoo.org/show_bug.cgi?id=323021
Desc:   Fix errors issued by modpost in vfb driver	

Patch:	2900_xconfig-with-qt4.patch
From:	http://bugs.gentoo.org/show_bug.cgi?id=320761
Desc:	xconfig patch for qt4 - thanks to Sam Iam

Patch:	4200_fbcondecor-0.9.6.patch
From:	http://dev.gentoo.org/~spock
Desc:	Bootsplash successor by Michal Januszewski

This code was originally written around the Solaris/FreeBSD lseek(HOLE) interface which generates a map of logical blocks and holes.  The Linux FIEMAP ioctl seems to be a lower-level interface; we need to rewrite the Linux version of setup_sparse() to process the extent map into a correct sparse list by merging logically adjacent extents.

updates.summary: Linux setup_sparse() should merge adjacent extents when generating sparse list

items.content:
I disabled the Linux support for sparse files until we can fix this.

Is there an alternative to FIEMAP for identifying holes in files on Linux?

This is pretty easy to address w/in sparse itself- question is- we can either expand archive_entry_sparse_add_entry to do a length check on it's combining logic (if the length of the sparse entry is the entry size, than it's not sparse).

Question is what to do in that case- if we just do a clear, this will allow subsequent archive_entry_sparse_add_entry calls to add a sparse range.

Specifically, if cumulatively for file x w/ len 1024, the resultant sparse_add_entry calls add up to 1024, current behaviour disallows trying to add offset 0, length 10.  If we do a clear, they could get away with it (it would add the entry, and 10->1024 would be sparse).

If we wish to preserve this behaviour, than we have to inject a sanity check into sparse_next; if offset 0, length == entry_size, than there is no sparse.

My personal inclination is to do a clear, but comments would be welcome.

Note also that while it's probably worth fixing the linux setup_sparse, the sparse_add_entry machinery definitely would benefit from the sanity checks I mentioned above- thus targeting that layer.
I believe this issue fixed in r3432 base on Brian's idea.
Marking this 'fixed'.

What version are you using? 2.8.3 On what operating system? redhat linux 9 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) What compiler or development environment (please include version)? Please provide any additional information below.

The "tar" program extracts archives.  It can extract a.tar.gz because that file is a tar archive (that happens to be gzipped).

The libarchive programming library can be used to build the tool you seem to want, but that tool is not "tar".

items.title: ZIP files having file headers with extra_length = 0 cause "Truncated ZIP file header" error
items.summary: ZIP files having file headers with extra_length = 0 cause "Truncated ZIP file header" error

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Attempt to read headers from a ZIP file having file headers with extra_length = 0 using archive_read_new()/archive_read_next_header() What is the expected output? What do you see instead? There should be no error and the headers should be "returned." Instead there is a "Truncated ZIP file header" error. What version are you using? 2.7.0 On what operating system? Linux mipsel uclibc How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) configure What compiler or development environment (please include version)? GCC 4.0.4 mipsel-linux-uclibc Please provide any additional information below. If I comment out the following lines in archive_read_support_format_zip.c, I am able to read the file headers and subsequently extract all of the archive members. /* Read the extra data. */ if ((h = __archive_read_ahead(a, zip->extra_length, NULL)) == NULL) { archive_set_error(&a->archive, ARCHIVE_ERRNO_FILE_FORMAT, "Truncated ZIP file header"); return (ARCHIVE_FATAL); } process_extra(h, zip); This suggests that an if(zip->extra_length == 0) should be wrapped around this block. I have attached an example file for reference.

I believe this has been fixed in libarchive 2.8 and in trunk.

The code block you quoted above is unchanged, but __archive_read_ahead() now correctly handles a request for zero bytes by returning a valid pointer to data.

Please try with libarchive 2.8 and let us know if you still see the problem there.

I did a little more research:  SVN r1441 is a fix for this, it was committed to trunk in Sept 2009, before libarchive 2.8 was branched.

Here's a link to the commit message for this:
http://code.google.com/p/libarchive/source/detail?r=1441

items.title: one ssize_t -> int64_t change missing since librarchive 2.8.5 (until r2763)
items.summary: one ssize_t -> int64_t change missing since librarchive 2.8.5 (until r2763)

items.content:
Hi

I'm cherry-picking some int64_t changes since librarchive 2.8.4 and
come up with this:

@@ -1899,7 +2030,7 @@
  */
 static int64_t
 gnu_sparse_10_atol(struct archive_read *a, struct tar *tar,
-    ssize_t *remaining)
+    ssize_t *remaining, size_t *unconsumed)
 {
        int64_t l, limit, last_digit_limit;
        const char *p;

Shouldn't the "remaining" be type int64_t


The same issue arises in function gnu_sparse_10_read() around line 2075.

Good catch!  Yes, that should be int64_t here and in gnu_sparse_10_read.   Otherwise, gnu_sparse_10_read() will compute the number of bytes read incorrectly due to integer truncation (for very large entries).

Fixed in trunk in r2764.

items.title: When an archive_entry exceeds format specific size limits, archive_write_header() should report it.
items.summary: When an archive_entry exceeds format specific size limits, archive_write_header() should report it.

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? Try to add a file with size > 4 GiB to a cpio_newc archive. no error is reported the archive gets corrupted. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? The function 'archive_write_header()' should return an error when a archive_entry exceeds format specific limits. What version are you using? 2.8.4 On what operating system? Windows How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) cmake + vs2005 What compiler or development environment (please include version)? Microsoft Visual Studio 2005 without SP1 Please provide any additional information below. I know cpio_newc is quite old, but it would help other developers using your library a lot, when their mistakes get caught and reported :-)
Maybe Type should have been Featuer Request.

Yes, archive_write_header() should return ARCHIVE_FAILED to indicate that this entry cannot be written.

The attached patch should fix this for newc format.  Similar changes may be needed for other formats.  Please try this patch and let us know.
Here's an updated version of that patch that also fixes a few other related issues.
I've tried out the patch, i've also extended the test for cpio_newc, it didn't catch a file with size > 4GB for me.

I think I see the issue:  You haven't set the file type.  Cpio formats don't allow bodies for any filetype other than regular files (AE_IFREG).  Since you haven't set the file type, the size is being set to zero.  (Format handlers do this to indicate to clients when they will ignore the body, so that clients can avoid writing bodies when it's not needed.)

I've extended the earlier patch to also return ARCHIVE_FAILED if the file type isn't specified, extended the test to exercise these checks, and committed the result as r2782.
I think setting an appropriate error message would be nice as well.
The patch I committed in r2782 does set appropriate error messages for all of the new failure cases.  If you find any that I missed, please let me know.

It doesn't set an error messages when the size of an entry overflows in  archive_write_set_format_cpio.c:259 and archive_write_set_format_cpio_newc.c:200
before returning ARCHIVE_FAILED.
Of course!  I apologize for overlooking that.  I just committed a fix for this (including a test update to verify that it doesn't break again).

"18: test_fuzz                                         unxz: (stdin): Compressed data is corrupt unxz: (stdin): Compressed data is corrupt"

This is not a test failure.  These messages are expected:  If the system does not have liblzma, libarchive will instead use the command-line "unxz" program.  The test_fuzz test exercises error handling by passing deliberately corrupted data to libarchive; in this case, the unxz program will emit warnings to stderr that are completely expected.

The errors reported earlier in this bug are real failures, though I suspect these specific issues have been fixed in the source code in SVN.
The crash reported in next_cache_entry (comment 6 above) may be the same issue I recently found and reported in Issue 199.

I just spent a little while looking at the backtrace in comment 3 above.

It looks like the read_CE code doesn't verify that the offsets are within the current block.  (though maybe this is checked elsewhere?)

I've attached a patch against libarchive/trunk that should guard against this particular issue.  It should not require much to adapt it to libarchive 2.8.

I just committed a candidate fix for the CE issue in comment 3 above to libarchive/trunk.

I'll run the fuzz tester overnight to see if I can reproduce any failures here.

items.title: bsdtar -x doesn't preserve xattrs
items.summary: bsdtar -x doesn't preserve xattrs

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. echo "This is only a test" > test.txt 2. attr -s user.testing -V HELLO test.txt 3. attr -g user.testing test.txt 4. bsdtar -cv --format=pax -f test.tar test.txt 5. cat test.tar 6 bsdtar -xf test.tar 7 attr -g user.testing test.txt What is the expected output? What do you see instead? The value("HELLO") for user.testing is visible when examining the contents of the .tar file (as well as by running attr -g on the original file), but when the archive is extracted, the xattr value for user.testing is no longer set. The man page doesn't seem to indicate this would need an explicit command line paramater to enable. What version are you using? bsdtar 2.8.4 - libarchive 2.8.4 On what operating system? Ubuntu Maverick, 10.10 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) What compiler or development environment (please include version)? Please provide any additional information below.

You need to include the -p option to restore extended metadata such as xattrs.

I just tried this using the bsdtar package distributed by Canonical and your example seems to work fine if you use -xp instead of just -x.

items.title: Do not disaply unavailable features
items.summary: Do not disaply unavailable features

items.content:
Even I have not build bsdtar with lzma, bsdtar still report:

C:\>bsdtar --help
...
-z, -j, -J, --lzma  Compress archive with gzip/bzip2/xz/lzma
...

I expected bsdtar should report:
C:\>bsdtar --help
...
-z, -j, -J          Compress archive with gzip/bzip2/xz
...

If you do not have lzma libraries, libarchive still compiles basic lzma support which attempts to run separate command-line programs.

So "bsdtar -c --lzma" will try to run the "lzma" command-line program to compress the data.  In particular, this works if you install lzma executables after you've built bsdtar.

I've decided not to change the existing behavior here.

As explained above, even when you build without lzma libraries, bsdtar will attempt to run external programs, so the --lzma option is available and can be used.
Maybe you should distinguish the two cases, let the user know whether the feature is built-in or need to run separate command-line programs.

Here is bsdtar output:

curl 7.21.2 (i386-pc-win32) libcurl/7.21.2 OpenSSL/0.9.8p zlib/1.2.5 libssh2/1.2.7
Protocols: dict file ftp ftps gopher http https imap imaps ldap pop3 pop3s rtsp

to archive.h and implement it in archive_util.c to return a string of the form:

archive_util.c to correctly build the full string.
This has been implemented by Ross Lagerwall.  Thanks for the suggestion!
