The tmp.zip file from this example is attached as charset_cp866.zip.
File created from GUI (not command line) and by WinRar and internally by Explorer (as compressed ZIP folder) are use codepage 866 too.

As You see, bsdtar use codepage 1251 (ACP, not OEMCP) and print wrong file listing.

BTW, in issue 33 (about C++ wrapper) exists link to objective-C code. In this code author use narrow char version of functions (for example archive_entry_pathname), and then tie it with charset defined from outside.

Addition about PaxHeader folder in tar archive.

On FreeBSD mbstowcs/wctomb does not use current charset defined in locale to make conversion between multibyte and wchar. The right way is to use iconv (or something like this). 

So, as minimum I think it is need to modify archive_strappend_w_mbs and archive_wstrcpy_mbs (which make conversion) to use iconv instead of standard functions.
As maximum i think it is need API to define functions for conversion to/from unicode for each "archive *".
Also it can help solve problem of archives comes from different OS with different  codepages. For example with archives from unix which opened on windows.

I have done a few experiments and I agree that we should be using iconv in archive_string.c.

This is a big change, though, so I want to explain the implications in case I miss something.

First, I do not want to call iconv_open every time we want to convert one small string, so the iconv conversion descriptor needs to be stored somewhere and reused.  It cannot be stored globally without breaking threaded programs.  So I think it should be stored in "struct archive".  This is good---it means we can add an interface later to select the codepage for each archive *.  But it requires a struct archive to be passed into every place where a string conversion might happen.

Most of those are in archive_entry.  So I think we have to change archive_entry_new() to be:

 struct archive_entry *archive_entry_new(struct archive *);

This is a big change.

Until now, archive_entry objects have existed separately from archive objects; they could be used completely on their own.  With this change, every archive_entry object must be created in the context of a particular archive object.   The case that I'm not sure about:  What should happen when an entry is copied between archives with different codepages?  (For example, when copying from a tar archive to an archive_write_disk handle?)

libarchive/trunk r2992 and r2993 change the charset conversion routines over to use iconv() when it's available.

This should fix the problem you saw on FreeBSD with KOI8-R filenames being incorrectly stored in pax archives (though I've so far only tested these changes on Mac OS).  I think I found a way to avoid breaking source compatibility; archive_entry_new() is unchanged and I've added archive_entry_new2(struct archive *) to create entries that are bound to a particular archive handle.  Internally, the iconv() conversion descriptors are stored in the archive handle to be reused for performance, and I've outlined support for allowing the character encoding to be set on a per-archive-handle basis.

There's still some code cleanup and testing that needs to be done; please let me know if you see any further problems.

With this change, bsdtar should correctly store KOI8-R filenames from FreeBSD.  After we've finished testing that, I'll take a closer look at extraction on Windows.

Build on FreeBSD8 with ports/convert/libiconv.
Build error at using iconv() by following message:
libarchive/archive_string.c: In function 'archive_wstring_append_from_mbs':
libarchive/archive_string.c:532: warning: passing argument 2 of 'libiconv' from
incompatible pointer type
libarchive/archive_string.c: In function 'archive_string_append_from_unicode_to_
mbs':
libarchive/archive_string.c:667: warning: passing argument 2 of 'libiconv' from
incompatible pointer type

There are different definitions for iconv() function; one is using 'const' to
the second argument and other is not.
As far I know, Solaris and NetBSD use 'const' but many Linux distro using GNU libiconv
do not.

Tim, your changes cannot work with eucJP when using archvie_entry_pathname_w() on FreeBSD because of issue 66.

setlocale(LC_ALL, "ja_JP.eucJP");

archive_entry_set_pathname(e, ".txt");// "\xC9\xBD.txt"

then archive_entry_pathname_w(e) returns 
      Dump of archive_entry_pathname_w(e)
0000_68_88_00 00 2e 00 00 00 74 00 00 00 78 00 00 00 h.......t...x...
0010 74 00 00 00                                     t...

but result of performing mbstowcs(ws, ".txt") is 
      Dump of ws
0000_bd_c9_00 00 2e 00 00 00 74 00 00 00 78 00 00 00 ........t...x...
0010 74 00 00 00                                     t...

An attached patch is to test eucJP in test_pax_filename_encoding_freebsd.c.

I have always intended that archive_entry_pathname_w() return Unicode.

The use of mbstowcs() was wrong, and causes bsdtar to generate incorrect pax-format archives; POSIX specifies that the filenames in pax archives are stored in Unicode.

The archive_entry_pathname_w() here is correct;  is \u8868

r3007 adds more checks to CMakeLists.txt.

This should now work properly on FreeBSD (and other platforms with POSIX iconv) as well as on platforms with non-POSIX iconv() and which require libiconv.

Still missing autoconf machinery...

Must the applications using libarchive treat wchar_t as Unicode even if __STDC_ISO_10646__
is not defined ?
On application side, to get wchar_t string is normally use of mbstowcs() or related functions.
What will be happen when using archive_entry_copy_pathname_w() in ja_JP.eucJP locale ?

On FreeBSD the archive_entry_pathname_w() with iconv returns Unicode as you say
but the function without iconv will return non Unicode string made with wcrtomb/wctomb,
that is quite different behavior.

And I have some concern about UTF-8-MAC, which is Normalization Form D(NFD).
Some platforms, which are X Window system, Windows XP or older Windows platform, cannot
correctly display UTF-8-MAC strings because they expect that UTF-8 is Normalization Form C (NFC) not NDF.

I think it is better that the way to get UTF-8 is converted from MBS with iconv than
converted from wchar_t string in assuming wchar_t as Unicode.

"I think it is better that the way to get UTF-8 is converted from MBS with iconv..."

Yes, I completely agree.  I want to make this change.

"What will be happen when using archive_entry_copy_pathname_w() in ja_JP.eucJP locale ?"

How do people use this?  This is needed on Windows to use the Unicode file APIs, but I don't know about other systems.

Right now, we're using these internally for Pax, Joliet, and CAB filenames, but those are all Unicode, so our Pax, Joliet, and CAB support is all somewhat broken right now.

We could add archive_entry_copy_pathname_unicode() and leave the _w() forms as locale-dependent wchar_t.  But I don't know if the non-Unicode _w forms are useful; we can't really test them, because the results are both locale- and system-dependent.

Here's another way to think about this:

The reason for libarchive to support character-set conversions is to properly support the various archive formats.

  Pax uses UTF-8 for filenames
  Joliet (and CAB?) use Unicode (technically UTF-16)
  Almost everything else uses locale-dependent MBS.

So we must support those three.  It's not clear to me why we need to support locale-dependent WCS.  mbstowcs() is readily available for people who need to work with WCS.

I'm happy to rename the existing _w functions to _unicode if that makes things more clear.

Some people use UTF-8 but other people still use eucJP, who say that the applications,
which they usually use, do not work properly in UTF-8. They are not only FreeBSD users,
NetBSD and Solaris users choose eucJP by the same reason or from force habit.

About filenames in Japan. There are many character-set.
For example, Windows platform uses CP932 aka MS-SJIS,
Linux platforms use UTF-8, MAC OS X uses UTF-8-MAC though locale name is UTF-8,
other POSIX platforms can use eucJP, UTF-8 and SJIS.
And thus I would like to support 'charset' option to specify a filename character-set
as "bsdtar -tvf file.cab --options cab:charset=CP932".

CAB can store filenames with UTF-8 but UTF-8 is not used, so CAB usually uses
local-dependent MBS for stored filenames. It means POSIX platforms may be not able to
display the filenames even if the platforms use UTF-8 locale. This is an another reason
why 'charset' option is needed. I think it is useful that at least CAB, LHA and ZIP
format reader would support the option.

I think we should worry about what WCS format is when UTF-8 is completely converted to/from
MBS with iconv; WCS is no longer needed to get UTF-8. Therefore, I do not think that renaming _w
functions is needed.

MS-SJIS is Microsoft SJIS, an alias of CP932, which is extended by Microsoft and OEM vendors of
MS-DOS/Windows, from SJIS(Shift_JIS character-set).
We need to translate filenames from CP932 stored on Windows platform to UTF-8 or eucJP
,which most of POSIX like system use, or, as I mentioned filenames on MAC OS X, translate
filenames from UTF-8-MAC(NFD) to UTF-8(NFC) or other character-set such as eucJP.

>   /* The archive is storing filenames in CP932 */
>   archive_set_charset(a, "CP932);
This is exactly the API I need!

>   /* Now we want to open the file using MS-SJIS, so... */
>   filename = archive_entry_pathname_in_charset(entry, "MS-SJIS")
This would be useful.
For an ISO Writer, to get UTF-16 characters, do you think it can be like this:
  filename_utf16 = (uint16_t *)archive_entry_pathname_in_charset(entry, "UTF-16LE") ?
Since the writer has to store filenames with multiple-character-set into an ISO-image.

I hope that all of converting character-set code in format-readers and writers would be removed.

Since libarchive now has full iconv integration for handling filenames in various character sets, I believe this issue is now Fixed.

If you think otherwise, let me know what you think is still missing.

items.title: call to abort() in __archive_check_magic.
items.summary: call to abort() in __archive_check_magic.

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Call archive_write_set_format_zip with handle created by archive_read_new. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Expected: return code ARCHIVE_FAILED or ARCHIVE_FATAL. Instead: program terminated. What version are you using? trunk / revision 2954 On what operating system? Windows 7 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) cmake What compiler or development environment (please include version)? VisualStudio 2010 Additional information: In file "archive_check_magic.c" in function "__archive_check_magic" if "a->magic != magic" then called function "diediedie". It is bad idea - in GUI application I don't see the output of "errmsg", and application is terminated in harmless call. Terminating application (in non fatal situation) in any case is bad idea - the other part of application may contents important for user data. For example - text editor, that can save in compressed format (by can save and w/o compression). If at save to file with using libarchive user lost all their data I think he may be angry. Yes, I know - it is wrong use of library. But it is not fatal error to _terminate_ application.

This test is intended to help ensure that developers using libarchive detect such basic errors very early in their development.

I do agree that the error message should be more visible.  If you could help us display a Windows dialog box at this point (using only very basic Win32 services, of course), that would certainly be an improvement.

I can write code for dialog box on Win32. It is not too hard, just say. But it is half of solution. There are still exists situation where dialog box will not help. For example - services in windows and daemons in unix can't show dialog box and don't have stdout/stderr.

If You want to inform programmer about misuse of library, then it is most consistent ways:
1) Return FATAL as result of function. The preferred way (for me). If user omit error codes, then it is his fault.

2) Make API to redefine diediedie function behavior. In one strategy it call abort (default), in other strategy - return some error code. So, user _can_ select - which type of error he want.

In any way, call "abort" on call archive_write_set_options for read archive is like kill people for crossing road in wrong place.

FATAL is not acceptable. It just makes any debugging a lot harder. If your code hits this assertion, you have either found a critical bug in libarchive OR your application is violating the API contract in a major way. abort() is completely justified behavior for that. I don't see any point in adding a more fancy API for this either -- if you don't have a mechanism to obtain a backtrace from a crashing program, your testing environment is broken.

I don't think that FATAL make debugging harder if user _analyze_ all result codes, and I don't think I can find  critical bug in libarchive. So in most cases  is violating the API contract in a major way. Yes, it is very bad. 

In all cases (not only on libarchive - when You call "abort" the rest part of application don't have any chance to save data (that may be _important_ and _correct_). It is why I hate the "abort", "exit", "terminate" functions. For example, MS Word when crashed always try to save user data.

In any way, this behavior is Your choice (You are the authors). Library is well designed, and I can easy make custom build where i will return FATAL instead of call abort() (what I love in open-source projects - it is always can be fixed or modified for custom requirements).

items.title: Call to archive_write_finish causes a crash when archive_write_open_filename fails
items.summary: Call to archive_write_finish causes a crash when archive_write_open_filename fails

items.content: If there's a way to free the archive structure without having to call archive_write_finish(), then this is not a problem. What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. archive_write_open_filename() fails (file was locked by Windows) 2. archive_write_finish() is called to free allocated memory What is the expected output? What do you see instead? archive_write_finish() should free archive structure (including internal buffer), but it terminates (crash) in archive_write_zip_finish(). archive.compressor member variables are mostly NULL due to failed initialization. What version are you using? 2.8.4 On what operating system? Windows XP Professional (32-bit) How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) cmake What compiler or development environment (please include version)? Visual Studio 2005 Professional Please provide any additional information below. Zip format was used. Also, file_close() attempts to close the file even if the file descriptor is -1.
I recall fixing an issue similar to this recently; please try libarchive trunk and let me know if that has the same problem.  If not, I'll track down the exact fix and backport it to the 2.8 branch.

Thanks for reporting this.

I believe the short patch attached to this comment will fix the problem you're seeing.  I'll include this in the 2.8 branch in SVN and it will be part of any future 2.8 point release.

Fix committed to 2.8 branch.

Note that trunk has a more complete solution to this problem.

items.title: archive_write_data_block does not defined for archives
items.summary: archive_write_data_block does not defined for archives

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? archive_write_new() archive_write_set_format_zip archive_write_add_filter_none ... create entry archive_write_header archive_write_data_block What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Expected: write data. See: access violation. What version are you using? trunk On what operating system? Windows 7 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) cmake What compiler or development environment (please include version)? VisualStudio 2010 Additional information. Function archive_write_vtable(void) in file archive_write.c does not fill archive_write_data_block field. When I call archive_write_data_block then got access violation (call by NULL pointer). If archive_write_data_block does not applicable to write archives (only for disks) then it must be defined in documentation.

I've updated the documentation to document this limitation.
I've also changed the virtual dispatch to return an error if the function isn't available on a particular handle.

I would like to support archive_write_data_block for archives.  If you would like to help implement this, please let me know.

Thank you for reporting this!

items.title: archive_read_open_filename fails on windows 7
items.summary: archive_read_open_filename fails on windows 7

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? Use the API this way: a = archive_read_new(); archive_read_support_compression_all(a); archive_read_support_format_raw(a); retval = archive_read_open_filename(a, input_filename, 4096); if (retval != ARCHIVE_OK) { printf("error:%s", archive_error_string(a)); } ... It works fine on Linux but fails on windows 7. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? It should not fail if the file opens correctly. What version are you using? libarchive 2.8.4 On what operating system? windows 7 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) cmake What compiler or development environment (please include version)? visual studio 2008 Please provide any additional information below. archive_read_open_filename gives me the error "Can't initialise filter". Tracing it comes from __archive_create_child that returns -1;
Seems tight to an issue with zlib; update once I have news. However the error message could be improved to reflect it.
The error tells you that you are not using the integrated compression handling and it tried to execute gzip. As such the error is pretty precise...

Thanks for the quick update. However, really without your explanations I could hardly know what it meant.

Anyway, this is it, so thank you!

Perhaps we could find a clearer way to word the message.  How about

   "Unable to run '<program>'"

Yes, "Can't initialize filter, unable to run '<program>'!" would be just perfect.

Thanks.

r2962 changes this error message for libarchive/trunk.

Thanks for the feedback!

items.title: archive_write_header breaks with Segmentation fault
items.summary: archive_write_header breaks with Segmentation fault

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? struct archive *b=archive_write_new(),*c=archive_read_disk_new(); struct archive_entry *entry; //setting compress and format of b if(archive_write_open_filename(b,selfpath.c_str())==ARCHIVE_OK){ archive_read_disk_set_standard_lookup(c); entry = archive_entry_new(); archive_entry_copy_sourcepath(entry, path); archive_read_disk_entry_from_file(c, entry, fd, NULL); archive_write_header(b, entry); // this method make seqfault and set the archive of 0 byte while ((bytes_read = read(fd, buff, sizeof(buff))) > 0) archive_write_data(b, buff, bytes_read); archive_write_finish_entry(b); archive_read_finish(c); archive_write_finish(b); } What version are you using? 2.8.4 On what operating system? linux natty 64bit How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) pre-packaged binary What compiler or development environment (please include version)? g++ 4.6

There are several things missing here:
   * You haven't set the format on the write handle with archive_write_set_format_ustar() or one of the other format setting functions.
   * You haven't opened the fd.
   * You haven't set the pathname.  ("pathname" is the name written to the archive; "sourcepath" is used in a few places where the name on disk and the name going into the archive are different).

I've made a couple of changes to libarchive trunk to hopefully help people better detect errors such as these.  If you have any suggestions for how to improve the error handling or documentation, please let me know.

i used the3 example from ManPageArchiveReadDisk3 there are  no set pathname func in the example

and the pathname was the only think i miss :/

PS: it makes segfaults if the archive file did not exist
the segfault is gone, i forget to init the format value
I corrected the example on ManPageArchiveReadDisk3 to use pathname instead of sourcepath.  Thank you.

I had the same problem and I have to say that I'd rather libarchive would not crash because I forgot at some point to call a function. We plan to use it in sensitive server code and that means we will wrap it into its own clases and libraries to avoid such mistakes.... Too bad.

Please try libarchive/trunk if you get a chance.

There have been some major changes to how libarchive handles errors.  In particular, programmer errors of this sort are handled with sticky ARCHIVE_FATAL return values rather than calling abort().

If you have other ideas for improvement, patches are always appreciated.

items.title: Work around broken PSXCRT headers
items.summary: Work around broken PSXCRT headers

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. A system implementation of getopt() (BSD, POSIX std) 2. macros controlling use of system visavi local implementation of which getopt to use. The effect of this force a restriction to use the names getopt, option, optarg, opterr, optind, optopt 3. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? sucessful build. Compiler error What version are you using? current SVN On what operating system? NT POSIX subsystem (SUA) aka Interix on Windows 2008 R2 x64 $ uname -a Interix max 6.1 10.0.7063.0 genuineintel Intel64_Family_6_Model_26_Stepping_4 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) VPATH configure, gmake What compiler or development environment (please include version)? Interix gcc-3.3, MS C/C++ x64 compiler Version 16.00.30319.01 Please provide any additional information below. I attach my getopt header file which very much explains the issue. This is not a bug in libarchive of course. All is due to clashes between system BSD getopt and GNU getopt. Since you use a local implementation of getopt, you can avoid issues like this by not using struct bsdtar:optarg, static struct option tar_longopts. Please rename to e.g. struct bsdtar:optionarg, static struct bsdtar_option tar_longopts.
Here is a suggestion patch
Additional suggestion patch

Do you know why the getopt.h header is being included at all?
None of the libarchive, bsdtar, or bsdcpio sources include getopt.h, so I don't quite understand why you see a conflict.

I'll look at your suggested patches more closely soon.

getopt.h is included by unistd.h, mostly to leave out the cumbersome issue with multiple getopt implementations from unistd.h. Even if getopt wouldn't be included, you still need optarg, opterr, optind, optopt and getopt specified in unistd.h due to POSIX specification.

Note: My headers are PSXCRT SUA replacement headers, not the official Interix SDK headers. PSXCRT headers are generated from the Open Group Specifications IEEE Std 1003.1-2008 (database generated), are Interix SDK compatible and aims toward NetBSD compatibility.
Macro versions of optind etc that don't expand to plain names consistently are IMO just broken. There is also no reason for having different optinds for BSD getopt vs GNU getopt.

First, as I said, this is not a bug, just perhaps an inconvenience issue. I had to change the source to get libarchive to compile. I'm just asking if a change is possible and not too extensive.

As for the macros (off topic): There are OS specific reasons to not expose global data other through functions. It's a choice by design. Just consider errno in a multithreaded application, in NT POSIX, the system keeps track of a function pointer to the correct errno variable (specified in the startup source). In most cases it works well and if some project tries to manipulate e.g. environ, the compiler will tell you right away. Many GNU projects (e.g. binutils, GNU make) have a local getopt without the GNUlib replacement macros. You will get a conflict between the system getopt global data and the local implementation (and if you don't - how to be sure which data is used?).

I've gone ahead and committed a variant of your suggested patches in r2979.  Please let me know if you see additional problems.

Please also complain to the PSXCRT developers.  Libarchive has been building cleanly on NetBSD for quite some time, so the PSXCRT folks are clearly failing in their aim of NetBSD compatibility.

updates.summary: Work around broken PSXCRT headers

items.content: Thanks

items.title: ruby wrapper problems
items.summary: ruby wrapper problems

items.content: i build a smouth ruby wrapper for libarchive but some functions are missing: *how to add a file without deleting the others? *how to delete specific entries *how to move a file to an other archiv? (extract2 did not work) i do not know what i must do What version are you using? 2.6.4 On what operating system? ubutu natty 64bit How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) pre-packaged binary What compiler or development environment (please include version)? g++ 4.6

"how to add a file without deleting the others"

If you want to update tar or cpio archive formats, you should look at the code in bsdtar/write.c that supports the -r and -u options.  It is neither simple nor fast.  If you want to add files to Zip archives, I suggest you look at zziplib or some other library designed specifically for Zip support.

"how to delete specific entries"

Libarchive does not directly support "in place" modification of archives.  In particular, it does not support deleting or modifying existing entries.

"how to move a file to an other archive"

You should look at examples/tarfilter.c, which is a simple example showing how to build a new archive by selectively copying and/or modifying entries from another archive.

"how to add a file without deleting the others"
it is possible with libachive? or chould i add this?

"how to delete specific entries"
is the in place modification planned?


the modification: it is posible to open archive, collect all data and headers, and write it back? this is the possible way or?

"how to move a file to an other archive"
i try the function extract2 but this did not work



i whould help you if i can

"the modification: it is posible to open archive, collect all data and headers, and write it back? this is the possible way or?"

This is essentially what examples/tarfilter.c shows how to do.  It does it by reading one archive and writing a new archive to a separate file.  You could use this approach and then delete/rename the archive files.

Questions like this are best asked on libarchive-discuss@googlegroups.com mailing list.

items.title: second archive_read_close() after archive_read_open_filename segfaults
items.summary: second archive_read_close() after archive_read_open_filename segfaults

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? #include <archive.h> int main(int argc, char **argv) { struct archive *a = archive_read_new(); archive_read_open_filename(a, NULL, 0); archive_read_close(a); archive_read_close(a); /* free(NULL) */ archive_read_finish(a); return 0; } What is the expected output? What do you see instead? it should either succeed (i wanted the archived closed, it's closed, everybody wins) or fail (archive_read_close() cannot close it when it's already closed). i lean slightly towards ARCHIVE_OK, ARCHIVE_WARN could also work. What version are you using? trunk @ r2988 On what operating system? freebsd 9 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) ./build/autogen.sh && ./configure && make check What compiler or development environment (please include version)? gcc 4.2.1 20070719 [FreeBSD] Please provide any additional information below. attached are three tests demonstrating the crash (no segfault without archive_read_open_*()), and a fix.

Thank you again!

Committed at r2996.

The tests were well-done, thank you very much.

Note that your suggested fix wasn't quite right:  A libarchive user is allowed to provide a data handle of NULL (this might be appropriate if they were relying on global state, for example).  Instead, I added an additional check on the archive->state value, which is set to CLOSED after an archive is closed.

items.title: archive_read_next_header on empty raw file returns ARCHIVE_FATAL, should be ARCHIVE_EOF
items.summary: archive_read_next_header on empty raw file returns ARCHIVE_FATAL, should be ARCHIVE_EOF

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? struct archive* a = archive_read_new(); struct archive_entry* e; archive_read_support_format_raw(a); archive_read_open_filename(a, MYFILE, 0); archive_read_next_header(a, &e); /* ARCHIVE_FATAL */ archive_read_finish(a); What is the expected output? What do you see instead? i expect ARCHIVE_EOF What version are you using? trunk @ r2988 On what operating system? FreeBSD 9 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) configure What compiler or development environment (please include version)? Please provide any additional information below. please review the attached tests. i have no fix for this problem.

Good catch!

Your test is slightly off:  The raw handler is not supposed to recognize empty files.  Only the "empty" handler recognizes empty files.  (There are many formats for which an empty file is valid, so it creates problems if you allow other format handlers to accept empty files.)

But after fixing your test (see attached), there is a real bug here:  A file that's not recognized by any handler should cause ARCHIVE_FATAL when you try to open it.  It looks like archive_read_open() might not be correctly returning errors when there's no successful bidder.

  9: test_archive_read_next_header_empty
/Users/tim/projects/libarchive/trunk/libarchive/test/test_archive_read_next_header_empty.c:40: ARCHIVE_FATAL != archive_read_open_filename(a, "emptyfile", 0)
      ARCHIVE_FATAL=-30 (0xffffffffffffffe2, 01777777777777777777742)
      archive_read_open_filename(a, "emptyfile", 0)=0 (0x0, 00)


I've changed your test a little:  I combined your tests into one C source file and also just created the files in the test rather than storing them as UUencoded reference files.

Fixed in trunk r3009 by moving the format detection into archive_read_open2() so that an unsupported format is reported earlier.

As a rule, we want to report errors as early as we can; Roman's proposed test pointed out that we weren't reporting an unsupported format until there was an attempt to read the first header.

What do you see instead? Expected: #mtree tc /set flags=uchg tc/a /unset flags tc/b Actual: #mtree tc /set flags=uchg tc/a tc/b Which applies uchg flag also to tc/b. What version are you using? % tar --version bsdtar 2.7.0 - libarchive 2.7.0 % /usr/local/bin/bsdtar --version bsdtar 2.8.3 - libarchive 2.8.3 On what operating system? % uname -v FreeBSD 8.2-STABLE #1: Wed Mar 2 17:18:23 CET 2011

Thank you for the reporting this issue.

tc
/set flags=uchg
tc/a
tc/b flags=none

items.title: Fix detection of iconv
items.summary: Fix detection of iconv

items.content: See Issue 146
Sorry for duplicating issue 146 but this is the first time I was using "Suggest patch" feature of Google Code and I didn't really knew what exactly would happen.
Issue 146 has been merged into this issue.

Committed as r3014.

I believe iconv detection is still broken on FreeBSD 9, though, and probably other platforms.  I think CMakeLists.txt has a more robust solution to this problem.

Gettext comes with robust iconv macros:
http://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/gettext.git/tree/gettext-runtime/m4/iconv.m4

> Gettext comes with robust iconv macros:
> http://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/gettext.git/tree/gettext-runtime/m4/iconv.m4

Thanks for the pointer!  Those iconv macros look like they might work very well.

If anyone has time to work up patches to integrate these into libarchive, it would be appreciated.

AM_ICONV defined in iconv.m4 requires config.rpath

I had to do following works in order to use it.
 1. copy /usr/src/contrib/tcsh/config.rpath to build/autoconf
 2. perform chmod +x build/autoconf/config.rpath
 3. apply a patch to build/clean.sh.
 4. perform sh build/autogen.sh

diff -r dfcc199f3cf4 build/clean.sh
--- a/build/clean.sh    Wed Mar 16 15:01:22 2011 +0900
+++ b/build/clean.sh    Wed Mar 16 20:55:38 2011 +0900
@@ -51,7 +51,8 @@
 rm -f bsdtar
 rm -f bsdtar_test
 rm -f build/autoconf/compile
-rm -f build/autoconf/config.*
+rm -f build/autoconf/config.guess
+rm -f build/autoconf/config.sub
 rm -f build/autoconf/depcomp
 rm -f build/autoconf/install-sh
 rm -f build/autoconf/libtool.m4

I am not sure this approach is right. Does anyone know a general way for config.rpath?

The upstream project for config.rpath seems to be gnulib (http://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/gnulib.git/tree/build-aux/config.rpath), it has gnulib-tool that generates it.
Gettext's autogen.sh script will fetch gnulib from git if necessary.

Running gettextize looks to be the canonical way to get config.rpath into your project but it will generate a lot of useless crap which you probably don't want.

So copying is probably the best way (that's what tcsh did). It also makes sense to use latest version from above url and maybe record somewhere list of url's for imported files to make updating them easier.

Or you can just drop autocrap. Cmake is quite popular nowadays ;)

Tanks for information about config.rpath

I brought it from http://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/gnulib.git/plain/build-aux/config.rpath to our trunk in r3027.

FYI:  This is failing on Mac OS X for me.  It seems to be trying to use /opt/local/lib/libiconv.dylib (GNU iconv installed through DarwinPorts) instead of /usr/lib/libiconv.dylib (system iconv).  I believe this is causing mismatches with the system iconv.h.
Can you compile latest gettext on your Mac ?

Haven't dug very deeply, but the latest GNU gettext sources do build properly on my Mac.

Further, it appears to link against the system -liconv, not the GNU iconv installed through Darwin Ports.

On Ubuntu I got following error when I executed build/autogen.sh

+ aclocal -I build/autoconf
configure.ac:240: warning: AC_LIB_PREPARE_PREFIX is m4_require'd but not m4_defun'd
build/autoconf/iconv.m4:9: AM_ICONV_LINKFLAGS_BODY is expanded from...

+ uname
+ libtoolize --automake -c
+ autoconf

build/autoconf/iconv.m4:20: AM_ICONV_LINK is expanded from...
build/autoconf/iconv.m4:225: AM_ICONV is expanded from...
configure.ac:240: the top level

      If this token and others are legitimate, please use m4_pattern_allow.
      See the Autoconf documentation.

configure:12323: error: possibly undefined macro: AC_LIB_LINKFLAGS_BODY

I had to copy three files, lib-prefix.m4/lib-link.m4/lib-ld.m4, from
 http://git.savannah.gnu.org/cgit/gnulib.git/tree/m4 into build/autoconf
to make configure. So we should commit those files.
I think this has finally been fixed.  I'll mark it "Fixed' now; we can re-open it if I'm wrong.

items.title: archive_read_next_header with raw format doesn't consume data, test
items.summary: archive_read_next_header with raw format doesn't consume data, test

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. archive_read.3 says the raw format "treats any data stream as an archive with a single entry" 2. second archive_read_next_header() call on a raw archive returns ARCHIVE_OK What version are you using? trunk BTW, http://code.google.com/p/libarchive/wiki/Examples says that "archive_read_data_skip() [...] is not actually necessary, since libarchive will invoke it automatically if you request the next header without reading the data for the last entry". this crucial bit of info is missing from archive_read.3.

Committed your test (and my fix for the bug) in r3039.

I'll also update archive_read.3.
Updated archive_read.3 in r3041.

items.title: archive_read_free does not properly close a file descriptor after ARCHIVE_FATAL error happend
items.summary: archive_read_free does not properly close a file descriptor after ARCHIVE_FATAL error happend

items.content:
test_empty_file1() in test_archive_read_next_header_empty.c left a file descriptor open.

archive_read_free() did not call archive_read_close() because the result of
performing archive_read_open_filename(a, "emptyfile", 0) failed and 
its return code was ARCHIVE_FATAL.
There is no way to close the file "emptyfile" in such cases.

Good catch!  I had to think a little about the contract here:
Because close() functions also release memory, they should always be called
exactly once in all cases.

I believe this is fixed in r3079.

items.title: Some Zip files can't be read in a streaming fashion
items.summary: Some Zip files can't be read in a streaming fashion

items.content:
Hi,

when i try to extract files from an XPS file created by 64bit windows 2003 with test-gxps which is in libgxps(git://git.gnome.org/libgxps), error returned:
Error: ZIP compressed data is wrong size

the libgxps extract xps files by using libarchive.
but i can uncompress it by using unzip aaaaaa.xps successfully.
unzip aaaaaa.xps 
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>
Archive:  aaaaaa.xps
  inflating: Metadata/Job_PT.xml     
  inflating: Metadata/MXDC_Empty_PT.xml  
 extracting: Documents/1/Metadata/Page1_Thumbnail.JPG  
  inflating: Documents/1/Pages/_rels/1.fpage.rels  
  inflating: Documents/1/Pages/1.fpage  
  inflating: Documents/1/Resources/Fonts/3DFDBC8B-4514-41F1-A808-DEA1C79BAC2B.odttf  
  inflating: Documents/1/_rels/FixedDocument.fdoc.rels  
  inflating: Documents/1/FixedDocument.fdoc  
  inflating: _rels/FixedDocumentSequence.fdseq.rels  
  inflating: FixedDocumentSequence.fdseq  
  inflating: _rels/.rels             
  inflating: [Content_Types].xml     


then i compress all the files with zip:
zip aaa.zip  -r *
>>>>>>>>>>>>>>
updating: [Content_Types].xml (deflated 63%)
updating: Documents/ (stored 0%)
updating: FixedDocumentSequence.fdseq (deflated 26%)
updating: Metadata/ (stored 0%)
updating: _rels/ (stored 0%)
  adding: Documents/1/ (stored 0%)
  adding: Documents/1/Metadata/ (stored 0%)
  adding: Documents/1/Metadata/Page1_Thumbnail.JPG (deflated 61%)
  adding: Documents/1/Pages/ (stored 0%)
  adding: Documents/1/Pages/_rels/ (stored 0%)
  adding: Documents/1/Pages/_rels/1.fpage.rels (deflated 27%)
  adding: Documents/1/Pages/1.fpage (deflated 57%)
  adding: Documents/1/_rels/ (stored 0%)
  adding: Documents/1/_rels/FixedDocument.fdoc.rels (deflated 27%)
  adding: Documents/1/Resources/ (stored 0%)
  adding: Documents/1/Resources/Fonts/ (stored 0%)
  adding: Documents/1/Resources/Fonts/3DFDBC8B-4514-41F1-A808-DEA1C79BAC2B.odttf (deflated 98%)
  adding: Documents/1/FixedDocument.fdoc (deflated 17%)
  adding: Metadata/MXDC_Empty_PT.xml (deflated 54%)
  adding: Metadata/Job_PT.xml (deflated 73%)
  adding: _rels/FixedDocumentSequence.fdseq.rels (deflated 28%)
  adding: _rels/.rels (deflated 45%)

this time, i can use test-gxps to extract aaa.zip and view it.
is there someting wrong with libarchive to uncompress zip file created by windows 2003 64bit?


Cheers,

Flos

Thank you for reporting this issue.

I checked out your zip file, aaaaaa.xps.
Both compressed size and uncompress size in local file headers of the zip file are all zero
and Documents/1/Metadata/Page1_Thumbnail.JPG is just stored(no compressed).
This case libarchive cannot handle it. It needs to read central directory
placed at the end of the zip file in order to get the real size of the JPG file.
libarchive is designed as streaming reader and writer, and so libarchive
cannot read such a zip file at this time.
We have already had the idea to cope with these matters but not yet implemented.

Hi ggcueroad,

thank you very much for your explanation! :D
the libarchive is very useful indeed. ok, i'll cc this topic to the author of libgxps.

Flos

Changing the summary for this issue so it will be clearer in the future.

It should be easy for the authors of libgxps to write Zip files that libarchive can read; they just need to specify the uncompressed size in the local file header (since they're storing the file uncompressed anyway, this should be easy to do).  If they want to use Deflate compression, they'll want to set the "CRC at end" bit and libarchive will then read the compressed contents until it finds the end-of-data marker.

As Michihiro mentioned, we would like to add the ability for libarchive to read Zip files by using the Central directory, but it requires some rearchitecting.

updates.summary: Some Zip files can't be read in a streaming fashion

items.content:
Libarchive now has a Zip reader that can handle these Zip files.

This new reader requires that the libarchive client provide a seek function; without the seek function, libarchive will use the old non-seeking reader.  (And since these files cannot be read without seeking, that will fail.)  Please try the newest libarchive/trunk and please let us know if this works for you.

After spending a couple of days with this, I realized that it is in fact feasible to read this type of file even in streaming mode.  I just committed some additional changes to libarchive that seem to correctly support this type of file even when using the streaming reader.

/project/libarchive/libarchive/libarchive/test/test_archive_read_support.h:37: 0 != archive_errno(a)
      0=0 (0x0, 00)

    errno: -1
   detail: Xar not supported on this platform
/project/libarchive/libarchive/libarchive/test/test_archive_read_support.h:36: Summary: Failed 2 times
/project/libarchive/libarchive/libarchive/test/test_archive_read_support.h:37: Summary: Failed 2 times

The format and filter support functions return ARCHIVE_WARN if the filter or format isn't "fully supported" on this platform.  This usually means that some library was not available at compile time, so the filter or format may work but only in a limited fashion.  For example, the gzip filter will try to use the gzip command-line program if it's compiled without zlib.

The attached patch should address this for the specific case described above.  Similar logic should be used in test_archive_read_support_filter_torture for gzip, bzip2, lzip, lzma, and xz.

   detail: Xar not supported on this platform

items.title: tar - multiple problems on Mac OS
items.summary: tar - multiple problems on Mac OS

items.content: I have reported the same problems to apple, http://openradar.appspot.com/9328765 I haven't tested with any recent version of tar. What steps will reproduce the problem? See if you can get my unittests working on your box. https://github.com/neoneye/AnalyzeCopy Feel free to write to me if you need help. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? I expected tar to pass all my tests, but had issues in 7 tests. See the row near the bottom that says 04_tar. http://www.flickr.com/photos/12739382@N04/4980416255/sizes/o/in/set-72157617780381352/ issue#1 - ascii letters in filename https://github.com/neoneye/AnalyzeCopy/blob/master/Tests/30_ascii_names.rb issue#2 - empty extended attributes https://github.com/neoneye/AnalyzeCopy/blob/master/Tests/70_extended_attributes.rb issue#3 - birthtime https://github.com/neoneye/AnalyzeCopy/blob/master/Tests/72_birthtime.rb issue#4 - creation+modified date before/after epoch not copied https://github.com/neoneye/AnalyzeCopy/blob/master/Tests/80_epoch.rb issue#5 - acl on brokensymlink https://github.com/neoneye/AnalyzeCopy/blob/master/Tests/82_symlink_acl.rb issue#6 - hardlinked dirs https://github.com/neoneye/AnalyzeCopy/blob/master/Tests/90_hardlink_dir.rb issue#7 - backup time https://github.com/neoneye/AnalyzeCopy/blob/master/Tests/91_bkuptime.rb What version are you using? bsdtar 2.6.2 (libarchive 2.6.2) On what operating system? Mac OS X 10.6.4 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) pre-packaged binary that came with os x What compiler or development environment (please include version)? none Please provide any additional information below. The testsuite tests lots of other libarchive tools. Dunno if this is the place to report all of them.

Thank you for reporting this!

Just to be clear, it appears this is all specific to Mac OS?

Is this the version of bsdtar that shipped with Mac OS X 10.6?  (which has several Apple patches applied and is not quite the same as the standard bsdtar 2.6.2 release).

It would obviously be nice to repeat these tests against newer releases.

This is the right place to report any failures in libarchive, bsdtar, bsdcpio, or related tools.  It's best if you can report one problem in each separate issue; that makes it easier to track work on each separate issue.

But we definitely appreciate the feedback.  (I used Elizabeth Zwicky's test to exercise an older version of the libarchive tools; it was very helpful, and I'm glad to see other people building on her excellent work.)

Yes that is the standard bsdtar that came with 10.6.4.

Yes, most of them are mac specific.  Maybe except for 30_ascii_names.rb.

I have recently started coding on my file manager again, so perhaps I soon will run some tests again.

ttyl :-)

I've downloaded your test suite and diagnosed some of the failures.  Here is my understanding so far:

Test 30:  bsdtar 2.6.2 appears to be reluctant to archive a file named "._".  I've filed this as Issue 156 to track further work on this issue.  I would suggest you split this into a separate test, since this is related to an Apple convention for using "._" as a special file prefix.

Test 70:  I've reproduced this but not yet diagnosed it.

Test 72:  For portability reasons, tar does not archive "birthtime" attributes in the default format.  Adding --format=pax to the tar command line when creating the archive fixes this.

Test 80:  This test is also stumbling over "birthtime" handling (the test failure here has nothing to do with the epoch).  As above, adding --format=pax to the tar command line when creating the archive fixes this.

Test 82, 90, 91:  I've not yet reproduced these here.  Apparently, these tests rely on tools I don't (yet) have installed.  Looking at the source for these tests, 90 and 91 appear to be features missing in libarchive, which doesn't support backup time or hardlinked directories.  I don't have any theory about Test 82 yet.

I'll add more information to this Issue as I get more information.

It had time to do anything else this morning, so here is the lastest results
http://www.flickr.com/photos/12739382@N04/5648437023/sizes/o/in/photostream/

birthtime and epoch tests are now satisfied  :-)
http://www.flickr.com/photos/12739382@N04/5655011037/sizes/o/in/photostream/

I've filed separate issues for the various pieces, so I'm going to close this issue as a duplicate of those other issues:

   Issue 156 - bsdtar 2.6.2 does not archive a file named "._" on Mac OS
   Issue 227 - MacOS extended attribute
   Issue 228 - MacOS: bsdtar 2.6.2 drops ACLs on broken symlinks
   Issue 229 - MacOS: bsdtar doesn't save/restore hard linked directories
   Issue 230 - MacOS: bsdtar doesn't save/restore bkuptime

Of these, Issue 227, Issue 228, and Issue 229 look like things that are probably straightforward to fix.  Issue 156 might be complicated because of how copyfile() works (and I'm not eager to duplicate copyfile()).  Issue 230 is probably easy, but may not be worth the effort for reasons described in that bug.

items.title: bsdtar 2.6.2 does not archive a file named "._" on Mac OS
items.summary: bsdtar 2.6.2 does not archive a file named "._" on Mac OS

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? Create a file named "._" tar cpf output.tar . What is the expected output? What do you see instead? The resulting archive does not contain an entry for "._" This was discovered by Simon Strandgaard and reported as part of Issue 155. I suspect this is due to a conflict with the Apple convention of using "._" as a file prefix for an AppleDouble-encoded resource fork in tar archives. I suspect it only occurs on Mac OS. I have not yet tested to see if the issue still appears in libarchive 3.
Move this issue back to "New" status since I'm not actively working on it.

items.title: Build of svn trunk fails with gcc 4.6
items.summary: Build of svn trunk fails with gcc 4.6

items.content:
The first two hunks are uninitialized variable warnings, of which the first looks like a not smart enough compiler, although this doesn't seem provable. The second hunk seems to me the best way to solve the problem of r being left uninitialized with unexpected inputs.

The third hunk seems to be a more serious problem- we go through the work of forming a three character temporary buffer (two chars plus a null byte) and then we don't use it at all, instead possibly walking off the end of our input string if there was only one character remaining. This was caught by an unused variable warning.

Committed.

Thanks!

items.title: Display a warning when UID/GID Overflows
items.summary: Display a warning when UID/GID Overflows

items.content: Minix UIDs are 16 bits and Minix GIDs are 8 bits. The highest allowable UIDs and GIDs in tar archives are much higher than the highest UIDs/GIDs supported by Minix. This causes a truncation/overflow when the owner of the file in the archive has a high uid/gid. We want a warning to be displayed when a truncation happens so that the user will know the UID/GID of the extracted files will be different than that of the UID/GID in the archive. What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Install libarchive via pkgsrc on Minix 2. Build tar using libarchive 3. Extract files from a tarball with a UID > 16-bits or a GID > 8-bits. You can create the tar archive with really high UIDs and GIDs on Linux. 4. Do an `ls` and see that the UID/GID was truncated. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? We want a warning like "uid 9999999 out of range; will be extracted as 99." What version are you using? 2.8.4 On what operating system? Minix 3.2.0 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) Built from pkgsrc using `bmake install`. From the Make file it looks like the configure options are --disable-bsdtar --without-expat --without-xml2 --disable-bsdcpio What compiler or development environment (please include version)? gcc 4.4.3 Please provide any additional information below. Patch attached.

This is a good idea but the implementation here won't work.

Libarchive is sometimes used to read archives without writing the results to disk.  For example, someone might be extracting the data to memory or writing the information to another archive.

The problem here is not reading the data from the archive, the problem occurs when writing it to disk.  You should look at archive_write_disk.c and have it return an error when it truncates a UID or GID when writing the file.

For reference, a few folks have asked that we follow a convention used elsewhere and use "nobody"/"nogroup" (or the platform equivalent) when extracting impossible user/group information.

The code you want to look at is archive_write_disk_set_standard_lookup.c.  The archive_write_disk.c code uses pluggable lookup functions to translate the uid/uname and gid/gname provided into appropriate platform-specific values.  The "standard" lookup functions are used by all of the stock tools (conceptually, they're just wrappers around the standard getpwuid and getgrgid, but they also handle lookup caching for performance).  You may need to take a careful look at error-handling here; I suspect some small rework will be needed to allow this code to pass warnings back up through the stack.

items.title: test failure for lzma and xz
items.summary: test failure for lzma and xz

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. install xz utils 5.0.3 from source with gcc 4.6.0 2. compile libarchive 2.8.4 from source 3. run the test suite What is the expected output? What do you see instead? failures in test_write_compress_lzma and test_write_compress_xz What version are you using? 2.8.4 On what operating system? linux from scratch, brand new (linux 2.6.39, eglibc 2.13, gcc 4.6.0) How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) configure? (if not, then the latest cmake) What compiler or development environment (please include version)? (linux 2.6.39, eglibc 2.13, gcc 4.6.0) Please provide any additional information below. the output files indicated that output had more bytes than input

I believe this is expected.  I think the check you're referring to was removed in a later version of libarchive because later versions of XZ utils changed the compression defaults, which does cause a higher compression level to result in slightly larger output than a lower compression level, at least for the data used in this test.

If you get a chance, please add the test_write_compress_lzma.log and test_write_compress_xz.log files to this bug to verify.

/tmp/libarchive_test.2011-07-07T18.52.35-000/test_write_compress_lzma.log:

libarchive/test/test_write_compress_lzma.c:191: Assertion failed: used2 > used1
   Description: Compression-level=0 wrote 689 bytes; default wrote 759 bytes

/tmp/libarchive_test.2011-07-07T18.52.35-000/test_write_compress_xz.log:

libarchive/test/test_write_compress_xz.c:199: Assertion failed: used2 > used1
   Description: Compression-level=0 wrote 736 bytes; default wrote 804 bytes

Yes, that is expected.  These particular checks have been removed from the current code in SVN.

Thanks for reporting the issue; the test will be fixed in the next release.

items.title: Memory corruption in "uuencode" decoder
items.summary: Memory corruption in "uuencode" decoder

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? Extract a .tar.gz or .tar.bz2 (or maybe any archive format) encoded in UUE cause memory corruptions. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? In the archive attached, there is the code source used and a small bash script to create test archives that reproduce the bugs (made from /dev/urandom). The 2.8.4 stable version of libarchive is used (download on this website, not a distrib package). Valgrind claims that invalid writes and read are done, and the program crashes with a libc memory corruption detection. A valgrind output is in the archive. A gdb backtrace is also included in the archive. Note that decoding the archive with uudecode and extracting it with tar works, so the test files are valid archive. On what operating system? Debian/sid. How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) CFLAGS="-ggdb3 -O0" ./configure --prefix=/usr/local What compiler or development environment (please include version)? GCC version 4.6.1 (Debian 4.6.1-3)

I believe the issue is fixed with this patch : 
http://public.geekou.info/libarchive_issue_163.patch .

The "ensure_in_buff_size" in archive_read_support_compression_uu.c only multiplied the size of the original buffer by 2 if it was too small, but didn't check that it was enough to handle the given size, hence the overflows.

Thank you for reporting this issue and pointing out where the bug is.
I fixed it in both trunk/ r3846 and release/2.8/ r3847.

items.title: Segmentation fault when reading a broken file.
items.summary: Segmentation fault when reading a broken file.

items.content:
The segmentation fault happened at line 432 in tar/util.c
when reading an attached file. I think a real problem is that archive_read_skip()
fails with ARCHIVE_FAILED in archive_read_next_header2() and bsdtar continues to
handle an entry object as if it were set in an error, but the fact is not,
just cleared by archive_entry_clear().

How should we solve it ?

Please take a look at libarchive/trunk r3833.

I agree there was a bug in how libarchive handled an error during the skip request.  I think this fixes it.
It seems nice. Thank you for your effort.

items.title: substitiion treats hardlinks as symlinks
items.summary: substitiion treats hardlinks as symlinks

items.content:
Extracting archives with substitution applied on hardlinks fails as shown below:

|=======
inflamm:16:/tmp$ cd /tmp                         
inflamm:16:/tmp$ mkdir -p ttt/sub && cp /etc/fstab ttt/ && ln ttt/fstab ttt/sub/
inflamm:16:/tmp$ bsdtar -c -v -f ttt.tar ttt
a ttt
a ttt/sub
a ttt/fstab
a ttt/sub/fstab
inflamm:16:/tmp$ bsdtar tvf ttt.tar
drwxr-xr-x  0 dieter wheel       0 Aug 10 10:02 ttt/
drwxr-xr-x  0 dieter wheel       0 Aug 10 10:02 ttt/sub/
-rw-r--r--  0 dieter wheel     372 Aug 10 10:02 ttt/fstab
hrw-r--r--  0 dieter wheel       0 Aug 10 10:02 ttt/sub/fstab link to ttt/fstab
inflamm:16:/tmp$ mkdir xx && cd xx
inflamm:16:/tmp/xx$ bsdtar -x -v -f ../ttt.tar -s ,ttt,mmm,
x mmm/
x mmm/sub/
x mmm/fstab
x mmm/sub/fstab: Can't create 'mmm/sub/fstab'
bsdtar: Error exit delayed from previous errors.
inflamm:16:/tmp/xx$ ls -ilR mmm
total 8
5730819 -rw-r--r--  1 dieter  wheel  372 Aug 10 10:02 fstab
5730818 drwxr-xr-x  2 dieter  wheel  512 Aug 10 10:02 sub

mmm/sub:
=======|

It would seem that the cause is a typo in tar/util.c; the following patch makes it work:
|======
--- tar/util.c.orig	2010-03-07 18:06:05.000000000 +0000
+++ tar/util.c
@@ -377,7 +377,7 @@ edit_pathname(struct bsdtar *bsdtar, str
 	}
 
 	if (archive_entry_hardlink(entry)) {
-		r = apply_substitution(bsdtar, archive_entry_hardlink(entry), &subst_name, 1);
+		r = apply_substitution(bsdtar, archive_entry_hardlink(entry), &subst_name, 0);
 		if (r == -1) {
 			lafe_warnc(0, "Invalid substitution, skipping entry");
 			return 1;
======|

resulting in:
|======
inflamm:16:/tmp/xx$ rm -r mmm
inflamm:16:/tmp/xx$ bsdtar_p -x -v -f ../ttt.tar -s ,ttt,mmm,
x mmm/
x mmm/sub/
x mmm/fstab
x mmm/sub/fstab
inflamm:16:/tmp/xx$ ls -ilR mmm 
total 8
5730819 -rw-r--r--  2 dieter  wheel  372 Aug 10 10:02 fstab
5730818 drwxr-xr-x  2 dieter  wheel  512 Aug 10 10:02 sub

mmm/sub:
total 4
5730819 -rw-r--r--  2 dieter  wheel  372 Aug 10 10:02 fstab
=======|

What version of bsdtar and/or libarchive are you using?

On what platform?

I just tried your test using the current libarchive/trunk on Mac OS X 10.6 and it seems to work just fine.

Sorry that I forgot to mention this. It's libarchive 2.8.4. I've tried it on NetBSD as well as on GNU/linux.

I've just now tried it with svn trunk on NetBSD, and it still fails in the same way.

Now I'm really confused:  I just downloaded NetBSD/i386 5.1 ISO, installed it under VMWare Fusion 3.1, used pkg_add to install svn and cmake, checked out and built libarchive/trunk.  Then:

# mkdir -p ttt/sub && cp /etc/fstab ttt/ && ln ttt/fstab ttt/sub/
# bin/bsdtar -cvf ttt.tar -s ,ttt,mmm, ttt
a mmm
a mmm/sub
a mmm/fstab
a mmm/sub/fstab
# bin/bsdtar xvf ttt.tar
x mmm/
x mmm/sub/
x mmm/fstab
x mmm/sub/fstab

And ls -i indicates that the mmm/fstab and mmm/sub/fstab files are indeed hardlinked.

I just tried again with the autoconf build (after installing autoconf, automake, and libtool), and it works correctly there as well.

Could you please:
  1) attach the broken tar archive to this bug report so I can see the constructed archive.
  2) Run the extract that fails under ktrace and look to see why the 'link' system call is failing (what are the arguments, what exactly is the return value).

Hmm, maybe I didn't explain this too well.
The steps to reproduce it are:

cd /tmp                         
mkdir -p ttt/sub && cp /etc/fstab ttt/ && ln ttt/fstab ttt/sub/
bsdtar -c -v -f ttt.tar ttt
mkdir xx && cd xx
bsdtar -x -v -f ../ttt.tar -s ,ttt,mmm,

I.e. it goes wrong when the substitution is performed on extraction, not on creation. There's nothing special (broken) about the created archive. (In fact, it could as well have been created with another tar implementation.)

What happens is that tar tries to link ttt/fstab to mmm/sub/fstab, which fails, because ttt/fstab is extraced as mmm/fstab.

kind regards
dieter

Ah.  I see now.  It appears that the current implementation uses a trailing 's' flag to enable regex substitutions on all links.  Which certainly seems a poor default.

This disagrees with both GNU tar (which uses 's' to enable regex substitutions on symlinks, 'h' for hardlinks, and enables both by default) and NetBSD tar (which uses 's' to disable regex substitutions on symlinks).

I recall that the bsdtar behavior was modeled on NetBSD tar.  I'm not sure whether we should reverse the sense of the current flag in bsdtar to match NetBSD tar (which is definitely a change that we can only make at a major version boundary!) or adopt the GNU tar flags (which provide more control for the user).

r3676 fixes the first problem here:  I've added a test to verify that symlink targets and hardlink targets both get rewritten by default and adjusted the code to agree with the test.  This makes bsdtar compatible with both NetBSD tar and GNU tar when no flags are present.

Right now, the trunk code uses 's' to disable both symlink and hardlink rewriting.  This agrees with NetBSD tar, but breaks compatibility with the previous version of bsdtar.  I'm tempted to adopt the GNU tar flags; if anyone else has opinions, I'd be interested.

I think adopting the GNU flags is a good idea. It makes more sense than disabling symlink and hardlink writing together. Except for special cases, disabling rewriting on hardlinks will almost always make the extraction fail.

By the way, NetBSD tar currently always performs rewriting on hard links. See the following (/tmp/i/bin/bsdtar is from libarchive trunk, tar is NetBSD's tar):

pavlov$ /tmp/i/bin/bsdtar -t -v -f ../tt2.tar          
drwxr-xr-x  0 dieter 0           0 Oct  1 15:09 tt2
-rw-r--r--  0 dieter 0           0 Oct  1 15:06 tt2/ab
-rw-r--r--  0 dieter 0           0 Oct  1 15:06 tt2/aab
-rw-r--r--  0 dieter 0           0 Oct  1 15:06 tt2/c link to tt2/ab
pavlov$ rm -fr tt2                                                             
pavlov$ /tmp/i/bin/bsdtar -x -f ../tt2.tar -s ,a,,s    
pavlov$ ls -l tt2/                                  
total 0
-rw-r--r--  2 dieter  wheel  0 Oct  1 15:06 ab
-rw-r--r--  1 dieter  wheel  0 Oct  1 15:06 b
-rw-r--r--  2 dieter  wheel  0 Oct  1 15:06 c
pavlov$ rm -fr tt2                                  
pavlov$ tar -x -f ../tt2.tar -s ,a,,s    
pavlov$ ls -l tt2/                       
total 0
-rw-r--r--  1 dieter  wheel  0 Oct  1 15:06 ab
-rw-r--r--  2 dieter  wheel  0 Oct  1 15:06 b
-rw-r--r--  2 dieter  wheel  0 Oct  1 15:06 c

I believe libarchive/trunk r3748 completely fixes this by implementing the GNU tar-style HRS (to disable) and hrs (to enable) hardlink, regular filename, and symlink substitutions.  I believe combinations of these characters are correctly handled, and that the default will always replace all three.

Please try it and let me know if you see any further problems.

items.title: Support reading from multiple data objects (multivolume reading)
items.summary: Support reading from multiple data objects (multivolume reading)

items.content:
RAR archives can be split into multiple files (to provide multivolume support). Each file contains the RAR signature header, a main archive header, and the optional EOF header. The data blocks are split arbitrarily between each file in a multivolume set of files. Currently, libarchive doesn't handle reading from multiple files.

This patch would introduce reading from multiple files by way of reading from multiple client objects. What would happen is that there is a chain of client objects, each with the callbacks and data necessary to open, read, skip, and close each object it's reading from (such as different files). Data is read from each of these clients as one large stream. I plan on implementing multivolume reading support of RAR files once general reading from multiple streams is accepted and committed to trunk.

I introduced a new callback (switch callback) that can be used to switch from reading of one client to the next or previous client. I needed some way to determine whether a file should be closed because it's going to open the next file, or if it's being closed because libarchive is done reading from the file set. The latter would mean that I also need to free all memory allocated for all data objects of each client.

I've introduced some test cases already for reading from these multiple clients. The test files are simply some reused test rar files that have been splitted using the 'split' program. There's also a test case for supplying custom callbacks and multiple client objects. This custom callbacks test case is essentially the way I see of using libarchive to read from multiple files with custom callbacks. I plan on using libarchive in this way in another application (XBMC).

This patch also updates test_fuzz so it can read from multiple files. Currently, the multiple files used in test_fuzz would have the same result as "test_read_format_rar.rar" would. Once I have RARv3 multivolume reading support implemented, this would provide a better test for test_fuzz.
I deleted the current patch as I found there were some memory leaks with the changes I was proposing. I'll post another patch soon.

Here's a new patch with the changes I'm proposing.

This is different from the last patch. Instead of using a doubly linked list of client objects, an array of void pointers inside a struct is used to maintain multiple data objects that will be used to chain multiple streams together. This should be an improvement as far as performance is concerned. Reading from multiple sources, such as multiple files in a multivolume file set, is done by giving libarchive multiple data objects. You can see the changes in archive_read_open_filename.c to see how reading from multiple file will work.

For the cases with archives that have been split using the 'split' program, all format readers will not require any change to read these files.

All existing functions and callbacks will perform the same tasks. The new 'switch' callback performs the operation of closing one file, and opening the next, without freeing the data objects given from a client (same proposed functionality as in the previous patch). There are now functions to set a data object at some index, add an object at an index, and append/prepend a data object in the array of data objects. I've not added functions to retrieve data objects at some index. Perhaps there should be, would welcome discussion on that.

The appropriate test cases are implemented including modifications to test_fuzz for testing multivolume files. All tests pass. Also, this timevthere are no memory leaks or any other memory related breakage.

Here's another patch that implements support for reading multivolume RAR files that have been split using RAR's mechanism for splitting RAR files. This patch applies after applying the 'multiple_data_objects.patch'

Test cases are also implemented and all pass.
I created a branch to make reviewing much easier I hope.

updates.summary: Support reading from multiple data objects (multivolume reading)

items.content:
Just a general ping.

Were there any other questions or concerns about these changes?
Oops, sorry. That last message is from me.
Ping

It feels like you're doing a lot more work than necessary to handle this particular case.

If you are just interested in handling files created by 'split', then you can do that by adding archive_read_open_filenames (which you've done), but you don't need to make any changes to archive_read.c at all.  Archive_read_open_filenames can keep a list of filenames and when it hits end-of-file on one, open the next file as necessary.  That doesn't require any changes to archive_read.c nor to the RAR reader, I don't think.

objects (multivolume reading)

particular case.

can do that by adding archive_read_open_filenames (which you've done), but
you don't need to make any changes to archive_read.c at all.
 Archive_read_open_filenames can keep a list of filenames and when it hits
end-of-file on one, open the next file as necessary.  That doesn't require
any changes to archive_read.c nor to the RAR reader, I don't think.

I will also need to supply my own list of IO handles (like for FILE).

Wow, I see the last comment got mangled.

So what I was trying to say, I want to make it possible for downstreams of libarchive to pass in their multiple IO handles (such as multiple FILE handles). Such is the case with XBMC which needs to be able to supply it's own callbacks and data objects.

Ping.

Any other questions/concerns about this issue?

My only concern is that your approach is overkill for what you want to do.

Since XBMC needs a custom reader anyway, that reader can itself keep a queue of data objects and start reading the next when one is complete.  There's nothing here so far that requires changes to archive_read.c.

Check the latest commits to the multivolume branch. I just fixed your last concern so that the error case is properly handled.

Also, some change in trunk that occurred between the summer and now has caused me to need a fix where I have to ensure the first data node is opened in archive_read_open1 after all bidding is done. It looks like I needed to make the changes in archive_read.c anyway. I'm not sure if I can implement multivolume support without touching archive_read.c.
Changes for this issue is now in the form of a pull request. See https://github.com/libarchive/libarchive/pull/2
Changes for this is now in the form of a pull request. See https://github.com/libarchive/libarchive/pull/2
Pull request has been merged.

items.title: Update bsdtar --owner and --group support
items.summary: Update bsdtar --owner and --group support

items.content:
GNU tar recently extended --owner and --group to support arbitrary names and ID values, for creating archives on systems with dissimilar user bases.  It's a nice idea and one that bsdtar should probably support.

Begin forwarded message:

From: Paul Eggert <eggert@cs.ucla.edu>
Date: August 13, 2011 10:29:23 AM PDT
To: Thayne Harbaugh <thayne.l.h@gmail.com>
Cc: 136231@bugs.debian.org, bug-tar@gnu.org
Subject: Re: [Bug-tar] Failure with --owner and --group when names cannot be	mapped to IDs

tar: --owner and --group names and numbers
The --owner and --group options now accept operands of the form
NAME:NUM, so that you can specify both symbolic name and numeric
ID for owner and group.  Also, in these options, NAME no longer
needs to be present in the current host's user and group
databases; this implements Debian enhancement request 136231
<http://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=136231> reported
by Mark W. Eichin, communicated by Thayne Harbaugh to bug-tar in
<http://lists.gnu.org/archive/html/bug-tar/2011-08/msg00001.html>.

bsdtar already has --gid, --gname, --uid, --uname options that provide the same functionality.  If someone wants to implement GNU tar-compatible --owner and --group options, I'm happy to review patches, but this isn't a priority for me.

items.title: Internal API changes for crypto support
items.summary: Internal API changes for crypto support

items.content:
RAR files can be encrypted. Before I started implementing crypto support for reading RAR files, I think it was best to do a small amount of housekeeping so that hash functions and cipher functions would be implemented from the same source file.

Here is a patch with the changes. A global struct of function pointers is used to hold all hash init, update, and final functions. The appropriate implementation from a crypto library is used based on availability and order of preference. The changes to autotools and cmake build system are for checking support of available crypto functionality, by checking if the new archive_crypto.c source file compiles and links against required libraries. There's now even a test case to ensure whatever implementation is chosen functions correctly.

The only changes to the rest of libarchive were for files that included archive_hash.h. They now include archive_crypto_private.h.

Forgot to mention the changes with openssl. Hash functions will go through the high level functions provided in openssl/evp.h. I made this change since I had planned on using openssl/evp.h for cipher functionality as well.

This looks good, though I would beef up the test a bit to try to catch some misconfigurations.  For example, I would change

#ifdef ARCHIVE_HAS_MD5

to

#if defined(ARCHIVE_HAS_MD5) || defined(_WIN32) || defined(__APPLE__) || defined(__FreeBSD__) || defined(__NetBSD__)

the latter will fail if the configuration logic fails to detect MD5 on platforms known to have such support.  Obviously, we can tinker a bit to tune this list.
Implemented the change in r3655. Fine tuning the tests will come later.

items.title: parsing ISO: read_entries() doesn't read child folders content
items.summary: parsing ISO: read_entries() doesn't read child folders content

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Write a file at the DVD. 2. Append a folder to the DVD, which must contain child folders and files. 3. Grab ISO-image. 4. While parsing ISO-image, folder content is missing. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Using ASHAMPOO BURNING STUDIO 6 FREE write file "abc.exe" on a clear DVD-RW. Then update DVD, apending folder 345, which contains subfolder "fld" with files. So windows explorer show DVD-disc structure normally: E:/abc.exe E:/345 E:/345/fld E:/345/fld/somefile ... Then grab ISO-image. While parsing ISO9660 using libarchive, folder 345 content becomes missing. It shows only: E:/abc.exe E:/345 What version are you using? 2.8.4 On what operating system? windows 7 sp1, vista, 2003, xp. How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) cmake What compiler or development environment (please include version)? MS Visual Studio 2008 Please provide any additional information below. POSSIBLE SOLUTION: module="archive_read_support_format_iso9660.c" function="read_entries(struct archive_read *a)" <current code> while ((file = next_entry(iso9660)) != NULL && (file->mode & AE_IFMT) == AE_IFDIR) { r = read_children(a, file); if (r != ARCHIVE_OK) return (r); </current code> <fixed code> while ((file = next_entry(iso9660)) != NULL) { if ((file->mode & AE_IFMT) == AE_IFDIR) { r = read_children(a, file); if (r != ARCHIVE_OK) return (r); } </fixed code>

I believe this is a duplicate of issue #168.

I believe the issue is fixed in the HEAD of the release/2.8 branch.  If you can test that, we would appreciate it.

If you have any small sample archives that we can include in the test suite, that could help.

What do you see instead? compile error What version are you using? 2.8.4 On what operating system? Windows 7 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) cmake What compiler or development environment (please include version)? MSVC 2010 Please provide any additional information below. The error is in the function archive_compressor_xz_init_stream in the file archive_write_set_compression_xz, The current code does: state->stream = (lzma_stream)LZMA_STREAM_INIT; This is an assignment and not an initialization. test_read_format_mtree

libarchive/test/test_read_format_mtree.c:130: archive_entry_mtime(ae) != min_int64
      archive_entry_mtime(ae)=0 (0x0, 00)
      min_int64=-9223372036854775808 (0x8000000000000000, 01000000000000000000000)
libarchive/test/test_read_format_mtree.c:134: archive_entry_mtime(ae) != min_int64

Thanks.  I did add some tests to verify the handling of very large values in mtree files.

Oh.  I see.  archive_entry_mtime() deals with time_t, and the test here uses a 64-bit value which overflows a 32-bit time_t.

I'll take another look at the mtree integer parsing; it should probably clip time values to the range of time_t.

Modified mtree code so that very old files return mtime() of TIME_T_MIN and very young files return mtime() of TIME_T_MAX.  Adjusted test to verify these (without making lots of unsubstantiated platform assumptions).

items.title: archive_compressor_program_finish returns failure on Windows when it actually succeeded
items.summary: archive_compressor_program_finish returns failure on Windows when it actually succeeded

items.content:
In the function archive_compressor_program_finish on Windows, it is very likely that the compressing program will terminate well before the call to waitpid.  When this happens, the call to OpenProcess in __la_waitpid will fail even though everything completed successfully.  This will result in the local variable status being unmodified which was never initialized in the first place and result in archive_compressor_program_finish failing.

This is happening when I run the test_write_compress_program on a Windows Vista 64 bit system and the test fails when it should not.

Thank you for your reporting.
I fixed this issue in libarchive/trunk r3706.
That initialize the variable `status' at the beginning of __la_waitpid.

I must admit it is not totally tiny, but does not much more than extract an included file. Qt is unfortunately required. I hope you can deal with it. Regards, Simon

Hello all,

Finally I realised it is the compiler flag, which is already mentioned in the source code of untar.c.
adding:
SET(CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS ${CMAKE_CXX_FLAGS} "-D_FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64")
in the CMakeLists.txt
or appending -D_FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64 to the gcc/g++ command line 
makes it work.
Issue may be closed, as it is no Software error..
The new libarchives got rid of the off_t, why they are independent from this flag..

Then I can still complain about the not-updated untar.c. In the actual SVN trunk it has still the "off_t offset" in line 203, although "int64_t offset" would be correct then.

Regards,

Simon
