items.title: bsdtar ignores mtree entries with missing content= files and does not exit with error and a non-zero status
items.summary: bsdtar ignores mtree entries with missing content= files and does not exit with error and a non-zero status

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? lizzy:/tmp% cat t #!/bin/sh mkdir dir date > dir/foo ls -l dir ( cat << EOT #mtree dir/myfoo type=file uid=0 gid=0 mode=0644 content=dir/foo EOT ) > m bsdtar -cf good.tar @m echo $? echo good: bsdtar -tvf good.tar ( cat << EOT #mtree dir/myfoo type=file uid=0 gid=0 mode=0644 content=dir/nothere EOT ) > m bsdtar -cf bad.tar @m echo $? echo bad: bsdtar -tvf bad.tar % What is the expected output? What do you see instead? An error message and a non-zero exit status upon encountering the faulty mtree specification (because it refers to a nonexistent file). Instead, the entry is silently ignored and bsdtar exits with a zero status. lizzy:/tmp% ./t FreeBSD lizzy 9.0-BETA2 FreeBSD 9.0-BETA2 #151: Tue Aug 30 10:13:26 PDT 2011 root@lizzy:/usr/obj/usr/src/sys/LIZZY i386 bsdtar 2.8.5 - libarchive 2.8.5 total 4 -rw-r--r-- 1 jos wheel 29 Sep 8 22:25 foo 0 good: -rw-r--r-- 0 0 0 29 Sep 8 22:25 dir/myfoo 0 bad: lizzy:/tmp% What version are you using? bsdtar 2.8.5 - libarchive 2.8.5 On what operating system? FreeBSD lizzy 9.0-BETA2 FreeBSD 9.0-BETA2 #151: Tue Aug 30 10:13:26 PDT 2011 root@lizzy:/usr/obj/usr/src/sys/LIZZY i386 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) configure What compiler or development environment (please include version)? lizzy:/tmp% gcc -v Using built-in specs. Target: i386-undermydesk-freebsd Configured with: FreeBSD/i386 system compiler Thread model: posix gcc version 4.2.2 20070831 prerelease [FreeBSD] lizzy:/tmp% Please provide any additional information below. I'm seeing the same problem on Linux (Funtoo) so it doesn't look like a platform issue.

I believe this has been recently fixed in libarchive/trunk by r3744, which fixes the error handling for @<archive>.

If you could repeat your test with libarchive/trunk, I would appreciate knowing if this fixes it for you.  You can also try applying the attached diff to the source for bsdtar 2.8.5.

r3748 works, but the error message is a little strange because we creating, not reading bad.tar:

lizzy:/tmp% bsdtar --version
bsdtar 3.0.0a - libarchive 3.0.0a
lizzy:/tmp% sh -x ./t 
+ mkdir dir
+ date
+ ls -l dir
total 4
-rw-r--r--  1 jos  wheel  29 Nov  4 22:55 foo
+ cat
+ bsdtar -cf good.tar @m
+ echo 0
0
+ echo good:
good:
+ bsdtar -tvf good.tar
-rw-r--r--  0 0      0          29 Nov  4 22:55 dir/myfoo
+ cat
+ bsdtar -cf bad.tar @m
bsdtar: Error reading archive m: Can't open dir/nothere
bsdtar: Error exit delayed from previous errors.
+ echo 1
1
+ echo bad:
bad:
+ bsdtar -tvf bad.tar
lizzy:/tmp% 

Thanks, Tim!

The error message says there is an error reading 'm', which is exactly correct.

If you can think of a better way to express this error, please let me know.
Oops, you're right, sorry. I was focusing on the wrong thing (archive creation). The message is fine. Again, thanks for fixing this, Tim.

items.title: Add libcdio as dependency and use it for ISO9660 and UDF (iso) files
items.summary: Add libcdio as dependency and use it for ISO9660 and UDF (iso) files

items.content:
Hi,

Currently libarchive supports reading and writing ISO9660 but there is no read nor write support for UDF thus miking it, at the moment, impossible to open an UDF iso without mounting it or using fuse.

Libcdio: http://www.gnu.org/software/libcdio/ is exactly there to support those formats and works for ISO9660, UDF, audio cd's and perhaps something else (didn't look into it that deep).

My proposal is to drop the current read support of ISO9660 and start using libcdio for that and UDF files. Another possibility is copying the UDF parts from libcdio if you really don't want a dependency on there.. I don't think that's the best way to go though.

Big advantage is that archive applications can be used to open udf iso files once this is implemented.

Regards,
Mark

Sorry, i pressed "Save changes" to quick. Please change the type to Enhancement.
Also this makes issue #27 obsolete once implemented.

I haven't looked deeply, but I did notice that cdio_open() requires a filename.

Libarchive can't use this.  It doesn't read files, it reads "streams", which can come from many sources, not just files.  See the archive_read man page for the description of archive_read_open():  http://code.google.com/p/libarchive/wiki/ManPageArchiveRead3

If libcdio can accomodate input sources other than files, then it may be possible to integrate.  Until that happens, programs that use libarchive can use libcdio beside it to handle ISO and UDF formats that libarchive can't handle.  Since libarchive's format modules are all optional, it's easy for a program to create a libarchive handle that recognizes formats other than ISO, ask libarchive to taste a new file and if that fails, try opening the file with libcdio.

But that's completely outside of libarchive proper.

If libcdio has some more flexible way of accessing the data, then it may be an option.

items.title: read_mtree() silently discards mtree specifications whose lines exceed 256 characters
items.summary: read_mtree() silently discards mtree specifications whose lines exceed 256 characters

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? While creating an archive, feed bsdtar an mtree file as input with at least one line exceeding 256 characters. This causes read_mtree() to return ARCHIVE_FATAL, which in turn causes read_header() to return ARCHIVE_FATAL. After that I lost track and couldn't determine why an error message is not generated, although that seems appropriate imo. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? An error message indicating invalid input. Nothing. An empty archive is created, and bsdtar exits non-zero. What version are you using? trunk, r3729 On what operating system? FreeBSD lizzy.catnook.local 9.0-BETA2 FreeBSD 9.0-BETA2 #164: Mon Sep 19 10:17:54 PDT 2011 root@lizzy.catnook.local:/usr/obj/usr/src/sys/LIZZY i386 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) configure What compiler or development environment (please include version)? Using built-in specs. Target: i386-undermydesk-freebsd Configured with: FreeBSD/i386 system compiler Thread model: posix gcc version 4.2.2 20070831 prerelease [FreeBSD] Please provide any additional information below. I'm not sure what the correct fix is. Ideally there should be enough room for the target archive filename and the content filename, both which can be of PATH_MAX size. For now I plan on using the following local patch at $WORK: Index: libarchive/archive_read_support_format_mtree.c =================================================================== --- libarchive/archive_read_support_format_mtree.c (revision 3732) +++ libarchive/archive_read_support_format_mtree.c (working copy) @@ -818,7 +818,7 @@ last_entry = NULL; for (counter = 1; ; ++counter) { - len = readline(a, mtree, &p, 256); + len = readline(a, mtree, &p, 3072); if (len == 0) { mtree->this_entry = mtree->entries; free_options(global);

Please try libarchive/trunk r3744.

I believe this fixes the tar bug which prevents the error message from being propagated all the way out.

If you can verify that, then I'll happily extend the line length used in the mtree reader.

In the failure case I now see:

bsdtar: Error reading archive (null): Line too long
bsdtar: Error exit delayed from previous errors.

and $? is 1. Much better :)

Please bump the line length in the mtree reader - I picked 3072 because it's at least 2 * PATH_MAX (destination and content= fields) plus leaving plenty of room for other metadata fields.

Thanks!

Thanks for helping to verify that.

I fixed the (null) display here and then bumped the line length limit to 64k.  (The limit is just a sanity-check in case we're reading something that's really malformed; there's no compelling reason to economize.)

items.title: libarchive allows an archive to be added to itself
items.summary: libarchive allows an archive to be added to itself

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? % ./bsdtar --version bsdtar 3.0.0a - libarchive 3.0.0a Create an archive: % touch foo; ./bsdtar cf a.tar foo Add the archive to itself: % ./bsdtar -cvf a.tar a.tar a a.tar The addition goes through successfully, without and error message. The resulting file has the following content: % ./bsdtar -tvf a.tar -rw-r--r-- 0 elftoolchain 0 0 Oct 30 14:02 a.tar What is the expected output? What do you see instead? An error message was expected. What version are you using? SVN -HEAD. On what operating system? NetBSD 5.0.2 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) % ./configure && make What compiler or development environment (please include version)? % uname -sr NetBSD 5.0.2 % gcc -v Using built-in specs. Target: i386--netbsdelf Configured with: /usr/src/tools/gcc/../../gnu/dist/gcc4/configure --enable-long-long --disable-multilib --enable-threads --disable-symvers --build=x86_64-unknown-netbsd4.99.72 --host=i386--netbsdelf --target=i386--netbsdelf --enable-__cxa_atexit Thread model: posix gcc version 4.1.3 20080704 prerelease (NetBSD nb2 20081120) Please provide any additional information below. In "libarchive/archive_write.c", the function _archive_write_header() assumes that the device ID for an archive file cannot be zero. if (a->skip_file_dev != 0 && archive_entry_dev(entry) == a->skip_file_dev && a->skip_file_ino != 0 && archive_entry_ino(entry) == a->skip_file_ino) { archive_set_error(&a->archive, 0, "Can't add archive to itself"); return (ARCHIVE_FAILED); } POSIX only requires that the dev_t type be a arithmetic type and does not place restrictions on the legal values of a dev_t type. In NetBSD, device IDs of zero are legal. % uname -sr NetBSD 5.0.2 % pwd /home/elftoolchain/trunk/ar % stat -f '%N: %d %Sd' ar.a ar.a: 0 wd0a % ls -l /dev/wd0a brw-r----- 1 root operator 0, 0 Aug 25 2010 /dev/wd0a Thus this error check will not work correctly on NetBSD. See also: http://sourceforge.net/apps/trac/elftoolchain/ticket/353

The attached patch makes the check in "archive_write.c" more portable.
With this patch, bsdtar behaves as expected:

  % ./bsdtar -cvf a.tar a.tar
  a a.tar: Can't add archive to itself

This patch is insufficient.  It works for bsdtar because bsdtar sets the 'skip_file_XXX' values and (on POSIX systems) always sets the dev/ino for each entry.  This is not true of all libarchive clients.  In particular, programs that generate contents in memory often skip these values; your patch would break such clients badly.

If any numeric dev_t value is legal, then you need to add another variable to track whether skip_file_dev and skip_file_ino values have been set or not and check the rest of the code to make sure that flag is set and obeyed correctly.  (Fortunately, there are only a couple of places these values are used.)

It's probably desirable to also skip this check if archive_entry_dev() or archive_entry_ino64 is not set.  archive_entry already has some logic to track which values have been set; that could easily be extended to track the dev/ino values as well.

Sorry, I only have a passing acquaintance with libarchive and cannot
produce a perfect patch for you.

The intent of filing this bug report is to alert you to the fact that
code such as that in file "archive_write.c" referenced above, is
incorrect.

It is incorrect because it assumes that '0' is some kind of sentinel
value for device IDs and inode numbers.  Even in FreeBSD, where I
presume libarchive was originally developed, the constant 'NODEV' is
defined as ((dev_t) -1).  IIRC, earlier versions of FreeBSD used to
have devices with a device id of zero (like NetBSD does today).

The 'NODEV' constant is not defined by POSIX.  IIRC portable code can
only rely on the pair (device_id, inode_number) uniquely naming a file
on a system.  Portable code cannot assume that specific values of a
device id or an inode number are 'special' across all POSIX-compliant
OSes.

I believe libarchive/trunk r3743 fixes this.

Thanks for the report!

items.title: Failure to find libiconv when building on Mac (but only if liblzma is installed)
items.summary: Failure to find libiconv when building on Mac (but only if liblzma is installed)

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Install liblzma and cmake using MacPorts 2. cmake . 3. make What is the expected output? What do you see instead? The build breaks with errors linking the iconv library. Uninstalling liblzma fixes it again. Apparently there is a problem either with how iconv is being detected or with how liblzma is being detected that results in libarchive using mismatched header/libraries for iconv. Please use labels and text to provide additional information.

I've constructed a small sample Cmake project that illustrates the problem.

This project builds correctly only if liblzma is not installed.  In particular, the first command line below builds successfully, the second fails.  (This uses cmake installed through MacPorts.)

$ sudo port uninstall liblzma && cmake . && make

$ sudo port install liblzma && cmake . && make

updates.summary: Failure to find libiconv when building on Mac.
Failure to find libiconv when building on Mac (but only if liblzma is installed)

items.content:
I'm starting to suspect this is really a bug in CMake.  In the CMakeLists.txt above, the obvious fix is to change line 10 to read:

include_directories(BEFORE ${ICONV_INCLUDE_DIR})

That should ensure that the correct include directory for iconv.h gets searched first.  But as far as I can tell, this line does nothing;  The include directory -- in this case, /usr/include -- doesn't seem to be added to the compiler flags.

A-ha!  It is a CMake bug (or perhaps I should say, part of an attempt for CMake to work around a number of nasty compiler bugs):

http://www.cmake.org/Bug/view.php?id=8598

Traced further; now it looks like a GCC bug (GCC ignores -I/usr/include so there is no way to tell GCC to find /usr/include/iconv.h before it finds /opt/local/include/iconv.h).

It seems the only workaround for this is to prefer the MacPorts iconv library in /opt/local to the system iconv library in /usr.

The following line added early in CMakeLists.txt seems to do the trick.

list(APPEND CMAKE_PREFIX_PATH /opt/local)

This also fixes the build of libarchive.  (libarchive/trunk r3753)

Is there a reason this should be conditional?  If so, on what?  (Making it depend on "having MacPorts installed" seems a little circular, since one test for MacPorts installation is the existence of that directory.)

items.title: st_blocks and st_blksize are not set by archive_entry_stat
items.summary: st_blocks and st_blksize are not set by archive_entry_stat

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Call archive_entry_stat() on a valid entry 2. The returned struct stat does not have valid st_blocks and st_blksize, and in fact are uninitialised. What is the expected output? The struct stat have valid st_blocks and st_blksize. What version are you using? 2.8.5 On what operating system? Debian Linux Please provide any additional information below. I have attached a very simple patch that fixes this problem. It sets the blocks to be ceil(size / 512), and sets blksize to be 4096 (for lack of a better value).

This doesn't make a lot of sense to me- I would perhaps expect these values (and the rest of the unused struct) to be zeroed out, but setting them to misleading values doesn't seem to make a whole lot of sense.

I would propose the following patch instead that ensures the entire struct is zeroed before it gets filled, which is future-proof for new fields and cross-platform as well.

I would agree on the st_blksize perhaps having a misleading value, but I chose 4096 as that's a memory page, and seems a sensible size to use. Programs such as "cat" will use this as a hint to what size buffer to allocate.

Also, st_blocks is typically the number of 512 byte blocks it would take to store this file. So ceil(size/512) expresses that.

For reference, I've encountered an issue with archivemount (a FUSE filesystem app that mounts zip files) was passing this struct directly through FUSE. So commands like "ls" were failing to show valid values (because st_blocks was invalid).

Anyway, I've sent a patch to archivemount that will explicitly set these two fields before passing it to FUSE. It should perhaps be documented which fields libarchive does and does not set in the stats struct.

I've changed the code in question to zero out the entire struct when it is allocated.

I've also made some updates to the archive_entry_stat.3 manpage to clarify the fields affected by archive_entry_stat() and archive_entry_copy_stat().

items.title: Tests fail without libz enabled
items.summary: Tests fail without libz enabled

items.content: Without libz enabled, two of the zip tests have unprotected assertions as is done in several other tests. The attached patch fixes this.

So you're asking me to do it differently in these two cases, even though this exact same check is already used in these files? Do you want me to fix the regressions, or refactor the code? I think they are separate concerns and I'm only worried about the simple fact that tests fail here that should not.

See: test_compat_zip.c:51, test_read_format_zip:67, test_read_format_zip:123
I'll see what I can put together to clean this up- it should be pretty easy to refactor this out as you stated into a little helper method. Thanks for the quick response.
Patch version 2. This cleans up all places where the libz error could be thrown and checks for ARCHIVE_FATAL when appropriate.

Very nice!

I normally balk at relying on configuration macros such as HAVE_LIBZ but it's appropriate in this case and much neater than the approach I came up with.

I made a couple of changes --- your edits pointed out a bug in the original test code that I corrected, and I also added some verification that archive_error_string() and archive_errno() actually get set when there is an error.

Committed at r3765.

items.title: ctime/mtime filter with date <= epoch fails
items.summary: ctime/mtime filter with date <= epoch fails

items.content:
This is due to using time > 0 as the condition for both the filter and to see whether it is enabled. This is very broken if you have a file timestamped on your system before January 1, 1970 and use that as the filter-by file (--newer-than or --newer-mtime-than). You'll end up with every file included instead of just those that are newer.

Add a new flag that stores only the enabled/disabled status of these two filters, and then use this whenever we are doing boolean check on the value.

Very nicely done.

Committed in r3762.

items.title: Quiet fuzz test stderr
items.summary: Quiet fuzz test stderr

items.content:
This quiets the stderr messages produced by the various libraries/external programs during fuzz testing.

[Is this the best way? I'm not sure. I was looking for a way to basically send the stderr stream to the test log file but couldn't find the fdreopen/dup/etc. gymnastics to do so.]

The cmake "make test" and autoconf "make check" test wrappers already capture stderr, I believe.

I'm not entirely convinced it's a good thing to even try to handle this here.  Certainly fdreopen()/etc. games are inappropriate because of the portability requirements for the test harness.  (The test harness needs to be very portable and can't rely on configuration logic as heavily as the actual product code does.)

"make check" most definitely does not. Output attached.

I'm fine with whatever you decide to do, but the problem here is the garbage output:
1. makes you think a test failed
2. makes it a lot harder to find the tests that are actually failing

This was just the quickest solution I could come up with.

$ make --version
GNU Make 3.82
Built for x86_64-unknown-linux-gnu
Copyright (C) 2010  Free Software Foundation, Inc.
License GPLv3+: GNU GPL version 3 or later <http://gnu.org/licenses/gpl.html>
This is free software: you are free to change and redistribute it.
There is NO WARRANTY, to the extent permitted by law.

$ uname -a
Linux galway 3.1.0-4-ARCH #1 SMP PREEMPT Mon Nov 7 22:47:18 CET 2011 x86_64 Intel(R) Core(TM)2 Quad CPU Q9400 @ 2.66GHz GenuineIntel GNU/Linux

items.title: Cleanups of archive_read_support_* code
items.summary: Cleanups of archive_read_support_* code

items.content:
Changes include:
** Make changes to this common idiom:
-	const void *h;
 	const unsigned char *p;
...
-	if ((h = __archive_read_ahead(a, 6, NULL)) == NULL)
+	if ((p = __archive_read_ahead(a, 6, NULL)) == NULL)
...
-	p = (const unsigned char *)h;

We don't need the unsigned char vs char vs void differentiation in any fixed case- we can simply use unsigned char all the time.

** Use memcmp when possible instead of repeated single byte compares, and in two cases strncmp (we are not comparing strings; we are simply looking for magic bytes that happen to be ASCII characters).
** Spacing issues in code between operators- always use a space.

All tests continue to pass.

Hmmm... if tests are passing, then we're missing some tests, since this looks wrong to me:

-		if (strncmp(key, "LIBARCHIVE.xattr.", 17)==0)
+		if (strcmp(key, "LIBARCHIVE.xattr.") == 0)

This handles keys that start with a particular prefix, so should use strncmp() or memcmp().

Rest of it looks pretty good so far, but I probably won't have time to study it in any detail for a couple more days.
Good catch- that was a bad replacement on my part. Apparently there is no test for that attribute, I will see if I can come up with one (although I have no idea how xattr works).

Committed most of this to trunk.

I fixed the xattr issue mentioned above.  I also took the opportunity to do some additional minor cleanup in this area of the tar code (in particular, I managed to eliminate some more casts).

The Zip changes are in my local tree and will get committed along
with some other Zip changes I have in progress.

Thanks again!  (I look forward to your xattr test.  It should be a simple matter of creating a file on disk with some xattrs, using bsdtar to tar it up, then adding a simple read test to libarchive that extracts and verifies that the xattrs are getting read out of the file correctly..)

items.title: Testing nlinks on dirs in cpio tests fails on BTRFS (Linux)
items.summary: Testing nlinks on dirs in cpio tests fails on BTRFS (Linux)

items.content:
affected:
* cpio/test/test_option_c.c
* cpio/test/test_format_newc.c

These tests both have one assert guarded by the following:
#ifndef NLINKS_INACCURATE_FOR_DIRS
 <assert here>
#endif

BTRFS on Linux does not populate the nlinks attribute with 2 for directories (it is 1, regardless of empty state or not, but this should not be depended on). Thus, two tests fail here when run with a testing directory on this filesystem, but pass on other filesystems.

Frankly, the test and guard seem bogus to me- we should be checking if the value was faithfully copied off of the filesystem (by calling stat and seeing the nlinks value from the struct encoded in the data), not whether it is set to an absolute value of 2. This would remove all of the NLINKS define mess from the picture completely.

Both 2.8.X and the eventual 3.0 are broken in this respect on these tests.

Excellent point!

Fixed in libarchive/trunk r3766 by removing the NLINKS_INACCURATE flag entirely and changing those tests to stat() the directory on disk and use that to verify the value in the archive.

items.title: typo in assertion in bsdcpio_test
items.summary: typo in assertion in bsdcpio_test

items.content:
The test_option_c.c source of bsdcpio_test has a typo in a check for different ino number.
(This typo, due to a coincidence of very low device number used, triggered a failure during my build on GNU/Hurd.)

Attached there is a patch that fixes the issue; it has been successfully tested on a Debian 2.8.5 libarchive, on a vanilla 2.8 release branch and on trunk.

Thanks!

Committed to trunk r3768 and 2.8 branch r3770.

items.title: archive_strncat valgrind Invalid read of size 1
items.summary: archive_strncat valgrind Invalid read of size 1

items.content: archive_strncat seems to read one byte beyond the end of the string. This causes valgrind to print this error: ==30961== Invalid read of size 1 ==30961== at 0x4E4FF09: __archive_strncat (archive_string.c:155) ==30961== by 0x4E4F739: archive_read_format_zip_read_header (archive_read_support_format_zip.c:422) ==30961== by 0x4E3A6AB: archive_read_next_header2 (archive_read.c:454) ==30961== by 0x40326B: main (archivemount.c:408) ==30961== Address 0x6820300 is 0 bytes after a block of size 10,240 alloc'd ==30961== at 0x4C2779D: malloc (in /usr/lib/valgrind/vgpreload_memcheck-amd64-linux.so) ==30961== by 0x4E3C4F5: archive_read_open_fd (archive_read_open_fd.c:82) ==30961== by 0x40312A: main (archivemount.c:369) What version are you using? 2.8.5 On what operating system? Debian Linux How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) ./configure make Please provide any additional information below. This seems to stem from __archive_strncat(..): while (*pp && s < n) { pp++; s++; } pp is being dereferenced when s=n, which is beyond where it should be reading. This doesn't actually cause any bugs because the "s < n" check is in there, but because *pp is checked first valgrind flags this as a error. To keep valgrind quiet you just need to change it to: while (s < n && *pp) { pp++; s++; } Also, this change now makes it agree with the comment just a few lines above.

This seems to have been fixed in libarchive/trunk some time ago (as part of a much larger redesign of libarchive's internal string management functions).

I've applied your one-line fix to the libarchive/2.8 branch.

Thanks!

(Please try out the libarchive 3.0.0a test distribution if you have a chance.)

items.title: Infinite loop in ISO reader
items.summary: Infinite loop in ISO reader

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. With current trunk bsdtar 2. Download the attached file 3. bsdtar tvf fuzz-failure.iso I found this on my local build after running the fuzz tester for a few hours. I'm using the autoconf build on Mac OS X 10.7. I've reproduced the hang using the CMake build as well. The hang occurs in archive_read_support_format_iso9660.c in rede_add_entry, due to a loop in the re->parent chain (appears to be 19 elements long).

Thank you for the report.
I fixed this in r3823.

After updating to get your fix, I ran test_fuzz overnight and had another crash that appears to be caused by the same root problem.  (The case I just found was a crash in build_pathname because file->parent == file, so the recursive function exhausted the stack.)

I think the real problem is in next_cache_entry where we relocate a directory tree.  If the RE/CL/PL data is corrupted, we can end up moving a directory to be a child of itself.  That can cause a variety of problems later on.

I think we should add a check before moving a directory to make sure that moving the directory won't cause a loop.   I don't yet understand the code here well enough to know what error handling is appropriate:  We should certainly not move the directory in this case.  I'm not sure if we can return an ARCHIVE_WARN for this entry, though.

I'm going to re-open this bug until we get more details.

Also see Issue 115, which may be another report with the same root cause..

I rewrote the code to resolve this issue and committed it in r3835.
Please try it and let me know the result.
I also will run test_fuzz to find a weakness in the ISO reader.

This is a much better way to handle this.

I'm marking this bug 'fixed'.

items.title: Problem in extraction of png files
items.summary: Problem in extraction of png files

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1.Extract a .png file 2.Files gets extracted in the correct order 3. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Extracted files should be of correct size and correct information. Instead all the file size is 0 What version are you using? 2.8.5 On what operating system? Linux How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) CC=ntoarmv7-gcc ./configure --host=armv5-nto --without-bz2lib --without-lzmadec --without-lzma --without-openssl --without-xml2 --without-expat --disable-bsdcpio --disable-bsdtar --prefix=/home/manju What compiler or development environment (please include version)? ntoarmv7-gcc /Built on Ubuntu Please provide any additional information below.

What kind of archive are you extracting the PNG files from?

What program are you using to do the extraction?

Are you building for a 32-bit or a 64-bit system?  If you're using a 32-bit system, did you define _FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64 when building your program?

What kind of archive are you extracting the PNG files from?

The PNG files are zipped as pkzip files 


What program are you using to do the extraction?

Have used the example code provided by the website to extract the pkzip files 
 
Are you building for a 32-bit or a 64-bit system?  If you're using a 32-bit system, did you define _FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64 when building your program?
We are building for a 32 bit arm processor . I did not define _FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64 while building the program

Please try again with _FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64.

Libarchive is always built with this setting, so programs that use libarchive must also do so.  (It is possible in theory to have libarchive support programs that are built with or without this, but it requires some complex macro trickery that no one has yet built.)

I'm going to close this as WorksForMe since it appears this could have been a mistake in building the program that used libarchive.

If you have any additional information, please add it and we'll take another look.

items.title: test_compat_zip failure without zlib
items.summary: test_compat_zip failure without zlib

items.content:
It seems the recent changes of test_compat_zip are causing this failure.
 
Please see an attached log file.

The streaming Zip reader now knows how to correctly skip entries when it does not recognize the compression.

So now bsdtar should be able to list contents for Zip files with any kind of compression, even though it does not know how to extract them.

items.title: bsdcpio stores incorrect mode in archive
items.summary: bsdcpio stores incorrect mode in archive

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Arch Linux running via NFS disk-less. 2. Installing a kernel from the disk-less client calls /sbin/mkinitcpio 3. /sbin/mkinitcpio uses bsdcpio to create the image. 4. The resulting /boot/initramfs-linux.img causes kernel panic failing to find init. 5. Extract the /boot/initramfs-linux.img 6. NOTE: executable bits are missing from important files... .... drwxr-xr-x 2 root root 27 2011-11-08 16:06 hooks -rw------- 1 root root 3512 2011-11-08 16:06 init -rw------- 1 root root 5021 2011-11-08 16:06 init_functions drwxr-xr-x 5 root root 4096 2011-11-08 16:06 lib drwxr-xr-x 2 root root 6 2011-11-08 16:06 new_root .... root@server# ll sbin total 308 -rw------- 1 root root 30472 2011-11-08 16:06 blkid -rw------- 1 root root 128776 2011-11-08 16:06 modprobe -rw------- 1 root root 149380 2011-11-08 16:06 udevadm root@server# ll bin total 368 -rw------- 1 root root 338548 2011-11-08 16:06 busybox -rw------- 1 root root 19936 2011-11-08 16:06 ipconfig -rw------- 1 root root 15228 2011-11-08 16:06 nfsmount =========== Fixed by editing /sbin/mkinitcpio and changing bsdcpio to regular cpio around line 358: =========== bsdcpio $( (( QUIET )) && echo '--quiet' ) -0oH newc | == changed to == cpio $( (( QUIET )) && echo '--quiet' ) -0oH newc | =========== Then recreate My guess is bsdcpio doesn't work well on nfs root filesystem. Issue was reported on Arch Linux forum and I was asked to repost with libarchive. https://bbs.archlinux.org/viewtopic.php?id=129937

Thanks for the report.  We really appreciate it.

Can you please try a couple of quick experiments to help us narrow the problem:

1) bsdcpio --version

2) Try reproducing the problem with a single file.   Something like the following, possibly:

$ echo foo > foo && chmod +x foo && echo 'foo\0' | bsdcpio -0oH newc > foo.cpio

Please attach the resulting foo.cpio file to this bug report so I can inspect it.

Trying the above with an NFS root filesystem and again on a non-NFS root would also be helpful.  (I doubt it makes any difference, but it would be nice to verify.)

[root@arch home]# bsdcpio --version
bsdcpio 2.8.5 -- libarchive 2.8.5

--

I ran the following foo script and it create a working archive with no errors...
echo foo > foo && chmod +x foo && find foo -print0 | bsdcpio -0oH newc > foo.cpio
rm foo; cat foo.cpio | cpio -i

I've attached mkinitcpio and the results of two images created by modifying line 358 (bsdcpio|cpio)

The bsdcpio-generated archive definitely has different permissions on the entries than the one generated by GNU cpio.  (I presume that when you say "regular cpio", you mean "GNU cpio".)

You weren't able to reproduce this problem with a simple cpio usage, so it's not just that you're using an NFS root.

I looked through the mkinitcpio script and don't see anything in there that should modify how bsdcpio behaves, so it should be possible to reproduce this with a find | bsdcpio from the command line.

I'll continue to experiment and see if I can reproduce this.  If you can find a way to consistently reproduce this, I'd be very interested in knowing how.

Here are a few ideas for diagnosing this:

 * edit mkinitcpio so that it does not remove the BUILDROOT directory but instead prints out the path: comment out the "rm -rf" command in the cleanup function around line 68 and replace it with the following command
       echo "BUILDROOT: $BUILDROOT"

 * Run mkinitcpio to build an image and note the BUILDROOT directory.  That directory will be left behind so you can now experiment.

$ cd <buildroot>
$ find . -print0 | bsdcpio -0oH newc | bsdcpio -tv

This should reproduce the previous problem.  Assuming it does, then we can try pruning down to a narrower test case:

1) Try removing the -print0 and the -0 option.
2) Try dropping the -H newc option
3) Try narrowing the 'find' command to just a few files or a smaller directory.

Once you've narrowed it as much as you can, let's see what strace says:

$ find <file> | strace bsdcpio -oH newc -O /dev/null

In particular, we want to see what bsdcpio is seeing when it invokes stat64() on the file.

What version of Arch Linux are you using?  Is there a recipe posted somewhere for setting up an NFS root similar to the one you're using?  I've installed the current Arch Linux on my system here and haven't had any luck reproducing the issue you've mentioned.
Changing summary to better reflect the actual problem.

updates.summary: bsdcpio stores incorrect mode in archive

items.content: Changing to "Waiting" state; I've had no luck reproducing this on my systems here.  If anyone does find a way to consistently reproduce it, please let me know.
Two years and no one has managed to find a way to consistently reproduce this problem, so I'm going to close it.

items.title: build failure on GNU/Hurd, due to PATH_MAX
items.summary: build failure on GNU/Hurd, due to PATH_MAX

items.content:
libarchive 3.0.2 fails to compile on GNU/Hurd, as PATH_MAX (optional in POSIX and generally not recommended) is not available; there are two unconditional usages of it.

The attached patch fixes the two places:
* libarchive/archive_write_set_format_xar.c:
gets rid of the temporary buffer "path" used, by directly calling archive_strncpy() with the correct start and size of the "b" buffer, capping it to "rsize" as done now
* libarchive/test/test_sparse_basic.c:
gets the current working directory in the same way as used in other places of {bsdcpio,bsdtar,libarchive}_test (maybe a common implementation for all of them would be an ideal solution?)

The patch compiles against a vanilla 3.0.2 and on SVN/3.0 branch (r4001); unit tests all pass when tested on GNU/Linux.

Thank you for the report.
I fixed this issue and committed it in r4006 on release/3.0 branch and in r4004 and r4005 on trunk.

items.title: Fix shadowed local in archive_read_support_format_iso9660.c
items.summary: Fix shadowed local in archive_read_support_format_iso9660.c

items.content:
Revision 3835 introduced a shadow declaration in archive_read_support_format_iso9660.c.

"archive_read_support_format_iso9660.c:1965: warning: declaration of 'p' shadows a previous local"

Solution: use a different variable name than 'p' (e.g. 'r').
Proposed fix attached.

Please also merge to release/2.8

I committed your patch in r4014 svn/trunk ,in r4015 svn/release/3.0 and
in r4016 svn/release/2.8.

items.title: Unable to build static release under win32
items.summary: Unable to build static release under win32

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? set CMAKE_PREFIX_PATH=c:\devlibs bsdtar xf libarchive-3.0.2.tar.gz cd libarchive-3.0.2 md builds cd builds cmake -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX=/devlibs -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release -G "NMake Makefiles" .. nmake install What is the expected output? What do you see instead? The system should build. It does'nt link and complaints about mix of static and dynamic libraries, mix of debug and release, and expat can't be linked After fix, libarchive\test\test_write_format_zip.c fails to compile because it uses S_IFLNK, which is not defined under Windows platform What version are you using? 3.0.2 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) cmake What compiler or development environment (please include version)? Visual C++ 2005 (VS8) Please provide any additional information below. See attached patch for a fix proposal. Using /mt (static runtime library) instead of /md (msvctr80.dll and so on) might be incorrect, and should depend on the way other libraries like expat, bz2, etc. were built. This part of my fix might be wrong

I can verify that the "#ifdef S_IFLNK" is needed to build using VS2005; I just independently made the same discovery before searching the issues db.

I'm not using it as a static library, so I can't speak to the cmake changes
I fixed the build failure about S_IFLNK in r3992 using AE_IFLNK instead of S_IFLNK.

I improved CMakeLists.txt to check libraries whether a macro such as XML_STATIC
is needed to link or not.

To christophe.baribaud, we never use or rely on BUILD_SHARED_LIBS since we always
create both shared libarchive library and static one. And so your patch might not
work completely.

items.title: Hard link fail under win32
items.summary: Hard link fail under win32

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? nmake test What is the expected output? What do you see instead? CTest -R disk_hardlink Test 139 - libarchive_test_write_disk_hardlink (Failed) What version are you using? 3.0.2 On what operating system? Windows 2000 SP4 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) cmake What compiler or development environment (please include version)? Visual C++ 2005 (VS8) Please provide any additional information below. The Windows API function CreateHardLinkW seem not understand the "\\?\" prefix, used to tell Windows API functions that we want long path names (up to 32768 wide characters). This should not be necessary, since this function only works with NTFS filesystems, were long paths are native. The attached path removes the "\\?\" prefix. Then, tests using hardlinks are PASSED.

I did further testing on various Windows platforms, using the attached program.
It appears that windows 2000 doesn't accept the "\\?\" prefix when using CreateHardLinkW (tests 5 and 7 fail with error code 123)
Windows XP and Windows seven 64 do accept the prefix
To use long path names (more the MAX_PATH long), it is necessary to prepend "\\?\" (test 8 fails on all platforms)

Based on the previous tests, I propose the attached patch. It works under Windows 2000 for hard links dealing with paths up to MAX_PATH wide characters. There is no limitation on other platforms.
I haven't found any way to create a hard link for paths more than MAX_PATH long on Windows 2000. It might not be possible.

Thank you very much for your great effort.
I fixed this based on your path, slightly changing style, adding a handling
of \\?\UNC\ prefix in order not to leave "UNC\" string at the beginning of the path.

items.title: Unable to archive one character long files under win32
items.summary: Unable to archive one character long files under win32

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? echo "hello" >t bsdtar cf archive t What is the expected output? What do you see instead? bsdtar: Can't FindFirstFileW: Unknown error What version are you using? 3.0.2 On what operating system? Windows 2000 SP4 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) cmake What compiler or development environment (please include version)? Visual C++ 2005 (VS8) Please provide any additional information below. The Windows API function GetFullPathNameW need extra buffer space when the name part of the path is one character long (it looks like a bug in the API, at least on Win2K platform...). The attached patch allocates 2 extra wide characters, making the "bsdtar cf archive t" test pass.
I fixed it in r4007 svn/trunk and in r4008 svn/release/3.0.

items.title: test_write_compress_program hangs
items.summary: test_write_compress_program hangs

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? As mentioned by Michihiro NAKAJIMA using my previous patch, the command bsdtar -cf foo.tar.gz --use-compress-program gzip foo-files never returns What is the expected output? What do you see instead? The program never ends What version are you using? 3.0.2 On what operating system? Windows 2000 SP4 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) cmake What compiler or development environment (please include version)? Visual C++ 2005 (VS8) Please provide any additional information below. One way to solve the issue is to close duplicate handles when creating the pipes between bsdtar and the child process. When the child process ends, it closes the last instance of the pipe handle, and so make the ReadFile function return. My proposition don't use any "sleep" function call, so doesn't depend on time. I also filled the "stderr" handle of the child process, just in case

Thank you for you effort to fix this issue.

I fixed this based on your patch in r4018 svn/trunk and in r4019 svn/release/3.0.

items.title: libarchive already depends on cmake 2.8, should just make it official
items.summary: libarchive already depends on cmake 2.8, should just make it official

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Try configuring libarchive 3.0.2 on windows using cmake 2.6.4 What is the expected output? What do you see instead? compiler error: "No 32-bit integer type was found." What version are you using? 3.0.2 On what operating system? windows server 2003R2 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) cmake 2.6.4 What compiler or development environment (please include version)? Visual Studio 2005 Please provide any additional information below. libarchive cannot be configured using cmake 2.6.x because config.h.in uses "@SIZE_OF_*_CODE@". These variables are only set in cmake 2.8 versions of Modules/CheckTypeSize.cmake. Near the top of libarchive's CMakeLists.txt file there is: CMAKE_MINIMUM_REQUIRED(VERSION 2.6.3 FATAL_ERROR) and a little further down there is: # Provide ADD_TEST_28 macro to approximate CMake 2.8 ADD_TEST(NAME). # TODO: Require CMake 2.8 and drop this workaround (perhaps late 2010). INCLUDE(AddTest28) It sounds like you should just do this now, since cmake 2.6 doesn't work today anyhow

Thanks for pointing this out.

I've made this change in trunk and in the 3.0 branch.  It will be in the next release builds.

items.title: possible memory leak in function create_dir in archive_write_disk_windows
items.summary: possible memory leak in function create_dir in archive_write_disk_windows

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Implemented the example: A Complete Extractor on windows What is the expected output? What do you see instead? No Memory Leaks but Visual C++ reports memory leaks in debug mode. What version are you using? SVN release/3.0 r3986 On what operating system? Windows XP How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) Cmake2.8 What compiler or development environment (please include version)? Visual C++ 2008 Please provide any additional information below. When testing I got memory leaks reported by Visual C++ debugger I traced the code and found that in the function create_dir() in archive_write_disk_windows.c a call to free(full) may be missing. See code extract below: /* * Apply __la_win_permissive_name_w to path in order to * remove '../' path string. */ full = __la_win_permissive_name_w(path); if (full == NULL) errno = EINVAL; else if (CreateDirectoryW(full, NULL) != 0) { if (mode != mode_final) { le = new_fixup(a, path); le->fixup |=TODO_MODE_BASE; le->mode = mode_final; } free(full); <<================ Probably missing return (ARCHIVE_OK); } else { la_dosmaperr(GetLastError()); } free(full);
I fixed it in r4021 svn/trunk and in r4022 svn/release/3.0.

items.title: Unable to traverse deep trees on Windows
items.summary: Unable to traverse deep trees on Windows

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Create a directory tree c:\abcdefx\... longer than MAX_PATH 2. bsdtar cf archive c:\abcdefx What is the expected output? What do you see instead? bsdtar: c:/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx: Unable to continue traversing directory tree What version are you using? release/3.0 r4019 On what operating system? Windows 2000 Windows Seven 64 bits How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) cmake What compiler or development environment (please include version)? Visual C++ 2005 (VS8) Please provide any additional information below. In tree_ascend function, SetCurrentDirectory("..") fails. It seems that Windows can't use relative path if the full path exceeds MAX_PATH, even under windows seven. I do think that tree traversal should only use absolute paths, with the \\?\ prefix, under Windows.

The new directory traversal code has been implemented in libarchive 3.0.
The new code completely supports the long path longer than MAX_PATH.
If bsdtar uses that, this issue will be resolved.

If you need the tar that can handle a deep directory tree, try attached patch.
It uses the new directory traversal code in bsdtar.

Great, it works!
I succeded in saving and restoring deep hierarchies using bsdtar under Windows using your patch.
After having applied your patch, the test "test_windows.c" fails (steps 15 and 16). I fixed it locally by adding:
#if defined(_WIN32) && !defined(__CYGWIN__)
	/* ASCII version APIs do not accept the path which begin with
	 * "//?/" prefix. */
	if (strncmp(path, "//?/", 4) == 0 || strncmp(path, "\\\\?\\", 4) == 0)
		path += 4;
#endif
at the begining of write_hierarchy function.
I would have been easier to remove tests 15 and 16 from test_windows.c, since they look strange (the \\?\ prefix is a Windows internal workaround, not sure that it has any sense in the bsdtar command line)

I already fixed that test failure in r4024 svn/trunk. Please apply that change
to your libarchive code and try it again.

Windows console command accepts \\?\ prefix. For example, mkdir command can make
the very long path that is longer than MAX_PATH when you add the "\\?\" prefix to
the path. Without "\\?\" prefix, mkdir command fail for the path, but, with the
"\\?\" prefix, mkdir command succeed.
I'm not sure that all console commands properly handle "\\?\" prefix because
using "\\?\" to type command causes cmd.exe crash after type command printed
the contents of the file the full path of which is longer than MAX_PATH.

bsdtar now uses the new directory traversals code.
That would be released as libarchive 3.1.

items.title: "grep -e" (used in configure.ac) is not portable, should use $GREP or stick to portable options
items.summary: "grep -e" (used in configure.ac) is not portable, should use $GREP or stick to portable options

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. ran ./configure on a Solaris 10 machine 2. noticed errors (although configure still seemed to mostly succeed) 3. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? checking support for ARCHIVE_CRYPTO_MD5_LIBMD... yes grep: illegal option -- e grep: illegal option -- m grep: illegal option -- d Usage: grep -hblcnsviw pattern file . . . checking support for ARCHIVE_CRYPTO_RMD160_LIBMD... no What version are you using? 3.0.2 On what operating system? Solaris 10 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) CONFIG_SHELL=/usr/bin/ksh SHELL=/usr/bin/ksh /usr/bin/ksh ./configure (I had problems with running libarchive's ./configure script under Solaris's /bin/sh in the past, so I always force it to use ksh, but that's unrelated to this issue) What compiler or development environment (please include version)? n/a Please provide any additional information below. In my case I worked around the issue by putting /usr/xpg4/bin in my $PATH before running ./configure. Another workaround would be to change: test -n "$(echo $mdLIBS | grep -e $4)" || mdLIBS="$mdLIBS $4" to the more portable: test -n "$(echo $mdLIBS | grep .$4)" || mdLIBS="$mdLIBS $4" Another option would be to use $GREP, which the ./configure script already populates as the location of a more fully-featured grep (in my case it finds GNU grep installed as "ggrep")

Thank you.  I've changed the line in question to use

      $GREP .$4

which will hopefully be portable enough.

Actually, I think I gave you a piece of incorrect advice (sorry).  The ".$4" won't match if it's looking for the first thing in $mdLIBS.  My initial glance at the code made it look like that wasn't possible anyway, but now I realize it probably is.

The simplest fix is to just change 

  echo $mdLIBS

to something like

  echo _ $mdLUBS

i.e. just make sure there is something on the line at the front that won't match the "$4"
I thought this too, at first, but if you look at how $mdLIBS is built, you'll notice there's always a space just before the library name, so ".$4" really will work correctly.

I don't think that is correct.  The leading space will be lost when it's expanded on the "echo" command line:

$ a=" foo"
$ echo $a | grep .foo
bash: exit 1

If it were in double quotes like:
   echo "$mdLIBS" | grep .$4
then it would be safe.  But that would interfere with the double quotes around the larger expression.

So I think the best thing would be to just do:
  echo _$mdLIBS

That way:
  1. it's safe even if $mdLIBS loses its leading space in some transformation
  2. there's no risk of $mdLIBS being considered a flag to echo (although if $mdLIBS had something like "-n" in it that would be pretty weird :-)

Ah.  Yes, you are exactly right.

I've made your suggested change to trunk as r4050 and the 3.0 branch as r4051.
Thanks for the careful analysis!

items.title: copyfile API not available on all versions of OS/X
items.summary: copyfile API not available on all versions of OS/X

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. compile against the OS/X 10.4u SDK 2. witness errors in archive_read_disk_entry_from_file.c complaining about COPYFILE_* constants missing 3. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? What version are you using? 3.0.2 On what operating system? OS/X 10.5, forcing compile against the 10.4u SDK by manipulating CFLAGS, etc How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) ./configure What compiler or development environment (please include version)? gcc version 4.0.1 (Apple Inc. build 5488) Please provide any additional information below. This one-line patch fixes this issue: --- libarchive-3.0.2/libarchive/archive_read_disk_entry_from_file.c.ORIG 2011-12-28 21:54:54.000000000 -0800 +++ libarchive-3.0.2/libarchive/archive_read_disk_entry_from_file.c 2011-12-28 21:55:22.000000000 -0800 @@ -246,7 +246,7 @@ return (r); } -#ifdef __APPLE__ +#if defined(__APPLE__) && defined(HAVE_COPYFILE_H) /* * The Mac OS "copyfile()" API copies the extended metadata for a * file into a separate file in AppleDouble format (see RFC 1740).
Committed to libarchive/trunk r4035 and libarchive/3.0 r4036.

items.title: MNT_NOATIME constant not universally available
items.summary: MNT_NOATIME constant not universally available

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. compile on a platform without a MNT_NOATIME constant (OS/X 10.4 is one, but I'm sure many older UNIXes qualify) 2. compile fails in archive_read_disk_posix.c 3. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? What version are you using? 3.0.2 On what operating system? OS/X 10.5, building against the 10.4u SDK How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) configure What compiler or development environment (please include version)? gcc version 4.0.1 (Apple Inc. build 5488) Please provide any additional information below. This trivial patch fixes it: --- libarchive-3.0.2/libarchive/archive_read_disk_posix.c.ORIG 2011-12-28 22:05:12.000000000 -0800 +++ libarchive-3.0.2/libarchive/archive_read_disk_posix.c 2011-12-28 22:05:45.000000000 -0800 @@ -1321,9 +1321,11 @@ t->current_filesystem->synthetic = 0; #endif +#if defined(MNT_NOATIME) if (sfs.f_flags & MNT_NOATIME) t->current_filesystem->noatime = 1; else +#endif t->current_filesystem->noatime = 0; #if defined(HAVE_READDIR_R)
Change committed in libarchive/trunk r4037 and libarchive/3.0 r4038

items.title: Could linking against CoreFoundation on OS/X be make ./configure-time selectable
items.summary: Could linking against CoreFoundation on OS/X be make ./configure-time selectable

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. compile on OS/X 2. notice that it links against "-framework CoreServices" 3. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? What version are you using? 3.0.2 On what operating system? OS/X 10.5, building against the 10.4u SDK How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) ./configure What compiler or development environment (please include version)? gcc version 4.0.1 (Apple Inc. build 5488) Please provide any additional information below. I understand that linking against CoreFoundation has advantages for dealing with unicode pathnames, but it also has some disadvantages. For example, if you are building against the (maximally portable) 10.4u SDK it precludes building the library 64-bit, even if you don't need the unicode filesystem support. My brief look at the code makes me think that the library will generally work without the CoreFoundation stuff (although maybe not as well).. so maybe a "./configure --without-CoreFoundation" flag would be appropriate. For now I've worked around this locally by patching archive_string.c to change all of the "#if defined(__APPLE__)" to "#if 0" and modifying ./configure to avoid adding "-framework CoreServices" to $LIBS

Such a configuration flag seems reasonable.

Do you have a  patch?  Even something incomplete is a help.

(Hint:  "/bin/sh build/autogen.sh" regenerates the configure script if you have the right tools installed.)
I guess I could try to make a patch, although my autoconf skills are *very* rusty these days
I think this bug can be retired; I just tried out libarchive 3.1.2 and it doesn't seem to be using CoreFoundation anymore
Closing.  Thanks.

items.title: bsdtar output truncated
items.summary: bsdtar output truncated

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. create a very long path (more than 256 chars) 2. archive this path i.e. bsdtar archive my_path 3. dump the archive i.e. bsdtar tf archive What is the expected output? What do you see instead? When the name of the path is longer than 256 chars, the systems prints random chars at the end of the string. Example : abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/abcdefx/\023c\215'<@ What version are you using? release/3.0 r4034, and a patch to allow long paths On what operating system? Windows 2000 SP4 and Windows seven 64 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) cmake What compiler or development environment (please include version)? Visual C++ 2005 (VS8) Please provide any additional information below. The function safe_fprintf located in file tar/util.c make the wrong assumption that vsnprintf returns the number of characters needed if the provided buffer is too short. The Windows version of this function returns -1 (Microsoft designed this function before the normalization...) To know the number of characters needed, it is necessary to use the _vscprintf function. See attached patch
My previous patch broke build under Linux... This one is better

I prefer to avoid #if conditionals when we can reasonably do so.  The approach in Comment 2 above seems pretty promising.

Now we just need a test for this...

Unfortunately, VC6 does not provide _vscprintf function.
So, I agree with Tim.
I fixed this issue in r4042 svn/trunk and in r4043 svn/release/3.0 based on mitchblank's suggestion.

items.title: make error
items.summary: make error

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. ./configure 2. make What is the expected output? What do you see instead? libarchive/archive_read_support_format_7zip.c: In function read_Bools: libarchive/archive_read_support_format_7zip.c:1573: error: avail may be used uninitialized in this function make[1]: *** [libarchive/archive_read_support_format_7zip.lo] Error 1 make[1]: Leaving directory `/libarchive' make: *** [all] Error 2 What version are you using? I tried libarchive 3.0.2 stable and trunk, both versions end with error. On what operating system? Ubuntu 10.04 i386 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) svn checkout http://libarchive.googlecode.com/svn/trunk/ . build/autogen.sh ./configure make What compiler or development environment (please include version)? gcc version 4.4.3 Please provide any additional information below. Building with cmake is ok. The patch is attached to fix issued error.

Thanks!

Committed to trunk r4045 and release/3.0 r4046.

Please let us know if you find any other problems.

I guess -Werror is on for some reason?  Do you have that set in $CFLAGS or something?  Otherwise I don't see why that would have been an error - it's just a warning when I build.

The patch isn't technically needed, either.  "avail" is always set before it's actually referenced, but the compiler can't see that

That is right, -Werror is on, but I do not know the reason, why configure script writes the flag to Makefile, because $CFLAGS is empty.

I understand, that it is not basically error, but gcc does not know it.

We do try to humor compilers in order to keep a clean warning-free build.  ;-)

-Werror should not be set on stable releases (even if we could get a perfectly clean build on every compiler available today, compilers will change over the life of the release).  However, it is set on libarchive/trunk and on testing releases in order to catch as many code nits as possible during development and testing.

If you ever see -Werror set on a build from a stable libarchive release, please let me know and I'll dig into it.

items.title: default build of r4072 with clang produces several compiler warnings
items.summary: default build of r4072 with clang produces several compiler warnings

items.content:
With svn r4072 I used CMake 2.8.7 and clang and there are a few warnings:

[  8%] Building C object libarchive/CMakeFiles/archive.dir/archive_read_support_format_7zip.c.o/libarchive-read-only/libarchive/archive_read_support_format_7zip.c:1385:18: warning: comparison of unsigned expression < 0 is always false [-Wtautological-compare]
                    t_avail_in < 0 || t_avail_out <= 0) {
                    ~~~~~~~~~~ ^ ~


[ 11%] Building C object libarchive/CMakeFiles/archive.dir/archive_string.c.o/libarchive-read-only/libarchive/archive_string.c:2156:29: warning: passing 'const char **' to parameter of type 'char **' discards qualifiers in nested pointer types
      [-Wincompatible-pointer-types]
                size_t result = iconv(cd, &inp, &remaining, &outp, &avail);
                                          ^~~~
/usr/include/iconv.h:73:30: note: passing argument to parameter here
        char ** __restrict /*inbuf*/,  size_t * __restrict /*inbytesleft*/,
                                    ^


[ 39%] Building C object libarchive/test/CMakeFiles/libarchive_test.dir/read_open_memory.c.o/libarchive-read-only/libarchive/test/read_open_memory.c:144:11: warning: comparison of unsigned expression < 0 is always false [-Wtautological-compare]
        if (size < 0) {
            ~~~~ ^ ~

The first and third items here have been fixed in trunk:  Michihiro just committed a fix for the first (removing the comparison) and I just committed a fix for the third (changing the variable to a signed type).

The second one appears to be a configuration issue:  The CMakeLists.txt file is supposed to automatically determine whether the iconv() on your system uses const char ** or char ** for the second parameter (there are several implementations of iconv in use with differing signatures).  Apparently, the CmakeLists.txt isn't correctly determining this for you.

What operating system?  What version of clang?

What iconv are you using?  (Many systems have GNU libiconv installed as a separate package in addition to a system libiconv or iconv in libc.)

Do the tests pass for you?

I can confirm the warnings are fixed (except the iconv one).

I'm using Mac OS X 10.7.2 with a recent build of clang from its svn.  I'm using whichever iconv comes with the OS. I didn't try the tests, but have just tried now with r4086:

100% tests passed, 0 tests failed out of 231

I'm going to close this as "Fixed".

The iconv issue is subtle:  The CMake script tries to determine whether your iconv uses "char **" or "const char **" for that argument by trying to compile a sample program each way and seeing if it fails.  Of course, a compile warning won't cause that to fail, so this configuration test doesn't prevent a warning at build time; it only ensures that you won't get a compile failure.

items.content:

But it seems that this case is not implemented in libarchive build process ? --includedir and --libdir have no effect on configure script, zlib is still "not present". 

Thank you !

What operating system?

What compiler?

How are you running ./configure?

What directory is zlib.a in?

OS : Linux, Solaris, AIX and BSD
Compiler : gcc
for the ./configure, i use : ./configure --enable-static --disable-bsdtar --disable-bsdcpio --disable-xattr --disable-acl --disable-largefile --with-pic --without-bz2lib --without-lzmadec --without-lzma --without-lzma --without-xml2 --without-expat

And the directory of zlib.a, I can move it where you want. (Actually it is : ../zlib/zlib.a)

I don't manage to say to the ./configure to watch in "../zlib/" to find headers and static lib of zlib. So, it says zlib not present.

Thank you.

I also can't work out how to configure my own zlib and bzip2 include folders and static libs.  This applies to several (all?) unix type platforms.

I've tried --with-zlib="../zlib" --with-bzip="..bzip", but this doesn't seem to have any effect.  Is there hack to do this?  It's not always easy to get xxx-devel pkgs on all platforms.
i'm using 3.0.3

Solved it by editing #defines in config.h.in.
Then run configure.
Then add include paths to Makefile.am.
Then make.

items.title: archive_read_finish is rather brittle in repeat calls
items.summary: archive_read_finish is rather brittle in repeat calls

items.content:
It isn't necessarily correct to call this function twice, but I'm seeing some rather odd behavior overall that seems like it could be better handled by libarchive.

Test program attached, which covers three different (mis)use cases:

1: ./test (no args) : create new archive object, try to finish/free it twice. The second time spits up the "Programmer error" warning. Probably fine as is.
2. ./test null : attempt to finish/free NULL. Segmentation faults. Totally against the principle of the normal free() call which handles NULL pointers just fine, so one would expect this function to do so as well.
3. ./test open : similar case to 1, except we actually open a file descriptor. This results in no "Programmer error" warning but a segfault instead.

1 and 3 would be fine if 2 didn't occur, but having to guard all calls to archive_read_finish() in a NULL check seems a bit extreme. It would make defensive coding a lot easier if archive_read_free() accepted NULL and returned without segfaulting.

Sorry I totally forgot that. I am using 3.0.2 on my system, and that is what I used for the example program.

$ grep 'define ARCHIVE_VERSION_NUMBER' /usr/include/archive.h 

$ bsdtar --version
bsdtar 3.0.2 - libarchive 3.0.2

$ uname -a
Linux galway 3.2.0-1-ARCH #1 SMP PREEMPT Thu Jan 5 11:34:46 CET 2012 x86_64 Intel(R) Core(TM)2 Quad CPU Q9400 @ 2.66GHz GenuineIntel GNU/Linux


Here is the output when I compile and link test.c:

$ ./test 
new
finish 1
finish 2
PROGRAMMER ERROR: Function archive_read_free invoked with invalid archive handle.
Aborted

$ ./test null
new
Segmentation fault

$ ./test open
new
2
finish 1
finish 2
Segmentation fault

Oh.  I found it.  archive_read_free() and archive_write_free() are virtual, so you can't look them up against a NULL pointer.

I've added the NULL check at the virtual wrappers in r4106.

Your test program now passes ./test null and the other cases abort with PROGRAMMER ERROR.  (Which is consistent with free(1), which does not permit freeing the same memory more than once.)
Merged to the 3.0 branch.
Awesome, thanks! I've fixed my buggy program code in the meantime but this is great for consistency, appreciate you looking into it.

items.title: archive creation fails for vmlinux image on ext4
items.summary: archive creation fails for vmlinux image on ext4

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. build a linux kernel 2. on ext4, bsdtar cf foo.tar vmlinux What is the expected output? What do you see instead? I expect an uncompressed tar archive. bsdtar throws a write error early in the process and I end up with a truncated archive. This doesn't happen when I try to write the archive to tmpfs, with the vmlinux file still on ext4. What version are you using? libarchive 3.0.2 On what operating system? (Arch) Linux, kernel v3.2.0. How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) Built with: ./configure --prefix=/usr --without-xml2 CFLAGS="-march=generic -mtune=generic -O2 -pipe -fstack-protector --param=ssp-buffer-size=4 -D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2" LDFLAGS="-Wl,-O1,--sort-common,--as-needed,-z,relro,--hash-style=gnu" -- Rebuilding without these CFLAGS and LDFLAGS does not affect the outcome. What compiler or development environment (please include version)? gcc 4.6.2 glibc 2.15 binutils 2.22 Please provide any additional information below. I've attached an strace of the same process performed on ext4 vs. tmpfs. You'll notice an EFAULT return from write(2) on the ext4 sample early in the archive creation. Also strange is that the previous write before the EFAULT write doesn't return the full requested amount, which is odd when dealing with a real file on disk. Running bsdtar under valgrind does not exhibit the error, (which makes sense since the address space is modified).

I would love to see a backtrace from the point at which the EFAULT occurs.  This suggests a problem in archive_write_client_write() (which has logic to try to recover from short writes), but I'm looking at that code and don't see anything obvious.  I'm not sure why you're seeing a short write (full disk?) but whatever is causing that should be handled more gracefully than this.

I'm very perplexed why in one case you see writes and reads alternating (one large read, several small writes), and in the other case, you see a bunch of reads before there are any writes.  I'm pretty sure that's related to whatever else is going on here.

Hmmm....  Is it possible that you're using the wrong archive.h?  I would expect to see problems like this if you somehow used the libarchive 2.8.5 archive.h with the libarchive 3.0.2 library (or vice-versa).  Some of the arguments have changed size (e.g. 32-bit versus 64-bit integers), and some of the behaviors here look like numbers are getting mixed up.

Sure thing. Attached is a full backtrace from where the EFAULT occurs. No CFLAGS/LDFLAGS involved in the build to avoid optimizations.

No possibility of running out of disk space, I've got over 1TB free on that particular partition.

Sorry for not mentioning -- this x86_64. I wouldn't expect any changes here for argument size.

Wrong archive.h isn't possible (wouldn't that be a build-sys bug, anyways?). The debug build I used to generate this backtrace was compiled with libarchive 3.0.2 installed to the root FS. 2.8.5 is nowhere in sight ;)
Also worth noting that building libarchive 2.8.5 and LD_PRELOAD'ing the .so with the build tree's bsdtar doesn't exhibit this behavior.

I checked this out into a git repo to make bisecting easier -- was able to track this down to:

http://code.google.com/p/libarchive/source/detail?r=3277

Sure enough, if I hack the build to remove the HAVE_LINUX_FIEMAP_H define, 3.0.2 generates a binary that can archive this file.

Ah.  Good detective work!

Between the backtrace and your comment about sparse file support, I think I know where the problem is.  It looks like archive_write_pax_data isn't correctly copying contents through when the file is sparse.  In particular, it's not accounting for data that was already written from the buffer when deciding how much can be written.

I haven't tested the attached patch, but I think it's at least on the right track.  To test it, please unarchive the resulting tar file and verify (with `cmp`) that the result matches the original file.
Perfect! bsdtar doesn't report a truncated write, and cmp returns 0 for the original file compared to the one extracted out of the newly written archive.

Tim, I've just committed a test for archiving sparse files.
It fails without your patch.

Thanks, Michihiro!

I think this might merit a 3.0.3 release.  If you agree, I'll have time for that tomorrow.
Tim, I agree with you. We should do it!

Hey guys, I don't mean to nag, but is 3.0.3 actually on the horizon? I've got libarchive 3.0.2 in Arch Linux's testing repo and holding up some other devs. I don't want to move it to our stable repos as is, knowing that it adversely affects kernel builds.

If 3.0.3 is actually going to be tarballed up in the next day or so, awesome! Otherwise, please let me know that you won't get to it until later so I can backport this patch to our 3.0.2 package. I'm fine with both of these scenarios; I just need some insight into your schedules so I can make a decision.
Libarchive 3.0.3 was posted to the Downloads section today.  Thanks for your patience.

items.title: Mishandling CD9660 images with RockRidge extensions from FreeBSD makefs
items.summary: Mishandling CD9660 images with RockRidge extensions from FreeBSD makefs

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? hammer# cat > this_is_a_test_file.txt This is a test file. hammer# cat this_is_a_test_file.txt This is a test file. hammer# ln -s this_is_a_test_file.txt this_is_a_test_file.tmp hammer# ls -la total 6 drwxr-xr-x 2 root wheel 512 1 17 15:05 . drwxr-xr-x 4 root wheel 512 1 17 15:04 .. lrwxr-xr-x 1 root wheel 23 1 17 15:05 this_is_a_test_file.tmp -> this_is_a_test_file.txt -rw-r--r-- 1 root wheel 21 1 17 15:05 this_is_a_test_file.txt hammer# cd .. hammer# makefs -t cd9660 -o rockridge tmp.iso tmp hammer# tar tfv tmp.iso drwx------ 2 0 0 2048 12 31 1969 . lrwxr-xr-x 1 0 0 23 1 17 15:05 this_is_a_test_file.tmp -> this_is_a_test_file.txt -rw-r--r-- 1 0 0 0 1 17 15:05 this_is_a_test_file.txt link to this_is_a_test_file.tmp hammer# mkdir tmp2 hammer# cd tmp2 hammer# tar xfv ../tmp.iso x . x this_is_a_test_file.tmp x this_is_a_test_file.txt: Can't create 'this_is_a_test_file.txt' tar: Error exit delayed from previous errors. hammer# ls -la total 4 drwx------ 2 root wheel 512 1 17 15:07 . drwxr-xr-x 5 root wheel 512 1 17 15:06 .. lrwxr-xr-x 1 root wheel 23 1 17 15:05 this_is_a_test_file.tmp -> this_is_a_test_file.txt What is the expected output? What do you see instead? hammer# mkisofs -R -o tmp2.iso tmp Setting input-charset to 'UTF-8' from locale. Total translation table size: 0 Total rockridge attributes bytes: 421 Total directory bytes: 0 Path table size(bytes): 10 Max brk space used 0 176 extents written (0 MB) hammer# tar tfv tmp2.iso drwxr-xr-x 2 0 0 2048 1 17 15:05 . -rw-r--r-- 1 0 0 21 1 17 15:05 this_is_a_test_file.txt lrwxr-xr-x 1 0 0 0 1 17 15:05 this_is_a_test_file.tmp -> this_is_a_test_file.txt hammer# mkdir tmp2 hammer# cd tmp2 hammer# tar xfv ../tmp2.iso x . x this_is_a_test_file.txt x this_is_a_test_file.tmp hammer# ls -la total 6 drwxr-xr-x 2 root wheel 512 1 17 15:08 . drwxr-xr-x 5 root wheel 512 1 17 15:08 .. lrwxr-xr-x 1 root wheel 23 1 17 15:05 this_is_a_test_file.tmp -> this_is_a_test_file.txt -rw-r--r-- 1 root wheel 21 1 17 15:05 this_is_a_test_file.txt What version are you using? hammer# tar --version bsdtar 2.8.5 - libarchive 2.8.5 On what operating system? hammer# uname -mprs FreeBSD 10.0-CURRENT amd64 amd64 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) Built in FreeBSD base. (Note: Both libarchive 2.8.5 and 3.0.3 built directly from sources show the same behaviour.) What compiler or development environment (please include version)? hammer# cc --version cc (GCC) 4.2.1 20070831 patched [FreeBSD] Copyright (C) 2007 Free Software Foundation, Inc. This is free software; see the source for copying conditions. There is NO warranty; not even for MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE. Please provide any additional information below. I can mount the image and everything works fine, e.g., hammer# mkdir tmp3 hammer# mdconfig -a -t vnode -f tmp.iso md0 hammer# mount_cd9660 /dev/md0 tmp3 hammer# ls -l tmp3 total 0 lrwxr-xr-x 1 root wheel 23 1 17 15:05 this_is_a_test_file.tmp -> this_is_a_test_file.txt -rw-r--r-- 1 root wheel 21 1 17 15:05 this_is_a_test_file.txt hammer# cat tmp3/this_is_a_test_file.txt This is a test file. hammer# cat tmp3/this_is_a_test_file.tmp This is a test file. This CD9660 image is attached as a reference. Please note this problem is critical because it prevented me from verifying FreeBSD 9.0-RELEASE CD-ROMs: hammer# tar tfv FreeBSD-9.0-RELEASE-amd64-disc1.iso > /dev/null tar: Ignoring out-of-order file (usr/sbin/chown) 83736576 < 564533248 tar: Ignoring out-of-order file (usr/share/man/man3/getlogin_r.3.gz) 617725952 < 618725376 tar: Ignoring out-of-order file (usr/share/man/man3/FD_CLR.3.gz) 618008576 < 618725376 tar: Ignoring out-of-order file (usr/share/man/man3/FD_ISSET.3.gz) 618008576 < 618725376 tar: Ignoring out-of-order file (usr/share/man/man3/FD_SET.3.gz) 618008576 < 618725376 tar: Ignoring out-of-order file (usr/share/man/man3/FD_ZERO.3.gz) 618008576 < 618725376 tar: Ignoring out-of-order file (usr/share/man/man5/malloc.conf.5.gz) 619102208 < 623835136 tar: Ignoring out-of-order file (usr/share/man/man8/inetd.8.gz) 624113664 < 625053696 tar: Ignoring out-of-order file (usr/share/zoneinfo/Europe/Oslo) 640262144 < 640591872 tar: Ignoring out-of-order file (usr/share/zoneinfo/Europe/Istanbul) 640348160 < 640591872 tar: Ignoring out-of-order file (usr/share/zoneinfo/Europe/Nicosia) 640391168 < 640591872 tar: Error exit delayed from previous errors. Please also note there are 'Ignoring out-of-order file' issue. I don't know how to reproduce it, though.
It is little hackish but I was able to work around the wrong hardlink problem with the attached patch.  I still don't know how to reproduce or fix the 'Ignoring out-of-order file' issue. :-/
This patch is the same patch redone against 3.0.3.

I found another problem.  It seems makefs generated .rr_moved directory is not properly handled.

hammer# mkdir tmp
hammer# cd tmp
hammer# mkdir -p this/is/very/long/directory/structure/which/generates/rr_moved/directory
hammer# touch this/is/very/long/directory/structure/which/generates/rr_moved/directory/test.txt

hammer# tar tfv tmp.iso
drwx------  3 0      0        2048 12 31  1969 .
drwxr-xr-x  3 0      0        2048  1 17 19:38 this

x .

x this/is

x this/is/very/long
x this/is/very/long/directory
x this/is/very/long/directory/structure
x this/is/very/long/directory/structure/which
