x this/is/very/long/directory/structure/which/generates/rr_moved
x this/is/very/long/directory/structure/which/generates/rr_moved/directory
hammer# find . -name test.txt
./.rr_moved/generates/rr_moved/directory/test.txt

I can mount this image just fine:

hammer# mdconfig -a -t vnode -f tmp.iso
md0
hammer# mount_cd9660 /dev/md0 /cdrom
hammer# ls -al /cdrom
total 8
drwxr-xr-x   3 root  wheel  2048 12 31  1969 .
drwxr-xr-x  24 root  wheel  2048  1 16 18:34 ..
drwxr-xr-x   3 root  wheel  2048  1 17 19:38 .rr_moved
drwxr-xr-x   3 root  wheel  2048  1 17 19:38 this
hammer# ls -al /cdrom/.rr_moved
total 4
drwxr-xr-x  3 root  wheel  2048  1 17 19:38 .
drwxr-xr-x  3 root  wheel  2048 12 31  1969 ..
hammer# find /cdrom -name test.txt
/cdrom/this/is/very/long/directory/structure/which/generates/rr_moved/directory/test.txt

mkisofs generated file is good, however:

hammer# mkisofs -R -o tmp2.iso tmp
Setting input-charset to 'UTF-8' from locale.
Total translation table size: 0
Total rockridge attributes bytes: 2995
Total directory bytes: 22528
Path table size(bytes): 166
Max brk space used 0
186 extents written (0 MB)
hammer# mkdir test
hammer# cd test
hammer# tar xfv ../tmp2.iso
x .
x this
x this/is
x this/is/very
x this/is/very/long
x this/is/very/long/directory
x this/is/very/long/directory/structure
x this/is/very/long/directory/structure/which
x this/is/very/long/directory/structure/which/generates
x this/is/very/long/directory/structure/which/generates/rr_moved
x this/is/very/long/directory/structure/which/generates/rr_moved/directory
x this/is/very/long/directory/structure/which/generates/rr_moved/directory/test.txt
hammer# find . -name test.txt
./this/is/very/long/directory/structure/which/generates/rr_moved/directory/test.txt
I am attaching the file with this problem.

bsdtar reads ISO files sequentially from the beginning.

This is good:  it allows bsdtar to read compressed ISO images directly, since it does not have to seek around within the image.

This is a problem:  Some ISO images cannot be accurately read this way; it depends on how the program that created the ISO image structured the data within the ISO.  The makefs program that was recently imported into FreeBSD does not order the data in a way that can always be cleanly read by libarchive.

You might also look at makefs to see if it's layout calculations can be improved.  In particular, it would be nice if it consistently put directory information before the file bodies referenced by those directories.  (This is what causes the "Ignoring out-of-order file" warnings.  This is also why the .rr_moved directory gets extracted the way it does; makefs apparently puts the .rr_moved directory before the file body but puts the file body before the splice point, so libarchive does not have full information about the directory relocation at the time it has to extract the file body to disk.)

I fixed this issue(the original problem) in trunk.
Attached patch files are for 2.8.5 and 3.0.3.

The patch fixed the issue, thanks!  Please close this issue.
As Tim pointed out, "out-of-order" issue is not easy to fix ATM.

items.title: Troubles extracting some Zip archives in bsdtar 3.x
items.summary: Troubles extracting some Zip archives in bsdtar 3.x

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Find archive that does not work, for example http://download.narechk.net/dos32a-912-bin.zip 2. bsdtar -xf dos32a-912-bin.zip 3. It says "binw/: Can't remove already-existing dir" What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Archive should be unpacked. It works with unzip command and worked with libarchive 2.x. What version are you using? 3.0.3 On what operating system? Linux x86_64 (ArchLinux 64-bit) How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) pre-packaged binary What compiler or development environment (please include version)? gcc 4.6.2 Please provide any additional information below. I don't know what archives return this error - there are zip archives that work. Other example could be minecraft.jar, and probably lot more.

It appears to be specific to the new seeking Zip reader, because it works just fine if you use:
   cat dos32a-912-bin.zip | bsdtar -xf -

I'll take a careful look at it over the weekend.

updates.summary: Troubles extracting some Zip archives in bsdtar 3.x

items.content:
Ah.  I see.  The archive in question was created on Windows.  The new seeking Zip reader interprets all non-POSIX files as regular files.  In particular, the 'binw' entry here is getting interpreted as a plain file.  This causes the restore-to-disk code to complain when it tries to replace the 'binw' directory that has already been created with a plain file.

I think this is an easy fix, but I'll need to do a little research to make sure I understand how non-POSIX Zip implementations record the file type.  (I suspect it's based on filename.)

I believe this is fixed in libarchive/trunk r4190.

If this looks good to you, I'll merge it for inclusion in the next 3.0 release.
That was fast! I just verified that it works now, thanks!
I applied r4190 on top of 3.0.3 and all tests passed for me. I did not tested trunk though (and now that I did, I can confirm #231)

Merged in r4199.

Thanks for the report!  Please let us know if you find any other issues.

items.title: Infinite loop on an XPS (zip) file
items.summary: Infinite loop on an XPS (zip) file

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Use evince or one of the xpstopng type tools from libgxps to open DefendYourComputer_brochure_HiResNoBleed.xps from http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/details.aspx?id=11479 2. 3. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? The xpstopng program should output some png images of the xps document, but instead the xpstopng program hangs using 100% of a CPU. What version are you using? libarchive 3.0.3 On what operating system? Fedora 16 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) I built from the 3.0.3 tarball after discovering libarchive 2.8.5 gave a "bad zip file" error for that file, and rebuilt various packages for 3.0.3. What compiler or development environment (please include version)? gcc 4.6.2-1.fc16 Please provide any additional information below. XPS documents are zip files containing XML and other files. libgxps is used by evince (the gnome.org document viewer) to display xps files, and libgxps uses libarchive to read zip files. "unzip -t" and "7z t" report no problems with that file. "zipinfo -v" reports "There are an extra 16 bytes preceding this file." for every file in that xps file. The first part of the backtrace from killing the program looks like this: #0 archive_read_format_zip_read_data_skip (a=0x628030) at libarchive/archive_read_support_format_zip.c:1096 p = 0x62c140 "X\210o\225FN\350\311\317\030\352x\003\236\301", <incomplete sequence \332> buff = 0x62c140 "X\210o\225FN\350\311\317\030\352x\003\236\301", <incomplete sequence \332> bytes_avail = 16 zip = 0x625c90 #1 0x00007ffff6a5ab11 in archive_read_data_skip (_a=0x628030) at libarchive/archive_read.c:687 a = 0x628030 r = 6404160 buff = 0x60aee0 size = 6380352 offset = 140737334465838 #2 0x00007ffff7bc7787 in ?? () from /usr/lib64/libgxps.so.2 I've attached a possible fix.

Your patch looks promising.

Do you have a (small) sample XPS file that we could add to the libarchive test suite to ensure that this doesn't break again in the future?

I don't think all XPS documents have those 16 extras bytes preceding each file that zipinfo reports, since another one I downloaded from microsoft doesn't, but both files I've created just now using the XPS Document Writer printer in Windows XP do.

testpage.xps is from printing a printer test page - I could reproduce the bug with this one.

notepad-test-file.xps is smaller, just a line of text printed from notepad, but I couldn't reproduce the bug with this file.
Another test file that I can reproduce the bug with, this time without the Windows logo, which is on printer test pages.

The "16 bytes garbage between entries" is not garbage (I don't know why zipinfo reports it this way).  It's a 16-byte marker that is inserted just after each entry so that streaming Zip readers (such as libarchive when it doesn't have a seek callback) can detect the end of an entry.  These markers are only inserted when the writer doesn't know the length of an entry when it starts writing it.

So here's an accurate description of the problem:  The streaming Zip reader hangs when reading an uncompressed entry using length-at-end where the length-at-end marker falls exactly at the end of a block.

I'm very impressed that you found this!  Based on the above, I now know how to build a test for this, but it might be a few more days before I can put all of the pieces together.

I finally worked up a test that reliably reproduces the failure, it uses the small Notepad-generated file you sent us.

The test and the fix were committed to trunk as r4191 (first draft of the test) and r4201 (complete test and fix).

These changes were merged to libarchive/3.0 at r4203.

If anyone needs a link at github: https://github.com/libarchive/libarchive/commit/f7cd53ca1eda0d08fc3b3876ed474321b9f70ac7
Thanks for the fix :)

items.title: MacOS: bsdtar doesn't save/restore bkuptime
items.summary: MacOS: bsdtar doesn't save/restore bkuptime

items.content:
Split out from Issue 155:  A general test suite used to verify file backup and copy utilities on Mac OS has found that bsdtar 2.6.2 does not save/restore bkuptime.

See Issue 155 for more details.

The source code for the particular test is here:
   https://github.com/neoneye/AnalyzeCopy/blob/master/Tests/91_bkuptime.rb

The test fails part 'A'.  (The file is copied but the backup time is not preserved.)

Archiving bkuptime should be routine:  It's easy to extend archive_entry to support a new time, and easy to add another attribute to the pax writer to save it.

Restoring bkuptime should also be routine.

The hard part is figuring out when bkuptime should be restored.  I don't think backup time should be restored by default.  The restored file is, after all, a new file.  The policy in bsdtar has been to tie extra metadata to the -p option, though that might be inappropriate as well.

I'm marking this as "Low Priority" since I expect it to only be used behind a special option, and therefore expect it to receive very little use.

items.title: SVN trunk fails to build on OSX: ld: malformed version number: 13.900
items.summary: SVN trunk fails to build on OSX: ld: malformed version number: 13.900

items.content:
Code from SVN trunk fails to build because of a restriction on the version numbers on OSX. It looks like the same problem as http://comments.gmane.org/gmane.comp.window-managers.enlightenment.devel/30780 : 

"The format of number is X[.Y[.Z]] where X must be a positive non-zero number less than or equal to 65535, and .Y and .Z are optional and if present must be non-negative numbers less than or equal to 255.  If the
version number is not specified, it has a value of 0.  This option is also called -dylib_current_version for compatibility.

So on OS X v_mic can't be larger than 255. Should we make this default for
all platforms, or just for darwin?"

The version here is intended to just be larger than any real 3.0 release, to indicate that the trunk is being prepared for 3.1.  So I've just changed it to 200 instead of 900.

Thanks for tracking that down!

items.summary: 7zip handler generates (null) error message when invalid options given

items.content:
When a 7zip archive is being created but invalid --options parameters are specified, instead of an error message bsdtar displays:

bsdtar: (null)

e.g.

bsdtar cf foo.7z --format 7zip --options a foo

(ar format writer does not support any options.)

bsdtar: (null)

Thank you for the report.

items.title: archiving fails on linux 2.6.18 using reiserfs
items.summary: archiving fails on linux 2.6.18 using reiserfs

items.content:
> What steps will reproduce the problem?
With source files on reiserfs: bsdtar cf foo.tar <directory-with-files>


> What is the expected output? What do you see instead?
I see a lot of errors: "bsdtar: FIEMAP failed: Invalid argument" for every file. The resulting archive has only directories in it.


> What version are you using?
3.0.3, with patches backported to fix a recent issue with non-POSIX zips.


> On what operating system?
Arch Linux (32-bit) running on a 2.6.18 kernel in an OpenVZ container. This isn't my VPS, but the reporter of the issue was nice enough to give me an account on the VPS to 


> How did you build?  (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary)
Built with ./configure --prefix=/usr --without-xml2


> What compiler or development environment (please include version)?
gcc 4.6.2
binutils 2.22
glibc 2.15


> Please provide any additional information below.
I've attached a patch that fixes the problem by merely returning from sparse_setup() with ARCHIVE_OK when the FIEMAP call fails for _any_ reason. In this particular case, ioctl() is returning EINVAL, which is not one of the "whitelisted" error codes. libarchive is smart enough to fall back on more conventional methods of reading the file and continues on.

Prior to this patch, a large number of tests are failing (as expected). I've attached the failing output for those. With the patch applied, the test suite passes on both the affected machine and my unaffected machine (which has a working FIEMAP ioctl).
the same in 2.6.32 kernel in OpenVZ container.

Thank you for the report.
I committed a fix as your patch.

works for me, thanks, please get this into version control asap

I already committed the patches.
I'll close this issue.

items.title: CAB decompression doesn't work when libarchive built with MSVC2010 (express)
items.summary: CAB decompression doesn't work when libarchive built with MSVC2010 (express)

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. download http://download.windowsupdate.com/microsoftupdate/v6/wsusscan/wsusscn2.cab 2. extract files from that archive => Error LZX Decompression failed (-25) What version are you using? libarchive 3.0.3 On what operating system? Windows 7 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) cmake on MSVC2010 express. I'm not using zlib, nor bz2, really just libarchive as a static lib. What compiler or development environment (please include version)? MSVC 2010 express Please provide any additional information below. Interestingly our build box is using MSVC2008 pro and the packages from there have a correct behaviour.
BTW, the error occurs when reading data from the archive. Getting the header and opening the cab file works.

I just checked and indeed if I compile libarchive with MSVC2008 and run archive_test test_read_format_cab, I get no failure
When I compile with MSVC2010, I get:

Exercising: libarchive 3.0.3
 66: test_read_format_cab                              FAIL

Totals:
  Tests run:                1
  Tests failed:             1
  Assertions checked:     612
  Assertions failed:       16
  Skips reported:           1

Failing tests:
  66: test_read_format_cab (16 failures)

Details for failing tests: C:\Users\thierry\AppData\Local\Temp/libarchive_test.e
xe.2012-02-15T14.26.31-000

I compiled libarchvie with MSVC2010 on Windows XP 32bit.
It works fine as well as compiled with MSVC2008.

Is your Windows 7 a 64Bit platform ?
Can I see your config.h cmake made, both for MSVC2010 and for MSVC2008 ?

Hi,

My windows is indeed 64 bit but I'm building 32 bit software.
I'm using MSVC2010 express version 10.0.40219.1 SP1.
Here is attached the config.h you asked for. I had tried to use the MSVC2008 config to build with MSVC2010 but it was still bogus. If it can help I just got a report that on a OSX 10.7 Lion machine, one of our developers is also experiencing the issue (LZX decompression failed (-25)). I haven't had time to test it myself yet.

To be totally clear, to run the test, I go to libarchive\test and run ..\..\bin\libarchive_test 66

Prior to that I simply run cmake . && nmake.

Thanks for your quick replies. It is really appreciated.

aha, I've just tried trunk and it works wayyyyyy better. Is it safe to use trunk?
We're not releasing before a long time so I guess my question is: is 3.0.4 (or whatever is the next release) going to be based off of trunk?

I just tried trunk and thought that would fix it because it seems it is able to extract at least some files and the unit tests are not showing errors but... the git repo's last change is dated from Feb 2nd, so older than what was fixed in issue 241...

We've migrated our source repository to GitHub.
You can get the latest source code from https://github.com/libarchive/libarchive

Attached file shows the difference between my config.h and you config.h for MSVC2010.
I wonder why your config.h does not define HAVE_STDINT_H macro and related definitions,
HAVE_INT*_T and HAVE_UINT*_T.
It seems the configuration for MSVC2010 didn't correctly be handled.
I doubt you might run cmake for MSVC2010 though CMakeCache.txt for MSVC2008 remained
since config.h and config.h.2008 you updated were the same. it looks strange to me.
If so, I recommend making a build directory for cmake.
  % make build-msvc2010
  % cd build-msvc2010
  % cmake -G <generator-name> /path/to/libarchive/source
It's clear and safety when you try different compilers against one source tree.

I have run cmake with MSVC 2010 on a clean source tree. So that is not the problem.
Maybe it is because. I somehow messed up the upload. Here is the correct MSVC 2010 config.h. I can't use yours because I don't have bz2 and all the others.

I've seen that the source is available on github. I must have been pulling from a different repo then.

Thanks a lot. I'll try latest trunk and see if it is better.
other attempt for getting config.h...
I just tried trunk and it works.... After some more check it seems the problem occurs when building in release.. This might very well be a miscompilation somewhere.
I think i'm approaching the problem. I tried a trunk and it works. And the actual thing that makes it work is that I'm building it in debug. Release fails...

It looks like a compiler issue in release. I was able to to up to -O1 (O2 and Ox fail).
Are you able to reproduce that on your side too?

Thank you very much for your great investigation.
I found out where the code was unexpectedly changed by MSVC optimization.

Please try an attached patch.
Thanks, that worked beautifully
I'll close this issue.

items.title: ssize_t not found when building on cygwin with cl.exe.
items.summary: ssize_t not found when building on cygwin with cl.exe.

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. win7, cygwin, using cl.exe compiler from x64 sdk. 2. configure and then make What is the expected output? What do you see instead? code configures well, but does not compile. Sounds like ssize typedef is not being found, leading to compile error. Also, many macros are not defined, which is probably why ssize is not defined. See output log. What version are you using? 3.0.03 On what operating system? win7, 64 build. How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) configure What compiler or development environment (please include version)? cl.exe cl.exe --version Microsoft (R) C/C++ Optimizing Compiler Version 16.00.30319.01 for x64 Copyright (C) Microsoft Corporation. All rights reserved. cl : Command line warning D9002 : ignoring unknown option '--version' cl : Command line error D8003 : missing source filename Please provide any additional information below.

Nothing here looks particularly alarming except for the lack of "ssize_t" and "pid_t".

Where are those declared on your system?

If they are not declared anywhere, try adding

#define ssize_t int
#define pid_t int

to the bottom of your config.h and then see how far you get.  (That will help identify if those are the only missing definitions.)  If this fixes it and those types are in fact not defined anywhere in your system, we may have to add additional configure tests to automate this.

Better:  If they are defined somewhere, let's make sure we're looking for that header and add the appropriate #include to archive_platform.h just before archive_windows.h is included (with appropriate guards, of course).

updates.summary: ssize_t not found when building on cygwin with cl.exe.

items.content:
SSIZE_T exists see http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/aa383751%28v=vs.85%29.aspx

defining ssize_t to an int if not good as there can be a problem with 64 bits architecture.

the GNU C library defined pid_t as an int so it should be good with an int.

items.title: Test failure, file corruption on ARMv5 platforms
items.summary: Test failure, file corruption on ARMv5 platforms

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Using bsdtar to create an archive in a chroot, sudo -u nobody, on an ARMv5 platform. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Expected is an archive with files intact. What is seen is consistent (though seemingly arbitrary) zeroing in the first 1024 bytes of some files within the resultant archive. What version are you using? 3.0.3 On what operating system? Arch Linux ARM How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) ./configure --prefix=/usr --without-xml2 make What compiler or development environment (please include version)? GCC 4.6.2 (snapshot 4.6-20120120), GLIBC 2.15 (snapshot 20111227) CFLAGS="-march=armv5te -O2 -pipe -fstack-protector --param=ssp-buffer-size=4 -D_FORTIFY_SOURCE=2" Please provide any additional information below. One test failure during 'make check': test_sparse_basic libarchive/test/test_sparse_basic.c:285: blocks != archive_entry_sparse_count(ae) blocks=5 (0x5, 05) archive_entry_sparse_count(ae)=0 (0x0, 00) libarchive/test/test_sparse_basic.c:300: blocks != data_blocks blocks=5 (0x5, 05) data_blocks=0 (0x0, 00) libarchive/test/test_sparse_basic.c:285: blocks != archive_entry_sparse_count(ae) blocks=2 (0x2, 02) archive_entry_sparse_count(ae)=0 (0x0, 00) libarchive/test/test_sparse_basic.c:300: blocks != data_blocks blocks=2 (0x2, 02) data_blocks=0 (0x0, 00) libarchive/test/test_sparse_basic.c:285: blocks != archive_entry_sparse_count(ae) blocks=20 (0x14, 024) archive_entry_sparse_count(ae)=0 (0x0, 00) libarchive/test/test_sparse_basic.c:300: blocks != data_blocks blocks=20 (0x14, 024) data_blocks=0 (0x0, 00) libarchive/test/test_sparse_basic.c:335: blocks != archive_entry_sparse_count(ae) blocks=5 (0x5, 05) archive_entry_sparse_count(ae)=0 (0x0, 00) libarchive/test/test_sparse_basic.c:335: blocks != archive_entry_sparse_count(ae) blocks=5 (0x5, 05) archive_entry_sparse_count(ae)=0 (0x0, 00) libarchive/test/test_sparse_basic.c:285: Summary: Failed 3 times libarchive/test/test_sparse_basic.c:300: Summary: Failed 3 times libarchive/test/test_sparse_basic.c:335: Summary: Failed 2 times

It seems the filesystem `make check` was running on does not support FIEMAP and
the test_sparse_basic should be skipped

Please try attached patch.

Received the same exact failure and log for test_sparse_basic as above with the patch.

The error appears to be more processor related than anything else, at least to me. Some more information that is hopefully useful: the platform that is experiencing the failure is a Marvell Kirkwood 88F6281 SoC (ARMv5tel).  Running the same set of circumstances that causes a failure on a Pandaboard (TI OMAP 4430 ARMv7l) running the v5 filesystem we have shows no test failure, no file corruption. It's also not experienced on PLX NAS7280 SoC (ARMv6l) platforms that use the same v5 system.

If it would help to attach any of the resultant archives with the corruption, I can do that.

Without access to the system, tracking this down will be tricky, but if you can give us some more details, maybe we can get there.

  * Are all three of these ARM systems running the same Linux kernel?  The sparse warnings have been reported elsewhere on older kernels.

  * Are all three ARM systems using the same filesystem?  (If the bug is related to sparse files, then it may vary with the specific filesystem, as different Linux filesystems report sparse file information differently.)

  * What exact command line are you using to create the archive?

  * If you can generate a small file archive that demonstrates the problem and upload it to this bug, that might also help.

  * You mention "corruption"; does that appear when you try to extract the archive?  What program are you using to extract it?

The three different systems are running three different kernels respective to their architecture, though all of them at least 3.1.

All three were tested using the same base filesystem and packages required to build libarchive.

The command is 'bsdtar -cf - <files> | xz -c -z -'  (FWIW, switching out bsdtar with tar here negates any corruption, and is the current workaround)

The corruption that happens is during the creation of the archive, not during extraction.  The files that end up with problems are all fine prior to packaging.  Extraction is done also with bsdtar by the system, with the same results using tar for extraction.

Attached is an archive built using bsdtar, the file to note within the archive is "usr/share/file/magic.mgc" which shows the zeroing at the beginning:
0000000    0000    0000    0000    0000    0000    0000    0000    0000
*
00a2a30    0000    0000    0000    0000    6143    636c    0000    0000

compared to the good file:
0000000    041c    f11e    0008    0000    0000    0000    0000    0000
0000010    0000    0000    0000    0000    0000    0000    0000    0000
*
00000e0    0000    0000    0000    0000    0000    0020    1f3d    0005

Yeah, that's what I suspected.  For some reason, bsdtar is storing this particular file as a sparse file.  It asked the kernel (using FIEMAP) and believes that the first half of the file (approximately) is empty.

Can you try again with the most recent code from github?  We've fixed a couple of issues related to FIEMAP support recently that may be related to this.  Though that doesn't really explain why you would be seeing this only on ARMv5.  That's very peculiar.

For what it's worth, here's the relevant parts of that archive:

The extended tar attributes that come shortly before the file body.  Note the GNU.sparse attributes that specify this is being stored as a sparse file:


00040a00  32 30 20 63 74 69 6d 65  3d 31 33 33 31 35 39 37  |20 ctime=1331597|
00040a10  30 37 39 0a 32 30 20 61  74 69 6d 65 3d 31 33 33  |079.20 atime=133|
00040a20  31 35 39 37 30 38 30 0a  32 32 20 47 4e 55 2e 73  |1597080.22 GNU.s|
00040a30  70 61 72 73 65 2e 6d 61  6a 6f 72 3d 31 0a 32 32  |parse.major=1.22|
00040a40  20 47 4e 55 2e 73 70 61  72 73 65 2e 6d 69 6e 6f  | GNU.sparse.mino|
00040a50  72 3d 30 0a 34 34 20 47  4e 55 2e 73 70 61 72 73  |r=0.44 GNU.spars|
00040a60  65 2e 6e 61 6d 65 3d 75  73 72 2f 73 68 61 72 65  |e.name=usr/share|
00040a70  2f 66 69 6c 65 2f 6d 61  67 69 63 2e 6d 67 63 0a  |/file/magic.mgc.|
00040a80  33 31 20 47 4e 55 2e 73  70 61 72 73 65 2e 72 65  |31 GNU.sparse.re|
00040a90  61 6c 73 69 7a 65 3d 32  32 36 35 37 31 32 0a 00  |alsize=2265712..|
00040aa0  00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00  00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00  |................|

And the file itself is stored with this header, which indicates that the archive is storing only a single block of 1599559 bytes that start at offset 666153.


00040e00  31 0a 36 36 36 31 35 33  0a 31 35 39 39 35 35 39  |1.666153.1599559|
00040e10  0a 00 00 00 00 00 00 00  00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00  |................|
00040e20  00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00  00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00  |................|
*

This is clearly screwy; 666153 is not at all a round number.  Holes in large files like this should always comprise an exact number of filesystem blocks.
Using a git pull as of about an hour ago, the file corruption seems to have disappeared.  The test_sparse_basic test still fails with the same as above, however.

The test failure is probably just a test issue.  Do you know whether that kernel/filesystem supports FIEMAP?

The most likely explanation of both issues:  FIEMAP isn't supported on that system.  The tests are reporting failures on tests that simply aren't relevant and should be skipped.  The 3.0.3 version of libarchive is trying to invoke FIEMAP, failing, and then trying to parse a garbage response.
I'll look more into FIEMAP support and see what I can come up with.  Since everything works in git I'd say this is a non-issue at the point.  Thanks for your time in helping to troubleshoot.

items.title: Could you please consider forcing the build of release from the CMakeLists?
items.summary: Could you please consider forcing the build of release from the CMakeLists?

items.content:
The thing is that on windows it is preferable to build both debug and release. It is currently impossible without patching the cmakelists.txt to remove the line that sets the current build as release.
AFAIK cmake anyway defaults to release, so could you guys remove that line?

Instead of removing the line, I suggest the following patch.

--- a/CMakeLists.txt
+++ b/CMakeLists.txt
@@ -7,7 +7,9 @@ SET(CMAKE_MODULE_PATH "${CMAKE_CURRENT_SOURCE_DIR}/build/cmake")
 if(NOT CMAKE_RUNTIME_OUTPUT_DIRECTORY)
   set(CMAKE_RUNTIME_OUTPUT_DIRECTORY ${libarchive_BINARY_DIR}/bin)
 endif()
-SET(CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE "Release")
+IF(NOT CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE)
+  SET(CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE "Release")
+ENDIF(NOT CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE)

 # On MacOS, prefer MacPorts libraries to system libraries.
 # I haven't come up with a compelling argument for this to be conditional.

That sounds good to me: not overriding my settings on the command line.
If you allow that in it means I will be able to use libarchive 3.0.4 finally without patching it.
I committed a fix about this issue and I'll close this.
Thanks a lot.

items.title: Unicode filenames inside RAR not working
items.summary: Unicode filenames inside RAR not working

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? Attached RAR file contains one file called ".xlsx". Read filenames in attached file with archive_read_next_header and archive_entry_pathname_w. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Expected filename == ".xlsx", but get "". What version are you using? 3.0.3 On what operating system? Win7-64 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) Cmake What compiler or development environment (please include version)? VS2010 Please provide any additional information below. 64-bit build.

Thank you for you report.
Please try attached patch and let me know the result.
Works perfectly.  Thanks.

Previous patch fixed the sample case you uploaded but I found there were unicode
filenames that bsdtar/libarchive did not correctly parse like this filename
abcdefghijklmnopqrs.txt.
Please use new attached patch instead of old one.
I will try it.  Does this also work on platforms where sizeof wchar_t == 4?
Not working on Ubuntu, just for this file.  Perhaps because wchar_t == 4 on that platform.

What error message did you see ? It works on my Ubuntu and FreeBSD machine.

We never assume that unicode filenames in RAR archives are wchar_t even on Windows
platform.

I've run some tests, and it doesn't seem to be working on Linux for me.  These are my results...

Results for Patches 1 and 2
Win64: Pass
Ubuntu: Error 84 - "Pathname cannot be converted from UTF-16BE to current locale."
Centos: Error 84 (only tested patch 2)

The error only occurs on the Unicode filename after the call to archive_read_next_header.  Otherwise, it's all working.

Ubuntu system details:
OS=2.6.35-30-generic #56-Ubuntu x86_64
Language option=English-US
gcc=4.4.5 (Ubuntu/Linaro 4.4.4-14ubuntu5)

echo $LANG ?
Does your test program call setlocale(LC_ALL, "") ?
libarchive uses the result of nl_langinfo(CODESET) for iconv.
If "./libarchive_test test_read_format_rar" or "make check-TESTS" pass,
your test program surely does not call setlocale() or LANG=C.

$LANG == en_US.UTF-8

The unit tests do pass.  I've now added setlocale(LC_ALL, "") to my test program and this cures the error message.  I didn't realise I had to do that.

The only problem now is that when I assign

std::wstring str = archive_entry_pathname_w(entry);

the endianess of the wchars are wrong, so I get the wrong symbols out.  The bytes are all there - just in the wrong order.

Also - is there any way to get at the raw filename to avoid the conversion to the current locale, and hence avoid the need to call setlocale?  

My project is also a library and I don't want to change the locale of the calling program.

There is not currently a way to get the "raw" filename.  That could be added, though it's a pretty complex interface (requiring that you handle a pointer to a block of memory with a length and an associated encoding specification).  It's probably simpler to require your clients to call setlocale().  (If no one ever calls set locale, you're basically limited to ASCII, which is the root source of the error you saw.)

Wrong endianness is worrisome; that should not happen.

Can you dump the output of archive_entry_pathname(entry) (which should be valid UTF-8) and archive_entry_pathname_w(entry) (which should be Unicode wchar_t)?
With respect to the raw filename - I could actually just use the UTF8.  I don't understand why converting from Unicode to Unicode requires locale info?
Which platform does that happen, Windows or Ubuntu ?

>>I don't understand why converting from Unicode to Unicode requires locale info?
1. As I said libarchive uses nl_langinfo(CODESET) on POSIX system to know what the current locale is. libarchive cannot decide what character-set libarchive convert filenames from Unicode to with iconv unless libarchive gets the current locale info.
2. libarchive uses mbrtowc function to translate multi-byte string to wchar_t string and mbrtowc entirely depends on the current locale. (some iconv can handle wchar_t but it's GNU' specific.)

There are many platforms. We have to consider that although modern Unix like system uses UTF-8 locale by default non UTF-8 locale is still used, and wchar_t is not Unicode on every plaform and the format of wchar_t is not specified by POSIX.
Dump of strings is from Ubuntu. Windows is working fine in all respects.

To Tim, I'm thinking of the raw interface for an internal use in the case of
doing bsdtar cf foo.tar @bar. If the bar archive includes the non-ASCII filename
the current locale does not support, that archive conversion may fail.
If archive_entry(archive_mstring) can hold raw filename and its encoding
bsdtar can properly copy the filenames on whatever the current locale is.

On linux, libarchive 3.0.3 uses mbsnrtowcs to translate a filename from MBS to WCS.

1. Cloud you try to use mbsnrtowcs with the output of archive_entry_pathname(entry)
to get WCS, and compare the result to  the output of archive_entry_pathname_w(entry) ?
I believe those two must be the same.

2. Cloud you try following patch ? It disables mbsnrtowcs and uses mbrtowc instead.

diff --git a/libarchive/archive_string.c b/libarchive/archive_string.c
index 550d7e7..c848958 100644
--- a/libarchive/archive_string.c
+++ b/libarchive/archive_string.c
@@ -589,7 +589,7 @@ archive_wstring_append_from_mbs_in_codepage(struct archive_wstring *dest,
 	return (ret);
 }
 
-#elif defined(HAVE_MBSNRTOWCS)
+#elif defined(HAVE_MBSNRTOWCS) && 0/* Disabled */
 
 /*
  * Convert MBS to WCS.

1. Yes - identical.

2. The behaviour of the library is unchanged - the endianness of archive_entry_pathname_w still seems wrong.

> string .xlsx
> e3,83,86,e3,82,b9,e3,83,88,ef,bc,93,2e,78,6c,73,78,

> wstring (funny symbols)
> c6,30,0,0,b9,30,0,0,c8,30,0,0,13,ff,0,0,2e,0,0,0,78,0,0,0,6c,0,0,0,73,0,0,0,78,0,0,0,

Assuming you're on a little-endian system (such as an Intel/AMD desktop or laptop), that looks exactly correct.  c6,30,0,0 is the four-byte integer 0x30c6, which is the Unicode code point for 'KATAKANA LETTER TE' ().

Why do you believe there is a byte-order problem?

dump expectedFilename ?

Does your test program invoke std::wcout.imbue(std::locale("")) or std::wcout.imbue(std::locale("en_US.UTF-8")) ?

I don't think the output of mbsnrtowcs/mbrtowc glibc provides is wrong, do you?

Guys - I have found that the conversion problem on different platforms is occurring in my own library function - not related to libarchive.  It was that that was generating the funny symbols I was seeing.  Libarchive is indeed producing the right result on Windows and Ubuntu.  My bad - sorry for that!

No problem.  After working on libarchive's character-conversion logic, I think everyone here understands how tricky it can be to get it right.

Glad you figured it out!

I'll close this.

items.title: add support for lrzip's new libs
items.summary: add support for lrzip's new libs

items.content:
See
   https://github.com/libarchive/libarchive/wiki/LibarchiveAddingReadFilter
for documentation on how to write this type of integration.
@kientzle - I have 0 experience coding in c.  If your comment directed at me?

My comment was directed to whoever might volunteer to implement this.  ;-)

For what it's worth, lrzip has been suggested before.  Integrating lrzip compression directly into libarchive (or any other archiving library) might not actually work very well; lrzip is designed to compress files, not streams, and so it might make more sense for the package manager or other program to use libarchive to package into a file and then invoke lrzip separately to compress the file.

Integrating lrzip decompression might work very well; it sounds like lrzip does work effectively with streams when decompressing.

In response to one of the observations posted in that thread:  Yes, libarchive is BSD-licensed.
   * This does not preclude it linking with and using a library that is published under a different license.
   * In fact, libarchive utilizes many libraries (libz, libbz2, libiconv, etc, etc) that are not BSD-licensed.
   * Any glue code contributed to libarchive should be under the same license, of course.
With https://github.com/libarchive/libarchive/pull/28 merged, I think this issue can be closed.

items.title: Uncompressed CAB fails to read subfile when archive has certain structure
items.summary: Uncompressed CAB fails to read subfile when archive has certain structure

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? Try to extract "folder/test2.txt" from the *uncompressed* archive (attached). (Using streams interface - not file-based interface). What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Error "-30" returned when attempting the actual extract. What version are you using? 3.0.3 On what operating system? Problem replicated on Win64 and Ubuntu. How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) cmake (win), configure (ubuntu) What compiler or development environment (please include version)? MSVC 2010, gcc Please provide any additional information below. 1. The problem seems to be related to subfolders. If I put the files in a flat structure, it's ok. When there are failures, it's always the files that are within subfolders that fail - never the files in the root. 2. The same code works properly when using the compressed version of the same file structure (also attached - mszip). 3. Another library can open the uncompressed archive correctly, so the archive seems ok. 4. Archive created on Windows using "cabarc -p -r -m NONE n c:\temp\uncompress-arch-cab-bug.cab *.*"

Thank you for the reporting.
Could you try the attached patch?
Initial test is successful.  Thanks again!

I recommend you to apply those patches.
shall do

I found that the patch I uploaded made another bug that listing filenames failed.
Please use a new patch instead.

items.title: problem extracting from CAB file
items.summary: problem extracting from CAB file

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. download http://download.windowsupdate.com/microsoftupdate/v6/wsusscan/wsusscn2.cab 2. try to list the files inside The portion of code that gets the filenames: archive_entry *entry = 0; int r = ARCHIVE_OK; while((r = archive_read_next_header(_archive, &entry)) != ARCHIVE_EOF) { if (r != ARCHIVE_OK) { dlog(kErrorMessage, "error while reading from archive '%1'", archive_error_string(_archive)); break; } ret += QString::fromUtf8(archive_entry_pathname( entry )); } What is the expected output? What do you see instead? The archive contains 26 items Instead it finds the 2 first items and then fails with fatal error What version are you using? tried with both 3.3 and trunk On what operating system? Windows 7 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) cmake with lzma support (nothing else so far) What compiler or development environment (please include version)? MSVC 2010 and 2008 (both express), 32 bit Microsoft is updating its offline catalog every 2 weeks. The new version from this week started showing the problem.

Thank you for your report. I really appreciate it!

Could you try the attached patch?
The patch is against 3.0.3 + issue 241,243 and 249, not plain 3.0.3.

I believe this issue has been fixed.
I'll close this.

items.title: Broken files extracted from .cab files.
items.summary: Broken files extracted from .cab files.

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Download arx_demo_english.zip ( list of download locations: http://wiki.arx-libertatis.org/Getting_the_game_data#Demo ) 2. Extract the zip file (with bsdtar or another utility). 3. Extract the .cab files: $ bsdtar xvf Setup1.cab $ bsdtar xvf Setup2.cab $ bsdtar xvf Setup3.cab 4. Verify the files: $ md5sum data.pak SFX.pak SPEECH.pak What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Expected (produced by running the installer under wine or by using cabextract instead of bsdtar) 5d7ba6e6c79ebf7fbb232eaced9e8ad9 data.pak ea1b3e6d6f4906905d4a34f07e9a59ac SFX.pak 62ca7b1751c0615ee131a94f0856b389 SPEECH.pak Actual results: 335b02892c7304eb10a14dc63e18f094 data.pak 913f8166d2a3d6fe5bf698469873d19d SFX.pak 9f8282f43dd72565fb0d5bb30d6bbc99 SPEECH.pak What version are you using? 3.0.3 On what operating system? Gentoo Linux How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) Gentoo ebuild USE flags: acl bzip2 e2fsprogs iconv kernel_linux lzma zlib -expat -nettle -static-libs -xattr What compiler or development environment (please include version)? x86_64 system gcc 4.6.2 xz-utils 5.0.3 bzip2 1.0.6-r3 zlib 1.2.6 Please provide any additional information below. The bsdtar-extracted files cannot be loaded by the game, but the cabextract-extracted / installed files can.

This is the same as issue 241.
Please get a patch for issue 241 and try it.
There are other patches for CAB reader, see issue 243, 249 and 250.

items.title: GCC 4.7.0 compile and test fixes
items.summary: GCC 4.7.0 compile and test fixes

items.content:
Fixes the following compile error exposed with GCC 4.7.0:

    libarchive/archive_string.c: In function 'cesu8_to_unicode':
    libarchive/archive_string.c:2450:11: error: 'wc' may be used uninitialized in this function [-Werror=uninitialized]
    cc1: all warnings being treated as errors

As well as a test failure that depends on signed integer wraparound,
which is a very bad thing to do in C [1]. Add a bit more magic to ensure
the assert is not optimized to always being false. This is still
extremely brittle, and a better way should probably be figured out, but
this ensures it works as before in all compilers.

As long as we're in the business of assuming two's complement (which seems pretty reasonable this day and age, there are also many assumptions we are using the ASCII character set).

Of course, on 64-bit machines, time_t isn't an int (32-bits) it is 64-bits. This seems to work for any size integral type, with no need for types, or signed/unsigned stuff which would be a lot harder with an opaque time_t type:

    min_val = 1; /* initialized so value is cast automatically and left shift doesn't complain */
    min_val <<= (sizeof(min_val) * 8 - 1);

I would probably prefer using this as it doesn't depend on overflow whatsoever, only that two's complement is the representation used. Updated patch attached.

Hmmm....  You are assuming that time_t is signed.  The standard doesn't require this.  I made the same mistake in Comment #1 above.  The original code handled this but of course is broken by standard compiler optimizations so we need something better.

So we're back to the basic problem statement: The library is documented to return the smallest possible time_t value if the value in the file is earlier than can be represented in the platform time_t.  But there is no portable TIME_T_MIN that we can rely on.  I believe the logic in archive_read_support_format_mtree() does this correctly but of course copying that code into the test suite isn't an ideal answer (the point of the test suite is to verify whether the code in the library is correct).

Now that I've thought about this for a couple of days, I now recall that my original idea was this: if the value returned is the *minimum* then subtracting one can't produce a smaller value.  That seems pretty straightforward and actually makes no assumptions at all about 2s complement arithmetic; the same would be true on a decimal or ternary computer.  Maybe I didn't express that idea very well in the initial code?

Hmm. What are you proposing for the "can't produce a smaller value" check then? The compiler, with a signed value in play, will assume it can subtract one, so it will optimize away any "x < x - 1" type check as it will assume that is not possible.

Also, from POSIX [1], throw integer assumptions away:
    time_t and clock_t shall be integer or real-floating types.

I'm assuming the value encoded in the test archive is INT64_MIN? What if you just cast the returned value of archive_entry_mtime() to an int64_t (guaranteed width type), and then just checked equality to INT64_MIN; if that is not true, fall back to INT32_MIN. If that isn't true (indicating an unsigned time_t type, or an actual failure), then you can rely on unsigned wraparound as that is not undefined behavior, subtract 1, and ensure it is greater than 0.

[1] http://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/009695399/basedefs/sys/types.h.html

Apparently, POSIX has recently reconsidered the idea of a floating-point time_t, so I think we're on safe ground there:

http://austingroupbugs.net/view.php?id=327
volatile seems to get everything "working" again. Patch attached that successfully compiles and passes all tests on GCC 4.7.0.

Thanks for your help, Dan!

I've applied this patch to the sources on Github.
Issue 261 has been merged into this issue.

items.title: libarchive fails to process zip files with garbage padding at end
items.summary: libarchive fails to process zip files with garbage padding at end

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. wget ftp://ftp.adobe.com/pub/adobe/magic/acrobatviewer/unix/1.x/viewer.bin 2. bsdtar tvf viewer.bin What is the expected output? The zip file listing. What do you see instead? bsdtar: Invalid central directory signature bsdtar: Error exit delayed from previous errors. What version are you using? 3.0.4, git On what operating system? FreeBSD 9.x How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) configure What compiler or development environment (please include version)? gcc 4.2 Please provide any additional information below. Now that libarchive have seekable zip reader, it can fallback to Central directory at the end of the zip file instead of terminating with error.

This is a very strange file.  It's not technically an SFX Zip archive.  It's really the concatenation of a shell script and a Zip archive (actually, a JAR).

It is not a fully correct Zip file (the end-of-central-directory record says the central directory starts at 0x298fa5, but the central directory actually starts a 0x2a0fa5.  This is why bsdtar reports "Invalid Central Directory"; it is following the references in the file but the Central Directory isn't where it should be.

It appears that Info-Zip has some special logic for such.  Libarchive would have to learn how to scan forward from the location indicated until it finds the real start of the central directory, then use the resulting offset to bias all future file location calculations.

updates.summary: libarchive fails to process some sfx zip files

items.content:
It seems that sfx archives like this is normal for infozip. From unzipsfx.txt (unzip 6.0):
Regular unzip may still be used to extract the  embedded  archive  as  with  any normal zipfile, although it will generate a warning about extra bytes at the  beginning  of  the  zipfile. Despite this, however, the self-extracting archive is technically not a valid ZIP archive, and PKUNZIP may be unable to test or extract it. This limitation is due to the simplistic manner in which the archive is created; the internal directory structure is not updated to reflect the extra bytes prepended to the original zipfile.

I can try and produce the patch for libarchive that implements this logic.

Please do try to implement this feature.  All of the logic is in archive_read_format_zip.c.
Here is how I think this will need to work:
  * Change slurp_central_directory so that it searches forward for the PK\001\002 signature value  (archive_read_format_zip_streamable_read_header has similar logic to find the next local file header.)
  * Keep track of the offset from where the central directory should have been and where it actually was.

The offset value will need to be used in _seekable_read_header() and possibly other places to adjust the offsets where you look for files.

I made a patch for this issue.
Please try the attached patch.
I tried patch with a few sfx archives (viewer.bin, q2-314-demo-x86.exe) and it works fine. Thank you.

Hi, 
I still get this problem on latest version (3.1.2) which already has this patch.
The file causing this problem is attached.
Many thanks

The attached file is not a sfx, just a very broken zip archive. It has weird version to extract: 0x603 and wrong centraldir_start (0x50890000 instead of 0x15089), centraldir_size (0x92002 instead of 0x91) fields. If you correct these[1], it opens just fine.

1)
00015125 02 91
00015127 92 00
00015129 00 89
0001512b 89 15
0001512c 50 00

Actually, correcting centraldir_start is enough:
0001512c 50 00
0001512d 01 15

centraldir_start looks fine to me.

The problem:  This file has 22 bytes of garbage appended to the end.
Libarchive is not currently able to find the end-of-central-directory record when it doesn't occur at the very end of the archive.  There's a comment in archive_read_support_format_zip.c about this:

archive_read_format_zip_seekable_bid(struct archive_read *a, int best_bid)
 ...
        /* TODO: More robust search for end of central directory record. */

Instead of simply grabbing the last 22 bytes, this function should probably
read the last 8k or so and scan backwards from the end to try to locate the
end-of-central-directory record.

That would also fix reading archives that have file comments at the end.

This would explain why the Zip seekable reader doesn't process this file.

I don't immediately see why the streaming reader doesn't like it.  I'll
dig a little further.

I can read the sources wrong, but it seems to me that zip_reader is already searching last 16k for EOCD: https://github.com/libarchive/libarchive/blob/master/libarchive/archive_read_support_format_zip.c#L271

It was searching but it was not correctly recording the location of EOCD when
it did find it.  So a later adjustment step was going awry.

I've just pushed a fix for this to github.  Please test and let me know what you see.

updates.summary: libarchive fails to process zip files with garbage padding at end

items.content: Issue 339 has been merged into this issue.

Ah, I have not checked code line by line, just general algorithm, it's similar to my POC for this issue.
I can confirm that all zip files from this issue and also zip file from 339 opens fine.
Thanks for fixing this.

Btw, search for first CD from presumed position to EOCD trick (comment #3) doesn't work with 2cf89..9c.zip file, it fails with assert cd_start(0x150089) > eocd_start(0x1511b),
but the current adjustment algorithm works properly. Clever.

hi thank you for you reply and help!
how can I get the fix for this issue?

You'll need to get the up-to-date source code from:

https://github.com/libarchive/libarchive

The specific change that fixes this issue is:

https://github.com/libarchive/libarchive/commit/37908ea3c9731a34c9a6216001fddbcf73ca5940

(though you'll also need

https://github.com/libarchive/libarchive/commit/1579f4ba819c632046790a0d9be0610cfbd548a7

If you rely on pre-built packages, you'll need to contact whoever you got that package from and pass this information along to them.
Is it makes sense to add the attached patch to archivers/libarchive port or you plan to release a new version soon?
works great on the file I uploaded here - thanks

items.title: symlink support/emulation/fallback on Windows
items.summary: symlink support/emulation/fallback on Windows

items.content:
Hi,

I'd like to have some kind of support for symlinks on windows. I'll probably be writing the code myself in the coming days but first, I'd like to discuss how to approach the problem.

On windows, symlinks can only be created by users with admin rights. That means that they're most often going to be unusable from libarchive and a fallback is therefore needed.

Hardlinks could do the trick to some extent but, quoting http://blogs.msdn.com/b/b8/archive/2012/01/16/building-the-next-generation-file-system-for-windows-refs.aspx :
  "The NTFS features we have chosen to not support in ReFS are: named streams, object IDs, short names, compression, file level encryption (EFS), user data transactions, sparse, hard-links, extended attributes, and quotas."
ReFS is coming in Windows 8 enterprise/server editions, as some kind of test, and actually can't be booted from. It's not there and not widespread yet, but it's definitely coming.

Apparently, junction points will still exist and they could maybe used but they're not perfect either I think.

As far as I'm concerned, I'd try to create regular symlinks if running as admin and otherwise, create a copy of the file, and not try any middle-ground (at least for now).

Are there any comments about this? Also, if not running as admin and there is a symlink pointing to a file outside of the archive, should that file be copied?

There are two problems:

First, how to put Windows filesystem objects into an archive?  Last I checked, there were several different variations of "link" on Windows filesystems with varying semantics across different versions of Windows.  Whether one or all of these should be archived as a "symlink" is an open question.  (Fortunately, the pax format provides a way to carry additional information, so we might be able to archive different things as "symlink" with an additional property to indicate what type of link it really was originally.)  It would be interesting to see if any Windows-specific archivers (such as Microsoft's CAB tools or PKZIP) do anything interesting here.

Second, how should "symlinks" in a tar archive be restored onto Windows?  The Cygwin folks have been wrestling with this problem for years and have come up with some workable answers.

Tim,

Whatever approach is taken in regards to symlinks, one must be chosen. This issue in libarchive is breaking some very popular downloads, e. g. OpenSSL.

I think taking the same approach as 7-zip is one possible and savvy choice. At least, it works and the code is already there.

Sounds like you know more about this than I do.  (It's been a long time
since I did significant work with Windows.)

Please take a look at libarchive/archive_read_disk_windows.c and 
libarchive/archive_write_disk_windows.c and see if you can help us
figure out how to improve this.

items.title: Code with undefined behaviour fails to build on Hurd
items.summary: Code with undefined behaviour fails to build on Hurd

items.content:
Building with gcc 4.7 on Hurd fails. Forwarding problem description from Debian GNU/Hurd porters with detailed description.

Original bug report available at:
http://bugs.debian.org/cgi-bin/bugreport.cgi?bug=672690


From: Samuel Thibault <sthibault@debian.org>

Hello,

libarchive currently FTBFS on hurd-i386, see 

https://buildd.debian.org/status/fetch.php?pkg=libarchive&arch=hurd-i386&ver=3.0.4-1%2Bb1&stamp=1336821322

This build was done with gcc-4.7, which is probably the "culprit", by
optimizing yet more. The issue is with the following piece of code:

	min_time = archive_entry_mtime(ae);
	assert(min_time <= 0);
	/* Simply asserting min_time - 1 > 0 breaks with some compiler optimizations. */
	t = min_time - 1;
	assert(t > 0);

This is supposed to check for overflowing when subtracting 1 from the
minimum time_t value.  Problem is: that is undefined in C, and the
compiler is thus allowed to do anything, including always raising the
assertion, since we have already checked that the integer is negative,
so subtracting 1 to it is not supposed to make it positive (again,
overflow is undefined).  Printing t, for instance, fixes the test, since
the compiler then actually computes t, but without it the assert always
gets triggered. I tried to reproduce it with i386, without success, but
anyway, the piece of code really has undefined behavior.

Samuel


-- System Information:
Debian Release: wheezy/sid
  APT prefers testing
  APT policy: (990, 'testing'), (500, 'unstable'), (500, 'stable'), (1, 'experimental')
Architecture: amd64 (x86_64)

Kernel: Linux 3.0.4 (SMP w/8 CPU cores)
Locale: LANG=fr_FR.UTF-8, LC_CTYPE=fr_FR.UTF-8 (charmap=UTF-8)
Shell: /bin/sh linked to /bin/bash

This was raised earlier in Issue 255.  Please read that thread for more details about the logic behind this code.  (If you know of a better way to test the assertion that "the variable min_time holds the smallest possible time_t value", I'd be very interested.)

A fix for this has already been committed to libarchive:
https://github.com/libarchive/libarchive/commit/da8ac32da9e5ee4a27674de4442e24c26cb2aa6a

GCC 4.4.5 Please provide any additional information below. Compiled for 32 bits. Listing the file in the archive works. It fails on extract.

I can confirm this issue with the latest libarchive release. The error that libarchive reports when trying to extract the file is "Parsing filters is unsupported".

I have several rar files that cannot be read by libarchive because of this (e.g. the official, but non-free "unrar" and the "theunarchiver" programs can read this kind of files); everything else works perfectly and I would like to completely switch to libarchive. 

Would it be possible to support "filters parsing" (I'm no expert in this field, so I don't know what this actually means) or is this something that is unlikely to be implemented in the near future?

I am having the same issue.
Any new regarding this "Parsing filters is unsupported" issue on rar files?

I have Fedora 20 and libarchive 3.1.2 (packages, libarchive-3.1.2-7.fc20.x86_64.rpm and libarchive-devel-3.1.2-7.fc20.x86_64.rpm) and I have the same issue. Certain subfiles cannot be read. I'm trying to use libarchive to open cbr files (basically, rar files with images files, usually jpeg). Some compressed files contains a subfile that produce that error "Unrecognized image file format". Even if I isolate the subfile in one compressed file, the problem persist.

I attach a file with this problem.

I'm having the same issue "Parsing filters is unsupported" decompressing some rar files.

My system is a Fedora 20 x86_64 and I'm using the provided packages (libarchive-3.1.2-7.fc20.x86_64 and libarchive-devel-3.1.2-7.fc20.x86_64).

I'm using libarchive to decompress cbr files. Certain images in some rar files are not decompressed by libarchive. This is something related with the content of the files, because the problem is reproducible when I isolate the file in a rar file.

Apart from my program, even bsdtar -xf shows the same error. I attach a rar file with the problem.

$ bsdtar -xf sample.rar 
013.jpg: Parsing filters is unsupported.
bsdtar: Error exit delayed from previous errors.

I'm having the same issue "Parsing filters is unsupported" decompressing some rar files.

My system is a Fedora 20 x86_64 and I'm using the provided packages (libarchive-3.1.2-7.fc20.x86_64 and libarchive-devel-3.1.2-7.fc20.x86_64).

I'm using libarchive to decompress cbr files. Certain images in some rar files are not decompressed by libarchive. This is something related with the content of the files, because the problem is reproducible when I isolate the file in a rar file.

Apart from my program, even bsdtar -xf shows the same error. I attach a rar file with the problem.

$ bsdtar -xf sample.rar 
013.jpg: Parsing filters is unsupported.
bsdtar: Error exit delayed from previous errors.
Issue 338 has been merged into this issue.

We're planning to use librarchive in Chromium but we've stumbled on the same issue: "Parsing filters is unsupported".

I looked into the base code used by libarchive at https://code.google.com/p/theunarchiver/. For details see
https://code.google.com/p/libarchive/issues/detail?id=40&colspec=ID%20Type%20Status%20Priority%20Milestone%20OpSys%20Owner%20Summary

It seems the problem is related with the fact that the RAR Virtual Machine is not implemented in libarchive. So that code must be also ported to libarchive.

Since it's very important to our project, I'd like to work on it and merge the patch to libarchive.

Are you fine with porting the filters support from thelibunarchiver to libarchive?

Thanks,
Mihail

FYI: I have a working port of TheUnarchiver's RARVM to portable C at https://code.google.com/p/sumatrapdf/source/browse/trunk/ext/unarr/ . It currently supports RAR v2.0 and v3.0 archives, including parsing filters and solid compressions (which libarchive doesn't support, either). It's however LGPL licensed same as TheUnarchiver.

items.title: mtree file generation issue
items.summary: mtree file generation issue

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. mkdir tmp && cd tmp 2. mkdir foo bar 3. bsdtar -cf foo.mtree --format=mtree --options='!all,type' * What is the expected output? What do you see instead? The current output is: #mtree bar type=dir foo type=dir I would expect: #mtree bar type=dir .. foo type=dir .. What version are you using? 3.0.4 On what operating system? Arch Linux How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) ./configure --prefix=/usr --without-xml2 What compiler or development environment (please include version)? gcc version 4.7.0 20120505 (prerelease) (GCC) Please provide any additional information below. When reading the currently generated mtree file, libarchive thinks the entries are for "foo" and "foo/bar". This is correct for the mtree file that is generated. The first entry "bar type=dir" has no "/" in so is treated as a relative path. As it is a directory, all subsequent entries are considered to be within that directory. Manually adding the ".." moves the current directory back down to the base level and then libarchive reads the entries correctly as "foo" and "bar"

Attached is a patch that fixes this issue.

Test with:
mkdir test && cd test
mkdir foo bar
touch foo/foo bar/bar baz
bsdtar -cf test.mtree --format=mtree --options='!all,type'

Which gives the following mtree file:

#mtree
bar type=dir
bar/bar type=file
..
baz type=file
foo type=dir
foo/foo type=file


Technically there probably should be a ".." at the end too (as we are exiting the foo directory), but this is cosmetic being at the end of the file.
Attached is an updated patch.  The only change is to print the cosmetic ".." at the end of the mtree file if needed.

I agree there is a bug here, but I fear your fix is making it worse.  The libarchive mtree writer is supposed to support two very different mtree variants:
  * The "old" variant (which uses ".." entries to navigate the hierarchy)
  * The "NetBSD" variant (which stores full path names).  This is the format generated by "mtree -C" on NetBSD.

When reading mtree files, the two formats can be distinguished by the presence of '/' in the pathname.  The "old" variant NEVER has a '/' in the pathname; the "NetBSD" variant ALWAYS has a '/' in the pathname.

For example, for the directory generated by "mkdir bar && touch bar/bar", either of the two following files are correct:

  #mtree ("old" variant)
  bar type=dir
    bar type=file
  ..

OR

  #mtree (NetBSD -C variant)
  ./bar type=dir
  bar/bar type=file

The NetBSD variant has the advantage that it can be easily filtered with standard tools like 'grep'.  Unfortunately, it's not as widely supported as the old variant.

The output you showed in Comment #1 above has some entries with '/' and some without, which makes it invalid for either variant.

As far as I can tell, there is nothing disallowing the use of both relative and and full pathnames in the "mtree v2.0" (NetBSD -C) format.  The 2.0 format only allows for full pathnames, in addition to the relative path name method of specification.  The only thing I see wrong with the output is that it does not have the "v2.0" string to confirm it is allowed full paths to files in it.  Note that the libarchive mtree reader can read the mixed format fine.

I can readily provide a patch to have libarchive generate the v2.0 format by just adding a leading ./ in front of directories in the root path.  However, unless I am missing something completely obvious...  I can not see a way to tell libarchive/bsdtar to generate the "old" variant.  Is that supposed to be available now?

Following this up... How would you like me to fix this issue?

If writing both versions of mtree file needs to be available, I propose providing writing functions for the v1 and v2 versions of the mtree format, and picking one for the current to default to. That would give (e.g.) archive_write_set_format_mtree_v1 and archive_write_set_format_mtree_v2.

The read function would not need multiple versions as it already deals with both format types.

The "v1" and "v2" names are ones that I made up when I created the mtree.5 manpage.  We should probably abandon those names, as noone else uses them.  I also made up the "#mtree" initial line requirement (wishful thinking on my part).  Again, that should be abandoned as it doesn't match current practice.  (I thought some form of signature line would be necessary to do good auto-detection of mtree files, but Michihiro did some work that seems to have proven you can do reasonable auto-detect without i.)

Mixing the two formats is certainly possible but I doubt that the various tools are consistent in how they handle it (there's some ambiguity in the NetBSD manpages about how this works).  Best to generate just one or the other.

Personally, I would like to see the NetBSD format be the default, as it's more useful in general.  So I would propose that:
   archive_write_set_format_mtree --- generate the NetBSD -C format
   archive_write_set_format_mtree_??? --- generate the older format

I'm not sure what a good name might be.  "legacy" is a little judgmental.  Perhaps "formatted"?  or "indented"?  Or maybe you have a better idea?

Or perhaps the older format should be the default and the NetBSD -C format should be called "full"?
How about "archive_write_set_format_mtree_classic" for the indented version?
That sounds great.

Attached is a patch that fixes mtree generation to always prefix files in the root directory with "./".   This results in the mtrees generated in the "NetBSD -C variant" format.

Adding another function to generate the classic indented format requires much larger changes to the mtree writer.  I will not have time to address that in the short term...

I just committed support for generating an older format.
I also added the ability to read the "NetBSD -D" variant a few days ago.

items.title: a format limit
items.summary: a format limit

items.content: libachive can work with xx.tar.gz, but xx.tar.xz; xx.tar.bz2 is not when archive_read_data is return -25(size_t)

tar.xz and tar.bz2 both work for me.

Can you provide example code that shows the problem?

What version of libarchive are you using?

What operating system are you using?

How are you compiling?

Do you have libbz2 on your system?

Do you have bunzip2 on your system?

Do you have liblzma on your system?

Do you have unxz on your system?

Can you run the libarchive test suite?
oh! i find the error , i consider libarhive can be build with bz/lzma without libbz2 and liblzma

Libarchive uses libbz2 and liblzma for bz and xz/lzma support.  If it is not built with them, it will try to run the bunzip2 or unxz command-line programs.  If you don't build it with the libraries and don't have the executables, then it won't work.

items.title: Support Microsoft Backup (MTF/BKF) format
items.summary: Support Microsoft Backup (MTF/BKF) format

items.content:
A useful feature would be to support the MTF/BKF file format produced by Microsoft Backup (also known as NTBackup). There is an GPL implementation of a decoder, which I have cleaned up to compile on BSD-like platforms (see http://www.lightbluetouchpaper.org/2012/06/13/extracting-microsoft-windows-backup-bkf-files-on-mac-os-x/).

Information about the format can also be found scattered around the web, e.g.
 - http://laytongraphics.com/mtf/MTF_100a.PDF
 - http://laytongraphics.com/mtf/
 - http://www.fpns.net/willy/msbackup.htm

GPLed code can't be pulled directly into libarchive.

But it looks like there's enough format documentation here to enable someone to
write this support from scratch if they wanted.

items.title: Windows build broken (__func__ not supported)
items.summary: Windows build broken (__func__ not supported)

items.content: Commit 1e5f600ee3f891c9f3427acc3746db32996d77bc (libarchive/archive_read_support_filter_lrzip.c) on April 22nd broke the Windows build (Visual Studio 2010) because __func__ is C99 and isn't supported in Microsoft compilers - it needs to use the older non-standard __FUNCTION__.
This issue was fixed removing a use of __func__ macro in 65a05028.

items.title: archive_write_finish_entry(3) refers to non-existant archive_write_next_header
items.summary: archive_write_finish_entry(3) refers to non-existant archive_write_next_header

items.content:
archive_write_finish_entry(3) contains the sentence:

Ordinarily, clients never need to call this, as it is called automatically by archive_write_next_header() and archive_write_close() as needed.

However, archive_write_next_header doesn't seem to exist in the current (3.0.4) libarchive sources.

Thanks for reporting this.

Fixed in git 8452ba9

items.title: bsdtar does not preserve executable flag when extracting zipfile
items.summary: bsdtar does not preserve executable flag when extracting zipfile

items.content:
take a zipfile that contains a file that has an executable flag.
for example phantomjs-1.6.0-source.zip @ http://code.google.com/p/phantomjs/downloads/list

it includes build.sh in the root dir.
when you unzip with `unzip` build.sh has the +x flag.
when you extract with `bsdtar -fx`, it doesn't.

libarchive 3.0.4-1 on arch linux 32bit.

also the executable flag is not visible when listing the contents:

$ bsdtar tvf phantomjs-1.6.0-source.zip | grep build.sh
-rw-rw-rw-  0 0      0        1586 Jun 20 23:28 phantomjs-1.6.0/build.sh

The sample file has a zip comment and our zip reader cannot find the central directory nor
get the file mode in that case.
Could you try the attached patch ?
I think Info-Zip looks at the last 16k of the file when looking for a central directory marker when there might be a comment.

Thank you for helpful information.
I will increase the number of the bytes to detect end of central directory with a comment.

I committed a fix for this issue.
I will close this issue.

items.title: when compress files to .zip . How can i get files only decompress once.
items.summary: when compress files to .zip . How can i get files only decompress once.

items.content: I use archive_write_set_format_zip to compress files to .zip, but i must decompress twice to get those files. how can i write file that like decompress once, what is it format?

Are you also specifying archive_write_set_compression_gzip ??

Don't do that.

Thanks.
No do archive_write_set_compression_gzip()the result is my expect!

What do you see instead? o. many redefinitions within 'archive_windows.h', examples S_ISUID, S_ISGID, S_IRxxx ... o. redefinitions errors of functions referencing mode_t What version are you using? current cmake and libarchive (3.0.4) On what operating system? Windows 7 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) cmake What compiler or development environment (please include version)? Please provide any additional information below.

What compiler or development environment (please include version)?
o Open Watcom C32 Optimizing Compiler Version 1.9

There was a little effort about two years ago to make libarchive
work better with Watcom compilers, but there don't seem to be
many people using it.

Patches eagerly solicited.
