items.title: full target of hardlink stored, duplicate hardlinks in archive when tar fed filelist (-T file.lst
items.summary: full target of hardlink stored, duplicate hardlinks in archive when tar fed filelist (-T file.lst

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. have a directory tree contained hardlinked files 2. find dir-to-archive > file.lst 3. tar cvf archive.tar -T file.lst What is the expected output? What do you see instead? That each hardlinked file is stored only once. Initial conditions tree root root snap.a hl.1 random.bin snap.b hl.2 where all the leaves are hardlinked files. Building the tar root root/snap.b root/snap.b/hl.2 root/snap.a root/snap.a/hl.1 root/snap.a/random.bin bsdtar cvf test.filelst.bsd.tar -T file.lst the output $ bsdtar tvf test.filelst.bsd.tar drwxrwxr-x 0 worker worker 0 Jul 31 15:34 root/ drwxrwxr-x 0 worker worker 0 Jul 31 15:33 root/snap.b/ drwxrwxr-x 0 worker worker 0 Jul 31 15:33 root/snap.a/ -rw-rw-r-- 0 worker worker 20971520 Jul 31 15:33 root/snap.a/hl.1 hrw-rw-r-- 0 worker worker 0 Jul 31 15:33 root/snap.a/random.bin link to root/snap.a/hl.1 hrw-rw-r-- 0 worker worker 0 Jul 31 15:33 root/snap.b/hl.2 link to root/snap.a/hl.1 drwxrwxr-x 0 worker worker 0 Jul 31 15:33 root/snap.b/ -rw-rw-r-- 0 worker worker 20971520 Jul 31 15:33 root/snap.b/hl.2 hrw-rw-r-- 0 worker worker 0 Jul 31 15:33 root/snap.b/hl.2 link to root/snap.b/hl.2 drwxrwxr-x 0 worker worker 0 Jul 31 15:33 root/snap.a/ hrw-rw-r-- 0 worker worker 0 Jul 31 15:33 root/snap.a/hl.1 link to root/snap.b/hl.2 -rw-rw-r-- 0 worker worker 20971520 Jul 31 15:33 root/snap.a/random.bin hrw-rw-r-- 0 worker worker 0 Jul 31 15:33 root/snap.a/hl.1 link to root/snap.a/random.bin hrw-rw-r-- 0 worker worker 0 Jul 31 15:33 root/snap.a/random.bin link to root/snap.a/random.bin I can confirm that the file is 3x larger than it needs to be. $ du -ch test.filelst.bsd.tar 61M test.filelst.bsd.tar 61M total What version are you using? bsdtar --version bsdtar 3.0.4 - libarchive 3.0.4 On what operating system? $ uname -a ; cat /etc/redhat-release Linux disk 2.6.32-220.el6.x86_64 #1 SMP Tue Dec 6 19:48:22 GMT 2011 x86_64 x86_64 x86_64 GNU/Linux CentOS release 6.2 (Final) How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) ./configure --prefix=path make make install added path/lib to LD_LIBRARY_PATH path/bin to path What compiler or development environment (please include version)? gcc --version gcc (GCC) 4.4.6 20120305 (Red Hat 4.4.6-4) Copyright (C) 2010 Free Software Foundation, Inc. This is free software; see the source for copying conditions. There is NO warranty; not even for MERCHANTABILITY or FITNESS FOR A PARTICULAR PURPOSE. Please provide any additional information below. This archive does not restore properly. It would appear that -T shouldn't be used on any of the *tar programs. $ bsdtar xvf ../test.filelst.bsd.tar x root/ x root/snap.b/ x root/snap.a/ x root/snap.a/hl.1 x root/snap.a/random.bin x root/snap.b/hl.2 x root/snap.b/ x root/snap.b/hl.2 x root/snap.b/hl.2: Can't create 'root/snap.b/hl.2' x root/snap.a/ x root/snap.a/hl.1: Can't create 'root/snap.a/hl.1' x root/snap.a/random.bin x root/snap.a/hl.1 x root/snap.a/random.bin: Can't create 'root/snap.a/random.bin' bsdtar: Error exit delayed from previous errors. (t.env)[worker@disk temp]$ ls -ls total 4 4 drwxrwxr-x. 4 worker worker 4096 Jul 31 15:34 root (t.env)[worker@disk temp]$ tree . root snap.a hl.1 snap.b 3 directories, 1 file
Attaching file with smaller contents than the example above.
hard link hardlink ## for searching

When you use -T in this fashion, you need to also use the -n option.

The archive is too large because you've asked bsdtar to archive everything more than once.

Because you've presented bsdtar with the files in a pretty odd order, the hardlink information is a little screwy.  It might be possible to make bsdtar's hardlink storage a little smarter to produce less-odd results when presented with odd requests like this.
Issue 276 has been merged into this issue.
This is a duplicate of Issue #274.

I gave the files to bsdtar in the order that `find` found them. And it created an archive that was corrupt that couldn't be properly restored. I haven't found a case where -T worked properly with any fileset created by find.

Also the manpage makes no mention of -n being required for -T and if it is, why not turn it on all the time?

These options have been implemented in many different tar programs for many, many years.

bsdtar needs to be compatible with those other tar programs, so having -T always turn on -n is (regrettably) not feasible, since that would break compatibility with established software that didn't expect this behavior.

You're right; the manpage should probably mention -n under the description for -T.

Had I not done testing of my backup pipeline I would have not caught what you think is not a bug. find cannot successfully pipe a list of files with hardlinks into *tar -T - w/o generating corrupt files. They will not restore properly. And as nearly all of the filesets I am backing up contain a huge forest of hardlinks I would have been screwed.

How about detecting that (-T -) isn't being used with -n and OR that the file paths are coming in in-the pretty odd order. It would seem that this is historically broken in the *tars, how about a new flag? I shouldn't be able to create tar files using command line switches that do not error out but are un-extractable. What do you think?

Issuing an unconditional warning for using -T without -n would break the following case:

$ cat dirs_to_backup
foo
bar
$ cat dirs_to_backup | tar cvf backup.tar -T -
a foo
a foo/file1
a foo/file2
a bar
a bar/file3

I've added a comment to the man page suggesting the use of -n with -T.

If you must use 'find' to generate the lists of files, you should investigate cpio.  find and cpio were designed to work together (in 1977, if I remember correctly); tar's -T option is a poor substitute.

The only change I can think that might help in your situation is to watch for the very specific case of a hardlink referring to itself:
   hrw-rw-r--  0 worker worker        0 Jul 31 15:33 root/snap.a/random.bin link to root/snap.a/random.bin

That would at least cause the command line you tried to use to generate an error when the archive was being created.  I suspect the right place to test this is in archive_write.c just before _archive_write_header() calls a->format_write_header.

items.title: ppc64 tests failed (test_option_b, test_option_nodump,test_read_disk_directory_traversals)
items.summary: ppc64 tests failed (test_option_b, test_option_nodump,test_read_disk_directory_traversals)

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1.run make check after complilation 2. or ./bsdtar_test test_option_b What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Tests should pass What version are you using? 3.0.4 On what operating system? openSUSE Factory/12.2 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) configure What compiler or development environment (please include version)? gcc 4.7 Please provide any additional information below. When omitting block size or set -b 1, the size of archive on ppc64 is 3072 but test expects 2048 here. Build log: https://build.opensuse.org/package/rawlog?arch=ppc64&package=libarchive&project=Archiving&repository=openSUSE_Factory_PowerPC Test logs and results are attached.

Apparently, your system is setting a lot of fflags on the test files that are confusing the tests.  If you examine one of the archives that's causing the test failure in test_option_b, you'll notice this bit:

SCHILY.fflags=schg,compdirty,nocomprblk,dirsync,imagic,journal,securedeletion,sync,notail,topdir,reserved

This is causing the created archive to be larger than expected.

What filesystem are you using?

Are these file flags expected on your system?

We can either change the test so that these extra properties aren't being stored, or change the test to tolerate this extra data.

The filesystem we are using, ext3.

But setup should be the same for x86 and ppc, build environment was prepared in the same way.

Also ppc (32bit) doesn't have such build failures. we are only seeing failures under ppc64 (64bit)

I'll definitely need your help to debug this.

The first part of test_option_b does essentially the following:

    $ echo file1 > file1
    $ bsdtar -cf archive1.tar file1

Can you run these manually and verify that the result is 3072 bytes on your PPC64 system and 2048 bytes on your PPC32 system?

Can you please verify what fflags are set on file1 on each system?

The relevant code is around line 190 of libarchive/archive_read_disk_entry_from_file.c, which reads:

                        unsigned long stflags;
                        r = ioctl(fd, EXT2_IOC_GETFLAGS, &stflags);
                        if (r == 0 && stflags != 0)
                                archive_entry_set_fflags(entry, stflags, 0);

If the flags on disk are what we expect (nothing), then this code is reading the flags incorrectly on your ppc64 system.  If you could check in a debugger and find out what value stflags has just after the ioctl call here, that would certainly help.

Harumph.  I don't think we have a Linux-specific test for libarchive to verify reading/writing flags from disk.  That would be a nice addition.

The only thing I can think of that might cause this would be a mismatch between the stflags variable here and what the kernel expects, but according to
  http://lxr.free-electrons.com/source/include/linux/fs.h?a=powerpc#L344
the ioctl we're using here does expect a long argument.

yes on ppc32 archive size is 2048 and flags are 0
on ppc64 size is 3072 and flags eq 775818427

Ah.  It took me a while to track down.  I misread the ioctl declarations.  This ioctl does expect a pointer to an 'int' argument.

I've made that change to the github sources.

Thanks for helping to track this down.

We still have bsdtar test_option_nodump and libarchive test_read_disk_directory_traversals tests failing.

Again those tests are fine for x86,x86_64,ppc32 but not ppc64

test_option_nodump fails in attempt to extract test2.tar created with --nodump option. It looks like it is empty.

test_read_disk_directory_traversals seems haven't produced any log files it just core dumps
 65: test_read_disk_directory_traversals               /bin/sh: line 5: 45607 Segmentation fault      (core dumped) LIBARCHIVE_TEST_FILES=`cd .;/bin/pwd`/libarchive/test BSDTAR=`cd .;/bin/pwd`/bsdtar BSDTAR_TEST_FILES=`cd .;/bin/pwd`/tar/test BSDCPIO=`cd .;/bin/pwd`/bsdcpio BSDCPIO_TEST_FILES=`cd .;/bin/pwd`/cpio/test ${dir}$tst

This is fixes test_option_nodump. same issue actually.
Index: libarchive-3.0.4/libarchive/archive_read_disk_posix.c
===================================================================
--- libarchive-3.0.4.orig/libarchive/archive_read_disk_posix.c
+++ libarchive-3.0.4/libarchive/archive_read_disk_posix.c
@@ -984,7 +984,7 @@ next_entry(struct archive_read_disk *a,
 #elif defined(EXT2_IOC_GETFLAGS) && defined(EXT2_NODUMP_FL) &&\
       defined(HAVE_WORKING_EXT2_IOC_GETFLAGS)
                if (S_ISREG(st->st_mode) || S_ISDIR(st->st_mode)) {
-                       unsigned long stflags;
+                       int stflags;

                        t->entry_fd = open_on_current_dir(t,
                            tree_current_access_path(t), O_RDONLY | O_NONBLOCK);


And I no longer have a problem with test_read_disk_directory_traversals

items.title: How to delete file(s) from *.tar.gz archive with libarchive API
items.summary: How to delete file(s) from *.tar.gz archive with libarchive API

items.content: What version are you using? 3.0.4 On what operating system? Linux piotr-desktop 2.6.32-25-generic #45-Ubuntu SMP Sat Oct 16 19:48:22 UTC 2010 i686 GNU/Linux How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) configure What compiler or development environment (please include version)? Using built-in specs. Target: i486-linux-gnu Configured with: ../src/configure -v --with-pkgversion='Ubuntu 4.3.4-10ubuntu1' --with-bugurl=file:///usr/share/doc/gcc-4.3/README.Bugs --enable-languages=c,c++,fortran,objc,obj-c++ --prefix=/usr --enable-shared --enable-multiarch --enable-linker-build-id --with-system-zlib --libexecdir=/usr/lib --without-included-gettext --enable-threads=posix --enable-nls --with-gxx-include-dir=/usr/include/c++/4.3 --program-suffix=-4.3 --enable-clocale=gnu --enable-libstdcxx-debug --enable-objc-gc --enable-mpfr --enable-targets=all --with-tune=generic --enable-checking=release --build=i486-linux-gnu --host=i486-linux-gnu --target=i486-linux-gnu Thread model: posix gcc version 4.3.4 (Ubuntu 4.3.4-10ubuntu1) Please provide any additional information below. I have created an archive and i'd like to remove some data (directories/files) from it. Is it at all possible with libarchive? Because i know that tar can do that and if i use file roller in ubuntu i can also remove data from this archive.

tar.gz files cannot be modified in place.  (tar cannot do it, nor can file roller)

You can use libarchive to read the existing tar.gz and write only some of the data to a new tar.gz archive.  (If you see programs that claim to let you "delete files from a tar.gz archive", they are in fact copying the entire archive and omitting some items.)

Outline:
  * Open the old archive
  * Open a new archive
  * Read each entry from the old archive:  If you want to keep it, write the header to the new archive and then copy the data

This works in libarchive.  The bsdtar program (which uses libarchive) provides a convenient command-line interface to this capability.

P.S.  When you refer to "tar", please be careful to specify which tar you are talking about, as there are many different implementations of the tar program:  GNU tar, star, bsdtar, AIX tar, Solaris tar, HP-UX tar, Heirloom tar, pdtar, OpenBSD tar, and many others.   Each of these implementations is different, each has slightly different options and capabilities.

Ok if i have to create a new archive that is no problem. Everything what i want to store from the old one in the new archive copies. But the problem is that when i have copied everything to the new one i still want to modify it (add new data). And my problem is that the new archive should be named as the old one. I thought about making temp archive to which i will be coping the old archive (without entries that i don' want) and than again coping from it to the main archive. For example:
- /home/XXX/Desktop/test.tar.gz <- old archive
- /tmp/test.tar.gz <- copied old archive (without some entries)
- /home/XXX/Desktop/test.tar.gz <- entire copy of /tmp/test.tar.gz with possibility to add new entries

If there is some other way to does this i would be pleased to see it:]

A slightly better strategy is to create the new archive beside the old one and then rename:

   - /home/XXX/Desktop/test.tar.gz <- old archive
   - /home/XXX/Desktop/test.tar.gz.temp <- copied old archive (without some entries)

Then rename test.tar.gz.temp to test.tar.gz.  This is much faster than copying again.

You can add new entries while you are writing the new archive.  Once you close it, things get more complicated.

So think about this:

   * Open old archive for reading
   * Open new archive for writing
   * For each entry in old archive:
   ** if you want to keep it, copy it to new archive
   ** else skip it
   * Close old archive
   * For each new entry:
   ** add it to new archive
   * Close new archive

   * Delete old archive
   * Rename new archive to old archive

items.title: update file in tar
items.summary: update file in tar

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1.bsdtar cf test.tar test.txt 2.modify text.txt 3.bsdtar uf test.tar test.txt What is the expected output? What do you see instead? test.tar should contain only 1 file ,that is texst.txt. but text.tar contain 2 file,the name is same = test.txt What version are you using? version 3.0.4 On what operating system? Windows XP + MinGW

This is how "tar u" has always worked.  Please try it on any other
tar implementation (GNU tar, star, AIX tar, Solaris tar, pdtar,
Heirloom Tar) and you'll see that.

Updating tar archives involves adding a new copy of the file
at the end.  The tar format allows this.

When extracting, both copies get extracted but the second
copy overwrites the first, so you get the desired result.

items.title: examples pass off_t* to expected int64_t*, causing pointer type incompatibility
items.summary: examples pass off_t* to expected int64_t*, causing pointer type incompatibility

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. build examples/minitar/minitar.c on Linux 32 bit system 2. build examples/untar.c on Linux 32 bit system What is the expected output? What do you see instead? On a 64 bit system, everything works. On a 32 bit system you get these warnings: examples/minitar/minitar.c: In function copy_data: examples/minitar/minitar.c:406:3: warning: passing argument 4 of archive_read_data_block from incompatible pointer type [enabled by default] In file included from examples/minitar/minitar.c:45:0: /usr/include/archive.h:420:15: note: expected int64_t * but argument is of type off_t * examples/untar.c: In function copy_data: examples/untar.c:210:3: warning: passing argument 4 of archive_read_data_block from incompatible pointer type [enabled by default] In file included from examples/untar.c:60:0: /usr/include/archive.h:420:15: note: expected int64_t * but argument is of type off_t * This suggests that off_t* is a 32 bit type on 32 bit, unless you enable large file support. However, the functions are declared to expect a __LA_INT64_T, not an off_t, so the examples ought to be fixed. What version are you using? 3.0.4 On what operating system? Ubuntu Linux 12.10 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) configure/make What compiler or development environment (please include version)? $ gcc --version gcc (Ubuntu/Linaro 4.7.2-5ubuntu7) 4.7.2 Please provide any additional information below.
This is the patch I applied to the Debian package.
Fixed in commit 7da8d576848982f2b0264febf89cb8e3f3580af2

Instead we get a "Truncated ZIP file data" error Using 7z, the file is uncompressed without errors, and "test" does not report any errors either What version are you using? trunk@3e71a61e004b8535a84a90607edf4abdfa266d6e On what operating system? windows 7 64-bit, using libarchive 32-bit How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) cmake What compiler or development environment (please include version)? visual studio 2010 Please provide any additional information below. A quick fix is provided here https://github.com/bamiaux/libarchive/commit/3797b8b5d789db558db28e71df9c577f3d5e7dfc However, there are many occurences of "if( bytes_avail <= 0 )" pattern throughout libarchive code base. Please repeat your tests with the current github master code.  Among other changes, the Zip support has been extensively overhauled.  The new Zip code seems much more robust.

items.title: configure should use pkg-config to find libxml2
items.summary: configure should use pkg-config to find libxml2

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Try to cross-compile libarchive on Linux using the autotools build system. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Configure uses the "xml2-config" to find libxml2, which picks up the one on the build system and passes -I/usr/include/... etc. to the cross-compiler. Instead, configure should use pkg-config to find libxml2. If a proper HOST-pkg-config wrapper is present, this will make it look for libxml2 in the right place. On what operating system? Linux Please provide any additional information below. Please use the PKG_ macros and do not call "pkg-config" directly, because "pkg-config" will still just pick up packages on the build system.
This patch changes configure.ac to use pkg-config instead of libxml2-config. With this, libarchive cross-compiles successfully.

items.title: APPLICATION_HANG_BlockedOn_FileIO while opening file libarchive-2.6.0.tar.gz

} 667: if (!WriteFile((HANDLE)_get_osfhandle(fd), buf, (uint32_t)nbytes, > 668: &bytes_written, NULL)) { 669: DWORD lasterr; 670: 671: lasterr = GetLastError(); 672: if (lasterr == ERROR_ACCESS_DENIED) 673: errno = EBADF;
r = archive_read_open_filename_w(a, filename, 10240);

libarchive is trying to read/write to an external gzip program to decompress the data.

I'm not familiar enough with Windows processes to be comfortable fixing this myself.  If you have suggestions, the relevant logic is in archive_read_support_filter_program.c.  The current code was designed for POSIX systems, and attempts to work on Windows by using adapter functions from archive_windows.c It is possible that we may need a completely separate version of this source file specifically for Windows.

Alternatively, you can build libarchive with zlib:  That will cause libarchive to perform the gzip decompression itself without relying on an external program.

items.title: Multiple "Can't create <file>" when extracting tar.bz2 file that works with tar
items.summary: Multiple "Can't create <file>" when extracting tar.bz2 file that works with tar

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Grab file that does not work, for example latest: http://downloads.sourceforge.net/math-atlas/atlas3.10.1.tar.bz2 2. Make sure that it works with tar: tar -xjf atlas3.10.1.tar.bz2 3. See it fail with bsdtar: bsdtar -xf atlas3.10.1.tar.bz2 Instead of files extracted, I see ATLAS/CONFIG/src/winf77.c: Can't create 'ATLAS/CONFIG/src/winf77.c' ATLAS/CONFIG/src/Makefile: Can't create 'ATLAS/CONFIG/src/Makefile' .....(lots more) ATLAS/include/C_lapack.h: Can't create 'ATLAS/include/C_lapack.h' bsdtar: Error exit delayed from previous errors. What version are you using? Found this out with 3.0.4, but confirmed it fails with 3.1.1 On what operating system? Arch Linux, current How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) Used pre-packaged 3.0.4 and 3.1.1 built using same options: ./configure --prefix=/usr --without-xml2 all 3 tests passed. What compiler or development environment (please include version)? gcc 4.7.2, glibc 2.17, kernel 3.7.4... like always with Arch Linux, very fresh. Please provide any additional information below. I have no idea if this is caused by wrongly created upstream ATLAS package, but it works with plain tar. I eliminated all possible outside causes I could think of, like permission issues or disc space.

btw, doing "repackage" with:

tar -xjf atlas3.10.1.tar.bz2
tar -cjf atlas3.10.1.tar.bz2 ATLAS

made it work. It makes me wonder if this is caused by some buggy tar or bzip versions on package authors side? Anyway, I'm leaving this to investigate.

This is a pretty screwed-up archive.  Here's why bsdtar doesn't like it:

Consider the 'winf77.c' file you referred to.  There are actually
two entries for that file.  The first one is just fine:

-rw-r--r--  0 whaley whaley    9057 Jan  8 10:15 ATLAS/CONFIG/src/winf77.c

The second one is the problem:

hrw-r--r--  0 whaley whaley       0 Jan  8 10:15 ATLAS/CONFIG/src/winf77.c link to ATLAS/CONFIG/src/winf77.c

Remember that tar extraction programs are always supposed to overwrite when
they see a later entry that has the same name as an earlier entry.

So when bsdtar sees the second entry, it first removes the existing file
(which was extracted from the first entry), then tries to create the
hardlink.  Since the hardlink here is nonsensical, that fails, ultimately
leaving you without a 'winf77.c' file on disk.

You should certainly raise this issue with the folks who are distributing this
archive.  There is a common misuse of -T or -I flags that causes damaged
archives of this sort; the folks who created this archive would likely
appreciate the chance to fix it.

I believe the GNU tar folks have put in some special logic on extraction to detect
and ignore self-links of this sort.  (Since you're using Linux, I presume that the
"plain tar" you refer to is GNU tar?)   We should certainly consider adding
a similar check to bsdtar.  (I don't think this belongs in libarchive, though.)

In the meantime, you can extract this by adding the -k option ("keep").  This
prevents tar from overwriting existing files; in this case, it prevents the later
link entry from removing the earlier file entry.

Yes, I meant GNU tar. As for -k option, it isn't that easy, I actually only partially "use" bsdtar - mostly because it is used by package management toolchain (pacman/makepkg) on Arch Linux, and I don't this there is way to pass extra options to it.

Anyway, I will report broken archive upstream. Thanks for explanation.

items.title: Zip files written by Python zipfile module extract to files full of null bytes
items.summary: Zip files written by Python zipfile module extract to files full of null bytes

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? $ cat bug.py import zipfile zf = zipfile.ZipFile('out.zip', 'w') zf.writestr('file.txt', 'This is a test.\n') zf.close() $ python bug.py $ unzip out.zip Archive: out.zip extracting: file.txt $ hexdump -C file.txt 00000000 54 68 69 73 20 69 73 20 61 20 74 65 73 74 2e 0a |This is a test..| 00000010 $ bsdtar xvf out.zip x file.txt $ hexdump -C file.txt 00000000 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 |................| 00000010 What is the expected output? What do you see instead? (see above) What version are you using? libarchive 3.0.3 and Git master (v3.1.1-14-g1148d8d) On what operating system? Fedora 17 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) Fedora package (libarchive-3.0.3-2.fc17.x86_64) for 3.0.3, configure for Git master What compiler or development environment (please include version)? gcc 4.7.2-2.fc17.x86_64 Python 2.7.3-7.2.fc17.x86_64 Please provide any additional information below.

Thank you for the detailed report.

This seems to work correctly with the current github master of lib archive.

items.title: libarchive reports ENOMEM on mtree generation
items.summary: libarchive reports ENOMEM on mtree generation

items.content:
- What steps will reproduce the problem?
bsdtar -czf MTREE --format=mtree --options='!all,use-set,type,uid,gid,mode,time,size,md5,sha256,link' my/file/path

- What is the expected output? What do you see instead?
I wanted my mtree file! Instead, I just get an ENOMEM error:
"Fatal Internal Error in libarchive: Out of memory"

- What version are you using?
3.1.1, but the issue still exists in the latest pull from git.

- On what operating system?
64-bit Linux (Arch Linux).

- How did you build?  (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary)
./configure --prefix=/usr --without-xml2

- What compiler or development environment (please include version)?
gcc 4.7.2

- Please provide any additional information below.
Appears to be caused by an uninitialized value in an archive_string leading to an attempt at an impossibly large allocation. I've attached a stack trace with some inspection which shows the archive_string (dent->parentdir) having a length of 18446744073709551124.

This is easily reproducible, and blocks Arch Linux from upgrading to 3.1. Please let me know if there's anything else I can provide.
Bisected this to f83da3539b0d32131d4b, when the mtree-classic format was introduced.
Attached patch fixes the bug for me, and the test suite still passes, but I'm not sure it's the right fix. It at least pinpoints where the failure occurs, though.
I'm afraid I have been unable to reproduce this issue. What is the exact path you are using as "my/file/path"? Are you using a path starting with "./my/file/path" or a path using ".."?

I'm attaching a tarball which reliably reproduces the issue for me. Decompress the tarball and run:

bsdtar -czf mtree --format=mtree --options='!all,use-set,type,uid,gid,mode,time,size,md5,sha256,link' pacman-git
Any news here? Is the tarball I provided sufficient for reproducing the error?

Hi, thanks for your patch. Indeed, the issue was from the use of dirname instead of file->pathname.s. Some entries would not have the leading './' so the if statement correcting this at line 1828 would fix this. The line executing archive_string_empty(&file->parentdir); would clear dirname, so file->parentdir.s would have to be used instead.

I'll provide a test case for this shortly.

items.title: LZO support broken on various architectures
items.summary: LZO support broken on various architectures

items.content:
On certain architectures, such as arm, when trying to build libarchive with LZO support enabled, the test_write_filter_lzop test case fails on these architectures.

Here is a build log from one of the architectures that has this problem.
https://buildd.debian.org/status/fetch.php?pkg=libarchive&arch=armel&ver=3.1.2-2&stamp=1360543656

The output shows this
258: test_write_filter_lzop
libarchive/test/test_write_filter_lzop.c:152: Assertion failed: used2 < used1
   Description: compression-level=9 wrote 7646 bytes, default wrote 6144 bytes

I have temporarily disabled building libarchive packages in Debian with LZO enabled.
Fixed in commit 26629c191a9e938e5952b4f926f4b29d2a52d5d7

CMake v2.8.10.2

Thanks for reporting this.

I have a couple of questions that will help narrow the problem:

  * Do you have "gzip" available on your system?

  * Do you have "zlib" installed?

  * If you do have zlib installed, did "cmake" find zlib?

  * Are any other tests failing?

This particular test verifies that libarchive can configure gzip
decompression in a particular way.  This test checks that you
have either built with zlib or have a gzip executable available
before it runs so that it won't try to check on systems that cannot
support gzip at all.

This might be a problem with the test (the way we're checking
for gzip might be wrong) or a problem with libarchive (it should
be able to handle gzip but can't).

I did not have zlib installed, and no, none of the other tests were failing.  I have since installed zlib and rebuilt, but now for some reason the tests are all crashing.  I would guess that this is a problem on my end, however, and this issue can be closed.

Thank you.

items.title: libarchive lrzip support broken on certain architectures
items.summary: libarchive lrzip support broken on certain architectures

items.content:
When attempting to build libarchive with lrzip support on certain architectures, some of the lrzip test cases fail.

So far, the failures for the Linux architectures have been consistent. Here is the failure for armhf.
https://buildd.debian.org/status/fetch.php?pkg=libarchive&arch=armhf&ver=3.1.2-5&stamp=1361747948

Failures for the other architectures can be found at
https://buildd.debian.org/status/package.php?p=libarchive&suite=experimental
and
http://buildd.debian-ports.org/status/package.php?p=libarchive&suite=experimental

It appears that the lrzip test issues for Debian have been fixed?  At least, I don't see them in the current build results on the Debian package building systems.

I am also unable to reproduce these problems locally.

I'm going to close this as "Fixed"; if anyone thinks otherwise, please reopen this bug and I'll take another look.

items.title: Memory error when reading a zip file
items.summary: Memory error when reading a zip file

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? Open a specific zip file and list the contents using the test program attached. If archive_read_open_filename is used, it works. If it's archive_read_open_FILE, we have memory errors. Errors result in a crash under Mac OS. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Bad memory accesses in the valgrind log. Two log files are given, using each of the APIs. What version are you using? libarchive 3.1.2 from ARCH Linux, rebuilt with symbols. What compiler or development environment (please include version)? gcc 4.7.2 Please provide any additional information below. I have censored the path names from the output. I can not distribute the archive file publicly, but I will send it to you in private if you need.

archive_read_open_FILE does not fully support seeking.  archive_read_open_filename does.

The Zip reader uses very different strategies for reading Zip archives when it cannot seek within the file.  This should not result in errors, of course, but it does explain why you see different results with the two approaches.

Unfortunately, the valgrind output isn't quite enough.  It points to a problem somewhere in zip_read_local_file_header, but the line number gives is the line number of a macro that's used many times in that function.

If you could share the Zip fie with me in private email to kientzle@acm.org, I should be able to isolate the problem very quickly.

items.title: abort trap in archive_read_data_skip
items.summary: abort trap in archive_read_data_skip

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. tar tf file.xar What is the expected output? What do you see instead? I expected to see either a clean error (the file format is xar, not tar). Instead, tar crashes with an abort trap. What version are you using? bsdtar 2.8.3 - libarchive 2.8.3 On what operating system? Mac OS X How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) Mac OS X comes with a pre-compiled version of bsdtar What compiler or development environment (please include version)? NA Please provide any additional information below. I uploaded _the first megabyte_ of the file I used when I got the trap. I get the trap the same way with the first megabyte (complete file was too big). If needed I can upload the complete file somewhere.

bsdtar does have some support for XAR archives.  That support is still pretty new, so there may well be shortcomings.

Please try the attached patch (against the newest source code from github) and let us know if that fixes it for you.
The patch fixes the abort trap. Now bsdtar fails cleanly.

That's disappointing.  I was hoping that it wouldn't fail at all.

Where did you get this archive from?
Can you create or somehow obtain a smaller one that shows the same problem?

We're always interested in files that libarchive fails on that are small enough to add to libarchive's test suite.  When we can add a file to the test suite, we can not only fix the bug but be confident that it won't ever come back.

The failing xar comes from the 2013 MacUpdate Bundle. It is the installer for the 1000 fonts pack.
I've uploaded it on a private server. It is available at http://www.frostland.fr/media/file.xar and will be removed from the server in 3 weeks.

items.title: bsdtar reports "Damaged tar archive" for tar file containing just a pax comment header
items.summary: bsdtar reports "Damaged tar archive" for tar file containing just a pax comment header

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? Creating two test archives, one using dd and the other using git because I don't know how to create tar archives with comments any other way (except byte by byte). Commands: mkdir dir; cd dir; git init; echo .gitattributes export-ignore >.gitattributes; git add .gitattributes; git commit -m.; git archive -o comment.tar HEAD; dd if=/dev/zero of=empty.tar bs=1024 count=10; bsdtar tf empty.tar; echo $?; bsdtar tf comment.tar; echo $? What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Both are essentially empty archives. The first bsdtar exists with status 0 and prints no output; this is the expected behaviour. The second one however (against the tar file containing only a comment) exits with status 1 and reports: bsdtar: Damaged tar archive bsdtar: Error exit delayed from previous errors. What version are you using? bsdtar 3.0.4 - libarchive 3.0.4, bsdtar 3.1.2 - libarchive 3.1.2 git version 1.8.2.1 (earlier versions can't create empty archives) On what operating system? Linux debian 3.2.0-4-amd64 #1 SMP Debian 3.2.41-2 x86_64 GNU/Linux How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) pre-packaged binary (3.0.4), configure (3.1.2) What compiler or development environment (please include version)? gcc-4.6 (Debian 4.6.3-14) 4.6.3 Please provide any additional information below. Empty archives are a dubious corner case, and bsdtar doesn't even handle pax extended header comment records, but still it's inconsistent to quietly handle completely empty archives but report a fatal error when a comment is added. GNU tar is silent in both cases. Original report: http://thread.gmane.org/gmane.comp.version-control.git/220485 The attached patch fixes the issue, but it may be too blunt.

Your patch is exactly correct:  An EOF condition immediately after a 'g' record should be treated as a regular EOF.

Thanks for sharing how to create a sample file; I've added a test for this case to the libarchive test suite and committed the test and your fix.

Which version did the patch end up in, because I have a simillar problem with this file :

http://sgh.dk/~sgh/Norway_geoids.dat

it's a targz stream ending with ARCHIVE_FATAL. I wonder if it's the same problem. I'm using libarchive 3.1.2

Concerning libarchive v3.1.2... This may or may not be known already, but more testing is required for the xz and 7zip formats because with small files, they work... But with larger files that contain several files, it either doesn't work or hangs.

What I'm testing with is about 100 files that total about 25 MB compressed as either .tar.xz or .7z

I just created a .tar.xz archive with 442994 files; the total archive
size was just over 1GB.  It worked just fine.

I'm repeating that test with 7zip format but I expect it will also work fine.

So something else is going on.

Are you using bsdtar or a custom program?
What operating system?
What compiler?
Did you compile libarchive with liblzma or is it using the command-line xz program?
When it hangs, is it using CPU time?
Can you run it under a debugger and see where it is hung?

For the record, I repeated my test (442k files, >1GB resulting archive) with 7z and it also worked fine.

Would like to get more details about the hang you saw so we can figure out what's really happening and get it fixed.

items.title: Seeking support?
items.summary: Seeking support?

items.content:
Would it be possible to implement seeking within archive entries? Or in other words, change the read position within the stream read by archive_read_data(). So far, the API seems to support linear reading only.

Most archive formats perhaps do not support random access directly. But it could be realized by storing the archive decompressor state all xx MB, and if a seek to a certain position is requested, resume from the closest state backup, then skip data until the seek target is reached.

Somewhat related to this, it would be interesting to know whether an entry is compressed or not. For some reason, it's popular to pack media files (like music or video) in uncompressed rar or zip files, either for packing bundling multiple files into one file, or for splitting a single file into multiple files. Some media players even have direct support for this (e.g. VLC in modules/access/rar/rar.c, which can open uncompressed rar files only).

It might be possible to implement seeking within entries:
If you have ideas on how to implement it, I'd be very
interested in seeing code.

Re: reporting the compression for each entry

This would be pretty simple to add, though possibly
misleading.

For example, because of how libarchive is designed,
entries in a tar.gz archive would have to be marked
"uncompressed."  Is that you would expect?

>If you have ideas on how to implement it, I'd be very interested in seeing code.

I don't know the libarchive code or its architecture. (I'm just someone who wants to implement transparent archive reading support to his application for streams that are mostly read linearly, but sometimes need random access.)

My idea was that each decompression filter can save/restore its state. So you could resume compression at places for which you have a state backup. Once you have this, it would be easy to implement byte-exact seeking by skipping all data between the restore point and the seek target. Since the amount of data that needs to be skipped will be relatively low (assuming a moderate number of such restore points), random access seeking can be fast.

Adding this resume/restore functionality to decompressors would probably be a bit of work, if it's feasible at all. Though I would guess/hope that most compression formats compress data in independent blocks, instead of making the decompression of every byte dependent on the full decompression of every preceding byte.

>For example, because of how libarchive is designed,
>entries in a tar.gz archive would have to be marked
>"uncompressed."  Is that you would expect?

No, it would be the expect opposite from what I'd expect. If there's a way to query the compression of the archive itself, it might make sense, though.

I started working on it by supporting seeking to an arbitrary header. To go incrementally, the first patch doesn't focus on filters. If a filter is used, then seeking will not perform well. However, for no filters, it will give a huge performance boost.

@kientzle: I created a pull request at https://github.com/libarchive/libarchive/pull/95. PTAL. Thanks.

items.title: fcntl(F_DUPFD_CLOEXEC) missing argument
items.summary: fcntl(F_DUPFD_CLOEXEC) missing argument

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. mkdir -p testdir1/testdir2/testdir3 2. Run bsdtar czf testdir1 under a system call tracer. 3. Notice that a fcntl(F_DUPFD_CLOEXEC) call fails because it is passed a bogus arg. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? I expect F_DUPFD_CLOEXEC to be used correctly. Instead, I get stuff like 23264 bsdtar CALL fcntl(0x5,F_DUPFD_CLOEXEC,0x120000) 23264 bsdtar RET fcntl -1 errno 22 Invalid argument 23264 bsdtar CALL dup(0x5) 23264 bsdtar RET dup 6 23264 bsdtar CALL fcntl(0x6,F_GETFD,<invalid>0xffffffff) 23264 bsdtar RET fcntl 0 23264 bsdtar CALL fcntl(0x6,F_SETFD,FD_CLOEXEC) 23264 bsdtar RET fcntl 0 This issues more system calls than needed and leaves a race window where a file descriptor may be incorrectly inherited if another thread forks and execs. What version are you using? I originally found the bug in FreeBSD 10-current's import. The bug is still in git master as of 2013-05-03. On what operating system? FreeBSD 10-current. How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) FreeBSD buildworld What compiler or development environment (please include version)? FreeBSD buildworld Please provide any additional information below. The bug is in the source file libarchive/libarchive/archive_read_disk_posix.c It does new_fd = fcntl(fd, F_DUPFD_CLOEXEC); This should be new_fd = fcntl(fd, F_DUPFD_CLOEXEC, 0);
The command should be tar czf test.tgz testdir1
Should be fixed by git 12f78cb8cc19e28e8ba66966c59a8d7f3e4c1511

items.title: Wrong struct stat size while compiled on Raspberry Pi
items.summary: Wrong struct stat size while compiled on Raspberry Pi

items.content:
Libarchive is built with large file support on Linux.
Linux programs that use libarchive must also enable large file support by including this option when building:

-D_FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64

(I've long wanted some Linux developer to step forward and help remove this limitation.  It requires understanding Linux' large file support macros, the various struct stat definitions, and how they all interact.  It will require very little change to libarchive itself.  Contact me off-list if you are interested in helping.)

Thanks! That worked. Please state this in bold in the documentation, since it is not obvious and does not appear on 64bit systems due to padding. Was quite hard to debug this in a huge s/w ported to RPi.

items.title: mingw-w64: undefined reference to `_set_invalid_parameter_handler'
items.summary: mingw-w64: undefined reference to `_set_invalid_parameter_handler'

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Try to compile libarchive using mingw-w64 What is the expected output? What do you see instead? CMakeFiles\libarchive_test.dir/objects.a(main.c.obj):main.c:(.text.startup+0x6c): undefined reference to `_set_invalid_parameter_handler' What version are you using? 3.1.2 On what operating system? Windows 7, but it shouldn't matter How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) cmake What compiler or development environment (please include version)? i686-w64-mingw32-gcc-4.8.0-win32_rubenvb to be precise, but the exact version shouldn't matter Please provide any additional information below. Mingw and mingw-w64 both use an old MSVCRT version that doesn't define _set_invalid_parameter_handler. Libarchive only calls it in test/main.c if HAVE__CrtSetReportMode is defined - and it's defined if the crtdbg.h file has a _CrtSetReportMode symbol. While mingw doesn't ship that header at all (causing the _set_invalid_parameter_handler call to be hidden), mingw-w64 does. The bug linked below is the reason why _set_invalid_parameter_handler is declared at all. (otherwise we would have a compiler error, rather than a linker error) http://sourceforge.net/tracker/?func=detail&aid=3610440&group_id=202880&atid=983354

Did you solve this?

I am facing a similar issue. It would be helpfull if you could shed some light on the resolution
I'm also facing this issue, any ideas on how to resolve this?

items.title: function tar_atol256() performs an undefined left shift of a negative integer
items.summary: function tar_atol256() performs an undefined left shift of a negative integer

items.content:
This is still present in current master (6b3531ff):

 https://github.com/libarchive/libarchive/blob/6b3531ff/libarchive
/archive_read_support_format_tar.c#L2480

This is still present in current master (6b3531ff):

 https://github.com/libarchive/libarchive/blob/6b3531ff/libarchive/archive_read_support_format_tar.c#L2480
I committed the fix back in June but didn't close the bug.

For reference, the fix was here:

https://github.com/libarchive/libarchive/commit/533e8fdaf3669fe0e246f675178f785e4eecd55a

This fix in CMake is now here:
http://cmake.org/gitweb?p=cmake.git;a=commitdiff;h=5ee1297d

Despite this, CMake's "ExternalProject" test is still triggering clang's undefined behaviour checker (ubsan), but a little differently than last time:

CMake/Utilities/cmlibarchive/libarchive/archive_read_support_format_tar.c:2488:10: runtime error: left shift of negative value -54

By inspection of the new tar_atol256() code, it seems to me that the one's compliment performed in the first 'if' will result in a negative 'l'.

Perhaps this function could/should be reworked to use unsigned types, where bitwise operations are more well defined, as is generally recommend:

https://www.securecoding.cert.org/confluence/display/seccode/INT34-C.+Do+not+shift+a+negative+number+of+bits+or+more+bits+than+exist+in+the+operand
https://www.securecoding.cert.org/confluence/display/seccode/INT13-C.+Use+bitwise+operators+only+on+unsigned+operands

I've rewritten it yet again.  Now the code simulates twos-complement arithmetic on a uint64_t rather than using native twos-complement arithmetic on an int64_t.

Let me know if this quiets things for you.

If anyone else would like to try their hand at writing a version of this function:  I've attached a short test program to this issue that exercises some of the boundary cases for this function.

Thanks for working on this, Tim.  Left shift of a negative integer type is undefined behavior so it is good to have an implementation that avoids it.

For reference, the Dec 7 rewrite commit was:

 https://github.com/libarchive/libarchive/commit/6cf33c9307bbf5827df9500750e59a35b6f2d5d3

I just added a portability fixup:

 https://github.com/libarchive/libarchive/commit/07686034efec92c75547def958ae618754e15013
CMake's "ExternalProject" test now passes with -fsanitize=shift.  Thanks to all!

items.title: Stack overflow in test_read_format_rar_binary
items.summary: Stack overflow in test_read_format_rar_binary

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. Build RUN_TESTS using Visual Studio 2012. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? All tests should pass. What version are you using? 3.1.2 On what operating system? Windows Server 2012 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) CMake What compiler or development environment (please include version)? Visual Studio 2012 Update 2 Please provide any additional information below. Running Code Analysis on the libarchive_test project confirms there's a problem with stack usage: "test_read_format_rar.c(661): warning : C6262: Function uses '1081364' bytes of stack: exceeds /analyze:stacksize '16384'. Consider moving some data to heap."
Try increasing the linker stack reserve size > 4m example: /stack:5120000000

Try the attached patch, which moves the biggest of those buffers onto the heap.

We really shouldn't be using that much stack space, not even in tests.

Similar changes can probably be applied anywhere else we're using more stack than we should.

Here's a corrected version of that patch which I've just committed to libarchive master.

Let me know what other problems you find and we'll work through them.

items.title: libarchive / tar with zero sized exclude files with -X.
items.summary: libarchive / tar with zero sized exclude files with -X.

items.content:
It seems there's a problem with zero sized exclude files.

FreeBSD-9.2 (works as expected):

# tar --version
bsdtar 2.8.5 - libarchive 2.8.5
# cd /tmp
# mkdir t
# date > 1
# date > 2
# date > 3
# touch excl
# tar -cvf foo.tar 1 2 3
a 1
a 2
a 3
# tar -xf foo.tar -X excl
# tar -xf foo.tar -X /tmp/excl -C /tmp/t
#

FreeBSD-10 (fails with bizzare error):

# tar --version
bsdtar 3.1.2 - libarchive 3.1.2
# cd /tmp
# mkdir t
# date > 1
# date > 2
# date > 3
# touch excl
# tar -cvf foo.tar 1 2 3
a 1
a 2
a 3
# tar -xf foo.tar -X /tmp/excl
tar: Error : Unrecognized archive format
# tar -xf foo.tar -X /tmp/excl -C /tmp/t
tar: Error : Unrecognized archive format
# echo # > excl
# tar -xf foo.tar -X /tmp/excl -C /tmp/t
# tar -xf foo.tar -X /tmp/excl -C /tmp/t
# rm excl; touch excl
# tar -xf foo.tar -X /tmp/excl -C /tmp/t
tar: Error : Unrecognized archive format
#

"Unrecognized archive format" is not an appropriate error for a zero sized exclude file.  If I had to guess, I'd suspect that something is trying to identify file type or encoding and failing on zero sized files.

Fixed in git f93e32f

Thanks for pointing this out; sorry it took so long to fix.
Issue 401 has been merged into this issue.

items.title: Cannot read 7zip, etc, with archive_read_open_FILE
items.summary: Cannot read 7zip, etc, with archive_read_open_FILE

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. unzip more.zip (more.com, more.7z, more_7zsfx.exe, more_zipsfx.exe ) 2. gcc 1.c -larchive 3. ./a.out more.7z What is the expected output? What do you see instead? more.7z and more_7zsfx.exe use archive_read_open_filename, the extract file is correct use archive_read_open_FILE, the extract file size is 0 more_zipsfx.exe use archive_read_open_filename, the extract file is correct use archive_read_open_FILE, output "not supported" What version are you using? libarchive-3.1.2 On what operating system? ubuntu 13.04 x64 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) cmake What compiler or development environment (please include version)? gcc version 4.7.3 Please provide any additional information below. #include <stdio.h> #include <stdlib.h> #include <archive.h> #include <archive_entry.h> int main(int argc, char* argv[]) { struct archive *a; a = archive_read_new(); archive_read_support_filter_all(a); archive_read_support_format_all(a); int r; //r = archive_read_open_filename(a, argv[1], 10240); FILE *in = fopen(argv[1], "rb"); r = archive_read_open_FILE(a, in); if (r != ARCHIVE_OK) { printf("not supported\n"); return 1; } int size; char buf[1024]; FILE *out = fopen("tmpfile", "wb+"); struct archive_entry *entry; while(archive_read_next_header(a, &entry) == ARCHIVE_OK) { while((size = archive_read_data(a, buf, 1024)) > 0) fwrite(buf, sizeof(char), size, out); if(archive_errno(a) != ARCHIVE_OK) printf("%s\n", archive_error_string(a)); archive_read_data_skip(a); } fclose(out); fclose(in); archive_read_free(a); return 0; }

Currently, archive_read_open_FILE does not support seeking.  archive_read_open_filename does.

Self-extracting Zip archives, 7z, and some other formats cannot be read without seeking.

Patches to add seek support for archive_read_open_FILE would be appreciated.
Updating bug title to more accurately reflect the actual issue.

updates.summary: Cannot read 7zip, etc, with archive_read_open_FILE

items.title: ACLs are not preserved by bsdtar
items.summary: ACLs are not preserved by bsdtar

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? localhost ~ # touch a localhost ~ # setfacl -m user:nobody:r a localhost ~ # ls -l a -rw-r--r--+ 1 root root 0 Jul 27 20:22 a localhost ~ # mkdir extract localhost ~ # bsdtar -cpf - a | bsdtar -xpf - -C extract/ localhost ~ # ls -l extract/ total 0 -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 0 Jul 27 20:22 a What is the expected output? What do you see instead? The ACL should be preserved, but it is not (no + in permissions). What version are you using? 3.1.2 On what operating system? Gentoo Linux ~amd64 How did you build? Gentoo ebuild, uses configure. What compiler or development environment? gcc 4.7.3 Please provide any additional information below. I distinctly remember bsdtar preserving ACLs some time ago. Libarchive is definitely being compiled with ACLs enabled, as can be seen in the build log.

I found out the cause of this bug and fixed it.

The problem is that ACL_TYPE_NFS4 is not defined in some systems in sys/acl.h (I am using Fedora 19 3.10.4-300.fc19.x86_64 and it is not here). 
This causes that functions translate_acl() in archive_read_disk_entry_from_file.c:404 and archive_write_disk_set_acls() in archive_write_disk_acl.c:69 are suppressed by #if defined() directive and thus saving and restoring ACLs is not performed.

I fixed the problem by removing #ifdef ACL_TYPE_NFS4 suppressing the whole functions and instead putting #ifdefs to all individual places where NFS4-only code is. So now these functions are compiled even if you don't have ACL_TYPE_NFS4 and only code that needs it is not compiled.

I already fixed it in Fedora 19: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=993048
Now it is on testing stage. If you find any problem please contact me.

* bump
This bugfix was recently pushed to Fedora 19 stable repository: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=993048
Please give a feedback, you can actually use this patch to fix the bug globally.
Thanks for the fix. I confirm the fix works on Gentoo (libarchive-3.1.2-r1).
Bump; will this ever be applied?
Doubtful if you'll get a reaction here, but the devs are responsive to pull requests on github: https://github.com/libarchive/libarchive/pulls

I've committed the fix.

Thanks for your patience!

items.title: x64 build of bsdtar fails for Visual Studio 2010 SP1
items.summary: x64 build of bsdtar fails for Visual Studio 2010 SP1

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. download libarchive (3.1.2) 2. download latest cmake (2.8.11.2) 3. start cmake_gui.exe 4. configure for Visual Studio 2010 (=10) x64. 5. generate solution file What is the expected output? What do you see instead? The generated config.h misses some defines that will exist in the 32-bit configuration. What version are you using? Visual Studio 2010 SP1 Professional was used. On what operating system? Windows 7. How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) cmage-gui (as described in https://github.com/libarchive/libarchive/wiki/BuildInstructions#wiki-WindowsVisual_Studio) What compiler or development environment (please include version)? Visual Studio 2010 SP1 (with all windows updates applied). The whole C/C++ x64 + Platform SDK was selected when installing VS2010. Please provide any additional information below. I attached the generated 32-bit.config.h + 64-bit.config.h + the modified.64-bit-config.h. See attached zip. For some (for me unknown) reason cmake did not detect that some header files did exist in the 64-bit build and thus causes build errors. The 32-bit ran fine out of the box. Note: you may benefit by using typedefs from (Microsoft's SDK) basetsd.h (e.g. SSIZE_T or LONG_PTR) which hides the 32-bit/64-bit differences in these types. Example: you can typedef ssize_t as SSIZE_T (bit-independent) or use LONG_PTR. Visual Studio is always equiped with a windows/platform SDK. Unfortunately, Microsoft has its own considerations in not using sys/types.h or a way that is very common on *NIX platforms.

items.title: Extracts garbage from Epub (zip) files that have incomplete mode information.
items.summary: Extracts garbage from Epub (zip) files that have incomplete mode information.

items.content:
libarchive-3.1.2-7.fc19.x86_64

$ bsdtar xf foo.epub META-INF/container.xml
$ cat META-INF/container.xml 
$ ls -l META-INF/container.xml 
0 -rw-------. 1 hadess hadess 227 Jan 28  2012 META-INF/container.xml

Opening the file with vim shows garbage inside the file. Opening the file with unzip from Info-ZIP works correctly.

$ unzip  foo.epub META-INF/container.xml
Archive:  foo.epub
  inflating: META-INF/container.xml
$ ls -l META-INF/container.xml 
4.1k -rw-------. 1 hadess hadess 227 Jan 28  2012 META-INF/container.xml

The file contains XML data with ^M control characters.

I just pushed a fix for this.  Please try it and let me know.

The epub writer that created this file stored incomplete "mode"
information:  The file was marked as having "unix-like" external
attributes, but the external attributes did not include the file
type as part of the mode bits.

I've changed libarchive to be more careful when it interprets
the external attributes information.  If the Unix file mode does not
specify a file type, it will now look at the filename and guess that
it is a regular file or directory depending on the last character
of the file name being '/'.

updates.summary: Extracts garbage from Epub (zip) files that have incomplete mode information.

items.content: Verified to work fine with current master, thanks!

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? Attempt to build libarchive with CMake using an Android toolchain. What is the expected output? What do you see instead? The build process fails with the following: [ 4%] Building C object libarchive/CMakeFiles/archive.dir/archive_read_disk_posix.c.o /home/preet/Downloads/build/libarchive/libarchive/archive_read_disk_posix.c: In function 'setup_current_filesystem': /home/preet/Downloads/build/libarchive/libarchive/archive_read_disk_posix.c:1663:17: error: storage size of 'svfs' isn't known /home/preet/Downloads/build/libarchive/libarchive/archive_read_disk_posix.c:1680:3: warning: implicit declaration of function 'fstatvfs' [-Wimplicit-function-declaration] /home/preet/Downloads/build/libarchive/libarchive/archive_read_disk_posix.c:1663:17: warning: unused variable 'svfs' [-Wunused-variable] make[2]: *** [libarchive/CMakeFiles/archive.dir/archive_read_disk_posix.c.o] Error 1 make[1]: *** [libarchive/CMakeFiles/archive.dir/all] Error 2 make: *** [all] Error 2 What version are you using? libarchive from git On what operating system? Cross compiling for Android on Arch Linux 64-bit How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) cmake (quick question, i dont see a configure file in the git master?) What compiler or development environment (please include version)? android ndk r8/gcc 4.6

> cmake (quick question, i dont see a configure file in the git master?)

The configure script is generated with autoconf.  The following should build it on systems that have the necessary tools installed:

   $  /bin/sh build/autogen.sh

Please try that and see if it gets you any further.  Cross-compiling can be tricky.

Using configure directly with the standalone toolchain path in my environment seemed to build libarchive successfully.

I'm still curious as to why the cmake build failed though. I'll update this issue if I figure out why.

It fails at the same place. Both cmake and configure say statvfs isn't available with the toolchain I'm using [checking for statvfs... no]. The error:

  CC       libarchive/archive_read_disk_posix.lo
libarchive/archive_read_disk_posix.c: In function 'setup_current_filesystem':
libarchive/archive_read_disk_posix.c:1663:17: error: storage size of 'svfs' isn't known
libarchive/archive_read_disk_posix.c:1680:3: error: implicit declaration of function 'fstatvfs' [-Werror=implicit-function-declaration]
libarchive/archive_read_disk_posix.c:1663:17: error: unused variable 'svfs' [-Werror=unused-variable]
cc1: all warnings being treated as errors

make[1]: *** [libarchive/archive_read_disk_posix.lo] Error 1
make[1]: Leaving directory `/home/preet/Downloads/build/libarchive-git'


The line in question in the source is

    struct statvfs svfs;

I'm guessing its undefined since statvfs isn't available?

+#ifdef __ANDROID__
+#include <sys/vfs.h>
+#define statvfs statfs
+#define fstatvfs fstatfs
+#endif
This should fix this problem.

items.title: Differences in newc output between GNU cpio and bsdcpio
items.summary: Differences in newc output between GNU cpio and bsdcpio

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? $ for i in 1 2 3 ; do echo $i > foo-$i ; done $ ls foo-* | tee /dev/stderr | cpio -o -H newc > foo.cpio foo-1 foo-2 foo-3 1 block $ ls foo-* | tee /dev/stderr | bsdcpio -o -H newc > foo.bsdcpio foo-1 foo-2 foo-3 1 block $ file foo.* foo.bsdcpio: ASCII cpio archive (SVR4 with no CRC) foo.cpio: ASCII cpio archive (SVR4 with no CRC) $ md5sum foo.* c61cf2e353370adffeb96c141fc5fe0a foo.bsdcpio 5621a7291e4148cab67328baa86b6332 foo.cpio $ sha1sum foo.* 0ccb36d387981c8933627171b640f42740b7e7c1 foo.bsdcpio 2aa98196c0d2010732bce779da98cab71aee3a70 foo.cpio What is the expected output? What do you see instead? I expected the checksums to be the same. What version are you using? $ cpio --version cpio (GNU cpio) 2.11 Copyright (C) 2010 Free Software Foundation, Inc. License GPLv3+: GNU GPL version 3 or later <http://gnu.org/licenses/gpl.html>. This is free software: you are free to change and redistribute it. There is NO WARRANTY, to the extent permitted by law. Written by Phil Nelson, David MacKenzie, John Oleynick, and Sergey Poznyakoff. $ bsdcpio --version bsdcpio 3.1.2 -- libarchive 3.1.2 On what operating system? Arch Linux. $ uname -a Linux mobster 3.10.10-1-ARCH #1 SMP PREEMPT Fri Aug 30 11:30:06 CEST 2013 x86_64 GNU/Linux How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) Standard Arch Linux PKGBUILD / official repos. What compiler or development environment (please include version)? gcc Please provide any additional information below. -

Please upload the actual files you created.

(Generally, there is no reason to expect the checksums to be
the same.  There are insignificant differences in the actual
byte layout created by different archiving programs, even
between different versions of the same program.)

I posted in "What steps will reproduce the problem?" how I created the files, you should be able to do this yourself ;)

Of course, there is a reason to expect the checksums to be the same: If I tell both apps to produce a file according to some spec (like SRV4 as I told them to with -H newc) I expect these files to be 'the same'. 'The same' should be verifiable with a simple file integrity checksum like md5. Period.

Also, I would expect there are a) either unit tests to validate this sort of behaviour or b) much more obvious warnings that the results are not the same. File integrity checking is an important part of long-term data archival and app-clones like bsdcpio should prove to create exactly the same product as the original cpio implementation.

"...app-clones like bsdcpio should prove to create exactly the same product as the original cpio implementation."

The original cpio implementation was part of
AT&T's 1974 PWB Unix system and predated GNU cpio
by over a decade.  (I wonder if cpio and GNU cpio actually
produce the same output? ;-)

"I would expect there are a) either unit tests to validate this sort of behaviour..."

There are now over 400 unit tests for the libarchive suite;
I was hoping to get your files so I could evaluate
whether they need to be added.

Admittedly, the libarchive test suite does more extensive
validation of the POSIX cpio format than the newc cpio format,
since the POSIX format is the only cpio variation with
a written standard.

I could create my own files per your instructions, but I wanted to
be certain I was seeing the exact same issue you're seeing.
(Many package systems apply their own patches, so the GNU cpio 2.11
that I would install on my local system may not be quite the same
as what you're using.)

updates.summary: Differences in newc output between GNU cpio and bsdcpio

items.content:
Versions are as above (though I don't know about the Arch Linux releases and dependencies), files created as above. Funny thing: even now the checksums are different then before, but they still are different from each other:

$ md5sum foo.bsdcpio foo.cpio
2c6aac6b300ae52570d3c73714ccd2ee  foo.bsdcpio
33ff061bf690b648e463b090f5465bb5  foo.cpio

Thank you for taking the time.

Here's the story:  libarchive's newc support was developed to match the output of GNU cpio 2.5 (which was current at the time).

Between version 2.6 and 2.7, GNU cpio changed how they write newc format files.  In particular, GNU cpio 2.7 and later use uppercase hexadecimal digits where GNU cpio 2.6 used lowercase.  If you try your experiment with GNU cpio 2.6 and GNU cpio 2.7, you will see that the checksums are different between those two programs as well.

Changing libarchive/bsdcpio to use lowercase for newc format is trivial:  Just edit the format_hex_recursive function in archive_write_set_format_cpio_newc.c  Note that this change will break the unit tests.

It's not clear whether we should change this.  It would make us the same as GNU cpio 2.11 but not the same as older versions of bsdcpio (or older versions of GNU cpio, though that's not very important now).  People who are using bsdcpio for long-term data archiving might not appreciate such a change.

I recognize the history, thank you very much for explaining.

I also recognize you can't do any better for the newc format without an accepted standard / specification. I will advise anyone against using the cpio newc format in particular and archive formats without standards in general, especially for long-term archiving.

Considering this, I guess the only change this issue constitutes is issueing a warning, maybe in combination with a verbose flag or without a quiet flag. Otherwise, I guess you can close this issue.

I'll close this issue.

Note that these formats are very reliable for long-term archiving.  But a simple checksum cannot verify that the files within an archive are the same.

items.title: inconvenient exit status on empty input in bsdtar 2.8.3 and 3.0.0
items.summary: inconvenient exit status on empty input in bsdtar 2.8.3 and 3.0.0

items.content:
With bsdtar 2.8.3 (comes with MacOSX 10.7) or bsdtar 3.0.3 (Ubuntu 12.04),
the command
   echo corrupt > bad.xz
   if xzcat bad.xz | tar -xf -
   then
       echo tar reports success
   else 
       echo tar reports failure
   fi
outputs 'success'.  (With gnu tar, it outputs 'failure' as expected.)

This makes portable-ish scripts that unpack uncommon formats
falsely report success with bsdtar.

I haven't checked to see if bsdtar 3.1.2 also suffers from this.

items.title: 7zip can not be read when opened with archive_read_open_fd
items.summary: 7zip can not be read when opened with archive_read_open_fd

items.content:
If a 7zip file is opened using archive_read_open_fd, then a corresponding archive_read_next_header2 will return a fatal error.

Ultimately, this is because slurp_central_directory calls __archive_read_seek, which in turn requires that the seek callback have been set (using archive_seek_callback).  However, archive_read_open_fd does not set this callback, presumably because it doesn't know if the file descriptor is seekable or not.

Unfortunately, client_seek_proxy, which returns the error if the archive has no seek callback set, does not set an error string on the archive.  So archive_read_next_header2 will return an error with no error string,  which makes it very difficult to figure out why its failing.

At a minimum the attached patch should be applied to have client_seek_proxy set an error string on the archive.  Also there should be documentation that 7zip is not readable via archive_read_open_fd (any any other archive which has this problem).

In the long run, 7zip should be fixed to not use seek.  Alternatively, it might be possible to detect if "fd" is seekable, and if so add the default seek callback (the error message should still be set when the fd is not seekable).

Excellent work btw.

7zip reader needs seeking since a list of archiving files is located at a bottom of
a 7zip archive file. So resolving this issue is libarchive should support seeking for an archive
opened by archive_read_open_fd function.

I believe this issue is fixed by my recent change c0dd6ae5c5369384c14fcc1486886d8463c98909.

I apologize fixing this issue is late. 
Thank you for reporting.

items.title: set_ownership()'s assumption that non-root can't set ownership is sometimes wrong
items.summary: set_ownership()'s assumption that non-root can't set ownership is sometimes wrong

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 0. Set up a zfs filesystem mounted as myself with the vfs.zfs.super_owner (allows non-root to act as root on particular volumes) 1. Try to extract an archive (like FreeBSD's base.tgz) as non-root with tar's --same-owner 2. get lots of messages like: ./usr/bin/indent: Can't set UID=0 set_ownership() in archive_write_disk_posix.c should not assume that non-root users can't change UIDs. It should instead try and only if that fails skip further attempts. What version are you using? 2.8.4 as shipped in in FreeBSD 9.1 On what operating system? FreeBSD 9.1 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) installed with os Please provide any additional information below. We're using this on the nfs host for a netboot cluster similar to the FreeBSD NetPerf cluster were we want to allow people to create NFS roots on ZFS without having to give everyone root. Being able to do this with release tar balls would be nice. As a workaround we could probably extract the permissions to an mtree file but that seems unnecessary.

Hmm...  Interesting.  I had always thought that restriction was part of the kernel, not filesystem-specific.  Apparently, I was wrong about that.

If it's really filesystem-specific, then it needs to be tested once per filesystem.  Libarchive already has machinery for detecting when it crosses filesystems; that's used to drive other filesystem property checks already, so it shouldn't be too hard to extend it to test UID changes.

Are there filesystems that permit some UID changes but not others?   (For example, are there filesystems where I can give away a file to anybody except tom, dick, or root?  What about filesystems that allow give-aways in some directories but not others?)  That would complicate things further.

Speaking only of FreeBSD, the only case I know of in the tree it's ZFS's ability to make the mounter act as a superuser on a per-fs basis.  Looking at the at the implementations of VOP_SETATTR for ufs and zfs, it would be easy to write a MAC module to do the same for other file systems via the priv(9) API, but it is not currently possible to write complex filters that limit what attributes you can set.  The code checking what you can and can't do is implemented per filesystem rather than higher up in the VFS code so in fact a filesystem is free to implement some arbitrary complex policy.

Given that tar's default mode is to no request uid/gid changes when run as a regular user I'd be tempted to just ditch the optimization in libarchive since it's not a common case.

items.title: Fails to decompress a rar file that both unar and unrar (non-free) decompress
items.summary: Fails to decompress a rar file that both unar and unrar (non-free) decompress

items.content:
Hi.

The following is what I reported on Debian's BTS earlier this year (see http://bugs.debian.org/711022), but I got no response from the maintainers.

I initially observed the problem with Debian's 3.1.2-5 and I still see it with 3.1.2-7 (not surprising, given the version numbers).

As I like the concept of bsdtar, I would love to get rid of other compressors/decompressors and simply use bsdtar as much as I can, having the bug listed below fixed would be amazing.

If more information is needed, then, please, let me know and I will do my best to provide it.


Thanks,

Rogrio Brito.

----

Date: Mon, 3 Jun 2013 23:52:50 -0300

Package: bsdtar
Version: 3.1.2-5
Severity: normal

Hi.

I have a rar file that bsdtar isn't able to decompress, though both unar
(the Free decompressor) and unrar (the non-free one) sucessfully decompress
the file.

Just as a sanity check, I compared the output of unar with that of unrar and
they were bit-by-bit the same.

While trying to decompress the file with bsdtar, I received the messages:

,----
| ...: Parsing filters is unsupported.
| (...)
| bsdtar: Error exit delayed from previous errors.
`----

Unfortunately, I can't send the file to the bug tracking system, but I can
send it privately.


Thanks,

Rogrio Brito.
Hi, I'm a user with the same problem. I think this bug has already been reported in issue #262

items.title: Mesa 10.0 rc1 fails to extract
items.summary: Mesa 10.0 rc1 fails to extract

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. get ftp://ftp.freedesktop.org/pub/mesa/10.0/MesaLib-10.0.0-rc1.tar.bz2 2. try to extract it with bsdtar What is the expected output? What do you see instead? Mesa-10.0.0-rc1/VERSION: Can't create 'Mesa-10.0.0-rc1/VERSION' tar: Error exit delayed from previous errors. With gtar It works. What version are you using? bsdtar 3.1.2 - libarchive 3.1.2 On what operating system? FreeBSD 10.0-BETA3 How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) OS build, and tested the latest github master. What compiler or development environment (please include version)? clang 3.3 Please provide any additional information below. This works with gnu tar 1.27 if that helps.

Technically, this tar archive is malformed.  Note the second entry here:

-rw-rw-r--  0 idr    idr        11 Nov 18 12:23 Mesa-10.0.0-rc1/VERSION
hrw-rw-r--  0 idr    idr         0 Nov 18 12:23 Mesa-10.0.0-rc1/VERSION link to Mesa-10.0.0-rc1/VERSION

These kinds of self-links are unfortunately quite common; they occur
when people inadvertently specify the same file more than once
in their tar command.

I believe GNU tar recently added some code to explicitly ignore such
circular links when they occur.  I'll see whether it makes sense to add
similar logic to libarchive's extraction code.

items.title: Windows: libarchive isn't threadsafe, causes heap corruption due to calls to setlocale() when build with visual studio 2012
items.summary: Windows: libarchive isn't threadsafe, causes heap corruption due to calls to setlocale() when build with visual studio 2012

items.content: What steps will reproduce the problem? 1. compile with visual studio 2012 2. run archiving/unarchiveing in concurrent threads 3. random heap corruptions occurs What version are you using? 3.1.2 On what operating system? Windows How did you build? (cmake, configure, or pre-packaged binary) A preconfigured visual studio project that builds it as a .dll What compiler or development environment (please include version)? Visual Studio 2012 Update 4
What I did to fix it for me is removing all setlocale() calls in archive_string.c and just return GetACP() in get_current_codepage() and GetOEM() in get_current_oemcp().

items.title: bsdtar should only warn on POSIXLY malformed pax headers
items.summary: bsdtar should only warn on POSIXLY malformed pax headers

items.content:
Tim, thanks for your attention.  I am submitting new ticket with tarball
examples.  For more info, see attached file and this thread:
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/libarchive-discuss/gKWjs14PoMI
Very relevant thread:
http://www.mail-archive.com/bug-tar@gnu.org/msg04285.html

Pavel
